webTitle: 31 December 2000 - King's Cross holds the key

fields.headline: King's Cross holds the key
fields.standfirst:
Time to start again somewhere else?

Wembley: what next? - Observer special
fields.trailText: 31 December 2000. Time to rip up Wembley and start again, says The Observer's Sports Editor Brian Oliver
fields.body:
To Diego Maradona, Wembley is the greatest football stadium in the world. To those who can remember when the FA Cup Final was the highlight of the season, it is just as revered. To those who go there to watch live sport, it is a dump, and its environs are even worse.

The latter view was widespread enough for football authorities and the Government to recognise some years ago that it would not do as a national stadium. But why should the new one be built at Wembley? No matter how good the stadium, it would still be in an inconsequential, unpleasant, inaccessible part of London.

Today's revelations put Wembley up alongside the British Library and the Dome in the league table of national embarrassments. But the total failure of the project has given English sport, and the Government, the chance to rip up all their plans and start again. Somewhere else.

There are those who argued, and lost last time around, that the stadium should be within easy reach of most of the country. In Birmingham, for instance, or Manchester. This makes sense to thousands of football supporters, but would not help any future bid to stage the Olympics or the World Cup. The world wants to come to London, not Birmingham. And London does not mean a slip road off the M1 near Luton.

London is one of the world's great cities. It could, and should, have one of the world's great stadiums. Some of the best new sporting venues are part of the cityscape, within walking distance of the city centre. Those in Paris and Sydney are on rail links only a few minutes from town.

The Millennium Stadium in Cardiff is a national treasure for Wales. England can have the same, provided those involved think big, and the Government offers substantial support from Lottery funds. The perfect site is there, and always has been, at King's Cross.

You can take the tube, the train, a bus, or even walk from almost anywhere in the West End. It might be bad for the sex trade, but a regenerated King's Cross would be great for London.

Yes, it would cost a lot, and yes, it would take time. And it would need leadership and commitment from above, not within, any individual sports body.

The practical difficulties and cost would present huge barriers. But they can be overcome. It is just a question of will.

fields.headline: Don't think it's all over
fields.standfirst: Wembley's team of 12 directors would need to choose one of four options - all of them flawed - to rescue the nation's sports arena, reports Denis Campbell
fields.trailText: Wembley's team of 12 directors would need to choose one of four options - all of them flawed - to rescue the nation's sports arena, reports Denis Campbell.
fields.body:
It is sport's mission impossible: to save the troubled redevelopment of Wembley Stadium from its perpetual crisis and finally produce a world-class sporting arena of which a nation can be proud. Wembley's 12 directors will meet this Friday to decide if it can be done. The omens are not good. Whatever they decide, someone or something important - football, sports fans, the Twin Towers beneath which Bobby Moore led England to World Cup glory in 1966, England's national honour and worldwide reputation, athletics, the Government and Britain's chances of ever again hosting the Olympic Games - will lose out. It is an unenviable task.

Wembley's bosses will try to draw a line under the past, the endless setbacks, delays and bitter rows which have plagued the project since its inception in the early 1990s. They must somehow stop the rebuilding of Wembley from looking any further like sport's equivalent of the Millennium Dome fiasco, a wretched combination of unfulfilled dreams, broken promises and questionable use of Lottery money.

The dream in Wembley's case was the grand vision of Ken Bates, the opinionated and intensely strong-minded chairman of both Chelsea football club and Wembley National Stadium Limited. He wanted the new Wembley to be not just the best sports stadium in the world - the scale and verve of Sir Norman Foster and HOK-Lobb's July 1999 blueprint were certainly stunning - but something else, too. Bates decided it could also be a thriving, all-year-round, profit-making commercial centre complete with hotel, offices and restaurants. Nothing on that scale has been tried before, except by Bates himself at Chelsea Village. But swanky Kensington is not the same as rundown suburban north London. From the outset critics said Bates's plan was grandiose, unworkable and dangerously experimental. But nobody listened.

Ironically, Friday's crucial meeting will be held at the Chelsea Village Hotel. Around the table will be directors of WNSL who privately regard Bates's tenure as Wembley chairman as little short of disastrous. He was demoted from that position 12 days ago when, after two years of inaction, the Football Association, which owns WNSL, belatedly took control of a project which, under Bates's leadership, was set to cost an incredible £660 million. WNSL's directors must decide this week whether to simply scale down the Bates-Foster plan in an attempt to slash up to £100m from that, or to throw it out altogether and come up with a new plan for a Wembley Mark III.

Their deliberations will be based on a document, seen by The Observer , which outlines four possible ways out of the mess. The good news is that WNSL has options. The bad news is that none of the four is truly satisfactory, much less attractive. The paper, prepared by Wembley's managing director Bob Stubbs, warns in stark terms that each of the four involves risks, problems and uncomfortable compromises.

Whatever WNSL decides, renewed controversy is guaranteed. Yet WNSL seems set to choose one of them, or something very like it, rather than radically rethink the whole Wembley concept. Under pressure to sort out the mess, they may make yet another unwise decision.

According to the document, further lengthy delays to the new stadium's reopening date - spring 2004 is the latest estimate - are inevitable. It says the closure period which began after England's 1-0 defeat by Germany at Wembley on 7 October could stretch into 2005, 2006 or even, under one option, autumn 2007. The only option which involves sticking to 2004, number one, is almost certainly a non-starter.

Beside the other problems confronting WNSL, though, that is trivial. Three of the four would apparently require new designs to be drawn up and fresh planning permission to be sought from Brent Council. Having been promised a world-class, 90,000-seater, brand new stadium that would renovate the surrounding area, Brent may withhold approval for a pale imitation which is, of necessity, being done on the cheap.

The capacity of whatever new structure eventually replaces Wembley is another huge problem. How many fans can attend is crucial to the chances of staging European football finals and the stadium's future profitability. If WNSL decide to simply renovate the existing stadium, option four, 'capacity may be limited to 55,000' instead of the existing 78,000, the paper warns. The maximum possible capacity, 65,000, could only be achieved by installing a new, deeper pitch and putting seats over the unused wide area which currently separates the crowd from the playing area. That seems a non-starter.

Even with option three, which alongside number two is the alternative likeliest to gain WNSL support, capacity would shrink from the promised 90,000 to 80,000. Fewer fans would be able to attend big events such as FA Cup Finals and England games, and the FA would lose vital revenue. As the document makes clear, building a slimmed-down, 80,000-seat Wembley 'may have an impact on the ability to attract certain events and will therefore influence the revenue which can be generated by the project'. The prestigious and lucrative European Cup and Uefa Cup Finals may never be held there.

The paper's executive summary also warns that if construction of a new stadium has not begun by December 2002, ownership of the land on which Wembley sits - bought with £103 million Lottery cash for WNSL - would revert to its previous owners, Wembley London Limited. It may seem inconceivable that rebuilding will take that long. Yet the options paper points out that two of the four alternatives - including the 80,000-capacity option - would mean construction could not start until autumn 2003.

It also highlights other obstacles to speedy progress. English Heritage may refuse permission to demolish the existing stadium, which is listed, because its replacement is not of sufficient architectural merit. And WNSL could have to pay back its entire £120 million Lottery grant because it has not, after all, built anything like what it always promised - the best sports stadium in the world.

Under the leadership of 'new broom' chief executive Adam Crozier, the FA now realises that Bates's attempt to transplant Chelsea Village II into rundown, suburban north London was a hideously expensive pipedream. It was only because City banks refused to lend a penny of the £410 million being sought by the Bates-led WNSL that the FA earlier this month finally got a grip on a scheme which, if WNSL gets it wrong, could still become even more disastrous.

With so much time having already been wasted, WNSL is under huge pressure to signal a fresh start and clear leadership. At Friday's meeting, they will probably rule out options one and four and concentrate on examining options two and three in detail. The likeliest eventual outcome is a new football arena, rather than truly multi-sport national stadium like those in Paris and Sydney, which costs much less than Bates envisaged. If WNSL go down that road, time may show that its directors - under pressure to somehow sort out the mess - acted unwisely, and in haste.

Influential figures in British sport think fresh ideas are required and ask other, more drastic questions - why not build the new Wembley on a greenfield site, and not necessarily in London? Three possible locations have already been identified. And, most radically, do we need to replace Wembley at all? Those, though, are not on the agenda.

OPTION 1

Stick with the current design for a new stadium but delay fitting out the hotel, offices, visitor attraction, two restaurants and one fast-food outlet until tenants are found...

New planning permission would not be needed, so no extra delays. The stadium could open on time in spring 2004. It would be truly world-class and get a five-star rating from European football's ruling body. But it would save only £24.5m. And why build something that may never be occupied? Brainchild of Ken Bates, recently ousted as Wembley's chairman.

OPTION 2

Don't build any of the 'non-core activity areas' - hotel, offices and so on...

A public relations fiasco. The stadium wouldn't open until early 2005. It would save only £3m - too little to bother with? WNSL says this option would require a new design and fresh planning permission, which would take a year. But Brent council may well not insist on that.

OPTION 3

A totally new but smaller-capacity stadium, which may or may not include athletics...

A public relations disaster. Only 80,000, rather than the promised 90,000, fans would fit inside. Would need new planning permission and so wouldn't open until early 2006 - two years behind schedule. May not be good enough to host the European or Uefa Cup Finals. Would be hard to upgrade later. But could possibly host major athletics events like the Olympic Games - and would save £121.5million at the same time.

OPTION 4

Renovate the existing stadium...

A public relations catastrophe. Norman Foster's design would be torn up. The Football Association, and England, would be ridiculed mercilessly. Capacity would shrink from the existing 78,000 to just 55,000 or at most 65,000 if a new, deeper pitch were installed. Wembley would stay closed until autumn 2007 - 27 months late. And it would not be world class - a new humiliation. The revamped stadium couldn't host European finals or athletics. Would save £70m. All in all, unthinkable, surely?

fields.headline: Roberts bags a victory
fields.trailText: Roberts ruins Allardyce's New Year.
fields.body:
One of the perils of success is the desire of others to bring you down a peg or two, and Bolton manager Sam Allardyce will know all about that after seeing West Bromwich Albion spoil his New Year celebrations.

The talk before the game surrounded Bolton's decision to hand manager Allardyce a new 10-year contract. Allardyce agreed to sign the mammoth deal on New Year's Day, but rarely can a football club have bestowed such extraordinary faith in their manager.

Bolton will know that much can happen during a decade in football. Ten years ago, they were fighting a losing battle to escape the old Third Division, but since those dark days, Wanderers have twice scaled the heights of the Premiership, been to Wembley for a League Cup Final and narrowly missed out on an FA Cup Final appearance.

Ten years ago, Sir Alex Ferguson was still searching for his first championship at Manchester United and Graham Taylor was enjoying a honeymoon period as England manager. How times change.

If Allardyce could look into a crystal ball, he would probably still be unable to predict what lies in store over the next 10 years at the Reebok Stadium. Still, when Jason Roberts swooped to give West Brom the lead in the dying stages of the first-half, 10-year plans were the last thing on Bolton's mind.

Roberts scored his 12th goal of the season after a mistake by Robbie Elliott, who failed to see the pacy striker lurking with intent as he rolled a weak pass back to goalkeeper Jussi Jaaskelainen. Bolton made a concerted effort to claw their way back into the game, but inspired goalkeeping, bad finishing and even bad luck conspired against them.

Their promotion ambitions remain intact, but so do Albion's. Perhaps their manager, Gary Megson, deserves a similar contract to Allardyce after reviving the comatose giants of the West Midlands.

However, if such a deal can inspire other opponents as it did with Albion, it may be best to keep the news under wraps.

fields.headline: Robson rewarded
fields.trailText: Robson's subs make a point.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at St James's Park
fields.body:
This was a tale of two lucky goals and a manager who leads a charmed life.

Bobby Robson was already deserving of praise for sending out a weakened team who actually went out and attacked Manchester United, instead of showing the champions the usual excessive respect. Yet for all Newcastle's spirit they were struggling to cancel out a debatable penalty until the 82nd minute, and had nothing to show for their endeavour until Robson sent on three substitutes at once in a last desperate gamble.

What happens next? All three combine to fashion an equaliser of course. And that's not even the lucky bit. Daniel Cordone's cross from Kieron Dyer's pass might have represented Newcastle's best attack of the game, but the Argentine's cross was met by a dreadful finish by Lomana Lua Lua, whose shot was heading for a corner flag until Stephen Glass popped up to turn it in at the far post. Manchester United probably felt like they had been mugged, though at least they were comforted by the result from Highbury.

Newcastle won this fixture 3-0 last year, precipitating a Manchester United backlash that took them all the way to the title, but with Duncan Ferguson back at Everton and Alan Shearer and Carl Cort both long-term casualties there appeared little chance of a repeat.

Dyer and 19-year-old Shola Ameobi were pressed into service up front, and though the pair lacked experience there was no shortage of pluck and running early on. Dyer especially was willing to run at defenders, and had he got his pass away a fraction earlier in the seventh minute Ameobi might have beaten the offside flag as well as a square defence to run clear on goal.

Ameobi's big moment, though, came after 20 minutes when he had an excellent chance to put Newcastle into the lead. Inevitably Dyer was the provider, skipping round Mickael Silvestre and sending in a cross shot that was probably too much of a shot for Ameobi at the far post, who somehow managed to turn the ball over the bar from a yard out.

That could have been the first half's key moment; instead it arrived five minutes later and saw Manches ter United take the lead in somewhat harsh circumstances. Ryan Giggs dribbled into the penalty area, beat Andy Griffin once then went down under a second challenge. As Griffin raised his arms to suggest his innocence, Mike Riley pointed to the spot and was instantly besieged by incredulous home players. In fairness to Riley, he was closer to the incident than most and may have seen something untoward. In fairness to everyone else in the ground, it was not a clear-cut penalty. David Beckham ended the argument, at least until the television replays, by smashing home from the spot. Newcastle continued to attack with invention, but lacked decisiveness in front of goal.

Giggs went close to a second at the start of the second half, after Dwight Yorke beat Clarence Acuna to the right byline. His cross was overhit and the chance appeared to have gone, but Giggs managed to curl a foot round the ball for a shot, which Steve Harper was relieved to see fly by his left-hand upright.

An even better Manchester United move after 62 minutes saw Beckham brilliantly pick out a run from Nicky Butt, and the midfielder find Ole Gunnar Solskjaer in front of goal. That should have been that, but Harper flung his body in the way of the shot, and with the help of his defenders even repelled the Norwegian's follow-up attempt.

As United strode forward looking to kill the game, there seemed little point in Robson introducing three new attackers, but the manager either got lucky or made his own luck. Newcastle deserved their share of the points.

An even better Manchester United move after 62 minutes saw Beckham brilliantly pick out a run from Nicky Butt, and the midfielder find Ole Gunnar Solskjaer in front of goal. That should have been that, but Harper flung his body in the way of the shot, and with the help of his defenders even repelled the Norwegian's follow-up attempt. As United strode forward looking to kill the game, there seemed little point in Robson introducing three new attackers, but the manager either got lucky or made his own luck. Newcastle deserved their share of the points.

webTitle: Johansson joy as City go bust

fields.headline: Johansson joy as City go bust
fields.trailText: The epithet 'boom club' can officially be dispensed with as Manchester City enter the new year. Such phrases as 'relegation-haunted' and 'crisis club' can be brought out of cold storage.
fields.body:
The epithet 'boom club' can officially be dispensed with as Manchester City enter the new year. Such phrases as 'relegation-haunted' and 'crisis club' can be brought out of cold storage.

In case they did not realise it, Joe Royle's side are in the throes of a fully-fledged relegation fight after a perfunctory surrender to Charlton - a fight which will become considerably tougher should they lose at Coventry tomorrow.

As any economist will confirm, boom times can turn to bust with breathtaking alacrity, a fate that has befallen a City team who have known only the former during successive promotion seasons.

Nor are the signs for a possible recovery at all promising, based on a City form book of one win in 11, five points from the last available 33, culminating in this defeat to a Charlton side, promoted with City last season, who opened the current campaign with a 4-0 victory over the Mancunians.

The manner in which City conceded yesterday's goals was particularly symptomatic of a side in freefall.

Poor defending at a corner; an errant goalkeeper's clearance; a penalty and a clearance kicked against a Charlton player and directly into their own goal earned City a torrid reponse from alarmed and disgruntled supporters at the end of each half.

Charlton had already signalled their intent, Claus Jensen forcing Nicky Weaver into a two-handed diving save from a tenth-minute free-kick, before forging ahead 16 minutes later.

Richard Dunne could only flick Jensen's corner to the edge of the six-yard box, where Steve Howey became entangled with his own feet, allowing Jonatan Johansson to turn and sweep in the opening goal.

Nine minutes later Weaver's clearance was intercepted by Radostin Kishishev, who raced forward and rolled the ball across the area for Johansson to bury his second.

There should have been another for Charlton before the interval, Mark Fish prodding the ball beyond the halfway line where Johans son collected and sprinted half the length of the field, only to chip the ball feebly into Weaver's arms.

City had already responded by bringing on new £2.5m signing Darren Huckerby - the answer to Royle's search for a 'proven goalscorer' - as a replacement for unpopular full-back Laurent Charvet.

But Huckerby, who has scored one Premiership goal since September 1999, could not be expected to have any bearing on a contest long settled by the time Charlton scored their third in the 78th minute.

Substitute John Robinson was tripped by Howey in the area, Graham Stuart dispatching the resulting penalty beyond Weaver with some degree of ease.

There should have been more. Johansson ended a four-on-one Charlton break with a woeful shot over, and Stuart volleyed over acrobatically from a Robinson cross.

By the time the Maine Road public address called for the club electrician to report to the tunnel, Royle must have hoped he would pull the plug on what was rapidly becoming the worst home performance and result of the season.

Sadly for the City manager that was not to be and he was forced to watch the fourth Charlton goal arrive in bizarre circumstances, when Howey's fiercely struck clearance cannoned off Jensen and flew fully 35 yards past Weaver into the City goal.

The consolation, in the loosest sense of the word, for City came from Huckerby's injury-time penalty, awarded for a Kishishev trip on the debutant himself.

fields.headline: Burley aims high
fields.trailText: Tractor Boys plough on.
fields.body:
Tony Blair, Bill Clinton and George Bush were all included in one newspaper's men of the year lists last week, but more eye-catching was the inclusion of George Burley for his achievements at Ipswich in the last 12 months.

Managing a Premiership football club may not seem much compared to managing the world, but there's no doubt who would top a popularity poll around these parts at the moment. Nearly everybody's tip to be relegated at the start of the season, the bookies have now cut Ipswich's odds of qualifying for the Champions League to 8-1.

Burley naturally is preferring to play down such wild talk but he did admit he would be disappointed if they did now not finish the season among the top 10. 'Before the match I said to the players we'd see if they wanted to push on in the second half of the season,' he said. 'I think they answered that question.'

It's all a long way from the opening day of the campaign four months ago when defeat at Tottenham had the soothsayers predicting a difficult year ahead. But after this performance, it was Spurs manager George Graham who bore the look of a man who wished he could start over again.

Defeat ensured Tottenham enter the new year still without an away league victory and forced Graham into issuing a public apology to the fans. 'That was easily the worst performance we've had this season,' he said. 'Sides associated with me don't give in as easily as that. I'm going to have to tell them some home truths.'

It took only nine minutes for Spurs to fall behind when Marcus Stewart forced home Martijn Reuser's low cross with the aid of his knee for his twelfth goal of the season.

Graham must have sneaked a look at Sergei Rebrov, the £11 million Ukrainian he had relegated to the substitutes' bench after his failure to make much impression on the Premiership. He might also have looked at Sol Campbell. The Spurs captain is refusing to sign a new contract but on the evidence of this perhaps Graham ought to be pleased.

Time and again Ipswich were able to knock balls into Tottenham's penalty area, spreading panic on nearly every occasion. It was from one of these that Ipswich increased their lead after 62 minutes when Stewart turned provider for Alun Armstrong to tap the ball in from three yards.

At the other end, hard though Rebrov's replacement Gary Doherty worked, it took until the 56th minute before they forced Ipswich keeper Richard Wright to deal with anything other than a back-pass.

In contrast, Ipswich looked capable of scoring every time they attacked and James Scowcroft came close to increasing that lead after 75 minutes with a fierce shot against the bar. It was a bedraggled Spurs defence which conceded a third goal in familiar fashion two minutes from time when substitute Jamie Clapham tapped in Reuser's low cross to score against his former club.

The Tottenham fans were already streaming towards the exits. They doubtless contented themselves with the statistic that they usually win something when the year ends with the figure one. An away win would be a start.

fields.headline: Rescue plan scales down Wembley
fields.trailText: Wembley's famous twin towers stadium could survive as the home of English football - but only if it shrinks to 55,000 seats and stays closed until 2007.
fields.body:
Wembley's famous twin towers stadium could survive as the home of English football - but only if it shrinks to 55,000 seats and stays closed until 2007.

A plan to renovate rather than totally rebuild the venue where England won the 1966 World Cup will be discussed on Friday by Wembley's bosses and the Football Association.

The scheme, designed to ease the financial crisis sur rounding the stadium's redevelopment, is one of four to be debated.

The plan is contained in a confidential briefing paper for Wembley National Stadium Limited and the FA, its parent company. The confidential document, prepared by WNSL managing director Bob Stubbs and which has been seen by The Observer , makes clear that each of the four options risks further problems, including the potential repayment of a £120 million lottery grant. It warns that a renovated sta dium could have as few as 55,000 seats, would not reopen until autumn 2007 and would not be able to host European football finals.

Two of the options involve scaling down the stunning design for the new Wembley unveiled 18 months ago by architects Sir Norman Foster and HOK-Lobb. A planned hotel, office block, visitor attraction and two restaurants and a fast-food outlet would either be built as shells or abandoned altogether, saving £24.5m or £3m respectively. While the first option would let the stadium reopen on schedule in spring 2004, the other would further delay reopening until early 2005.

The fourth option involves designing a new, 80,000-capacity stadium, 10,000 fewer seats than Foster's plan. That would save WNSL £121.5m on the £660m cost but would see the stadium stay closed until 2006. Like the other three options, it would be a public relations disaster for Wembley.

The briefing paper warns WNSL and the FA that three of the four options would involve seeking fresh planning permission from Brent Council - something WNSL's new chairman, Sir Rodney Walker, has ruled out.

Faced with such unpalatable options, WNSL may consider whether to abandon Wembley as a location altogether and build a new stadium on a greenfield site.

fields.headline: Unsolved Jimmy riddle
fields.trailText: Greaves and Spinks are snubbed again by the Palace.
fields.body:
Jimmy Greaves and Terry Spinks would not have been rushing to their newspapers yesterday morning to see if they had made the New Year Honours List. There's only so much disappointment a man can take.

It is 34 years since Greaves did his bit in helping England reach the final of the World Cup, which they went on to win without him; and it is 44 years since Spinks won an Olympic gold medal at boxing, ending a drought for Britain of 32 years (the same as Audley Harrison, newly-MBE-ed, managed in Sydney).

Not once has either of these fine athletes been within shouting distance of a gong.

To those of us who regard this back-scratching exercise as a waste of time, such oversights might not matter much. But don't tell that to Jim or Terry, two working-class Londoners who grew up in more reverential times and who would probably throw a street party if Her Majesty ever saw fit to recognise their deeds with a bauble.

You cannot find out officially why someone is not given a gong. The civil servants who sit in judgment do so on the recommendation of various sports associations but not one of them is accountable. It is masonic secrecy of the worst kind. A citizen can achieve great things in his or her chosen field yet be judged unworthy of wider recognition on the say-so of some mandarin. It's then the innuendos kick in. Greaves and Spinks have heard them all.

Greaves, it is said, is paying for his excessive drinking - even though he has not had a drink in years. Spinks is being punished, he acknowledges, for the slightest, youthful association with the Kray twins. As Spinks told my colleague Steve Bunce recently: 'A lot of people say the reason I've not got it is because I was photographed with the Krays - but everybody was photographed with them.'

Including half the cabinet, at one point or another. Not to mention a few peers of the realm and their 'friends'.

Terry also had a drink problem, of course. And he and Jimmy did not speak with the diamond polish of their supposed betters. And wouldn't you love to trawl the private lives of the well-spoken bureaucrats who hand out these awards?

Meanwhile, the likes of Alan Knight (football, OBE), Sheila Begbie (women's football, MBE), Jean Perkins (netball, OBE) and Dale Reid (women's golf, OBE) - worthy citizens, all, no doubt - will be well pleased with their new adornments. Whoever they are, some might say.

Everyone this morning will be lauding the knighthood granted to Steve Redgrave. And rightly so. But few awards were more predictable this year, given his achievement at the Sydney Olympics and his long-term service to his sport. This was natural justice. So, too, was the recognition of his teammates in the coxless four as well as all the gold medallists from the 2000 Games. But it's still a bit hit-and-miss.

From what I gather of the workings in this byzantine world, if an athlete is not given a gong at or near the peak of his career, he might as well forget it - unless he goes on to serve his sport as an administrator. Those older recipients have served their time. Time-servers is the derogatory term. But not everyone wants to toil away over a ledger in the hope of getting the trip to Buckingham Palace.

Last March, Greaves was left on the shelf again when the five remaining members of Sir Alf's squad were honoured in the Birthday Honours List. It was the most horrible snub for a player who, between 1957 and 1965, ranked alongside Pele as the best goal-scorer in the world. A few of us got a bit upset. 'His 44 goals in 57 internationals stands comparison with Stan Mortensen's 23 from 22, Sir Bobby Charlton's 49 (106) and Gary (OBE) Lineker's 48 in 80. He scored 357 goals in the top division, more than anyone else has yet managed,' this column pointed out nine months ago. So much for journalistic dudgeon.

Terry Spinks's family, meanwhile, have been campaigning for six years to have his wrong righted. His cousin, Rosemary, told The Observer in September: 'I want it before anything happens to Terry. He deserves something.'

It should be irrelevant that Ramsey (whom Her Majesty later saw fit to knight, of course) left Greaves out of the final; Jim helped get England there and might have been in the team had he not gashed his shin in the third qualifying match, against France. Instead, Geoff Hurst came in for the Argentina quarter-final and the rest you have seen a thousand times. The night of the final, with the nation swimming in self-congratulation, 21 members of the England squad got drunk at the Royal Garden Hotel; Jimmy, maybe the best toper of them all, did not. He went off by himself. Maybe Sir Alf held that against him. Both were from Dagenham but they were a thousand miles apart in attitude and lifestyle.

Spinks, the son of a Canning Town bookmaker, has his memories and his medal. When I sat next to him at a Boxing Writers Club dinner a few years ago he was on the mineral water and trawled over his past fondly. He was a proud little man, and, according to those who saw him box, some fighter. He retired at 24, probably at the right time after a brief but hard campaign as a professional. And he'd still reckon it was all worth it.

fields.headline: Reality bites after high hopes
fields.trailText: The rise and fall of Kevin Gallen.
fields.body:
Kevin Gallen will be back in London tomorrow with Huddersfield Town, playing Crystal Palace at Selhurst Park, the ground he once described as his least favourite. He is slightly embarrassed to be reminded now. 'I was playing in the Premiership when I said that,' explained Gallen, whose side drew 0-0 with Sheffield Wednesday yesterday (see right). 'I used to compare everything to Manchester United. 'I've played on a few worse grounds than Crystal Palace since then.' Gallen's story is a cautionary tale familiar enough in football, the meteoric rise and dazzling promise of teenage years giving way to a decidedly unspectacular mid-career. There are a few twists in the telling - he has never had any recurring problems from the cruciate ligament injury which put him out of the game for almost two years, and he has repaid Huddersfield's faith in him by leading their scoring lists this season - but you could not have told anyone five years ago that the Queens Park Rangers striker who famously scored 153 goals in 110 matches to break Jimmy Greaves's South East Counties youth record would ever end up on a free transfer to the McAlpine Stadium.

Lou Macari, the Terriers' manager who knows a thing or two about scoring, believes Gallen faces a long slog to recapture what he had at under-18 and under-21 level, when he used to receive more publicity than his contemporary Robbie Fowler. 'You don't have injuries like he had and emerge unscathed,' Macari said. 'You always lose something. Those injuries were the reason he struggled to find a club in the summer.

'I don't think anything has affected his football brain, but sometimes the body won't take you where you want to go. 'He still knows where the goal is, but it will need an awful lot of work on his condition if he wants to be as lethal again.'

Gallen smiles and claims Macari would say that about any of his players. 'Hard work is always the answer as far as the gaffer is concerned, whatever the question,' Gallen said. 'I'm not knocking him, though. He's turned this club around since he's been here, and he's given me a decent run in the team.'

If pushed, Gallen will accept that he is not as lethal as he once was. 'I've maybe lost a yard of pace. I don't know, it's hard to measure those things,' he said. 'Plus, my overall fitness or sharpness is not the only consideration. You also have to take into account what sort of team I'm playing in, how well they are doing, how many chances are created, all sorts of things.

'I had it pretty good when I first broke into the Premier ship. Rangers had a good team at the time and I quickly struck up a rapport with Les Ferdinand, but it all started to slide a bit when they sold Les and didn't buy a replacement. 'I was 19, Danny Dichio was only a year older, and there was a lot of pressure on us.'

If relegation was bad, Gallen's cruciate injury two games into the following season was worse, particularly as he had managed a promising three goals in one-and-a-half matches. He had only the one serious injury - 'I hate it when people say I'm injury prone' - but despite playing 40 games for QPR in his first full season back, he made only seven starts last season under Gerry Francis.

He knew it was time to sever his connection with the club he had supported as a boy when he was finally offered a new contract. He discovered it to be for one year only, at about half the money he had been put on when Rangers had been fighting off interest from Liverpool and Manchester United.

'I made a deliberate decision to get out of London and make a fresh start,' he said. 'I'd been at Rangers too long, and it had become too easy and comfortable. 'I could have just carried on, but no 25-year-old wants to be in the reserves or on the bench.

'At that age you've got to be playing, so I decided to go to a club who could give me a regular game. 'Steve Bruce promised that, and to be fair he was as good as his word. 'The present manager has stuck with me as well. The only games I've missed have been through minor injuries, and I'm happy with that. I would have been depressed if I had come up here and been left out of the team.'

Gallen should be even happier soon. He is on course to reach double figures in a season for the first time as a professional. Now halfway through a one-year contract he is effectively a free agent from tomorrow, so to an extent he is in the shop window as well. Does he worry he is now viewed as damaged goods?

'No, I'm just glad to be playing again, and I feel I've still got a lot of my career ahead of me,' he said. I very much want to get back into the Premiership, and I won't give up on that ambition.' Does he ever wish, then, that his rise had not been quite so rapid so that he could continue his career in relative peace and quiet instead of constantly being asked, in a somewhat less cheery manner than George Best used to be, where it all went wrong?

'What's done is done. You can't change it even if you wanted to,' he said. 'I'm still glad I beat Jimmy Greaves's scoring record, if that's what you mean. That was a great achievement, and I'm proud of it. I didn't know what the future held. But who does?'

As the biggest influence on his career he always cites his older brothers, Joe and Steve, whose professional careers were blighted by back injuries.

And a prescient realism surfaced in his QPR heyday, at the very same time he used to describe Selhurst Park as his least favourite ground. 'I don't actually know if Manchester United bid £7m for me,' he said in 1995. 'But all the lads at Loftus Road say the club should have sold me. 'I don't think anything has affected his football brain, but sometimes the body won't take you where you want to go. 'He still knows where the goal is, but it will need an awful lot of work on his condition if he wants to be as lethal again.' Gallen smiles and claims Macari would say that about any of his players. fields.headline: Fergie the father figure
fields.trailText: Success comes from nurturing talent and keeping egos in check.
fields.body:
As the biggest and most glamorous club in Britain, it is easy for Manchester United to corner the market in promising young players.

But that's not the only reason why United are the best starting point for any list of potential Premiership stars to watch in 2001. An even more important factor, perhaps, lies in the ability of Sir Alf Alex Ferguson to help them realise their potential.

This has never been easy for any manager - I have lost count of the players who made a big impact at the start of their careers, but then faded into obscurity.

It happened to me for a while when I began my career at Dundee. I was only 16 when I started playing for their first team, but I did not have the physical attributes to keep going, nor the right approach in terms of my professional habits concerning diet and rest, and got lost for two years. I was able to come again - I was Dundee's captain at 19 - but some players never do.

To me, one of the main reasons is the pressure of being subjected to higher expectations. Moreover, once they have made their mark, players easily lose sight of the need to keep working hard.

The danger of that has become more pronounced since the formation of the Premiership and, more specifically, the rise in players' basic earnings. These days, a Premiership player does not have to be at the top for very long to set himself up financially for the rest of his life. A number are able to do so without winning anything.

There is a tendency for them to start thinking of themselves as celebrities. You have to keep on top of them. Nobody can do that more effectively than Sir Alex, as I found when I started working with him at Aberdeen. If any manager understands young players, and all the problems they face during their key development years, it is him. To many of the players nurtured by him from a very early age, he is more than just their manager, he is their father figure. He is exceptionally clever in his dealings with them.

This, of course, has already been brought into sharp focus by the success of players like Phil and Gary Neville, David Beckham, Nicky Butt, Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs. Now, it is again being highlighted by another crop of Old Trafford youth and reserve team graduates.

The one who stands out is their 21-year-old England defender Wes Brown, whose comeback from the cruciate ligament injury that put him out of action for last season, must rank as one of the most inspiring stories of the year. Of the players who can be expected to go from strength to strength over the next 12 months, he is an obvious choice.

I see a number of United's reserve matches - on the club's TV channel - and one player who has caught my eye is a strong-running, 19-year-old Scottish midfielder called Michael Stewart. After only two first-team appearances this season - both in the Worthington Cup - Stewart has recently had the opportunity to gain more experience by being loaned to United's Belgian partners, Royal Antwerp.

United's 20-year-old winger, Luke Chadwick, who has also gone down this road, is another who has impressed me. He is quite similar to Giggs.

It is impossible to exaggerate the importance of clubs having good youth systems, allowing managers to influence players from a young age. I know that I have been helped by that at Coventry, with youngsters such as my son Gavin, Barry Quinn, John Eustace, Marcus Hall and Chris Kirkland. When it comes to ensuring that players are brought up in the right way, it also helps if you have senior professionals who can set the right example, such as Steve Ogrizovic and Gary McAllister at Coventry.

One player with a great chance of making a big impact on the game is Kirkland, our 19-year-old goalkeeper. He has had a difficult job, in replacing the injured Magnus Hedman, in a team in relegation danger, but has handled the challenge. He is a joy to work with, because, in addition to his talent, he is such an honest lad. He desperately wants to keep improving.

Others I would single out as having more going for them than most include Leeds United's 21-year-old keeper Paul Robinson and West Ham's 19-year-old midfielder Michael Carrick. Robinson's composure in dealing with the flashes of attacking magic from Leeds' big-name European Champions League opponents has been remarkable for one so inexperienced.

Carrick was a member of the West Ham team who beat Coventry in the FA Youth Cup final the season before last, as was the outrageously gifted Joe Cole. He has not had as much publicity as Cole and, bearing in mind what I was saying earlier about players being weighed down by expectation, I am inclined to think that this might have helped him. He is not as individualistic as Cole, but, none the less, he has greater physical power and an excellent passing range.

webTitle: FA's cup of cheer back in place

fields.headline: FA's cup of cheer back in place
fields.trailText: Why it's make or break for the Cup next weekend.
fields.body:
I hate Yeovil. I particularly hate them at this time of the year. I particularly hate them this year. Where I come from, we call them the 'green slime'.

Watching them dominate the Nationwide Conference, and beating Blackpool so excitingly in the second round of the FA Cup, then drawing Bolton Wanderers in next Saturday's third, has been a painful. experience. You see, my team is Weymouth, of the Doc Marten's League Premier Division. Yeovil used to be our rivals, opponents in many a fierce New Year encounter.

I hate Morecambe, too. Next Saturday they will be at home to Ipswich Town of the Premiership. The last time they reached the third round was in 1962, when, astonishingly, they drew the only other non-League side to make it through - Weymouth. We won 2-1 at Christie Park in front of 12,000 people. This year, while they delight in their day, fewer than 1,000 will welcome Welling United to Wessex Stadium.

You may detect a little envy here. This year's third round looks especially one to relish and one in which the non-League is unusually well-represented, with Chester City, Kingstonian and Dagenham and Redbridge (our opponents in the FA Trophy; after the Lord Mayor's Show of Charlton Athletic come us) also through.

To boot, there are some intriguing local rivalries - Leeds United v Barnsley, for example - and meaty all-Premiership ties, such as Newcastle United v Aston Villa - John Gregory's present club away to his future one? Pick of them all, though, is the mouth-watering encounter between Fulham and Manchester United, which will tell us more about just how good are Jean Tigana's side, so silky in the First Division, and their prospects for more demanding weekly meetings next season.

Indeed, the FA have got lucky with such an evocative draw. This year marks the start of their new chief executive Adam Crozier's mission to rehabilitate the Cup after last year's nadir when Manchester United were excused (though it means that it is an amazing 19 months since they won a tie) and dates were shifted, with the third round being played before Christmas.

Now it is in its rightful place, a diverting tonic after the excess of the holiday period. Optimism is kindled anew - at least until next week when, for many, their season is reassessed. For managers, the sacking season begins in earnest when for many clubs disappointment and the prospect of a relegation struggle at worst, a flat few months at best, kick in.

George Graham, for example, has much to fear from a trip with Tottenham Hotspur to Leyton Orient. It may only be a few miles through east London but Spurs travel very badly. With new owners possibly looking at a change of direction and fans unlikely to tolerate quietly four months of mid-table mediocrity, Graham's need for a result is pressing. Glenn Hoddle - possessor of a get-out clause in his Southampton contract - waits for the call from repertory to the West End.

The ever-entertaining Gordon Strachan may also have to account for himself if Coventry City fall at Swindon Town, unlikely as the prospect looks. Arsenal also look unlikely to subside at Carlisle, but then didn't they say that when George Graham took his Highbury aristocrats - as champions indeed - to Wrexham eight years ago? For Watford, the respite from league travails of a home tie against Everton could represent a turning point they are desperately seeking.

It could be, in fact, that a few Premiership teams at home are more in danger. West Bromwich Albion should fancy their chances at Derby, Birmingham City at Manchester City. Chelsea, though, ought to dispose of Oldham Athletic at Stamford Bridge, but what of Claudio Ranieri if the unthinkable occurs?

Outside of Fulham, much interest will focus on the non-League clubs. And having seen two rounds in which the Conference acquitted themselves so well against Nationwide League opposition, the FA will again be looking for evidence to support their proposed shake-up of the game outside the Premiership.

In the week before Christmas, the FA, the Conference and the League met to discuss a proposal of three up, three down with the Third Division. The League, aware of the fate of turkeys around the festive period, were not keen to vote in the idea. They especially did not like the plan for 'parachute' payments to relegated clubs to soften the blow. The FA is likely to pursue the matter, however, believing that some Conference clubs are in better order than some in the Third Division.

They want the League to come up with inventive ways of solving the parachute problem. For example, there could be play-offs between the team finishing ninetieth in the League and third in the Conference, the profits going to the defeated club. In addition, the Conference are believed to be negotiating a TV deal with a terrestrial channel, which could be attractive to the current lower orders.

I also understand that the FA are holding back a trump card: if the League will not agree to three down, then they could get their mates in the Premiership to suggest only one down, and consequently one up from the First Division. The New Year promises intrigue on and off the pitch.

There is still some way to go for the Cup to re-establish itself fully after a period of neglect. It remains annoying, for example, that replay dates are dictated by local police forces, despite Crozier's desire to return them to the few days after the initial tie, when interest is at its height. This time, they will take place in the week beginning 15 January. Curious, though, isn't it that Nuneaton v Stoke in the first round was played a few days later when Sky television decided they wanted to cover it? Money still talks.

At least less so, in some circumstances. It is encouraging that the Leyton Orient and Morecambe ties have not been switched, with the less wealthy clubs seeing the games as windfalls rather than chances for glory. The FA are getting tougher in their criteria for changing venues.

Actually, now I think about it, I don't hate Morecambe. Don't even hate Yeovil. Much. In fact, teeth gritted, I wish the 'green slime' well at Bolton, particularly an old mate in the Yeovil captain Terry Skiverton. Better we join them up there than drag them down to where we are.

fields.headline: Said & Done: 2000 awards
fields.trailText: Man of the year
fields.body:
Man of the year

TOMAS BROLIN. This year, every year. Sweden's favourite Hoover nozzle exporter, supplier of shoes to Observer Sport and all round Elk-eating legend.

Loser of the year

Ken Bates, David Mellor and Francis Maude have nothing on BARRY HEARN. Despite recruiting teenage Kosovan refugee Naim Uka to play for Leyton Orient, Hearn made headlines in March by telling Nicky Campbell on BBC 5 Live: 'I think it's disgraceful we let all these people [refugees] into the country. It's about time we started looking after ourselves. I wouldn't have one of them in.' Uka - who arrived in the country in the back of a lorry after his parents disappeared, his home was blown up and his neighbours murdered - seemingly fell into Hearn's 'one of us' category. A few black and black-ish boxers could remain in the country, Hearn said, 'because they could make me a fortune'.

Top rediscovery

Eight years ago, LARS ELSTRUP - Luton's record signing at £850,000 - scored the Euro 92 semi-final winner for Denmark against France. A year later he quit the game to join a religious commune ('The Wild Geese') and, in August, we found him in the middle of the busiest pedestrian shopping street in Copenhagen circled by a rope, waving his penis at passersby. 'In some respects,' he told us, 'I do this to provoke people. I like experiencing people's reactions. Some might take my message to be "sod off" and others an offer of sex. I am very aware of people's reactions and I love the fact that people recognise me as Lars Elstrup.' He placed a scarf on the pavement for contributions, and made 27 Danish Kroner (£2.25) in one afternoon. He later slapped a heckling schoolboy before wrestling a police officer to the ground and being arrested.Elstrup told police he 'should have hit the boy harder' and filed a complaint against the sect - 'They are inhuman and even stole Devi, my dachshund. I am now ready to go to the European Court of Human Rights.' We've not heard from him since.

Top tabloid shocker

A big category. At the start of the year, Manchester United chairman Martin Edwards was caught 'romping' with a Brazilian prostitute, Kieron Dyer was exposed in a 'sickening sex rampage' (© News of the World); and Hartlepool mascot 'H'Angus, a blue monkey (real name Stuart), was sacked for simulating sex with a female steward. But the winner is Tottenham's STEFFEN IVERSEN, exposed after demanding dog noises from team-mates during bawdy international away trips. 'Some of the players met in a mobile home,' revealed team-mate Erik Mykland in his new book. 'I was ordered to walk around naked and drunk. At every corner he said I had to lift my leg like a dog urinating and say "Woof, woof".' Iversen came clean: 'Every word is true. I don't care.'

Strangest player

EMMANUEL PETIT also revealed this year: 'I want to be a doggy'. Petit's wish, which came just a week after Iversen's revelations, was provoked by death threats aimed at colleague Youri Djorkaeff. 'I started thinking about Youri and I decided "I'd like to be a dog",' said Manu. 'Dogs are nice. They can sleep anywhere, they wag their tails and on top of that they get stroked all the time.' It was the greatest profundity of a busy year - previously he'd used his official website to describe his love of leather, and mused 'I wish humans could live on the moon.' He's now been linked with an £8m move home from Barca reserves to Fulham, but still can't work out why he's so widely quoted. 'Why write about me? To do half a page on me - well , I sneeze, frankly. With the war in Chechnya, I think there are better things to do.'

Most moving website

In January, out-of-work managers queued up to put their CVs online at the League Managers Association website. Highlights among the original 29 candidates included John Hendrie playing the dating game: 'I am a bubbly character with infectious enthusiasm' (the entry has since been toned down) and 'Terence' Fenwick, who looked back on his time at Portsmouth as a 'real success'. Pompey fell into administration just after he left, as did his next club, Crystal Palace. Twelve months on, after a near miss at Middlesbrough, he's still looking.

Top stats of the year

In January, ARSENAL claimed to be 'officially best team of century' after an Independent newspaper study of results rated them more successful than any other English club side over the past 100 years. The Daily Telegraph's version, though, had Liverpool leading - while we had Everton (P3,758, W1,545, D917 L1,296) the clear winners. We were probably wrong.

Scoop of the year

20 December, The Mirror: 'KEANE: I WON'T MOVE TO LEEDS' 'Robbie Keane last night pledged his future to Inter Milan and insisted he does not want to return to the Premiership.'

Keane joined Leeds approximately 7 hours later.

webTitle: Remember when football feared live TV?

fields.headline: Remember when football feared live TV?
fields.trailText: Evidence that the amount of football on television has reached a point where viewers are looking elsewhere for their kicks shows no sign of slowing down the game's exposure.
fields.body:
Evidence that the amount of football on television has reached a point where viewers are looking elsewhere for their kicks shows no sign of slowing down the game's exposure.

On Sky alone, there were 290 live football matches in 2000, an average of 5.5 games a week. And then there were the offerings - notably Euro 2000 - of the BBC, ITV, Channel 5, ONdigital and even u>direct, who popped out of the shadows last October to put England's World Cup qualifier in Finland on pay-per-view.

Too much, some said, and certain figures backed this up, including a drop of 1.5 million viewers per match for the first phase of the Champions League on ITV (a fall, incidentally, that was less dramatic than in other parts of Europe).

Undeterred, though, football is letting TV have even more games next year when the new contracts, struck last June, come into effect. Sky's 60 Premiership matches per season - unchanged since the Premier League formed in 1992 - go up to 66 in 2001-02, while ONdigital and ITV will push the number of televised Nationwide League and Worthington Cup games per season past the century mark for the first time.

Then there are the pay-per-view matches, although here there are signs that television may be sated. The Premiership are having to renegotiate p-p-v rights after the £328 million deal with ntl, the cable company, to screen 40 matches per season broke down in October, and ONdigital are still considering their options six months after they agreed to offer some Nationwide matches on a p-p-v basis from next season.

Jeff Farmer, ITV's respected head of football, believes it is too early to conclude that there is too much football. 'If you look at anything, even popular soaps such as Coronation Street or Emmerdale , you'll see a similar drop, because of the multi-choice environment in so many homes,' he says. 'Look at your own viewing habits and it would be unusual if you were viewing in exactly the same way that you were two years ago.'

Farmer expects there to be no clamour for a cut-back in Champions League matches when the main broadcasters of Europe's premier club competition meet in Switzerland in February.

At the same time, the Uefa Cup may be extended along the lines of the Champions League because big clubs do not like the precariousness of the knock-out system that can mean one bad performance and they're out with the subsequent loss of TV revenue.

And it wasn't all that long ago that football was holding out against live broadcasts because of the damage they might do to the game.

Unsurprisingly, Sky have received enquiries from terrestrial TV about showing highlights of rugby union's big event next summer - the Lions tour of Australia - but have yet to strike a partnership deal.

Sky's contract for exclusive live rights to rugby union in the southern hemisphere takes in the Lions' trip and also entitles them to sell on delayed coverage to a terrestrial broadcaster.

The BBC are known to be interested in screening what is likely to be a highly competitive series of matches, but no agreement has been reached.

fields.headline: Four tough choices facing Wembley
fields.trailText: OPTION 1
fields.body:
OPTION 1

Stick with the current design for a new stadium but delay fitting out the hotel, offices, visitor attraction, two restaurants and one fast-food outlet until tenants are found...

New planning permission would not be needed, so no extra delays. The stadium could open on time in spring 2004. It would be truly world-class and get a five-star rating from European football's ruling body. But it would save only £24.5m. And why build something that may never be occupied? Brainchild of Ken Bates, recently ousted as Wembley's chairman.

OPTION 2

Don't build any of the 'non-core activity areas' - hotel, offices and so on...

A public relations fiasco. The stadium wouldn't open until early 2005. It would save only £3m - too little to bother with? WNSL says this option would require a new design and fresh planning permission, which would take a year. But Brent council may well not insist on that.

OPTION 3

A totally new but smaller-capacity stadium, which may or may not include athletics...

A public relations disaster. Only 80,000, rather than the promised 90,000, fans would fit inside. Would need new planning permission and so wouldn't open until early 2006 - two years behind schedule. May not be good enough to host the European or Uefa Cup Finals. Would be hard to upgrade later. But could possibly host major athletics events like the Olympic Games - and would save £121.5million at the same time.

OPTION 4

Renovate the existing stadium...

A public relations catastrophe. Norman Foster's design would be torn up. The Football Association, and England, would be ridiculed mercilessly. Capacity would shrink from the existing 78,000 to just 55,000 or at most 65,000 if a new, deeper pitch were installed. Wembley would stay closed until autumn 2007 - 27 months late. And it would not be world class - a new humiliation. The revamped stadium couldn't host European finals or athletics. Would save £70m. All in all, unthinkable, surely?

webTitle: Deadly Durie in timely rescue for Hearts

fields.headline: Deadly Durie in timely rescue for Hearts
fields.trailText: Scottish review.
fields.body:
Hearts did it the hard way. But spectators looking for some excitement to take their minds off the weather were hardly complaining as they took the lead at St Johnstone, fell 2-1 behind and finally made it 2-2 through their substitute Gordon Durie.

Steve Kirk had put Hearts in the driving seat after only six minutes. That St Johnstone were able to recover was due mainly to the influence of Paddy Connolly.

He supplied the cross from which Mohammed Sylla equalised after 23 minutes and put St Johnstone ahead - from a Keigan Parker cross - 10 minutes before the interval.

With Parker failing to capitalise on two chances to extend St Johnstone's lead, Hearts equalised after 77 minutes.

In the build-up to the goal, Gary McSwegan appeared to bundle Gary Bollan off the ball but the referee ignored the challenge and the Hearts forward was allowed to set up Durie for his decisive finish.

Aberdeen's manager, Ebbe Skovdahl, has suggested that he is prepared to take a pay cut to remain in the position.

Skovdahl, whose future at the club has been the subject of speculation, and whose contract runs out at the end of the season, said: 'I have built up strong feelings for Aberdeen since coming to Scotland.

'I am willing to consider anything that will help the club improve its financial position.'

Rangers winger Andrei Kanchelskis - someone else whose future could be described as uncertain - said that he is likely to leave Ibrox at the end of the season if he cannot regain his first-team place after the mid-winter break.

Kanchelskis, who came into conflict with Rangers' manager, Dick Advocaat over his refusal to play for the Rangers Under-21, insisted that there is no animosity between the two men.

However, on the subject of his lack of first-team action, he said: 'Maybe I will speak to my agent. I am fit and at 32, I feel ok.

'I would like to go back to the Premier League [in England] and play there.

'But we will see what happens here.'

fields.headline: Woe for Whelan
fields.trailText: Woe for Whelan but Boro have last laugh.
fields.body:
Coventry fans chanted Noel Whelan's name with a fervour they rarely displayed while he was a player at Highfield Road. Then again, the player they sold to Middlesbrough in the summer scored few goals for City as stunning as the one that earned them a point here.

With time and space to clear, Whelan volleyed David Thompson's 41st-minute corner past his own startled goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer from the angle of the six-yard box.

A nightmarish way to mark your twenty-sixth birthday, but the own goal represented only one of the reasons for Whelan's obvious distress when he was put out of his misery and substituted midway through th second half.

Alen Boksic's 86th-minute equaliser will have eased his despair marginally, but this was still a birthday from hell for Whelan. It might have been so different, though, if he had accepted a 12th-minute chance.

The striker did well to squeeze a shot inside the post from a sharp angle after Hamilton Ricard's shot was diverted to him, but Barry Quinn's excellent sliding interception deprived him of a confidence-boosting goal.

Whelan's final contribution to a mediocre first-half came in stoppage time when he went down under a challenge from goalkeeper Chris Kirkland. It was a fall that fooled nobody.

Referee Dermot Gallagher rightly dismissed Middlesbrough's claims for a penalty, while Coventry's feisty midfielder David Thompson had plenty to say to Whelan in an angry exchange which followed.

The second-half was no better for Whelan. He shot against the legs of Kirkland when clear in the 51st minute and lashed an easier chance over the bar in the 66th minute. He was heading down the tunnel with his head bowed seconds later.

Boro boss Terry Venables said: 'He was upset because he felt I brought him off because of the miss, I'd already decided to substitute him.

'It was just one of those days for him. These things happen. I thought Noel worked very hard, but you can try too hard playing against your old club. He was a bit uptight.'

Middlesbrough's best spell followed Whelan's exit and Kirkland made an excellent save from Keith O'Neill before Boksic, a half-time substitute, accepted a pass from Ricard and finished with a quality rarely witnessed yesterday.

Coventry manager Gordon Strachan smiled: 'Boksic's terrific. You don't half become a better coach when you bring on a world-class player.'

As for Coventry, Craig Bellamy's 63rd-minute shot saved by Schwarzer was their only threat, but at least they are becoming more difficult to beat. Strachan said: 'It wasn't looking great a couple of months ago, but this is another step on the road to recovery.'

Venables, yet to experience a defeat since taking over, said: 'Sometimes it doesn't go for you, but we kept at it.'

fields.headline: Thomas leads Blades triumph
fields.trailText: Thomas leads Blades triumph.
fields.body:
New Year is a period for hope and optimism but it came a little early at Bramall Lane where Sheffield United came back from two goals down to beat Preston.

No wonder United manager Neil Warnock said after wards: 'I was so emotional at the end. I felt like doing a David Pleat when Luton stayed up at Manchester City and run onto the pitch.'

Both teams were forced to make changes. While United were playing a new centre-half partnership for the first time Preston were introducing a new striking partnership.

Preston's strikers had a hand in their first goal after only four minutes with a well-rehearsed set piece straight out of the training ground manual. A corner kick was flicked on at the near post by Brian McBride, who only arrived in this country from Colombus Crew in America on Thursday into the path of their record £1.5million signing David Healy who nodded home from close range.

It got even better for the visitors when they scored a second after only 20 minutes.

Lee Cartwright broke down the right-hand side and his pin-point cross into the penalty area found Mark Rankin who had timed his run to perfection to head home.

Prior to the game United manager Warnock had said that Preston were one of the best if not the best defensive side in the division but even he must have been surprised at the turn of events.

On the half-hour after a period of sustained pressure United eventually got the breakthrough they deserved even if it was a little fortunate.

A corner was only partially cleared and when David Kelly looked as if he was through Preston captain Sean Gregan's clumsy challenge was adjudged a foul and a penalty was given.

Bobby Ford made no mistake and fired it home.

Sheffield United may not satisfy the purists of the game but their pace, power and passion takes them a long way in this division certainly at home where they have acquired 33 points out of 43 points so far. After the interval United laid siege in the Preston half and a Bobby Ford shot hit the post and bounced to safety.

But just as it looked as if the visitors had weathered the onslaught they conceded a goal. Michael Brown threaded a ball into the path of their nifty winger Paul Devlin whose accurate ball floated over the goalkeeper David Lucas onto the head of Kelly who made no mistake at the far post.

The fight-back was completed 10 minutes from time when Rob Kozluk floated in a long ball into the Preston area where it was flicked on by Georges Santos into the path of James Thomas who controlled the ball before poking it past the advancing Lucas.

There was still time for Preston to launch one final attack and McBride's header from a corner flashed just wide.

Both these teams are attempting to get into the Premiership by frugal means. Even though Preston have just broken their transfer record it is still a small speculation for large Premiership accumulation which could come their way if they were successful.

For Sheffield United their high tempo and robust style will mean they will lost several players through suspension and more importantly they are putting pressure on themselves by relying on their home form. On this occasion they got away with it.

fields.headline: Owls claw draw
fields.trailText: Owls claw draw in basement battle.
fields.byline: Stuart Barnes at The McAlpine Stadium
fields.body:
On current form, there was a huge gulf between these teams. On the day, there was nothing to separate them. On reflection, both managers declared themselves content.

Huddersfield went into December eight points adrift with one win in 19 games. They have come out of it with five victories and two draws, and while Lou Macari continues to preach caution, he will say that they have given themselves 'a fighting chance' of surviving. What is for certain is that no one will be able to match him for the First Division manager of the month award.

'If anyone had said that we would go through the month unbeaten I would have thought they were crackers,' declared Macari, who took over at the beginning of November after Steve Bruce's sacking.

'It would be too much to expect to win every game. But things do seem to be on the up. We have shown it's not just a five-minute wonder.'

webTitle: O'Neill stays focused after 12 heady months

fields.headline: O'Neill stays focused after 12 heady months
fields.standfirst: Glenn Gibbons on a year of transformation at Parkhead
fields.trailText: Glenn Gibbons on a year of transformation at Parkhead.
fields.body:
It is fair to assume that a substantial number of Scottish football people will experience a certain elation on hearing tonight's chimes at midnight, glad to see the back of a year that has been generally unkind.

Martin O'Neill will not be among them. For every small disappointment that paid a visit during the past 12 months, the Celtic manager can recite a litany of gratifying moments. With the Worthington Cup won with Leicester City in February and his present team 12 points clear of their fiercest rivals, Rangers, in the Scottish Premier League as 2000 ebbs into history, the Irishman has little cause for regret.

Clearly an irrepressible enthusiast, he does, however, exercise a sense of reality and perspective that will prevent him from letting off a celebratory whoop until Celtic, like Leicester, have a trophy in the cabinet. They have, it should be remembered, won nothing yet.

It is for that reason that he reflected on the cup victory over Tranmere at Wembley as the highlight of his year, ahead even of the extraordinary progress the Parkhead side have made in his care. 'It would have to be,' said O'Neill, 'because it is a tangible reward, something you can look at and use to measure success. Don't get me wrong, it's been a fantastic year all round and I could not be more delighted than I am with the way things have gone here, but nothing has been won yet. I'm very pleased with the players I have brought here, but I'm even more satisfied with the way the guys who were already here have responded and contributed.'

O'Neill would not admit it even under torture, but his achievement at Celtic Park runs much deeper than merely improving a team to the extent that a new, all-embracing spirit permeates the club. More than any of his predecessors since Billy McNeill's reign between 1978 and 1983, he has established himself as the main man, the figure revered by supporters above anyone else on the premises, probably having already reached the status of a messiah.

It would be an insanely brave (or foolhardy) director who would even offer a criti cism of O'Neill, far less raise the subject of how long he will remain in charge. All of the others since McNeill - David Hay, McNeill himself during his second period in charge, Liam Brady, Lou Macari, Tommy Burns, even the league and League Cup-winning Wim Jansen, Jozef Venglos, John Barnes and Kenny Dalglish - imparted an impression of precariousness and impermanence, for one reason or another.

O'Neill has, within six months, convinced multitudes of supporters not only that he is likely to end Rangers' stranglehold on the league championship, but that he is capable of sustaining the success far beyond one luminous season. It is indicative of Celtic's renaissance under O'Neill that the constant stream of embarrassing stories that tended to flow from the club when performances and results were poor - players rushing to the media to publicise their unhappiness, tales of dressing-room discord, constant accusations by hostile papers of bungling by the board of directors - has virtually dried up.

O'Neill is claiming none of the credit for a volte-face by the media, which would have been unimaginable only eight months ago. Instead, he cites the team's solid form and the fact that they have lost only one match in domestic competition as the single most significant fac tor. 'Listen, in any dressing room, discontent of some kind will always be underneath the surface,' he said. 'But, if you win your matches, it tends to stay there. When you start to lose games, you may find that it starts to simmer again. Every manager has that, because you can't please everyone. There are people who won't be happy, even in good times, but you will find they are mainly people who are not in the team.'

O'Neill accepted the job in the wake of a traumatic season, in which disharmony, dispiritedness and lack of character - at least partly attributable to the weak management of Barnes and Dalglish - appeared to be the most obvious problems. He insists that he approached his task utterly without preconceptions. 'That wasn't always easy, because there were plenty of people around dying to give me information and advice. I ignored all of that and assessed everybody from my own perspective. I can honestly say the players have been great. I didn't find anything about their willingness or their spirit to concern me.

'The only real disappointment I've had was losing to Bordeaux in the Uefa Cup. I think we played very well in that tie, and I also believe Bordeaux are far from a mediocre side. I think they are a fine team. But it helped to perpetuate this image of Scottish teams being unable to remain in Europe beyond Christmas. That is something we would like to address. Rangers have had to take the brunt of the criticism in recent years, but it's time Celtic played their part, too. That kind of thing also makes people outside Scotland think it's easy to win the championship, but it never is.

'Rangers may have won all but one in the last dozen years, but I know it hasn't been easy. Ask Celtic fans how difficult it has been. I saw John Gregory the other day saying that the Premiership is a foregone conclusion, that Manchester United are a certainty. Well, I'll tell you one man who will not be thinking it's a foregone conclusion and that's Alex Ferguson.

'I think Arsenal, pound for pound, are as talented as United, but Alex's team have won so many titles because their players don't believe it's easy. They keep going for it, as Arsenal will, because great players retain that hunger for success. We're just trying to attain success. But I think when managers talk of foregone conclusions, they've given up on themselves.
