fields.headline: Morrison finds a minder
fields.trailText: It's like Alan Smith has two quests at Crystal Palace: managing the football team and developing Clinton Morrison.
fields.body:
Midway through gushing about Clinton Morrison in the most paternal and affectionate way a manager could ever talk about a player, Alan Smith checked himself and quipped that if he carried on like this, their relationship would sound like a romance.

The bond is certainly an intense one. A couple of months ago they fell out. Morrison, 21, a vibrant talent with ability and attitude to burn, wasn't realising his potential, so Smith taught him a lesson by slapping him on the transfer list. One kick up the backside and a flurry of goals later, Smith is choosing Christmas presents for the boy, taking him out for meals, and putting a great deal of time into nurturing a player he expects to be outstanding once he is fully matured.

Recently Ray Houghton, one of Smith's coaches, admitted they spend more time talking about Morrison than anything else.

Not for nothing is Crystal Palace's prodigious striker teased by his team-mates about being the gaffer's son. It's as if Smith has two quests at Selhurst Park: managing the football team and developing Morrison.

'We have a really good relationship which is a bit more than just manager and player and I have to be careful with the other players that I don't let that go too far,' he adds. He can't hold back too much, though, because he reckons Morrison is a rough diamond well worth polishing but in need of plenty of elbow grease.

'He needs constant management and attention. If he was left alone I think he would go off at a tangent.'

With Morrison hailing from a broken home in south London, Smith has taken it upon himself to guide him. The message seems to be getting through. Morrison, who has just bought a new house for himself, his mum and sister, explains: 'He's made me see different sides to life, like how lucky I am to be a footballer. There are so many people out there who are struggling and we are earning so much money and we're only working two hours a day. Earlier on in the season he thought I wasn't pulling my weight and made me buck up my ideas. He's trying to make me progress into a top player so fair play to him.

'When he put me on the transfer list I didn't know whether I was coming or going. I thought I can only go one of two ways: the wrong way or forward. And I've just gone forward. Since then my game has changed a lot, I've got much stronger and more confident and every time I go out there I have belief in myself that I can score goals.'

Smith's fireworks were always intended as a short, sharp shock (both of them knew full well he was never going to sell his prized asset, more so when the only bids came from Notts County and Cardiff). It turned out to be a turning point after a disastrous start to the season: Palace embarked on a 12-match unbeaten run, spearheaded by Morrison's 11-goal streak. He has been a revelation, as he showed with another strike at Loftus Road yesterday.

Considering the desperate search for strikers afflicting a host of Premiership clubs - the likes of Aston Villa, Newcastle and Tottenham have been scouring the globe for some time now - it is surprising that bright British prospects in the Nationwide League remain overlooked. Morrison's progress can't be ignored for too much longer. Valuing himself conservatively at around the £2.5 million mark, he is eager to play in the Premiership, spurred on by the experience of victories over Leicester and Sunderland this season.

In the next month he has the chance to prove himself at that level again, with an FA Cup trip to the Stadium of Light and a Worthington Cup semi-final against Liverpool. 'I think I could do a job in the Premiership and I'd like to be playing there in the next year or so,' he says. 'That's not to say time is running out but I want a taste of it. My dream would be to play in the Premiership with Palace and I think we've got a good enough team now.'

If they are to make it, Smith is in no doubt about who will lead them there: 'If Clinton is as good as I think he is, and I can mould him into more of a team player, he can get us where we want to go and he can come with us.' Together, they are working on the necessary improvements. Morrison reckons he is playing at 60 per cent of what he hopes he can be one day. And he is absolutely convinced the other 40 per cent will come.

They say that if you look for the coolest, flashiest kid around Selhurst you will find Morrison. Sauntering, strutting, shooting from the lip, he is, as Smith says, 'different'. The manager sees in him something of Ian Wright, another cocksure south London boy blessed with spontaneous skills and honed at Palace. The club have been trying to replace Wright ever since they sold him and Morrison is the closest they have come. 'If I could finish like him then I'd be a top player,' Morrison says. 'I'd do anything to achieve my ambitions and I'm not going to stop until I get there.' He just might.

fields.headline: McCann silences guns
fields.trailText: Arsenal let slip a two-goal lead.
fields.body:
So the great escape was showing over the holiday period after all. Two goals up and purring like a panther, Arsenal instead allowed the Black Cats of Sunderland to finish with a share of the cream. With Manchester United stumbling, it was a missed opportunity for Arsenal to breathe new life into the Premiership title race.

They got the perfect start with a goal by Patrick Vieira and doubled it before half-time with Lee Dixon's composed finish. The crucial part was what came between those two goals, however, with a glut of chances going begging. Sunderland must have felt reprieved; they certainly played like it after the break, and a penalty by Kevin Phillips coupled with Gavin McCann's stunning late strike rewarded their persistence.

'We lost the pace in our game, lost our movement and didn't win the ball back quickly,' lamented Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger afterwards. His patently pleased Sunderland counterpart Peter Reid said: 'I asked my players a lot of questions at half-time and they gave me the right answers.'

How do Arsenal do it? Not win every game they play, that is. They have so much attacking talent, pass the ball crisply, move lithely and carve out openings galore. Perhaps the game seems too easy for some of their exotic talents at times and they get bored, then coast. Perhaps they want to score perfect goals rather than simple ones of the sort Ian Wright used to bang in when required.

They seemed hungry for them at the outset, no doubt motivated by the 1-0 defeat at the Stadium of Light on the opening day. Then, they outplayed Sunderland but were sent home in disgrace - Vieira with a red card and Wenger on a misconduct charge after allegedly tangling with the fourth official, a case whose appeal is still waiting to be heard.

Vieira exacted swift vengeance of the best kind. Robert Pires swung in a corner and Vieira popped up amid a static Sunderland defence to head home. It was the overture to a period of fluent dominance, Arsenal quicker and surer of touch and pass, typified by Vieira. All went through him and the hapless McCann, theoretically marking him, was out of his depth.

A feeling of profligacy left the match when Henry got to the left byline and crossed, the ball eluding all until Dixon arrived at the far post to guide home with an experienced eye through the melee. Newcastle conceded five here, Leicester six. Sunderland looked candidates for similar treatment.

'If you are not competing, they pick you off,' said Reid. 'We showed them too much respect, didn't win enough second balls. I said to my players: "Just show me what you can do. Let's win the second half."' You can bet it was more colourful than that.

His team certainly were, and as a reflection of new intent, they quickly got the turning-point goal. Niall Quinn, hitherto subdued, turned on to a half-clearance by the Arsenal defence and the ball hit Vieira's hand. 'Penalty,' said the referee, Graham Barber, and Phillips duly stroked the ball home for his ninth Premiership goal of the season.

A bizarre equaliser almost followed. Phillips seized on to a long ball and found himself with just Manninger to beat. Again he shot too close to the goalkeeper, but from the rebound, Igor Stepanovs's impulsive clearance hit Quinn and ricocheted on to a post.

Now Sunderland sniffed some reward from the game, their passivity of the first half just a memory. McCann got tighter to Vieira and Arsenal's supply line was cut. The Sunderland back four were no longer under such pressure and no longer looked error-prone. The midfield were on the front foot rather than the back. McCann even had time to get forward for a shot that was just wide.

Time to come back for more, too. As Vieira dwelt on the ball some 25 yards out, Rae snapped into the tackle and the loose ball ran for McCann. He swung a boot and the ball sailed into the net between a flailing Manninger and his left post for the equaliser.

Another Stepanovs error almost led to Phillips stealing a winner, but the cross shot was wide. Sunderland were pleased enough with what they had already poached, though. Who needs Steve McQueen when you've got Gavin McCann?

fields.headline: Latapy leaves it late
fields.trailText: Latapy leaves it late to seal the points.
fields.body:
Hibs finally found a reason to celebrate the festive season when Russell Latapy converted a penalty kick, awarded for unfathomable reasons in the fifth minute of injury time, that cruelly denied United a precious point in their struggle to beat relegation.

It was impossible to determine why the referee awarded the penalty, as the ball dropped among a posse of players from a right-wing corner. But the visitors' goalkeeper, Alan Combe, could be in serious bother with the SFA, as he appeared to spit at a linesman as he left the field at the end of a game that had been controversy-free until the closing seconds.

Any team threatened with a future that includes wage cuts and visits to venues where the players outnumber the supporters is bound to make strenuous efforts at avoidance, hence United's energetic resistance for lengthy periods.

The conditions were no help, of course, as the participants were frequently the unwitting victims of a playing surface that appeared to become more treacherous as the sky darkened and the temperature dropped.

Even allowing for the visitors' fear-induced commitment and the climatic changes, however, Hibs spent much of the time disappointing a support who have come to expect cavalier football and convincing scorelines.

There was no mistaking their style, once again demonstrating a capacity for finding each other with precision passing, but their aggression seemed for much of the time to have been turned down to simmer.

During the entire first half, for example, they contrived only three situations from which they might have scored, although even they could not have been called golden opportunities. Latapy inspired the first with a magnificent through-ball to John O'Neil, the latter bursting from midfield into the right side of the penalty area.

O'Neil's timing was impeccable and he hit the volley on the run as crisply as he would have wished, but Jim Lauchlan, the central defender who had distinguished himself against Rangers a week earlier, once again showed his alertness by coming across to deflect the ball for a corner. It was a marvellous piece of defensive work.

It was from a corner that Hibs had their next chance, Mathias Jack's drive from outside the area coming off Mixu Paatelainen and falling kindly for the lurking Ulrik Laursen. Unfortunately, it landed at the big Dane's weaker right foot and the drive, from 15 yards, was pulled well wide.

O'Neil made an opportunity for himself when he received a long ball from defence and drifted past two opponents as he came in from the left, but his low, curling right-foot drive was well held by Combe.

But, having noticeably increased the pace of their assaults throughout the second half, Hibs should not have needed the referee's late charity. Though it will be of little consolation, that they did perhaps signifies a change for the better in United's luck.

The Tannadice team were fortunate, for example, that the home forwards, especially Paatelainen, seemed to have left their ruthlessness in the dressing-room. The big Finn supported this claim when he miskicked the ball feebly into the arms of Combe from three yards with the ball loose in the goalmouth.

Paatelainen may have been considered a trifle unlucky with a looping header from Franck Sauzee's chip, which slid marginally wide, but those of a more cynical cast would doubtless argue that he should at least have kept the ball on target.

Combe's behaviour at the finish was a shocking way to complete a day's work, especially as he had done as much as anybody to keep United in the match during those patches of the second half when Hibs seemed likely to win as convincingly as most observers had expected.

fields.headline: Jansen boosts Rovers
fields.trailText: League review .
fields.body:
The feeling that Blackburn are the team best equipped to present a genuine First Division title challenge to Fulham have been reinforced.

While second-placed Bolton slumped to a home defeat by West Bromwich Albion, Blackburn beat Crewe 1-0 - their fourth successive win, and one which showed that, like all successful teams, they can get their hands on maximum points when not at their best.

Matt Jansen, who came off the bench to score both of Blackburn's goals in a Boxing Day triumph over Birmingham, got in the scoring act again with a left-foot from just inside the penalty area.

The biggest surprise was at the top of the Second Division, where Millwall lost 3-2 at home to Notts County.

They had twice come from behind to make it 2-2, but continued to make life difficult for themselves through having Christophe Kinet sent off, and were eventually sunk by a Gary Owers goal in the last minute.

Dave Bassett, one of Atkins's managerial heroes, has confirmed he has applied for the vacant manager's job at Wolves. 'I think other applicants are being considered over the weekend and I hope to hear something early in the new year,' he said.

If he does get it, one man who might be quite envious of him is Ian Atkins. To Atkins - one of Bassett's greatest admirers - being manager of Carlisle has been tantamount to 'banging my head against a wall'. He adds: 'But for my enthusiasm for football - for working with players - I would have chucked this job in two or three months ago.'

Still, despite Carlisle's position at the bottom of the league, there are compensations. One concerns the extent to which Atkins has galvanised some of his players - notably their 22-year-old striker, Scott Dobie, who is producing his best form for some time and again attracting the attention of bigger clubs.

The other will be provided by next weekend's FA Cup third-round tie at home to Arsenal. If any lower-division manager could do with a match like this to bring some glamour into his life, and emphasise his true worth, it is Atkins.

Noted for his transformation of Northampton, whom he steered from the Third Division to the brink of the First, Atkins has not had much scope to rise to the fore again since his controversial sacking there last year.

His move to Carlisle in the summer was preceded by four months at Chester, where he ultimately failed to prevent them going out of the league by just one point. He suggests that in some ways, the challenge of saving Carlisle is even more stressful.

Referring to the behind-the-scenes turmoil over Michael Knighton's sale of the club, he says: 'I did not fully appreciate the problems for me.

'For example, when I joined Carlisle in July, I did not know that because a new board was coming in, I could not sign any players until the following month.

'Ten days before the start of the season, I had no more than six players, and I had to make up the numbers with players on monthly contracts, which is not an ideal situation when you are trying to develop a solid base.

'But I have no trouble sleeping at night because I know that I have done as much as anyone can have expected of me - as much as anyone can expect of anybody. It would not matter who was manager here; even Arsène Wenger or Sir Alex Ferguson would struggle to cope with the problems I have had'

While it is difficult to believe that Arsenal are at risk against Carlisle - despite the latter's recent record of only two defeats in eight matches - it is a different matter with Tottenham and West Ham at Leyton Orient and Walsall.

But the latter will certainly have to do better than they did yesterday, when they could only manage a goalless draw against lowly Oldham.

Peter Davenport, the former Manchester United striker, has been sacked as manager of Macclesfield Town because of his refusal to work alongside Director of Football Gil Prescott in a new managerial set up.

fields.headline: Ice-cool Beattie
fields.trailText: Ice-cool Beattie scores ten out of ten.
fields.body:
James Beattie is said to be asking for a pay rise from a mere £2,500 a week to something approaching £20,000. After scoring his tenth goal in as many games, Southampton must prepare to dig deep if they want to keep him.

It is hard to imagine another transformation as complete as that which has befallen 22-year-old Beattie over the last couple of months. Crystal Palace offered £2.6m for him in October and their chairman was quoted as saying at the time that even Beattie's mother knew he was overpriced at such a figure.

Beattie had by then gone 18 months without a goal and would not have got back into the side had the experienced German Uwe Rösler not sustained a groin injury which has required an operation and lengthy recuperation.

At least Beattie has a year and a half of his contract to run, which gives Southampton time to reorganise their finances, while Glenn Hoddle's agreement as manager finishes at much the same time.

Hoddle felt Beattie had not enjoyed the best of matches and until his goal. It is true that Taribo West had kept him under control. But when it mattered in the 72nd minute, Beattie's power and determination got him ahead of his illustrious marker to meet Marian Pahars's right-wing centre with a downward header.

Hoddle said: 'I do not want to talk about Beattie's contract but I thought his movement was not as good as in recent matches. Even so he got the winning goal which is significant and he will only get better.'

Derby's manager Jim Smith was disappointed not only with the result but also that the match was allowed to go ahead after two inspections by Essex-based referee Andy D'Urso, the last of them only 90 minutes before the kick off.

The referee was vindicated even though ground staff were still sweeping snow from the pitch as the players warmed up and by the final whistle the Milton End was proving treacherous, a condition not exploited by attackers Derby.

Smith said: 'We should not be playing Premiership matches in these conditions but that was no excuse for our poor showing in the second half. We were never in it.'

One small consolation for Derby was the form of the tall and talented Youle Mawene, the new £500,000 signing from the French club Lens making his full debut. Mawene made light of the surface to defend and attack when required with comfort and poise.

There is no doubt that the return to Derby of Colin Todd to work on the defence and bolster ageing manager Smith has had a tightening effect, and Derby were far better organised than they had been at the start of the season when points were elusive.

But their attack of Burton and Christie, after forcing Paul Jones into early saves, looked too lightweight even on a pitch which in theory might have suited their pace, and they can expect a tougher winter ahead than habitual strugglers Southampton.

fields.headline: Clinical Clinton rescues Palace
fields.trailText: Clinical Clinton rescues Palace.
fields.body:
Having spent Christmas at the bottom of the first division table, QPR start the new year with hope as this point lifts them out of the basement position.

Their optimism has foundation as the battle to avoid the drop from this division is so tight that even mid-table clubs cannot feel safe. Only goal difference separates QPR from bottom club Crewe, though, so relegation remains a threat, especially if they continue to throw away winning leads. Rangers twice surrendered the lead in losing to Norwich on Boxing Day and were ahead in this game too.

Palace's future seems far more secure. With a League Cup semi-final against Liverpool also to look forward to, manager Alan Smith believes his younger players can lead Palace up the table.

Smith said: 'Every time I put the youngsters in they respond. You have to ask yourself whether you would rather play cynical old pros or not. Alex Ferguson puts the youngsters in every year at Manchester United and that's the route I see us going now. We played as well as you can without winning.'

Smith's analysis was ultimately accurate, but it would not have stood up at half-time. Peter Crouch had given QPR a 14th-minute lead with a near-post volley from Stuart Wardley's corner. Chance after chance followed and with more assurance in front of goal they could have had the game won by the interval.

Palace seemed alive to that fact as they played throughout the second half with real purpose. They had a series of chances to equalise before Rangers gifted them a goal after 59 minutes.

Chris Plummer blasted a clearance straight at team-mate Ian Baraclough, who was knocked down by the force of the ball, which then flew straight back towards goal and an unmarked Clinton Morrison, who calmly scored from 10 yards.

Palace looked like winners from then on, but Rangers rode their luck and manager Gerry Francis admitted: 'The Keystone Cops come to mind for Palace's goal and it was very tough for us after that. But the game should have been over by half time - we have done that too many times and have got to start taking our chances.'

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Ruairi
fields.trailText: I know your plan is to go to Lima, but if at all possible try and fit in a visit to Bolivia. The most beautiful spot I have ever been to was called Rurrenebaque. It has UNESCO biosphere status and is full of the most diverse and wonderful wildlife. You can take a three day tour on a canoe and sleep rough on wooden pallets in a sleeping bag under a mosquito net under the most spectacular night sky on earth.
fields.body:
Sue,

I know your plan is to go to Lima, but if at all possible try and fit in a visit to Bolivia.

Three years ago I spent three months travelling around the northern countries of South America and by far the best was Bolivia. It has by far the greatest concentration of indigenous peoples and the country is as beautiful and diverse as any could imagine.

The most beautiful spot I have ever been to was called Rurrenebaque. It has UNESCO biosphere status and is full of the most diverse and wonderful wildlife. You can take a three day tour on a canoe and sleep rough on wooden pallets in a sleeping bag under a mosquito net under the most spectacular night sky on earth.

If it is at all a possibility please go, you'll keep in in your heart forever. ps stay at hotel "Tuichi"

Either way, good luck with your travels, I wish you a fantastic trip.

Ruairi Felix Keene

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Sheena
fields.trailText: Some advice on Malaysia. Sarawak is great, especially Kuching. There are plenty of places to stay, whatever your price range. A stroll along the esplanade in the evening is wonderful because they play music and the fountains by the fort light up and dance.
fields.body:
Sue,

Hi! I had that yeti sit on my lap when I was in Kathmandu... Sorry you were there in times of trouble (know what that's like from experience).

Some advice on Singapore and Malaysia. Internal flights in Malaysia are much cheaper when bought within the country, rather than from outside. What you can do when you arrive in Singapore is make a booking with Malaysian Airlines for flying to or from Sarawak, then you can take a Malaysian Airlines bus from Singapore to Johor Bahru (which only costs $10) as the flights to Sarawak go from there. If you ask at the Malaysian airlines desk at Changi (Singapore airport) they should be able to tell you about this.

Sarawak is great, especially Kuching. I stayed first in an awful hotel called the Arif in the Islamic area (do NOT stay there) then moved to the Goodwood Inn on Jalan Green Hill near the city centre which was much better and still not too expensive. There are plenty of places to stay, whatever your price range. Lots to see too - the city itself is great, especially Shop Street along the esplanade, where there are some great artifact shops scattered amongst the kitsch ones. Pepper biscuits are yummy; pepper is THE crop of Sarawak and they make everything from it - biscuits, perfume, tea, etc. A stroll along the esplanade in the evening is great because they play music and the fountains by the fort light up and dance. You can hire one of the boats on the river to yourself for an hour which takes you up and down the river and isn't too expensive. There is a cat museum which is actually quite interesting, although on the 'wrong' side of the river. The Islamic museum behind the new museum is very good. The new and old museums aren't bad. There is the cultural show which is in a village displaying each tribe's house style. Definitely worth a visit; you can book from any of the major hotels and the coaches go from the hotels and back. Also, you should book a couple of days at the Bako National Park (booked through tourist bureau near the museums) which is the best place in Sarawak for viewing or hearing wildlife (watch out for the monkeys which steal anything not nailed down). Sarawak is very humid and quite hot and it rains very heavily most afternoons. Eat early in the evening as most eating places seem to close down at 6pm!

If you want to go to other towns you can get a boat from Kuching to Sibu (once a day) which takes four hours and is good fun. I liked Sibu; it is a frontier town (like Manaus in Amazonas) with a terrific market, a nice chinese pagoda giving good views, and from there buses run north up the coast to Miri which is the jumping off spot for Gunung Mulu national park and also the Niah caves at Batu Niah. Batu Niah has the best hostel accommodation in Malaysian Borneo and the caves are awesome.

Gunung Mulu I felt was a rip off - you could only fly in, you have to stay two nights to see all four caves because of the flight times, the hostel is OK but is no longer self-catering (no kitchen) and there are only two places to eat (the one outside the camp over the river is run by the surliest people I ever met!) If you're there on a Sunday look for the Iban market under the trees by the river. The caves are quite good, although you need a good torch and the bats leaving the cave at night are worth seeing, but on the whole it's an expensive trip.

Anyway, that might help you make up your mind. I had a week in Kuching itself which was just enough. Sarawak only really has the one road up the coast, and buses are like coaches and run to timetables.

Have a great time and happy new year.

fields.headline: Cheap but cheerful
fields.standfirst: Winter prompts dreams of backpacking off to sunnier climes. Observer journalists recall the personal pitfalls and pratfalls of travelling light in their youth
fields.trailText: Winter prompts dreams of backpacking off to sunnier climes. Observer journalists recall the personal pitfalls and pratfalls of travelling light in their youth.
fields.body:
Debbie Lawson

Morocco, 1993

It was our second visit to Morocco and this time we were ready for it - a small rucksack, a few words of Arabic and an attitude of practised nonchalance. We were heading south to the Algerian border, where the first shallow dunes of the Sahara spread out. It was so hot my T-shirt stuck to my back. The book had mentioned a quirky-sounding hotel, the Auberge de Repos du Sable, a former kasbah run by artists. We took a taxi to the desert and there it was, complete with sign to 'Timbuktu - 52 jours'. Beside it was the burnt-out shell of a Fifties Citroën van, relic of the hippie trail, and beyond, in the dunes, an old car seat and a family of camels. Our room was made of mud and straw, with a window that looked out on to an island of palm trees. We lay in the shaded courtyard as the sun went down, drinking mint tea sweetened by sugar lumps the size of coal. There was no chance of a shower - the bathroom floor was teeming with scorpions - and as we settled down to sleep I became aware of a scrabbling sound coming from the gap under the door. By the light of the moon we watched them march in: flying ants, crickets, darkling beetles, giant cockroaches, strange slug-like creatures I'd never seen before. There was nothing for it but to retreat to the roof, where a stiff breeze kept the beasties at bay and overhead shooting stars filled the sky with cascades of bright light. We didn't sleep a wink. It was a night I'll never forget.

Jacqui MacDermott

France, 1980

'We must have some money left,' said Karena. I checked again. 'Not a centime.' We were on a campsite just outside Perpignan on the French/Spanish border with nothing but a small tent, a couple of coach and ferry tickets and half a bottle of Pastis (the last evidence of our rampant overspending). And we were hungry. You think we might have gone home. You think we might have rung and persuaded long-suffering parents to wire some cash. But we were 18 (just), stupid and proud. 'There's nothing for it,' said Karena, 'we'll have to beg for food. We'll walk around the campsite and ask everyone we see.' It seemed a good enough solution, so we set off separately to accost fellow campers. It's a sobering experience, begging. Young people generally just tell you to piss off, and parents gather their children nervously about them as if you might steal one. An hour later we met back at the tent. I had half a jar of jam, Karena produced an almost full packet of Quaker Porridge Oats. So that was that. Mind you, being 18 and off the leash, we always managed to persuade someone to buy us beer in the evenings...

Mexico, 1990

What relief we felt when we stumbled into a hotel room in Puerto Angel, Mexico. Our shoulders ached after a slow journey down from Acapulco on a bus shared with chickens and goats. My friend Sonia grunted, keeled over and fell asleep. I sat on my bed enjoying the sporadic breeze offered by the cranky fan. Then I spotted a big black scorpion poised to strike about three inches from my big toe. I catapulted on to Sonia's bed. Still mumbling, Sonia ran to get help. The manager and his family of 14 came to the rescue, cackling helplessly with laughter at the stupid 'gringos'. The scorpion was tracked down and dealt with brutally by the manager's children. They had the last laugh by telling us that scorpions always travelled in pairs. 'Good night, senoritas,' grinned the manager, chewing on his toothpick. Fat chance.

Jay Rayner

Italy, the 1980s

With a pack on your back, wherever you drop is your bed. For me it was the train or, to be more exact, the floor of the train. I chose trains as my bed because, with a European rail pass already paid for, it was the cheapest place I could find to spend the night. It had to be the corridor floor because everyone else with a rucksack was doing the same thing and all the seats had gone. I did at least have an advantage over most people: I was awfully large. My size was crucial. If you were slim of hip, sure, you too could stretch out in the corridor but you could guarantee that you would be kicked awake repeatedly by people getting past you in the narrow space between your body and the wall. With me there was never any narrow space. I filled it. What's more, being large, people seemed to be scared of me. (I suspect the Mohican haircut may have had something to do with it.) And so they would do anything to pass without touching me. I remember waking one night between Florence and Brindisi and seeing a young guy clinging to the walls above my head, trying to traverse the carriage three feet above the floor. I smiled up at him. He smiled uneasily down at me. And then he went on his way. I, in turn, rolled over and gently drifted back to sleep.

Oliver Owen

The Balkans, 1983

Backpacking means economising, and for the smoker this is always difficult. Back in 1983 my favoured fag was a John Player Blue - now, sadly, no longer available - but in Israel, on a kibbutznik's meagre wage, the smoke of choice was a Sheraton. They were rough, but three months on the kibbutz and the Sheratons and I were getting along fine. How I missed them when I left. In Egypt the affordable smoking option was the Cleopatra and its equally ghastly sister-smoke the Nefertiti. But on my travels the worst of a bad bunch was the Greek gasper - Hellas Gold. So keen was I to avoid these Athenian firesticks that I extravagantly bought a pack of 10 Marlboro to see me through a 27-hour train ride to Belgrade. As I slept, my friend Giles smoked my cigarettes. I was horrified and very hurt. The trust was gone. The remaining month of the trip was a strain.

Dave Hills

Italy, the 1990s

As a teenager who had rarely travelled beyond Surrey, I didn't realise that wearing a shiny new backpack was an open invitation to Europe's rip-off merchants. But so it proved . We were soon lured into an original deathtrap hotel in Rome - bread rolls and salami for breakfast and dinner, one toilet per 50 guests and - even we knew this was not right - bare wires in the shower. In an expensive travellers' hostel we slept three to a bed in 90-degree temperatures with stinking sheets and the owner used a laser pen to chase rats from the corridors as well as trace the contours of my girlfriend's body through the shower curtain. We spent four nights in a Prague concrete block being charged £20 for a two-mile taxi ride into town, every day, without complaining once (Englishness strikes the young hard); and one evening was spent eating what seemed to be raw lamb in Malta, an unforgettable meal, tasting of playground nosebleeds. We went as teenagers and came back as bitter teenagers, but with a bigger world view none the less.

Jason Burke

India, 1993

This was my moment. I glared down from the balcony of my Delhi guesthouse at the banana-pancake munching hordes stopping over in the Indian capital on their way to Goa or across to Thailand. Not for me the fleshpots and tropics. My destination was lean and rugged - the Himalayas and a solo attempt on a 21,000ft mountain. I would, I decided, climb above the mess, and mass, of humanity. I rang my mum first. Barely able to shoulder my pack, full of French post-war novels, I staggered on to the train north. Three days later I had hiked up to the snowline. The next night I spent in a shepherd's cabin burning pages of De Beauvoir to keep warm. I was miserable and lonely. After drinking melted snow for a couple of days my guts were in a state of disrepair. Accepting my destiny, I admitted defeat and headed back to the villages below. I never read Sartre with quite the same pleasure again.

Joanna Walters

France, 1981

My mate Suzette and I were 17 when we set out on the autoroute with thumbs up and big smiles. We clambered up into the cab of the lorry as dusk fell. We let the driver put our rucksacks in the back and soon fell asleep. I woke to find the driver tugging at my clothes. He'd pulled into a deserted layby in the pitch dark. Suzette woke to the sound of my firm 'Non!' We said we'd walk but he reminded us our rucksacks were locked in his trailer. Then he tutted and said something in French I didn't understand. Suzette wailed - he'd said if one of us did not have sex with him in five minutes he would kill us. Just then a car pulled up in front. I ran to it sobbing for the man inside to help me. He accompanied me back to the lorry where the driver had given in and was lifting down our rucksacks. We've both backpacked and hitchhiked thousands of miles since then and got into many scrapes. But I've never again let anyone lock my rucksack in the back or fallen asleep on the road.

Liz Myers

The French Alps, 1980

Dammit, that's the zip gone, I thought. Slipping on the ice outside my lodging, I had sat down on my bum with enough force to break the zip on my, admittedly skintight, jeans. I had been working in a French ski equipment/hire shop; on days off I was free to ski. After work, I'd hit the après ski. It was as I was heading for my favourite bar one February night that I fell. By the next day my lower back was agony. The manageress at work called a doctor. Things moved fast. My right leg swelled alarmingly, and I was soon on my way down the mountainside in an ambulance. Hospital tests showed acute compression of several vertebrae plus a clot in the main vein alongside. I found myself immobilised in a hospital bed, with a drip to dissolve the clot. There I remained for a month. It was March by the time they let me out, on a solemn promise not to work for another month. By that time the skiing, and seasonal jobs, would be finished, but I consoled myself with the thought that when friends back home asked about the 'ski bum' experience, I could say I had found a whole new meaning for the term.

Jonathan Cook

Turkey, 1991

I was standing in the middle of a dark road, my rucksack locked in the boot of a taxi, having a blazing row with the driver which - if the bedroom lights being switched on provided a clue - was waking most of the street. I'd arrived late at Dalaman airport and, caught by the usual late-night taxi cartel, started canvassing other travellers to share a ride. That upset the cabbies, of course, one of whom agreed to my knock-down price in an attempt, I suppose, to stop me putting ideas into the heads of other customers. By the time we arrived at my destination, Fethiye, he'd had second thoughts and doubled the price. That's why we were arguing in the street. As the driver rapidly lost his command of English and started shouting in Turkish, a young male passerby turned translator. Soon bleary-eyed people were appearing from doorways, some in their nightwear. They listened attentively to both our arguments. Then after a few minutes the translator, sensing a consensus, delivered their verdict. Without a word the driver opened the boot, handed over my pack, accepted the agreed fare and drove off into the night.

Harriet Lane

The Philippines, 1990

You haven't had the full backpacking experience unless your travelling companion has fallen in love and left you playing gooseberry in one of the most beautiful places in the world. Ten years ago, my best friend, Miss X, and I found ourselves on the paradisical Filipino island of Boracay, sharing beers with a moustachioed American of advanced years (well, at least 35) who rolled enormous spliffs and managed to hint, without actually saying anything specific, that he was a senior member of the CIA. Before long, I was spending long hours of solitude in my hammock and even after we left the island it led to some terrific rows.

webTitle: I know more about Laos than Liverpool

fields.headline: I know more about Laos than Liverpool
fields.trailText: I've been to Tibet, Pakistan, Laos and Morocco. I have not, on the other hand, visited Nottingham.
fields.body:
This year, I went from Russia to China on the Trans-Siberian railway. I spent six weeks in Senegal, Mali and Gambia. I saw the sun rise on the new millennium at the top of the Langtang valley in Nepal. I've been to Tibet, Pakistan, Laos and Morocco. I have not, on the other hand, visited Nottingham. Similarly, Liverpool is familiar to me only through Brookside , although I'm told I have been there en route to Ireland when I was about six. I went to Manchester at the age of 14 on a geography field trip, and although several of my friends went to university there I never got around to visiting.

I don't think this is unusual. Many of my friends, particularly those I've met travelling, have been to more parts of the globe than I have, and, indeed, know less of their homelands. As round-the-world air tickets routinely cost less than £1,000, and allow you to travel for up to a year, it becomes easy to save up to go away, and the availability of working visas in the Antipodes allows for a convenient rebuilding of funds halfway round.

Meanwhile, the shift away from the job-for-life culture has made 'going away travelling' something everyone wants to do; a perfectly legitimate option to contemplate after a relationship break-up, or when you're fed up with your job. When the heir to the throne scrubs lavatories in southern Chile, we understand exactly why he's doing it.

As we visit places that were inaccessible a generation ago, our perceptions of the world and our place within it alter. The excitement and the fascination offered by faraway destinations means that we are happy to ignore places in our own backyard. We are part of a global, not a British, community of backpackers.

Whether this is a good thing or not depends on the traveller's attitude. Countless times I have realised with a jolt exactly how lucky I am. I sat on African buses last summer, and, as we passed through villages of mud huts, I watched women of my own age, surrounded by children, roasting maize on hot coals to sell to the passengers when the daily bus passed through. They could aspire to nothing else. In Nepal, my boyfriend and I stayed overnight with a family of Tibetan exiles. When it emerged that James, then aged 25, was at university, they were astonished. 'No job?' asked one man. 'You are so lucky.'

His daughter, Chimka, was a bright and delightful two-year-old. She clapped her hands, blew kisses, told us a long story in Tibetan and parroted what we said.

'You're not shy,' James noted.

'Not shy,' she retorted.

If she lived in Britain, Chimka would have the opportunity to use her brains and her charm in whatever way she chose. As it is, unless something dramatic happens to change her family's life, she will grow up running a small lodge in the Himalayas, gathering firewood, feeding the animals and entertaining international visitors. But unlike most of us, she breathes crystal clear air and is adored by everyone around her.

Encounters like this should make us appreciate our opportunity to make whatever we can of ourselves. It does not, however, always work out like that. When I arrived in Asia alone, two years ago, I was surprised and relieved to find numerous others like me. Even in Vietnam, there was an industry in place to cater for us. There were cafes which served nondescript Western food (most ubiquitously, banana pancakes) and there were buses especially for backpackers to get from one Lonely Planet -recommended destination to the next.

It takes a surge of strength to reject this, to branch out alone and do things that are scary. Backpacker culture is the reason everyone hates backpackers: they stick together, they don't learn any of the local language, they colonise villages that cannot afford to refuse the money. They do this because it's easy. I know, because I've done it myself.

James and I have decided we'll do something different, so we're greeting 2001 in the north of Scotland (and passing through Nottingham as we go). Having a holiday closer to home than usual seems both easier than going abroad, and more difficult, in that it might not be as immediately thrilling as last new year in the Himalayas. Jeff, an American friend of ours, is coming too. He's going to stay behind afterwards and travel slowly through Britain.

By the middle of January, he will doubtless have seen more of our country than we have.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Rebecca
fields.trailText: When you get to Auckland, do go to Kelly Tarlton's Underwater World - this visionary guy built a magnificent aquarium and penguin house in the old sewers under the city. The penguins are the main stars...
fields.body:
Sam,

When you get to Auckland, do go to Kelly Tarlton's Underwater World - this visionary guy built a magnificent aquarium and penguin house in the old sewers under the city. The penguins are the main stars...

You seem to like heights - try the Sky Tower and I dare you to jump on one of the glass floor panels. Ponsonby is a great suburb about one mile from the city with funky shopping on the Ponsonby Road - and this city really understands latte. webTitle: Sects, power and miracles in the Bible belt of Essex

fields.headline: Sects, power and miracles in the Bible belt of Essex
fields.standfirst: Tory-loving evangelist Bishop Michael Reid puts the fear of God into opponents. Can the Man in the White Suit take him on and win? John Sweeney on the battle for Ongar
fields.trailText: Tory-loving evangelist Bishop Michael Reid puts the fear of God into opponents. Can the Man in the White Suit take him on and win? John Sweeney on the battle for Ongar.
fields.body:
An Essex Tory MP, a 'miracle-working' bishop and the Man In The White Suit, the independent MP Martin Bell, are lining up to play a part in a compelling fight in the next general election.

The battle for Ongar will turn on the close support Conservative MP Eric Pickles has received from Bishop Michael Reid and the members of his Pentecostal church, which some describe as a 'disturbing religious sect'.

Bell is to stand against Pickles for Brentwood and Ongar - the sixth safest Tory seat in the country - and may well pick up votes from those who are worried about the influence of Bishop Reid's hot-gospelling church in the constituency. Ex-members of the Peniel Pentecostal Church and others believe Pickles has 'an appalling conflict of interest' because Brentwood and Ongar Conservatives have received thousands of pounds from church members.

Reid - a former policeman turned insurance salesman turned evangelist - and his companies have donated at least pounds 2,500 to Pickles's fighting fund and the Conservative Party, while his church members have boosted Tory funds by around pounds 5,000.

Pickles has defended members of the church 'as wonderfully normal people'. Others disagree.

Former church member Caroline Green was a constituent of Pickles at the time she left the sect. She is one of those who will be writing to the Westminster standards ombudsman. She told The Observer: 'The bishop is a deeply troubled man who says terrible things about people who have opposed him. He has been excommunicated from another church, runs companies controlling millions of pounds and is very intimidating. How can you ask your MP to help you, if he supports the bishop?'

Reid refers to himself and other evangelists as the 'anointed of God'. He was excommunicated for 'raillery' - a biblical term for slander - from Liverpool's Devonshire Road Christian Fellowship in 1969 and his 'flesh was committed to Satan'.

The billboard next to Sainsbury's car park in Brentwood proclaims 'Miracles, Healing, Faith: Come and See' and shows Reid holding a small boy with one hand and a microphone in the other. The miracle mentioned in the billboard is not detailed.

Miracles cited by the church have included the sensational recovery of a boy from leukaemia. The church explains the case of Sam Mildenberger as follows: 'The miracle was that he was cured of a rare form of leukaemia when he was 18 months old having been given an hour to live, Bishop Reid having been asked by his parents - who are not and never have been members of the Peniel church - to pray for him at Great Ormond Street Hospital. He died some eight years later from complications following a viral infection.'

The church did not highlight the fact of a bone-marrow transplant in the boy's recovery.

Mildenberger's death certificate shows he died from haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis - the rare form of leukaemia he had allegedly been miraculously cured of. Dr Peter May, a GP and member of the General Synod of the Church of England, said: 'Viral illness is not mentioned in the death certificate. Cause of death is attributed to the rare form of leukaemia he was suffering. It led directly to his death. I have not found any evidence to support the claims of instantaneous cure of incurable diseases.'

A spokesman for Great Ormond Street said they did not want to comment on any aspect of the alleged miracle.

Reid now fronts a multi-million pound videos-to-insurance empire that includes one company, McCartney and Dowie Investment Management plc, which controls funds of pounds 41 million but paid only pounds 1,715 in tax in 1999. Reid's spokesman says the company is liable for tax only on its taxable profits.

Members of his church are invited to tithe 10 per cent of their gross income and to take out insurance policies through the bishop's companies.

Now the Bible school of which Reid is president is to be sued for assaulting children. Reid has been an enthusiastic supporter of corporal punishment or 'paddling' in the past. He has said: 'Children are little demons. They have foolishness in their hearts. You have a stick and they have a rear end. I believe in smacking them - a sharp smack on the rear end. But make sure it's a real shock.'

The court proceedings, due to be issued in the new year, will turn on allegations of assault on two children, then aged seven and nine, who claim they suffered beatings by Peniel members. Their mother told The Observer yesterday: 'I am bringing this case not just for my children, but also for the other youngsters still inside this disturbing religious sect.'

Reid, the church and the school deny any wrong-doing. The church says the bishop has never spanked a child personally, nor does he encourage churchgoers to use corporal punishment.

At first glance, services at the Peniel headquarters, in Pilgrim's Hatch, Brentwood, are impressive. Hundreds of well-dressed, polite church-goers make their devotions. The choir sways and sings in smiling harmony. But the main event is the sermon by Reid. At the service The Observer went to the bishop was sweetness and light. But extracts from other sermons recorded on tape tell a different story. Reid has denounced Buddhists and Hindus as 'foul heathens', declaring 'non-Christians are ignorant. They are on their way to hell'.

Reid was enthroned by the late Archbishop Benson Idahosa of Benin City, Nigeria. Reid tells a story which illustrates Idahosa's allegedly supernatural powers. A Benin witchdoctor is supposed to have made it rain on one of Idahosa's ceremonies. Idahosa promised that the troublemaker would die. According to Reid, recorded on tape, 'The archbishop said by nine o'clock he'll be dead: "I'll kill him". At a quarter past eight he dropped dead.'

The church describes these allegations as bizarre and denies that Reid made such comments.

Pickles took part in a photocall with Reid, Idahosa and a third controversial evangelist, Bishop Earl Pearly Paulk of Atlanta, Georgia, some years ago.

Idahosa once claimed he raised eight people from the dead. The Advertising Standards Authority asked to see death certificates to prove they had been dead before Idahosa stepped in. No death certificates were provided, and the claim was dropped.

He first surfaced in the public eye in 1986 when a US embassy official found two US tennis players, Bud Cox and Skip Strode, in a hotel room in Lagos. 'I could hear chanting through the open door,' the US official said. 'Both were stripped naked. Everywhere were tiny pieces of paper, pieces of US currency, pieces of traveller's cheques, pieces of a Bible. They were born-again Christians and Rev Idahosa was the catalyst,' said the official. The babbling, naked tennis players were given clothes and tickets back to the US.

Idahosa drove a pink Cadillac. Reid drives a blue Mercedes.

There are many people who have fallen foul of Reid who disagree with Pickles's view of the 'wonderfully normal' Peniel church and its bishop. One doubter is the Rev Norman Meeton, pastor of the Devonshire Road Christian Fellowship in Liverpool at the time Reid was excommunicated on 3 November, 1969. He told The Observer : 'He was excommunicated for raillery', for slandering people. It was horrendous and destructive. He lived with us for a time. He would swing from one mood to another, at one moment contrite, the next a roaring lion.'

A second doubter is the Rev Ian Wilson, best man at Reid's wedding in October 1971. Wilson, a Christian evangelist now living in Canada, told The Observer : 'He's the original spinmeister, a master salesman. He can be charming and then switch and be a frightening adversary who suppresses opposition with the most violent language. He caricatures people, vilifying them and impugning their character. I think Reid is a little Mussolini.'

Mother-of-three Caroline Green, who fled the church three years ago, is a third sceptic. She said: 'It is hard to think of a less "wonderfully normal" person. Michael Reid has a toweringly strong personality, which he uses to dominate church members. Families end up being torn apart. My children have lost their father because he is still in the church and under the thumb of the bishop. My ex-husband started calling me The Enemy. It was like talking to a robot. That was an appalling thing for my children to endure.'

Green continued: 'We paid a tenth of our gross income to the church, plus all kinds of extras. We took out 13 insurance policies with companies the bishop or his associates control, taking the commission. We paid out at least pounds 400 a month to the church, plus pounds 402-a-month fees for the Peniel school. The cost was crippling, but the real damage was psychological.'

She is making a claim to recover more than pounds 100,000 which she says was paid out under undue influence. Among others, she is writing to the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards about the alleged conflict of interest of Pickles.

A fourth doubter is Green's sister, Susan Hilton, who said: 'I felt helpless to do anything to rescue her as she was entrenched within the sect. He would unsettle the congregation with the idea that if they ever went against his word there would be trouble. It was like an emotionally abusive marriage.'

Three more critics of Reid are Max and Joan Carter and their son Tim. Life-long Christian Max Carter said: 'Michael Reid is a powerful manipulator. We left the church in 1988, as we were concerned about the way things were going. Reid had hinted there was a young man with homosexual tendencies in the congregation. Then word went round that it was our son, Tim, then 17. This was a horrible false rumour which Michael did nothing to combat. When we left, my family was vilified. I was identified as an evil man.'

Tim Carter said simply: 'Bishop Reid is a bully.'

When the Carters left the church they were shunned by their old friends. Max Carter's sister remains in the church and no longer speaks to him. Joan Carter said: 'It was awful to be shunned and ignored by Christian people you had known for so many years.'

Max Carter said: 'It seems as though down the years I somehow threatened Michael Reid. My son was called a homosexual. The accusations were totally false. He could have squashed these evil rumours, but nothing was done. Since we left the church, I have been called a pervert. Again, totally false, again totally unfair.'

An eighth critic of Reid is Helen Hagerty, who is incapacitated by ME. She travelled to the Peniel church four years ago, having answered a 'healing' ad in the ME newsletter. She said: 'Soon Reid was mocking and ridiculing a broad spectrum of Christian denominations and practices, and I became increasingly aware that I was watching and listening to the most un-Christlike man I have ever met.'

A ninth is another ex-member of the church, who declined to be named: 'When someone falls out with the bishop, families end up falling apart. My sister is not talking to my father because he was critical of Bishop Reid. He has a heart condition and is greatly upset.'

A tenth met the bishop recently: 'Time and again the bishop turned the conversation to homosexuals and paedophiles. He has an astonishing capacity for hate.'

Reid and the Peniel church insist they are just successful Christians who have attracted jealousy from a 'handful of individuals'. On the subject of Reid's companies, his spokesman said he has remained a director of companies with which he was con cerned prior to his consecration as a bishop. He merely continues in his role as a non-executive director to supervise the proper running of the companies concerned.

On his alleged excommunication, the church says there was a disagreement about doctrinal interpretation, but subsequently relationships were restored and Reid re-attended meetings. The church says Reid does not 'have the habit of denouncing people who oppose him'.

Caroline Green told The Observer : 'What has happened is a catastrophic failure by people to see Bishop Reid for what he really is. In this sort of case you want to get in touch with the local MP. But he supports the bishop and the church. So what do you do?'

The Brentwood and Ongar Conservatives have received thousands of pounds from the bishop, his associates and members of the sect. In 1998, 119 Peniel members joined one branch of the local Tory association over two days, boosting Tory funds by around £5,000.

Reid donated £500 to Pickles's 1997 election fighting fund, and £1,000 to the Tories when he attended a Quota Club dinner in 1997 at the Carlton Club with then Chancellor Kenneth Clarke. The bishop's spokesman said it is a matter of public record that McCartney and Dowie Investment Management donated £1,000 to the Conservative Party in 1999.

Reid and his companies have, then, donated at least £2,500 to Pickles and the Conservatives in the three years up to 1999. Pickles told The Observer : 'I have personally received no financial donations from Bishop Reid or his associates. The fighting fund is for the party locally and not for my exclusive use. This is the normal practice among associations.'

Tony Donnelly - president of the breakaway Independent Conservative Association, set up in the wake of the Peniel members joining the Pilgrim's Hatch branch of the party - said: 'Eric Pickles is helped by the support of the Peniel and the bishop. It's difficult to express what's going on. Ordinary people in Brentwood and Ongar are frightened of Peniel.'

Chairman of the Brentwood and Ongar Conservative Association, Michael Parrish, was critical of Bell and the independent Conservatives, saying they were guilty of 'religious bigotry and Nazism, something which won't show up well on his [Bell's] CV.'

Bell said yesterday: 'I am not, nor have I ever been, a member of the Nazi party.'

Donnelly said: 'A lot of people are writing off Bell as dead in the water, but the late Archbishop Idahosa isn't the only one who can bring back people from the dead.'

fields.headline: Feeling hot, hot, hot...
fields.standfirst: Desmond Balmer and  Joanne O'Connor  pick the cool places for travellers in the new year
fields.trailText: Desmond Balmer and Joanne O'Connor pick the cool places for travellers in the new year.
fields.body:
Safari 2001
Selous/Ruaha Parks Tanzania

Expect to hear more about the remote game parks of southern Tanzania - the Selous and Ruaha - where it is still possible to enjoy the wild feeling of the true African bush. The Rufiji river flows through the Selous, forming a network of lakes ideal for boat safaris. There are 350 species of bird to see. The Ruaha is named after the wide river that forms its border and much of the game can be found on the banks. You stay in small, attractive tented camps in both reserves.

 Book British Airways flights from Gatwick to Dar es Salaam from £473 with Trailfinders (020 7938 3939). Africa's biggest ground handler UTc (020 8905 6525) can put together a six-day package for £2,250, including three internal flights, full-board at two tented camps and all game-viewing.

Pacific 2001
The Cook Islands

Tourists have traditionally been drawn to Tahiti, the French Polynesian island associated with Gauguin. But those in the know head for the secluded Cook Islands. Last year's Fijian coup has put the Cooks firmly on the map and Air New Zealand has launched twice-weekly direct flights from Los Angeles. The islanders, cousins of the New Zealand Maoris, are the friendliest of the Polynesian people. The international airport is on the main island of Rarotonga. But make the 50-minute flight to Aitutaki, the small northern island with a perfect lagoon.

 All-Ways Pacific (01494 432747) offers 10 nights' B&B at the Pacific Resort on Rarotonga plus two nights at the Aitutaki Pearl Beach resort from £1,515 to £1,655. This includes Air New Zealand flights from Heathrow via Los Angeles and internal flights to Aitutaki. Best time to travel is from June to September, the South Pacific winter.

Cruising 2001
Freestyle

Think of a cruise and you imagine the formality of the captain's table and black-tie cocktail parties. Think again. Norwegian Cruise Lines has introduced 'freestyle cruising', in tune with today's more casual lifestyle. Dress is 'resort casual', which means no jeans, shorts or T-shirts after 6pm. You can eat in any of the restaurants between 5.30pm and midnight at cosy tables for two or dine with new friends. A weekly formal night is retained for traditionalists. Freestyle cruising is available on the Norwegian Sky, Majesty and Sea but will be rolled out across the seven-strong fleet during the year.

 A nine-night Caribbean cruise on the Norwegian Sky costs from £1,245 per person, including return flights from Heathrow to Miami, all meals and entertainment on board, plus overnight in a Miami hotel and transfers. Details on 0800 181560, or see www.uk.ncl.com.

Euro city 2001
Maastricht

The Dutch city has suffered an image problem ever since it gave its name to the treaty that shaped the European Union in the Nineties. But Maastricht is gaining recognition as the next northern European short-break destination. It takes much of its cultural and gastronomic style from its neighbours, Belgium and Germany. Many of the churches and buildings are more than 1,000 years old and were left undamaged by the war. A river runs through the city and on either bank are specialist shops selling designer clothes, books, music and art. There are 20 Michelin-recommended restaurants and some excellent bars and cafes - two beers are brewed locally.

 Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333) offers two nights at the seventeenth-century, four-star de Pauwenhof for £258, including flights from Stansted, private transfer on arrival and full Dutch breakfasts.

South America 2001
Bahia, Brazil

Northern Brazil will be opened up to mainstream British tourism in the summer, when Airtours launches a weekly charter from Manchester to the city of Salvador de Bahia and Air 2000 flies from Gatwick to Natal and Recife on alternative weeks. Bahia has the finest colonial architecture in Brazil but remains the most African city in the Western hemisphere: its lifeblood is candomblé , an Afro-Brazilian religion in which natural deities are worshipped alongside a supreme creator. The carnival is even livelier than Rio's. Most of the packages focus on beach holidays at Costa do Sauipe, but optional excursions are available.

 Airtours (0870 900 8639) offers seven nights' B&B in a two-star pousada from £599. Unijet (08705 336336) has flights from £399 and holidays from £669 for 14 nights' hotel B&B.

Baltic city 2001
Vilnius

If Prague is the new Paris then where is the new Prague? The compact Lithuanian capital has one of the largest old towns in eastern Europe, with enough cobbled squares, coffee houses, courtyards, churches and lively bars to satisfy most weekend visitors. But unlike Prague, locals still outnumber tourists and prices are kind to the wallet. Libya

The 14-night 'Lost cities and sand seas' tour includes visits to Tripoli, Leptis Magna, the Akakus mountains and a two-day desert Jeep safari. It costs £1,385, excluding flights.

Haiti

If your idea of the perfect Caribbean holiday is sipping rum punches by the swimming pool, the chances are you will not be booking a holiday in Haiti next year. The world's first black republic has stayed closer to its African roots than the rest of the Caribbean, apparent in its distinctive art, music and dance. Haiti's poverty can be shocking and the infrastructure frustrating, but those who go there tend to fall under its spell. It's still one of the few places in the Caribbean where you can escape cruise ships and all-inclusive hotels.

 Interchange (020 8681 3612) has a seven-night package staying at the ornate Hotel Oloffson in Port-au-Prince starting from £859, including Air France flights via Paris. A seven-night island coach tour starts from £1,545.

Shanghai

The speed of Shanghai's transformation is breathtaking. Glass tower blocks reach ever closer to the sky and every day the old Shanghai of missionaries, opium dens, silk traders, intellectuals, artists and gangsters, slips further into the past, though you will still catch glimpses in the narrow streets of the Chinese Old Town. More Chinese than Hong Kong, with more edge than Singapore, you won't find a better introduction to the new face of China.

You fly into Salt Lake City, Mormon country, and Park City is a 30-mile drive. There are 14 lifts serving 100 trails - 18 easy, 44 intermediate and 55 advanced. The longest is 3.5 miles. There are also six bowls offering excellent powder skiing.

 Ski Independence (0870 555 0555) has a week in the Landmark Inn, room only, two sharing, from £713, including flights . Adult six-day lift ticket covers Park City, Deer Valley, The Canyons, Snowbird and Solitude, £203.

The Rufiji river flows through the Selous, forming a network of lakes ideal for boat safaris. There are 350 species of bird to see. The Ruaha is named after the wide river that forms its border and much of the game can be found on the banks. You stay in small, attractive tented camps in both reserves.  Book British Airways flights from Gatwick to Dar es Salaam from £473 with Trailfinders (020 7938 3939). webTitle: Focus: Dispersal is failing as asylum-seekers opt out

fields.headline: Nowhere left to run
fields.standfirst:
Dispersal is failing as asylum-seekers opt out, numbers rise and racist attacks increase. Martin Bright and Kamal Ahmed report

Special report: refugees in Britain
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Dispersal is failing as asylum-seekers opt out, numbers rise and racist attacks increase. Martin Bright and Kamal Ahmed report.
fields.body:
Tomorrow is Cumali Sinangili's 42nd birthday. The Turkish refugee will spend it in a critical condition in a south London hospital. He left a friend's house in Bermondsey, south east London, at around 11 o'clock on Christmas Eve and was expected by another friend later in the evening. Before he could arrive, he was set upon in the street by three white men who had lurched out of a local pub looking for some action.

They threw him to the ground, kicked and punched him in the head and stabbed him in the face. The attack on Sinangili, who is applying for asylum in this country, was described by local police as 'gut-wrenching' in its ferocity. It is the third time Sinangili has been attacked in Britain in as many years.

Sinangili is just another asylum statistic, another racist attack in a country which for a year has seen politicians bat back and forth one of the most emotive and complex issues to face the nation - asylum seekers. Are they really fleeing persecution? And what of the criminal gangs and unscrupulous business people who prey on the vulnerable and scared who are looking for a better life abroad?

An investigation by The Observer reveals a system in chaos. The dispersal programme, that much-vaunted political fix to try and move thousands of asylum seekers from Kent and London to less visible locations around the country, is failing. The costs of dealing with asylum seekers is soaring. The numbers of asylum seekers entering Britain will hit record numbers when the final figures for 2000 are published in a fortnight's time.

The heavily criticised process which pays asylum seekers benefits in vouchers rather than cash will be condemned in a report from influential lobby groups including Oxfam and the Refugee Council. The controls put in place to try and stop the flow of people into the country are simply failing.

The attack on Sinangili took place during a week when asylum was suddenly back in the headlines. On Wednesday, nearly 30 of his compatriots were found stuffed into the back of a Ford Transit van en route to Dover from Calais. Earlier in the week a pregnant mother, Sheena Tuckfield, was caught, also in Calais, with two Pakistani asylum seekers in the boot of her Ford Orion.

Since ferry company P&O Stena started a crackdown on illegal immigrants on 6 December their security guards have discovered 485 people crammed into cars, vans and lorries making the Calais to Dover crossing. P&O Stena believe that they may have saved up to £1 million in fines that they would have had to pay if the asylum seekers had been discovered on the British side.

Ann Widdecombe attempted to wade into the choppy waters, saying on Wednesday that if the Tories win the next election they would lock up all asylum seekers in detention centres. It seemed to be in line with an announcement made by the shadow home secretary earlier in the year on the need for secure detention centres.

But as with all political pronouncements on asylum, the message leaned more to confusion than understanding. What Widdecombe failed to say was that the Tories had backed away from the detention-for-all policy when it was pointed out that building the 50 secure centres needed would cost £2 billion. Tory critics gleefully say that it is yet another Conservative U-turn.

But the Government cannot gloat. Its central dispersal system is causing the most headaches at the Home Office as officials see a policy melt before their eyes. The targets for the number of people to be moved out of the south-east of England are now constantly being revised downwards.

When the new system was introduced in April, it was designed to ease the burden of refugee seekers on London and the South-east by setting up a compulsory system to spread new arrivals in 'clusters' around the country. At the same time, all asylum seekers were given vouchers to pay for food and essentials to remove them from the benefit system. The National Asylum Support Service was given the job of dealing with new arrivals, who would receive no support unless they agreed to entering the scheme.

The original Home Office dispersal target of 65,000 asylum seekers has already been revised downwards twice as officials at NASS have discovered that many people prefer to go without help rather than leave their communities in London. The latest Home Office figures show that just over 9,000 people have entered the system and it is unlikely that the new target of 36,000 will be met by the end of the financial year.

And there is a further problem. Of the 9,000 people who have joined the dispersal programme the Home Office has little idea how many have already returned to London or disappeared from the system altogether. The private companies employed by the Home Office to manage the dispersal scheme have been accused of dumping refugees in slum conditions and several deals with regional local authorities have fallen through.

Amanda Sebastyen of the Asylum Education and Legal Fund said: 'We have one example of a brother being dispersed to Leeds and his sister to Nelson in Lancashire. What sort of cluster is that? The system is completely arbitrary.'

Richard Kemp, Liberal Democrat leader of Liverpool Council, has been a consistent critic of the dispersal scheme, which he claims has been a disaster from the beginning. So far Merseyside has taken over 2,000 asylum seekers, well short of its target of 6,000, but, according to Kemp, the local authority and social services are often not informed of their arrival. 'Sometimes it's absurd,' he said. 'They tell us that they have sent four Iranians and we find three Afghans. We said it wouldn't work and said people would gravitate back to London and that is just what has happened.'

January will be the month when asylum will make its way back up the greasy political pole. In a fortnight's time the Government will publish the final figures for the number of asylum seekers who have come to Britain in the last year. It will be a record number, significantly higher than the 71,160 that sought asylum in 1999.

The Government knows that the figures will cause a row.

'I don't like using the word bogus, but I believe that 90 per cent of people who come to Britain are not genuine asylum seekers but are economic migrants,' said Martin Slade, the general secretary of the Immigration Service Union which represents immigration officers around Britain. 'There has to be a quantum leap in the way we are dealing with this problem. Every clampdown that is announced leads to a brief fall in numbers before the upward pressure begins again. We have to tighten up.'

The Home Office feels it is caught in a cleft stick. For the Middle England readership of the Daily Mail it is almost impossible to be too harsh on asylum seekers. For the liberals in organisations such as the Refugee Council every intemperate reference to 'bogus' asylum seekers swamping the country leads to an upsurge in violence against those fleeing genuine persecution.

Jack Straw has to ride both horses. So he announced the hated voucher system and then, under pressure at the Labour Party conference last autumn, announced that there will be a review. Just as with Widdecombe, every pronouncement is fraught with difficulties.

The Home Secretary wants to keep the review as limited as possible, so as not to appear to be giving in to the liberal lobby. He is expected to announce that change in cash - banned at the moment - can be given for vouchers and that a wider number of shops can take the vouchers.

But those opposed to the scheme are already massing. In their joint submission to the review the Transport and General Workers Union, Oxfam and the Refugee Council say that the scheme is failing the country.

'This government has made it clear that it wants to build a more inclusive Britain, one that values freedom, justice, fairness and equality,' says Bill Morris, the leader of the T&G in the report's introduction. 'But if we want these rights for ourselves, then surely we should not be denying them to others who come to our shores.

Regrettably, the voucher scheme does exactly that.' A survey of local refugee help organisations in the report reveals a litany of stories of asylum seekers who have to go without essential items such as shoes, sanitary products and baby's nappies because the level of support through the voucher system is so low.

But Straw knows that there are few votes in giving asylum seekers more money. Although Downing Street was heartened by the result of the Romsey byelection - taken by the Liberal Democrats after a Tory campaign high with anti-asylum seeker rhetoric - it is still nervous about taking on the Daily Mail on such a fraught issue. Tony Blair has demanded a softening of asylum-seeker rhetoric. A softening, but not a U-turn.

The Government now wants to make much more of its fight against the slew of new companies which are entering the market and making wild claims about what they can offer asylum seekers for a price. One contract document obtained by The Observer reveals the way unscrupulous organisations prey on the vulnerable.

The 'preliminary contract' from the company, based in east London, says that for a fee equivalent to £2,600 for families or £2,000 for individuals the company 'will provide the client [asylum seeker] with the following:

a) Legal representation on [sic] the home office interviews.

b) Housing benefit and council tax benefit.

c) Free medical and dental treatment.

d) Living allowances, free primary and higher education.

e) Free translation services, where needed.'

The contract fails to mention that the final four of these are provided free by the state. The company also says that it will 'supply the client with the British national insurance number (eg ID) which will take one month'. The Government wants to crack down on such operators.

In his hospital bed, Sinangili battles against his horrific injuries as New Year's Day comes and goes. He is another statistic, a victim of a political football that no-one is quite sure how to kick.

Tough or soft, January will see the battle rejoined.
