webTitle: Damilola's family want to stay in UK

fields.headline: Damilola's family want to stay in UK
fields.standfirst:
Parents of murdered boy need British doctors to save his sick sister's life

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The parents of murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor want to settle in Britain to ensure their epileptic daughter receives the daily medication she needs to survive,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
The parents of murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor want to settle in Britain to ensure their epileptic daughter receives the daily medication she needs to survive, The Observer can reveal.

Richard and Gloria Taylor hoped British doctors would be able to cure Gbemisola, 23, enabling the family to return home, but had their hopes dashed before Christmas when doctors admitted her condition was incurable.

Their request for exceptional leave to stay comes after Damilola's father criticised British society in the days after his son's murder. 'Family values have been bastardised and allowed to go to the dogs,' he said. 'There's a lack of discipline in this society. Parents do not care about their work any more. They rely on the social security to take care of their children. Parents will have to be re-educated.

'There's no doubt Damilola would have been alive if he was in Nigeria,' he said. 'There are a lot of family values we still appreciate in Nigeria.'

Gbemisola and her brother Baba Tunde, 21, were born in Britain and hold British passports, giving them automatic right of entry and entitlement to NHS treatment. Tunde left his university course in Nigeria to accompany his family to Britain in place of his father, who remained behind to fund the trip.

Damilola's parents, however, are both Nigerian citizens. Damilola and his mother entered Britain on six-month visas in August, while his father was granted exceptional leave to stay in the aftermath of his son's death in November.

Nigerian citizens wanting to enter Britain must obtain a visa, which will be granted only if they have enough funds not to have to claim state benefits. Damilola's mother had already applied for an extension to her and her youngest son's visas in the weeks before his murder when Gbemisola's health began to deteriorate.

None of the 45 Nigerians who appealed to the Home Office last October was granted leave to stay, according to Home Office figures. Only 90 Africans were granted exceptional leave to remain, while more than 1,000 were turned away.

However, although it is unwilling to comment on specific cases, the Home Office has indicated that it would probably be sympathetic to the Taylor family's request. 'There are grand compassionate grounds in this case and those would be taken into consideration,' said a spokesman.

The family was moved to emergency accommodation in Mitcham, south London, after Damilola's death, although Dorcas Fayemi, the sister-in-law of Damilola's mother, was moved from the north Peckham flat in which she, Mrs Taylor and her three children had lived for four months, only last week.

'It was a relief to leave the place where there were so many memories,' she said yesterday.

'But I still think of Damilola every minute.'

Twelve youths and one woman have been arrested - and released on bail - in connection with the stabbing. Police sources said last week that senior officers know who was responsible for the killing, but lack sufficient information to make the arrests.

Richard Taylor, a civil servant in Lagos, and Gloria Taylor, an accountant, sold their two cars and saved for two years to raise £5,000 to send Gloria and the children to Britain for Gbemisola's treatment at King's College Hospital in Camberwell, south London.

The parents had lived in Uxbridge, west London, for 10 years with their two eldest children in the late Seventies and early Eighties before emigrating to Nigeria.

webTitle: Shops slash prices to end slump

fields.headline: Shops slash prices to end slump
fields.standfirst: Gloomy retailers blame cold weather for poor takings over Christmas
fields.trailText: Consumers can expect to snap up bargains galore in the January sales as retailers, snowed under by a glut of unsold stock after a disappointing Christmas, slash prices in a desperate move to get cash tills ringing.
fields.body:
Consumers can expect to snap up bargains galore in the January sales as retailers, snowed under by a glut of unsold stock after a disappointing Christmas, slash prices in a desperate move to get cash tills ringing.

A chill wind blowing through high streets was this weekend reinforced by a warning from Sir Eddie George, the Governor of the Bank of England, that the good times may be ending.

Flat sales figures have also hit the much-vaunted e-commerce sector, which has endured a 'gloomy' time according to insiders.

Early indications from major UK stores show that cash tills have only just improved their takings on last year.

Hardest hit is the clothing sector, dominated by beleaguered Marks & Spencer, BhS and Next, where competition is fiercest.

'I think Christmas was a bit disappointing. Yet again, retailers are left with lots of stock to shift in the sales. It's not helping that vast tracts of the country are cut off by freezing conditions,' said Clive Vaughan, director of leading consultancy Retail Intelligence.

City institutions are poised to downgrade as many as one in three retailers next year because of lacklustre Christmas trading. Last Friday, department store John Lewis, normally a retail star performer, reported that its takings were up just 1 per cent this month.

City analysts fear that if John Lewis has posted flat results, the outlook for others, most notably Marks & Spencer, is not promising.

But electrical retailers such as Dixons, whose sales in the Christmas run-up rose 5 per cent, are thought to have fared better as the British public stocked up on mobile phones and digital television subscriptions.

Up-market stores such as Harrods and the jeweller Asprey & Garrard will be affected by dwindling bonuses received by City professionals. For the first time in a decade, the main stock markets on both sides of the Atlantic finished the year lower than they started. As a result, equity traders' bonuses have been slashed.

'The gravy train express may well have reached the end of the line,' said a leading figure at a London finance house. 'It's only the chaps involved in mergers and acquisitions who have got anything to show this year. Conspicuous consumption was all the rage this time last year, but don't expect too many orders for sports cars this time around.'

This year's queues for sales, particularly in London, have been slow to form. Out of the South-east, however, the picture is brighter. In Manchester, the huge Trafford Centre mall has reported record crowds, with more than 100,000 shoppers eager to pick up bargains. Other regional malls are reporting brisk trading this weekend.

Christmas has been disastrous for Britain's internet vendors. 'There's been some scepticism that's crept into the whole e-commerce economy,' commented Budd Margolis, head of shopping for Btopenworld, the UK telecom giant's e-tail division.

'Besides the downturn in the technology sector, there is a general lack of enthusiasm in the consumer market. Many companies have been holding on by the skin of their teeth expecting a pick-up in Christmas trade. It hasn't happened.'

Mortgage lenders suggest the steam has gone out of the UK's housing market. Annual house price growth is only forecast to reach 7 per cent in 2001 compared with 9.3 percent this year and 13.3 per cent in 1999.

fields.headline: Blackboards
fields.standfirst: Inspired teachers bring hope to the downtrodden Kurds
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...the theme of tyrannical oppression and enforced ignorance is pursued in the oblique, coded style that a rigid society has forced on Iranian film makers and which has given their films such resonance
fields.body:
The 20-year-old Samira Makhmalbaf appeared at the age of eight in The Cyclist, directed by her father, Mohsen Makhmalbaf, one of Iran's leading directors. She then studied film before becoming his assistant. Whether she'd have become a more interesting cinéaste had she had a traditional academic education, we shall never know.

Blackboards, which won the Special Jury Prize at Cannes this year, strikes into different territory from The Apple, her semi-documentary debut about two little girls in Tehran escaping the bondage of their parents. But the theme of tyrannical oppression and enforced ignorance is pursued in the oblique, coded style that a rigid society has forced on Iranian film makers and which has given their films such resonance. The setting is the arid, awesomely beautiful north-west of the country, where Kurds are being persecuted on either side of the borders between Iran, Iraq and Turkey.

Offering hope and relief to the downtrodden of Kurdistan are itinerant schoolteachers, 10 of whom are first seen in the distance on a dusty mountain road, carrying blackboards on their backs and resembling the bird-like sculptures of Lynn Chadwick and Elisabeth Frink. They hide from a helicopter gunship, and then split to go in search of pupils. Like travelling holy men, they seek little in return for their simple, liberating lessons in reading, writing and arithmetic. The movie concentrates on two of them, Reeboir and Saïd.

Reeboir attaches himself to a party of teenage smugglers who risk their lives carrying heavy contraband goods across the border for exploitative, conspicuously absent employers. Saïd joins a large group of old men attempting to make a pilgrimage over the mountains to the native lands from which they presumably fled during the recent war. The only young person with the old men, and the only woman in the film, is Halalheh, the widowed daughter of one the most decrepit of the men, and she's accompanied by her little child. No one in either camp sees any value in education, having adjusted themselves to a life of permanent exploitation and persecution that leaves them at the mercy of cruel, anonymous border guards.

Nevertheless Reeboir and Saïd persist in a doggedly heroic manner, using their blackboards variously as protective camouflage, stretchers, clothes lines, screens for a wedding, doors for privacy, splints for broken limbs, shields against gunfire. So emblematic does his professional prop become that Saïd becomes known to the old men as Blackboard.

Blackboards is plainly an allegory or parable, but it has a force and documentary vividness that resists simple explanations and deters us from reading easy messages into it. But ultimately, and unsentimentally, it's an affirmative work. Only the young woman and one of the teachers has any previous acting experience, but Makhmalbaf (whose father co-scripted the film as well as editing it) manages to bind the two groups of young and elderly non-professional actors into distinct communities on the move.

fields.headline: Unbreakable
fields.standfirst: Bruce Willis develops a 'sick sense'
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...a film to see, to enjoy, and perhaps to ponder
fields.body:
The 29-year-old M. Night Shayamalan was brought up in Philadelphia, the son of sub-continental Indian parents, both of them doctors. He started to make short movies at the age of 10 and decided at 17 that he wanted to become a professional filmmaker, attending film school in New York rather than studying medicine.

Shayamalan's third film The Sixth Sense (its two low-budget predecessors made little impact and weren't released here) garnered six Oscar nominations and became the tenth most profitable film of all time.

Like The Sixth Sense, Shayamalan's new film, Unbreakable, is an occult thriller, and it too is set in Philadelphia, and stars Bruce Willis as a traumatised victim of violence. In this case Willis plays David Dunn, a former college football star with a tottering marriage and an unrewarding job as security officer at a university sports stadium. He emerges unscathed as the sole survivor of a railway accident in which 131 people die.

As David comes to terms with his miraculous delivery he's contacted by Elijah Price (Samuel L. Jackson), the well-off African-American owner of a gallery dealing in original art works by comic book illustrators. Since birth, Elijah has suffered from a severe form of osteoporosis that results in constant fracturing of his bones, and he's in search of someone at the other end of the spectrum - someone like David who appears indestructible. Such a person, he believes, must have superhuman powers that could make him a hero comparable to those of ancient times, a type kept alive in purest form, so he argues, by comic books.

The Old Testament names (Elijah the prophet who sought to purify society and predated the coming of the Messiah; David the heroic leader and man of destiny) hint at the underlying allegory. With some subtlety the director traces the increasing if uneasy involvement of the two men and how one makes the other aware of his predetermined role.

As in The Sixth Sense the dark, lowering city provides a portentous setting for the story. Sometimes we're made to see events from the characters' point of view, as when we watch TV upside down through the eyes of David's hero-worshipping son looking at a newsreel of the train crash, or we observe a would-be assassin on a railway platform from the twisted perspective of Elijah after he's fallen down a flight of stairs and fractured several bones. More often, however, there are long takes in deep focus in which we overhear conversations at some distance, with bars, staircases, rows of restaurant tables, the seats of a railway carriage or open doors between the camera and the people we're listening to.

A visual tour-de-force occurs when David becomes aware of his unusual powers at night on the railway station concourse. His mind takes in confusing information about the depredations of those he bumps into, and he has to decide whose victims are most worthy of his heroic attentions. Shyamalan, however, doesn't know how to resolve his picture. It ends abruptly, surprisingly and shockingly, and one leaves vaguely dissatisfied. But it's a film to see, to enjoy, and perhaps to ponder.

webTitle: Uranium shells linked to Kosovo veterans' deaths

fields.headline: Uranium shells linked to Kosovo veterans' deaths
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Nato chiefs were last night facing Europe-wide calls for an investigation into the safety of depleted uranium ammunition used by US pilots in the Kosovo war, following Italian claims linking the cancer deaths of five of their peacekeepers.
fields.body:
Nato chiefs were last night facing Europe-wide calls for an investigation into the safety of depleted uranium ammunition used by US pilots in the Kosovo war, following Italian claims linking the cancer deaths of five of their peacekeepers.

The allegations have put Britain's Ministry of Defence under new pressure to re-examine links between the use of depleted uranium ammunition and health problems suffered by servicemen who fought in both the Gulf War and in the Balkans.

The revelation yesterday that Italy's military prosecutor is examining five fatalities among 20 cases which the Italian media is linking to a so-called 'Balkans syndrome' - similar to Gulf War Syndrome - follows concern in both Belgium and Portugal last week.

Depleted uranium has been a source of controversy for over a decade amid claims that its contamination of battlefields in Iraq has caused widespread cancer among Iraqi civilians and contributed to health problems among allied military veterans of the Gulf War.

Belgian Defence Minister André Flahaut called on Friday for EU Defence Ministers to examine the issue. This followed reports that Portugal's Ministry of Defence had ordered medical tests for its soldiers serving in Kosovo to check for radiation.

US attack jets are thought to have fired more than 31,000 rounds of depleted uranium ammunition - used to pierce armour - at Serbian tanks and armoured cars.

Last night a spokesman for the MoD in London said: 'It is toxic in much the same way that lead is toxic, and it has a very low level or radiation. In its solid form it poses no great risk.

'There is more cause for concern when it is fragmented and can be inhaled. For that to happen it would have to hit a fairly hard target, like a tank. Then, if a soldier were to enter an overturned tank immediately afterwards they might be at some risk. But it quickly disperses. A year on we believe it would pose no risk at all.'

fields.headline: Russians send tycoon into space - for $20 million
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Dennis Tito, a 60-year-old multi-millionaire who wants to be the world's first space tourist, has announced he is to hitch a ride to the new International Space Station.
fields.body:
Dennis Tito, a 60-year-old multi-millionaire who wants to be the world's first space tourist, has announced he is to hitch a ride to the new International Space Station.

His trip, scheduled for May, will dismay many Nasa officials who had hoped to keep the £25 billion manned station - now being constructed in orbit - as a restricted, pristine scientific laboratory, not a playground for the rich.

But Tito, a former Nasa engineer turned investor, said last week that he had confirmed with Russian space engineers that he will fly on a Soyuz rocket to the station after 30 April.

He told journalists his trip 'has been okayed by the Russian Space Agency', and confirmed he had made the final payment of his fee, believed to be around $20 million, to MirCorp and RSC Energia, Russia's main space corporations. He intends to return to Russia in January for space training.

Tito had originally expected to fly on board Russia's creaking 14-year-old Mir space station, but Russian space controllers have decided it is no longer possible to keep the orbiting laboratory in orbit. They lost radio contact with it for nearly 20 hours early last week. Mir is expected to be allowed to crash into the Pacific in February.

Following news of Mir's imminent demise, its controllers, MirCorp, have held talks with investors - including RSC Energia, the privatised Russian space agency - and foreign partners in the International Space Station programme, in an attempt to let Tito fly on their new, still-to-be-completed orbiting laboratory.

The plan calls for Tito to ride in an unreserved seat of an already scheduled Soyuz mission. This flight will replace the Soyuz spacecraft already docked at the ISS. Russian flight rules say Soyuz spaceships must be replaced every six months.

Tito would therefore fly to the ISS on the new Soyuz, and would help its crewmen transfer equipment and supplies and carry out research. After spending six days on board the orbiting outpost, Tito and two cosmonaut colleagues would then board the original Soyuz before being blasted out of orbit for the return journey to Earth.

fields.headline: Get cracking
fields.standfirst:
Seaweed, sea salt, exquisite blue eggs... here's a
taste of next year's hot ingredients
fields.trailText: Seaweed, sea salt, exquisite blue eggs... here's a taste of next year's hot ingredients.
fields.body:
Could 2001 be the year I finally get it right? Will this be the one when I succeed in grasping only what is worthwhile about food and cooking, and discard, with the thwack of a meat cleaver hitting a chopping board, that which is not?

I long to be the perfect cook; to shop knowledgeably and to prepare my food with total understanding; to respect the materials I work with and to comprehend fully the techniques I use; to make my own stock, my own chips, my own bread, every time.

Will this be the year I buy only that which has been produced organically and with deference for the environment? Is 2001 set to be the date I finally bottle my own fruit and grind my beans for every cup? Perhaps, just perhaps, I could now bear to sieve my sauces twice, and through muslin.

Is this to be the year I learn to choose faultlessly in restaurants, always put away the dishes before I go to bed and never let the greengrocer get away with sneaking a duff one into the bag? Will I be able to get through the entire year without forgetting something in the oven, cribbing an idea or opening a wine bottle in lieu of a meal? Is this, the second year of the new millennium, the one in which I will never, again let anything go slushy in the salad drawer of the fridge?

But I am not a perfect cook. Yes, I can enthuse wholeheartedly about the buzz ingredients for 2001 - which, for the record, will be seaweed, verjuice, maple syrup, sea salt (it is turning up in both butter and chocolate), rare breeds of poultry and their exquisite blue-grey eggs, sushi, dim sum and teas from way off the beaten track. But should I be a good boy and agree with those who say that restaurant cooking has never been better? Well, no. It is now almost impossible to find simple food, cooked with care and restraint. All I see now are menus that are a hotchpotch of ingredients, cultures and styles. A bit of French, a bit of Thai, a bit of Italian. (Will somebody please, please put that mess known as Pacific Rim cooking out of its misery?) It seems to me that anything goes nowadays just as long as the chef can pile it high in a deep, wide-rimmed dish and crown it with a froth of hamster straw, aka deep-fried leeks. Hype and artifice are what much restaurant cooking is now all about.

In the year that follows, I promise to never resort to frozen chips, to bunk off from the compulsory five-a-day fruit and veg rule and to bang on mercilessly about how good food used to be 20 years ago. I will always eat a square meal, never get drunk and never go food shopping when I am hungry.

But I am not sure I can. I know very well that for all the life-enhancing, vitamin-packed liquid that spurts daily from my juicer, nothing quite beats the sweet shock of an ice-cold Coca Cola when I want one. That the best curry is the one you scoff from its tin-foil takeaway container while watching the football on the telly. And you know that, hiding underneath those organic, artisan-crafted ingredients in my shopping bag, there lurks a Terry's chocolate orange.

This cook hasn't a clue whether the strainer he uses is actually a sieve or a chinois. I only know that it gets the lumps out of my sauce. Neither do I know whether it is correct to use a sauté pan to fry my bacon, or if it is acceptable to boil rather than steam rice for a Chinese meal. Neither, frankly, do I care. The only thing I know is when something feels right, when it rings my bell, and when it works for me. Cooking and eating are intensely personal things. Misplaced pedantry and culinary bigotry have no place in my kitchen.

My favourite cooking has always been sound, everyday sort of stuff, understated, do-able and as comfortable and 'feelgood as a favourite old sweater. I dislike fussy, fiddly cooking. That doesn't mean that little things don't matter. It is an attention to detail that often makes the difference between something being good and being utterly sublime. What really matters is that we concentrate on those few details that do matter and relax totally about that which makes little difference.

It is, I think, necessary to be specific and meticulous about the details of a classic recipe, for instance. While I believe a recipe can often be a straitjacket for the cook, I do think it matters that recipes for traditional dishes are not watered down by slapdash methods and short cuts. To do so is to lose the history, the authenticity and therefore the point of the dish. How many times have I eaten crème brlée or bread and butter pudding whose soul has been lost because of the sloth or maniacal meddling of a creative cook? It is good to let a recipe relax and breathe, but don't, please, present it to me as a classic when it plainly is not.

The buzz words this year are provenance, integrity and authenticity. Who, may I ask, is now going to eat a piece of beef whose origin and source they do not know? (This could be a bad year for those polystyrene trays of bargain mince.) I for one will be demanding the how, why and wherefore of everything I put in my mouth. Well, almost.

Could this be the year I become the cook I aspire to be; the year in which I get overexcited about food rather than gently enthusiastic; when I produce creative and jaw-droppingly original recipes; the one in which I agonise fashionably over which way to fold my new Donna Karan caramel-coloured napkins? Or could this be the year I replace David Beckham at Manchester United?

Noodles with oyster sauce

You will, I assume, have worked out what you are going to eat for this New Year's Eve. I offer this simple but tantalising noodle dish for New Year's Day, which, if nothing else, will clear your head in the morning. If you cannot face chillies on New Year's Day (and well you might not), then leave them out. The result will simply soothe rather than invigorate. Enough for 2.

250g thin noodles

2 tbsp vegetable oil

1 large clove of garlic, peeled and crushed

a piece of ginger about the size of your thumb, peeled and cut into fine matchsticks

2 small, hot chillies, seeded and finely shredded

2 large handfuls (about 300g) of greens, such as spinach, pak choi or spring greens, shredded

1 tsp nam pla

2 tbsp oyster sauce

1 tbsp dark soy sauce

Prepare all the ingredients, seeding and chopping and shredding before you start. Once the oil is hot, you will need to work quickly if this is to be truly good.

Put on a big pot of water for the noodles and bring it to the boil. Add salt and drop in the noodles, cooking them for the length of time it says on the packet - each type will differ slightly - tasting them from time to time to check for tenderness.

Meanwhile, get a wok hot over your highest flame. When it starts to smoke, pour in the oil and shake the pan around so that the oil gets hot quickly. Now add the chopped garlic and the shredded ginger - it will brown in seconds - then add the chilli and the greens. Keep the food moving around the pan and the heat up high (I use chopsticks to move it round).

Add the drained noodles then add the liquid seasonings. Toss and stir, and when the greens are wilted and bright in colour and all is sizzling hot, serve.

Zaafraani chawal

I am not suggesting that anyone should overdo things tonight, but I must admit I include the calming and gently restorative recipe that follows from Madhur Jaffrey's new Step-by-Step Cookery (£19.99, Ebury) because it is soothing and gentle and just might be what you want to eat tomorrow. It is really a side dish, but I have eaten it by the large white bowlful when I need it. Although this recipe calls for basmati, any long-grain, fine-quality rice can be used instead. Serves 6 as side dish.

1 tsp saffron threads

2 tbsp warm milk

350g basmati or long-grain rice

salt

2 tbsp vegetable oil

5 cardamom pods

2 x 7.5cm cinnamon sticks

Dry roast the saffron in a cast-iron frying pan, cool slightly, then crumble into the warm milk and leave to soak for about 30 minutes.

Put the rice in a bowl and wash well in several changes of cold water. Fill the bowl with 1.1 litres of fresh water, add tsp salt and leave to soak for 30 minutes. Drain.

Heat the oil in a heavy-based pan or cooking pot over a medium heat. Put in the cardamom and cinnamon sticks and stir over the heat a few times. Add the rice and fry, stirring, for one minute.

Add 550ml water and tsp salt. Bring to the boil, cover with a tight-fitting lid, reduce the heat to very low and cook for 20 minutes.

Gently but quickly fork through the rice to separate the grains. Drizzle the saffron-infused milk over the rice to form streaks of colour. Re-cover and cook for a further 10 minutes or until the rice is done. Serve at once.

fields.headline: Back to the future
fields.standfirst: Nobu Matsuhisa has turned Japanese cooking (and his own name) on its head to give us Ubon
fields.trailText: Nobu Matsuhisa has turned Japanese cooking (and his own name) on its head to give us Ubon.
fields.body:
There is something so very this century about the location of Ubon, the second Japanese fusion restaurant in London from Nobu Matsuhisa. It sits above a swanky health club at Canary Wharf in the Docklands, as if there were something simpatico about the assaults on fitness being performed in the ground-floor gym and the light, delicate, often raw food served in the restaurant four floors above. The decor - simple lines, acres of stripped wood, lots of plate glass affording views of the Thames - adds to that aura of purity. It's all rubbish, though. There's more than enough booze on the wine list, oil in the deep-fat fryer and sugar in the puddings to allow the committed hedonist to treat their body less like a temple and more like a bordello.

But here at the epitome of the modern restaurant, a place which has its eye set firmly on the globalised future rather than the past, image is all, as it should be in a location as fake and invented as the great film set which is Canary Wharf. Attention to image and detail should not, however, be mistaken for authenticity. As you enter Ubon the entire floor calls out with a traditional Japanese welcome; in Tokyo you only hear it when entering a department store, not a restaurant. It added to the theatre because, as each person entered and the cry went up, you could not help but turn and look to see who this important soul could be. And in would walk another anonymous Paul Smith suit, another Gucci tie, another two-piece by Nicole Farhi.

But that, as I say, is all about image, the common currency of the modern restaurant trade. What really counts here is that the food which underpins the image is, for the most part, terrific. I went with my brother Adam who, as well as killing pheasants with his bare hands, is also a Nipponophile. He rated the sashimi - raw fish, unburdened by vinegared rice - as good as the best he had ever tried in Tokyo. What the food can not be called is easy on the wallet. We ran up a bill of £95 and all we drank was mineral water. Take in that figure. Digest it. That's what this kind of stuff costs and, more to the point, that's what this kind of restaurant can get away with charging. Trade was brisk the lunchtime we went.

Let's get the one duff dish out of the way first. Ubon - being a branch of the Nobu empire - specialises in reinventing Japanese food. From the special appetisers we chose a tartare of yellowtail tuna with caviar at £14. It came as a small (read tiny) tian in a pool of miso sauce which overwhelmed the silver-grey grains of caviar and left us wishing that the tuna had remained a lump of sashimi. We were reassured by a plateful of unmucked-with sashimi (as against their slightly seared 'New Style' version); it was beautiful stuff, particularly the beige jewels of fragrant, almost gamey sea-urchin roe.

For our main course we ordered rock-shrimp tempura dressed with a sharp lemony cream sauce. The batter was extraordinarily light and the dressing - which would never turn up on a traditional Japanese menu - was a beautiful accompaniment that cut through the richness of the fish. From that climax, the meal went only upwards to the black cod with miso, a signature dish of Nobu Matsuhisa which is truly a thing of beauty: a cut of fish from the tail marinated in miso for three days then seared to give the outside a sweet stickiness while maintaining the rich softness of the flaky flesh. It was chopsticks at dawn as every ounce of sibling rivalry, nurtured at our mother's knee, came roaring out in the fight for the last flake. If any dish can be said to be worth £22.50, this one was and is.

We finished with some delicate white-chocolate spring rolls and, as an ideal palate cleanser, a plate of exotic fruit specimens neither of us had ever seen before - combinations of lychee, passion fruit and mango. Was it worth £95? Who knows, but we had a bloody nice time.

As we're on the question of money, a quick warning with which to start the new year. A few weeks ago four of us went to a restaurant in west London called Veronica's. The meal was so desperately mediocre I could not even summon the will to review it. We split the bill and handed over two cards. The restaurant charged both halves to my card, which fact I only discovered when I checked my statement a month later. Veronica's, apparently content that it has received payment, has proved remarkably unwilling to check its records to see exactly what happened that night, despite the fact that they took an unauthorised second payment. The lesson here, I suppose, is always check your bank or credit-card statements. I know I will.

 Ubon by Nobu, 34 Westferry Circus, Canary Wharf, London E14 (020 7719 7800). Lunch for two, including wine and service, around £125. Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk.

webTitle: Monty Don: Heat of the moment

fields.headline: Heat of the moment
fields.standfirst: Less mechanisation, less pruning and less spadework... slowing global warming isn't all hard work
fields.trailText: Less mechanisation, less pruning and less spadework... slowing global warming isn't all hard work.
fields.body:
There is always a slightly forced, doing-your-homework feeling when approaching a new year. It has never felt anything more or less than just tomorrow to me, certainly no more significant than September merging silently into October, and for gardeners or anyone that works the land, much less of a measured starting or ending point of the calendar than October or March. But it is as good a time as any to take stock.

My own gardening life at the moment is dominated by water. Water across the fields as far as the eye can see, water in the garden, water stopping the septic tank working for a week now, water grinding the traffic to a halt, water flooding the railway tunnels and water falling incessantly from the sky. All the evidence is that it will continue this way. What we gardeners desperately need is a long cold spell followed by a reasonably dry summer followed by a cold dry winter. I imagine that, for purely selfish reasons, there are few non-gardeners who would reject that climatic recipe. But the odds are that we are not going to get it.

And we all know that it is not going to happen. There is no scaremongering to be done, global warming has happened and cannot be reversed. The mongering needed now is in methods of adapting and dealing with it rather than anything else. Politicians are showing themselves to be embarrassingly bad at doing this. It is too big, has too many big ideas and crosses too many boundaries - national, cultural and scientific - for them to cope with. They are the wrong people for the job. I tend to go along with the notion that politicians of all hues are a waste of space, but in this instant it is not their fault that they are not up to the task in hand. Global warming cannot be dealt with by edict or posturing and it certainly cannot be 'dealt' with by a Canute-like edict. It is the weather for Christ's sake! All of us as individuals have to accept it and react intelligently to it.

So, in the year ahead, what will global warming mean for us? Over the next few weeks, I will be looking at some specific groupings of plants for wet and milder weather, but while we are in stock-taking mode, let's stick with the bigger picture for the moment. Gardeners are certainly right there in the front line when it comes to providing solutions to these climatic effects. I saw in the paper a week or two ago that new buildings in Tokyo will now have to include roof gardens as a means of lowering temperatures. Certainly cities such as London, which is comparatively rich in parks and gardens, will become increasingly attractive places to live.

There is a growing realisation that farming methods can directly affect climatic changes. The idea of using biological 'sinks' to soak up greenhouse gases is not a new one - and the Americans have recently used it in a shockingly irresponsible way to avoid cutting their own greenhouse gases - but it has thrown up two really relevant issues for gardeners. The first is unarguable, namely that garden vegetation, especially trees and shrubs, are a vital part of the control of global warming. Anyone with a garden should be planting trees and shrubs in 2001. Resist the temptation to remove any perennial leafy plant without replacing it with two others. As any regular reader of this column will know, I am in love with hedges and now I can bask in the sure and certain knowledge that they are not only aesthetically glorious but morally right. Almost every garden can be improved with more hedges. Hedge yourself in. Surround, bisect and quarter your plot with deciduous hedges and make the weather better for me and everyone else.

All of us who garden know that gardens are important. We know that, for us, for our sanity, they are vital. We know that, thanks to the imbecility of the British approach to agriculture since the Second World War, gardens are among the most important wildlife habitats in the western world and now we know that they are an essential ingredient in the physical world that we know. Nothing affects us so much as weather and it is beginning to look as if the weather is interactive. We must learn to influence it as much as it inevitably influences us. The good news is that gardeners can make changes.

The second point is more contentious. Research at Ohio State University has shown that soil can soak up a lot of carbon. Soil contains three times as much carbon as all the earth's forests. As a 'soak' it is enormously effective. But over the past 100 years, it is estimated that around 100bn tons of carbon has been lost from the soil into the atmosphere through farming. Most of this has come through ploughing. The enormous extra power that has come through machinery in the past 50 years has meant that much more land is ploughed. Ploughing introduces oxygen into the soil and helps rot organic matter. For ploughing, read digging. In gardening terms, so far so very good. But, as organic matter decomposes, it releases carbon dioxide into the air.

The argument is that the process can be reversed. If farmers cut back on their ploughing, added plenty of organic manure and planted more trees, the soil could soak up much more carbon than is currently being lost. This information has made me think hard. It contradicts my empirical view of agriculture that ploughing is a good thing as opposed to direct drilling and more relevantly, contradicts my oft-vaunted view that digging is superior to no-dig gardening.

I think I may be wrong. If the Ohio thesis is correct then gardens are potentially a significant contributor to carbon loss. Every time you stick your spade in the ground and turn it over you are adding a fraction to the flood in my garden. Every time that I, all spade and vigour, dig my already well-dug garden, I inch the waters nearer your back door. No-dig gardening still requires the soil to be initially deeply prepared, but untouched thereafter. The wetter winters and dryer summers will need masses of organic material added to the soil to provide drainage and water retention when it matters - and nothing does that better than lots of organic material added to the soil annually. The solution is not to dig it in but to mulch all bare soil every year with a thick layer of home-made compost.

The no-diggers will cry victory, but not disturbing the soil is only one part of the complicated equation. Bonfires should be seen as a last resort and the ash put back into the ground. Compost everything. All of us should use as little mechanical energy as possible. This is not a matter of self-consciously attaining sufficient brownie points to reach an organic, recycling, eco-heaven but simply a question of harnessing our resources and dealing with those things at home that we are best dealing with rather than leaving it to politicians to make more of a mess of.

None of this will make the weather better. At best it will stop it getting worse. If we all really make a difference it is likely to slow the rate of decline. So for the rest of our lives we have to adapt and get used to it. There will be some real advantages. The milder winters will mean that we will increasingly be able to grow plants out of doors that have formerly been considered too tender. Wet and boggy gardening is interesting and has a huge range of plants. The hotter summers will mean that fruit and vegetables that need heat to ripen, such as peppers, tomatoes and all top fruit, will become easier to grow outside and set fruit more freely in milder spring weather.

The point is that everything changes. There is no going back. It is time to stop whingeing about global warming and to make it better while making the most of the opportunities that arise from the change.

But it is as good a time as any to take stock. My own gardening life at the moment is dominated by water. Water across the fields as far as the eye can see, water in the garden, water stopping the septic tank working for a week now, water grinding the traffic to a halt, water flooding the railway tunnels and water falling incessantly from the sky. All the evidence is that it will continue this way. What we gardeners desperately need is a long cold spell followed by a reasonably dry summer followed by a cold dry winter. webTitle: Pincer movement on the paper tigers

fields.headline: Pincer movement on the paper tigers
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A happy new ( newspaper) year? Probably not - but a profoundly interesting one as belts grow a little tighter and the going, at last, turns a little rougher. Next year will be a time of trial. The pincers are moving in.
fields.body:
A happy new ( newspaper) year? Probably not - but a profoundly interesting one as belts grow a little tighter and the going, at last, turns a little rougher. Next year will be a time of trial. The pincers are moving in.

Pincer one is a slowing economy; or maybe, if America is any guide, something nastier. That means fewer jobs and fewer display ads, especially in computing and internet start-ups. Thus far, ironically, the net has provided succour for the clunky old media because it has needed to get its initial messages across in the traditional way, on paper. Retreat and retrenchment in cyberspace may mean a longer-term silver lining for Fleet Street, but there'll be short-term holes in the revenue books.

Pincer two is an even more venerable blast from an inflationary past. The newsprint manufacturers have finally got their act together. Paper mills are closing, theoretically for ever, so supply and demand will fit more closely - no more surplus production swilling around. Prices can go up again, perhaps by 15 or 20 per cent. A short-term canyon on the costs side.

Now nothing, of course, is certain. Western economies, after nearly a decade of growth, may make a soft landing which does no more than blow a coating of froth away. And, even if they don't, a steep recession in the US would rapidly cause less newsprint usage and thus more flexible pricing. (The paper mills have an uncanny reputation for getting their timing wrong). But suppose what we slowly begin to see happening is what, by the middle of 2001, we get. Suppose the pincers close.

Then a grim, ancestral logic takes over. Newspapers have two key sources of revenue. One is advertising, the other is the pence you push over a newsagent's counter. That's a constant balancing act. You can keep your cover price down if the ad take goes up - or vice-versa. But you can't just sit there and do nothing if rising costs and falling ads are hacking into profit margins. Something has to give, and - staff layoffs and hiring freezes of the kind lately imposed by Rupert Murdoch apart - it can only be cover prices.

Nobody has talked much about upwardly mobile cover prices since seven years ago - when the Times started a broadsheet price war which, at one stage, delivered your morning Thunderer for 10p. The cost of Saturday papers has edged up since (with added supplements to sweeten the pill) and there's been cautious movement in the red-top tabloid and middle markets.

But, at root, the price war isn't over. The Guardian, Independent and Telegraph are stuck, through the week, in the same headline price rut (with the Telegraph, in particular, bobbing and weaving through 400,000 bulk, discounted or subscription copies): the Times, at 35p, is still below its 1993 level.

An unhealthy equation. The most prudent broadsheet revenue balance is some where in the 60 per cent ads and 40 per cent sales revenue area, a rough balance with scope for fine tuning; but such equilibrium went missing through the buoyant Nineties. Reckon something more like 70 per cent to 30 per cent today - with 80:20 not too far over the horizon. You don't need a doctorate in statistics to see the problem.

Because the sales revenue slice is so much smaller, proportionately, it must rise far higher and more sharply to compensate for any fall in ad revenue. A fall of £10 million-£20m in the ad take may represent only a minor drop, but compensating action at the cover price end would need to be brutal.

What would it mean? Circulation drops which may not wear off if everyone was tugging the same price lever. Those fine citizens who buy two or three morning papers would content themselves with one or two. A shrinking market.

The difficult fact, however, is that the market has been shrinking without any of these pressures. Go back to November 1992, before the wars began, and compare those figures with figures of November 2000. Only three nationals - the Mail, the FT and the Times - are doing better: some of the falls, for the Express, Independent and Mirror especially, are woundingly steep. The broadsheets doing direct battle with the Times have at best held their ground, but the Times itself has suffered since going up to 35p.

Scant reassurance here. A return to necessarily harsh cover price rises would be hell for the circulation managers and thus, later on, for the ad managers: but what other recourse is there?

Stark dilemmas have a natural tendency to grow fuzzier in practice, of course. There will be some lowering of profits, of the kind just announced at Associated Newspapers. There will be parings back and decreased paginations. Not the end of the world: Fleet Street, when it digs into its memory bank, is used to surviving lean years.

But the strain is always greatest for the papers at the bottom of their particular market league. It is they who get knocked off ad schedules first, they who have fewer readers they can afford to lose. That could be very bad news for Richard Desmond and his Express stable, all flat bottom of their respective leagues and, in the ides of December, taking fresh hits from a rampant Mail. It will also bring nil comfort to the two Independents (though Tony O'Reilly is made of sterner newspaper stuff than Desmond).

The fascinating thing, though, is also the most obvious. What about ventures such as the Mail's Metro string of freesheets launched in cities across Britain? On the one hand, making rapid progress; on the other hand, lacking any cover price to raise. It's no fun when your 'free' sheet suddenly costs 20 per cent more and the ad stream has dwindled to a trickle. Watch this and adjacent spaces, and pray for an infinitely cushioned landing.

fields.headline: Blair claims a Tory crown
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair sought to move the political debate onto fresh ground last night when he claimed that Labour has now taken over from the Tories as the party of economic competence.
fields.body:
Tony Blair sought to move the political debate onto fresh ground last night when he claimed that Labour has now taken over from the Tories as the party of economic competence.

In his new year message, the Prime Minister said that after the tight public spending decisions of the first two years of his administration the public was beginning to see positive changes in the country. He admitted that the railway crisis was causing frustration, he said that investment in public services was at record levels. With an election believed to be only a matter of months away, Blair said there was 'more to come'.

'I know there are people who held back from supporting us in 1997 because they were unconvinced that a Labour government could manage the economy properly,' he said. 'But we have shown ourselves sound economic managers and it can be felt on cheaper mortgages, more jobs, improving schools and hospitals - the very things families depend on.

'I would go further: I believe the mantle of economic competence now falls to New Labour.'

Labour strategists, stung by Democrat Al Gore's defeat in the American presidential elections, say Blair now intends to hit the issue of the economy much harder.

They believe that Gore's failure to make statements on the long-term strength of the economy were part of the reason he was defeated.

'There are still big challenges requiring radical policy choices ahead,' Blair said, signalling that he wants the next Labour manifesto to be an adventurous document rather than the safety first affair some are advocating.

He said that he would now be focussing on retaining 'hard-won economic stability', improving productivity and promoting further improvements in education.

The Tories attacked Blair's message, accusing him of promising 'jam tomorrow'.

fields.headline: Labour urged to name '£2m donor'
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Labour Party was under growing pressure to name its richest donors last night after it was reported to have received a £2 million gift from a rich businessman.
fields.body:
The Labour Party was under growing pressure to name its richest donors last night after it was reported to have received a £2 million gift from a rich businessman.

Martin Bell, a member of the House of Commons Standards and Privileges Committee, which adjudicates on allegations of parliamentary sleaze, said the party should come clean if such a large donation had been made.

'My reaction is that they should name him,' the independent MP said. 'Allegations about large donations to parties have caused enough trouble in the past for us to know that the public has to have confidence in the system. That only comes from true transparency.'

The donation, if confirmed, would be largest Labour has received since Lord Sainsbury disclosed that he had given the party £2m in 1999.

The party was also mired in controversy when it admitted taking a £1m gift from the Formula One tycoon, Bernie Ecclestone, when the Government was considering new rules on tobacco advertising which would adversely affect motor sport.

John MacGregor, the Conservative MP and a member of the Committee on Standards in Public Life which has drawn up new rules on party funding, said Labour should name the donor before the next election.

'It is in the spirit of the new legislation [on party funding] that donors should be named every quarter,' he said. 'That would mean this person should be named by the end of March if the donation has just been made.'

Labour refused to confirm or deny that such a large amount had been given to the party by one individual, leading to speculation that it had. A party spokesman admitted he did not know 'the truth of the matter'.

The Sunday Telegraph reported that the money had come through the efforts of Lord Levy, the party's controversial chief fund-raiser who is also the Prime Minister's special envoy to the Middle East. Tony Blair was so delighted with the large sum that he invited Levy to Chequers on Boxing Day as a reward, the paper said.

Parties will be forced to disclose major donors when the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act is implemented in February. An Electoral Commission set up under the Act will publish regular reports on their funding, listing donors and the amounts they have given.

A Labour official pointed out it was Blair's govern ment that had pushed through the new transparency measures in the teeth of opposition from the Conservatives. He said that the Tories would have much more to lose than Labour by naming their key donors.

New figures show that corporate donations to the Conservative Party have sunk to their lowest level since records began.

Last year, 31 companies gave a total of only £359,059 last year, compared with the £2.5 million handed to the Tories in the equivalent year of the last Parliament. It signals a crisis of confidence in the party among its most loyal traditional supporters.

'It's a fact of life that our corporate donations are declining,' a party spokesman said last night. 'It's something we've got to live with. We're doing all we can to encourage wealthy individuals to donate instead.'

The Conservatives refuse to disclose details of company gifts, simply listing donors of more than £5,000. However, the new figures come from a survey to be published this week by Labour Research, the independent analysts who check firms' annual reports.

Those which stopped Tory donations in the last financial year include the property developer Castlemore, which gave £100,000 the year before, and road builder Tarmac, which donated £40,000.

fields.headline: Much more than a bubble
fields.standfirst:
The lesson of history is that the web's flaky start need not be fatal, writes John Naughton

More net news
fields.trailText: Those who would forget history are condemned to repeat it. Readers of the lurid accounts of the Great Internet Bubble of 2000 could be forgiven for thinking that this was a folly unique in human history, rather than just one of those periodic outbursts of irrational exuberance to which humans with more money than sense are prone.
fields.body:
Those who would forget history are condemned to repeat it. Readers of the lurid accounts of the Great Internet Bubble of 2000 could be forgiven for thinking that this was a folly unique in human history, rather than just one of those periodic outbursts of irrational exuberance to which humans with more money than sense are prone.

And as the bubble burst, irrational exuberance gave way to an equally irrational pessimism, and a conviction in some quarters that the whole technology thing was really just a passing fad, with the result that even serious, well-managed companies such as Cisco, Microsoft and Sun have seen their stock market valuations plummet.

The strange thing is that we have been here before; with radio in the Twenties. Even the ubiquitous acronym www, nowadays an obligatory part of every beer commercial and billboard hoarding, has been around a long time. It was an integral part of the corporate logo of RCA, the Radio Corporation of America, from 1920 to 1927, though the letters then stood for 'World Wide Wireless' rather than World Wide Web.

When radio emerged from military control after the First World War, nobody really knew what to do with the technology. It was initially perceived as a point-to-point medium and thus a competitor to the (wired) telegraph. It took quite a time before people figured out that it was best employed as a broadcast (few-to-many) medium.

This led to a scramble to (a) build receivers and (b) transmit content which would persuade people to purchase them. But for a time, the only people who made money from radio were the manufacturers of receivers. Nobody could work out how to make profits from broadcasting itself, and hundreds of companies went under in the search for a viable business model which could harness the potential of this radical new technology.

In the end, of course, the problem was cracked: audio broadcasting became a profitable business which shaped the evolution of mass culture based on national advertising. But it took a long time and there were innumerable casualties on the way.

Much the same is happening now with the internet. The business world reckons that the netis the Next Big Thing, but few have yet figured out a viable way of making serious money from it. Many of those who thought they had it sussed have already gone bust, or are in the process of doing so. According to the Economist, 60 of the biggest internet firms have seen their share price fall by 90 per cent from their March 2000 peaks, and hundreds more have fallen by more than half.

Accordingly, the stock options customarily offered to dotcom employees in lieu of proper salaries are now rarely worth the paper they're printed on, bringing a totally new interpretation to the phrase 'negative equity'. And the original quick-exit route for dotcom investors - the stock market flotation or IPO, which converted stock holdings and options into real money - has effectively been closed off. Cancellations of forthcoming IPOs now exceed new listings. And the Nasdaq has gone through the floor.

Does all this matter? No and yes.

No, because the bankruptcy of half-baked fantasy firms does not constitute a definitive test of anything. Some of the most spectacular dotcom failures of 2000 were basket cases, managerially speaking, whose only measure of performance seemed to be their 'burn rate' - the speed with which they got through investors' money. Boo.com, an aspirant fashion etailer, consumed $185 million in 18 months and never even managed to get its site working properly.

British visitors to San Francisco start-ups returned with awed tales of executive prodigality. They told of one company which employed FedEx to move parcels from one floor of its building to another. Or of a senior manager in another firm who ordered Mont Blanc pens by the gross because he 'kept losing them'.

Publicity surrounding the collapse of such preposterous enterprises has diverted attention from the radical economic and social changes being brought about by the net. So yes, all this stuff does matter. Even in the uncool area of online retailing, companies such as Amazon continue to change the commercial landscape. Ask any bricks-and-mortar bookseller. As Bill Davidow, a prominent US venture capitalist, remarked recently: 'There was a tulip business even after the tulip mania.'

The internet is bringing far-reaching changes to our economy, in the form of new ways of doing business, greater productivity in important sectors, lower transaction costs as buyers and sellers come together without the intervention of middlemen, new exchanges in which everything from electricity to broadband capacity can be traded efficiently, and increased consumer the power to resist price rises.

These developments represent permanent changes to the economic landscape. And the indifferent commercial performance of early Business-to-Business (B2B) exchanges will not reduce the determination of global firms such as Ford, General Motors, Boeing and General Electric to conduct most of their supply-chain transactions online. Why? Because it costs them about $65 to process a paper-based order and less than $5 to do the same thing online - and to an accountant that's the nearest thing in life to a cast-iron argument.

So whatever happens to dotcoms, the commercial world will increasingly adopt the net, and anyone who wants to do business with large firms will have to adopt it too. Andy Grove's prediction that 'companies that are not internet companies by 2005 will not be companies at all' is beginning to look like an understatement.

Meanwhile, the underlying technology continues to develop and mutate in unexpected and sometimes subversive ways. A little over two years ago a teenager named Shawn Fanning wrote a program for swapping music files over the net. He then founded a company called Napster to provide a central database enabling subscribers to locate MP3 files on other people's machines, and download from those machines if desired. What he created, in effect, was a system which turned computers used by Napster subscribers into mini-servers, doling out MP3 files on request, using what has become known as 'peer to peer' (P2P) networking.

In less than 18 months, Napster attracted 38 million members, which made it one of the fastest-growing enterprises in history. And all on the back of a small program hacked out in a teenager's attic.

The record companies eventually sued Napster for copyright infringement in a case which has attracted huge amounts of media attention but is, as yet, undecided. From a long-term perspective, however, the fate of Napster is unimportant: in the end it's just another dotcom. What matters is that it has spawned an internet technology - P2P networking - which is potentially as revolutionary as the web.

We are rapidly moving to an era when millions of people will have broadband connections to the net via fixed and wireless links. If even a fraction of these newly wired users allow their machines to become P2P hosts, which means acting as servers for particular purposes, none of which need have anything to do with pirated music, the collective power of the net will be enormously amplified, with consequences that we can barely imagine.

P2P technologies could unravel the elaborate structure of search engines and portals which dominate today's web, and turn it into a system where resources are much more dispersed and distributed. Ten years ago, Tim Berners-Lee invented the web and turned the world upside down. A decade from now, we may be looking back at the emergence of P2P and saying much the same. In the circumstances, the collapse of Boo.com & Co. seems a price worth paying.

fields.headline: Harsh words can deform children's brains for life
fields.standfirst: Abuse stunts one part of the young mind, says a new study. The result can be depression, or genius
fields.trailText: Abuse stunts one part of the young mind, says a new study. The result can be depression, or genius.
fields.body:
Smacking, slapping or even shouting at children can significantly and permanently alter the structure of their brains and lead to long-term behavioural problems, new research in the United States has revealed.

The findings - by senior consultants at McLean's Hospital, a psychiatric centre affiliated to Harvard Medical School, in Massachusetts - fundamentally challenge many of the basic precepts of childcare and of orthodox psychiatry.

Dr Martin Teicher, who led the study team, said there was evidence that emotional trauma in childhood could cause deformities in critical parts of the brain, in turn causing depression, anxiety and other conditions.

'The brain is fundamentally sculpted by our experiences. Adverse experience will sculpt our brain in a different way,' Teicher said. 'We are finding that verbal abuse is devastating... These changes are permanent. It is not something people can just get over and then get on with their lives.'

His team took hundreds of brain scans from children who had been admitted to the hospital after suffering neglect, physical or sexual abuse and compared them with scans of young people who had not suffered anything similar.

They found that in the children who had been neglected or abused, the corpus callosum , the bundle of nerves that links the two hemispheres of the brain and act as the main information pathway between them, was up to 40 per cent smaller than average.

An underdeveloped corpus callosum inhibits communication between one hemisphere and the other, the researchers claimed. As a result children could end up 'residing' in one hemisphere rather than moving rapidly and easily from one to the other, as is usual.

The left brain hemisphere controls the right side of the body, and is where logical, rational thought and use of language takes place. The right hemisphere controls the left side, and is the location for creative and emotional thought. An over-favouring of one side or the other can cause serious problems. 'A lot of individuals who have survived childhood trauma reside in their left hemisphere when they function well. But when traumatic thoughts arise, they retreat into their right,' said Teicher. 'They can get very emotional, without any of the logic of the left side there to guide them.'

Some researchers speculate that abuse may have been behind the genius of creative giants such as Beethoven or D.H. Lawrence. Beethoven was treated appallingly by his alcoholic father, who dragged the boy from his bed and forced him to play music through the night, beating him when he got things wrong. Lawrence had an dreadful relationship with his drunken, coal miner father. Philip Larkin, the poet, famously wrote about what he felt 'mum and dad' did to their children.

More recently, Sinead O'Connor, the Irish singer, talked of being locked naked in freezing rooms for days on end and beaten as a child. Brian Wilson, one of the founders of the Beach Boys, has alleged that he was badly beaten as a child.

However, senior psychiatrists warned this weekend against applying the conclusions of the new research too widely.

'Statistically, there is not much to show that genius can be caused by psychiatric illness. There is in fact plenty of evidence to show that abuse can make learning very difficult,' said Dr David Wood, a consultant child and adolescent psychiatrist. 'Children can be made chronically anxious by inconsistency and shouting.'

However, Wood said that the research was welcome: 'It raises very important questions about the optimal treatment of children.'

Modern neuroscientific research has centred on the way the brain physically changes in response to external stimuli. 'The nature versus nurture debate is being seen as increasingly outmoded,' Wood said. 'We are talking now about a complex interaction between genetic disposition and experience.'

Peter Wilson, director of the children's mental health charity Young Minds, said modern research showed how vulnerable the very young are: 'We are learning that the brain is an evolving organism, and is growing and developing an enormous amount in infancy. It is not static and inert but responds to its environment.

'These new findings show what very powerful effect negative experiences have on children's emotional lives and their subsequent development.'

Experiments with animals have shown that neurons in the brain react to certain experiences during its early growth. Stresses at critical periods determine whether certain parts of the brain grow or die.

Previously, psychiatrists believed all mental illnesses were either physical or emotional in origin. They felt that many conditions - such as schizophrenia and manic depressive disorder - were caused by inherited chemical imbalances in the brain that could be countered by drugs. Others, such as personality disorders, were thought to be rooted in traumatic experiences, and could be dealt with by therapy.

Teicher believes his research points towards a different type of treatment. Certain activities - such as playing the piano - involve concentrated co-ordination of both brain hemispheres. That could lead to a regeneration of some damaged parts, and could be a potential cure.

Useful sites:
McLean's Hospital website
Royal College of Psychiatrists

fields.headline: Mars attacks!
fields.standfirst:
Since the first days of HG Wells, science fiction
has played on our fears. But what are the odds
on our being wiped out by asteroids or little green
men from Mars. Here, Robin McKie separates
the sci-fi from the facts
fields.trailText: Since the first days of HG Wells, science fiction has played on our fears. But what are the odds on our being wiped out by asteroids or little green men from Mars. Here, Robin McKie separates the sci-fi from the facts.
fields.body:
Earth hit by asteroid

A comet streaks across the sky. Men and women clutch each other in terror as it plunges earthwards. A massive eruption shakes the ground, followed by a blast of searing-hot gas that incinerates everything in its path. The sky is choked by a thick veil of dust, and a decade-long winter settles over the world - curtains for any lifeform bigger than an amoeba. Such cataclysms have fascinated science fiction writers for decades. But now the prospect is beginning to worry scientists, following their discovery that one of these astronomical killjoys was responsible for eradicating the dinosaurs 65m years ago. As a result, astronomers have set up the Torino Scale, their answer to the Richter scale, in which celestial bodies are classified according to their ability to wreak havoc. Examples include a four rating for 'a close encounter with one per cent or greater chance of a collision capable of causing regional damage', to a 10 rating for an object that will cause total global destruction and from which only Bruce Willis could rescue us. Since then, only one object, codenamed 2000 SG344, which is set to reach us around September 2030, has been considered dangerous enough to be put on to the Torino scale... though only as a one.

Odds: 1,000 to 1

Global warming

For the smart money. Rising atmospheric levels of carbon dioxide and other industrial gasses are trapping the sun's rays and triggering a greenhouse effect. Europe's growing season has lengthened by 11 days in the past century; all Arctic ice is likely to have disappeared by 2080; sea levels will have inundated all low countries in 50 years; and new weather patterns and outbreaks of diseases will have erupted. And all that will happen, even if we started to take action tomorrow. We won't, of course. American intransigence and refusal to give up their polluting ways meant that last month's climate summit in The Hague ended in high farce.

Odds: 2 to 1 on

Second ice age

Most scientists now believe in global warming. Yet only a couple of decades ago, many of these same experts were confidently predicting global cooling and a new ice age. 'A new ice age must now stand alongside nuclear war as a likely source of wholesale misery and death,' said International Wildlife in 1975, while Science reported that we were 'heading for extensive northern hemisphere glaciation.'

Odds: 100 to 1 against

Worldwide epidemic

Over the past couple of decades, epidemics of all sorts of strange ailments have erupted across the world: West Nile fever, Ebola, Lassa, and hentavirus, not to mention Aids, which has affected more than 60m people. Cheap travel, the overuse of antibiotics and the destruction of habitats of wild animals - which then pass on diseases to humans - are making our world increasingly vulnerable to new illnesses. All a person with a deadly bug has to do is board a jet plane and he or she is on another continent before their symptoms strike. Ironically, the world was lucky with Aids. It may be devastating some regions of Africa, but its transmission is still a relatively tricky business. 'It's still a difficult virus to pass on to others. You have to give it via infected blood or semen,' says the DNA pioneer James Watson. 'The next one may be just as deadly but far easier to contract.' So our next great epidemic may be our last.

Odds: 10 to 1 against

Nuclear war

Our leaders still worry that we risk being obliterated in an all-out nuclear war. We no longer have to worry about reds and rednecks, of course, but in a world in which warring states, such as Israel, Pakistan and India, and cash-strapped nations, such as Ukraine and Russia, all possess atom bombs, there is little room for festive cheer. The Doomsday Clock, the symbolic timepiece created by the American Bulletin of Atomic Scientists after the Second World War, stood at two minutes to midnight in 1953, its closest approach to Armageddon. By 1991, it had slipped back to 17 minutes. Since then the hand has crept back and now stands at nine minutes before the fateful hour.

Odds: 50 to 1

Sun explodes

Every so often, a star explodes in a devastating supernova explosion, vapourising everything within several billion miles. Bad news if you have planetary real estate in the vicinity. The question is: will the sun suffer a similar fate? Fortunately, the answer is no. The sun is simply not massive enough to sustain the destructive nuclear processes that lead to a supernova. But don't get too excited. We are still very vulnerable even to tiny perturbations in its behaviour. In the 17th century, solar activity decreased fractionally, and the world went into a mini ice age. The Thames froze over, glaciers expanded and global temperatures dropped. Now the sun's output has bounced back, worsening the impact of our own man-made climate warming. And if that's what happens when the sun's rays fluctuate only fractionally, think of the likely impact if it really varied its output...

Odds: 100,000 to 1

Population explosion

Last year, Earth's population topped 6bn, double the number it had reached in 1960. Yet only 20,000 years ago, mankind consisted of about 10,000 people, most of whom were wandering around the tundra making a hash of their attempts to club mammoths. Then humans invented agriculture and began producing more food than was really needed, triggering a massive acceleration in the growth of numbers of our species. Everyday, we add the population of a city the size of San Francisco to humanity's swelling ranks. By 2050, there will be 12bn of us. It is an horrific prospect, though you never know - it does increase our chances of finding someone that could run Britain's trains. To feed this staggering mass of humanity, every last scrap of forest or savannah will be turned into farmland. Humans will have come close to exhausting the planet's resources, paving the way for us to starve ourselves out of existence.

Odds: 2 to 1 against

Population dies out

Earth's population may be swelling but so, it seems, are most of its male members' gonads - with the result that infertility among men is rising alarmingly. Some researchers say that if this trend continues, our species will no longer be able to reproduce. Childlessness will become the norm, and mankind will go out with a whimper. Given the number of people we already have on Earth, the risk seems remote, however.

Odds: 6bn to 1 against

Judgement day

The Old Testament has the Book of Daniel; the New has the Book of Revelation; Islam has the coming of the Mahdi; Zoroastrians predict the arrival of the third son of Zoroaster. And all bear the same bad news: very soon God is going to get very angry and say he has had enough. History will brought to an end. And when that happens there will, of course, be a wailing and a gnashing of teeth, the waters will rise, and a pestilence will spread across the land. For the righteous, the Judgment Day will bring heavenly rewards, for the rest, it will mean the Big Drop or, as Tom Lehrer put it: 'We will all burn together, when we burn!/ There'll be no need to stand and wait your turn/ When it's time for the fallout,/ And Saint Peter calls us all out,/ We'll just drop our agendas and adjourn!'

Odds: A dead cert
