fields.headline: Winners and losers
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The hi-tech year at a glance
fields.body:
The hi-tech year at a glance

Website of the year

Amihotornot.com, a wheeze dreamed up by two Californian advertising men which invited people to post photographs of themselves on a site and rank the pictures of other subscribers. Went from zero to over a million hits in just over a week. Runner up was Amipresidentornot.com, a wonderful spoof on the legal shenanigans involved in the Florida recounts.

Turkey of the year

Shared jointly by Wap - a brain-dead technology with the performance characteristics of slow-drying paint - and Clickmango.com, a half-baked dot.com fronted by Joanna Lumley (qv).

Best-kept secret

FortuneCity.com, a British web-hosting firm that nobody's heard of but which manages to attract 600 million page impressions a month, making it the eleventh most popular website in the world.

Punt of the year

The mobile phone companies who paid more for 3G mobile licences than they will ever get back in revenue.

Stasi award for surveillance

Shared by Home Office ministers Jack Straw and Charles Clarke whose Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act undermined the civil rights of UK subjects while driving abroad the e-commerce companies on which they will eventually depend for a living.

Angus Deayton award for silliest dotcom name

Unanimously awarded to Jellyworks.com before it was swallowed for some unfathomable reason by Shore Capital.

Newbie of the year

T. Blair of 10 Downing Street, London SW1 who took a computer familiarisation course in his Sedgefield constituency after an embarrassing, and much leaked, failure to order flowers for Cherie over the net. As he sucked his pencil over the multiple choice questionnaire, Blair apologised to one of his classmates for the disturbance caused by his entourage. 'What's bothering me,' said his neighbour, 'is that I'm having trouble with this questionnaire, but I'm nobody. You're having trouble and you're the bloody Prime Minister.'

fields.headline: The euro, subsidies, carbon tax, red tape and, oh yes, the euro
fields.standfirst: Digby Jones: the view from the CBI
fields.trailText: When Digby Jones took over as head of the Confederation of British Industry a year ago attention focused on two things, writes Oliver Morgan. These were: a more confrontational relationship between government and the voice of big business; and his roly-poly figure. Perhaps it was inevitable, given his New Labour-friendly, not to say slim, predecessor, Adair Turner. Jones did little to dispel these impressions, berating the Government for its lack of spine over the euro, while chirping merrily that he wouldn't mind losing a few pounds.
fields.body:
When Digby Jones took over as head of the Confederation of British Industry a year ago attention focused on two things, writes Oliver Morgan. These were: a more confrontational relationship between government and the voice of big business; and his roly-poly figure. Perhaps it was inevitable, given his New Labour-friendly, not to say slim, predecessor, Adair Turner. Jones did little to dispel these impressions, berating the Government for its lack of spine over the euro, while chirping merrily that he wouldn't mind losing a few pounds.

You can scarcely blame the likeable Jones, a West Midlands man who has seen that region's manufacturing base pummelled by the exchange rate and, to be blunt - which he can be - some government policies.

Let's be fair. Jones, whose natural constituency consists of the engineers and textile producers who have been hit so hard, has had more important things on his mind than the bathroom scales. He likes to spend time on the road, lunching and connecting with those who are feeling the pain.

The big issue has been the sterling/euro exchange rate, which has savaged companies exporting to Europe. Jones has held his peace since saying it was the Government's job to campaign for the single currency.

But he makes no bones about his members' views: 'There is a minority view in the CBI that we should not go in, and a majority view that we should go in when the conditions are right.'

Precisely when, he leaves to Government, as he does the timing of a referendum. But early in the next parliament he will poll CBI members. He hopes other business organisations and unions will do the same, and that they will all ask the same question.

Jones also believes the Government has pursued some policies which have damaged manufacturers. Industrial enemy number one is the Climate Change Levy, which taxes companies on their use of carbon.

'The exchange rate is something which can reverse, whereas the Climate Change Levy goes to the heart of competitiveness with European rivals.' It is the issue members most complain to him about.

There are others. Double taxation relief, which gives tax breaks to multinational companies based in the UK, and which the Government proposed abolishing. And his perennial bugbear - red tape: 15 new pieces of legislation in the past three years at a cost of £12.3 billion to business.

Jones says the Government has not been deaf to CBI pleas. He is pleased with attempts to educate and train adults both in and out of the workforce; Ministers resisting pressure from unions to impose a training levy on businesses; and the Government's performances at the Nice and Lisbon summits.

But on the Blair administration's broad approach to manufacturing, and Stephen Byers' much-vaunted new industrial policy, outlined in a series of autumn speeches, his views are more equivocal.

Jones believes money aimed at encouraging 'value-added' industries and helping businesses make higher value products, is laudable, but asks 'should the money be supporting commodity industries [such as mining]?'

On the whole, he says, 'the Government has concentrated on very high technology and helping investment in these industries, but they have not helped those who have to manage businesses in the traditional areas'. (Such as mining?)

Jones planned to spend last week in his country cottage, thinking of the Trades Union Congress chief, John Monks, wrapping his presents in red tape.

Not even a Christmas truce, then.

Precisely when, he leaves to Government, as he does the timing of a referendum. But early in the next parliament he will poll CBI members. He hopes other business organisations and unions will do the same, and that they will all ask the same question. Jones also believes the Government has pursued some policies which have damaged manufacturers. Industrial enemy number one is the Climate Change Levy, which taxes companies on their use of carbon. 'The exchange rate is something which can reverse, whereas the Climate Change Levy goes to the heart of competitiveness with European rivals.' It is the issue members most complain to him about. There are others. Double taxation relief, which gives tax breaks to multinational companies based in the UK, and which the Government proposed abolishing. And his perennial bugbear - red tape: 15 new pieces of legislation in the past three years at a cost of £12.3 billion to business. Jones says the Government has not been deaf to CBI pleas. He is pleased with attempts to educate and train adults both in and out of the workforce; Ministers resisting pressure from unions to impose a training levy on businesses; and the Government's performances at the Nice and Lisbon summits. But on the Blair administration's broad approach to manufacturing, and Stephen Byers' much-vaunted new industrial policy, outlined in a series of autumn speeches, his views are more equivocal. Jones believes money aimed at encouraging 'value-added' industries and helping businesses make higher value products, is laudable, but asks 'should the money be supporting commodity industries [such as mining]?' On the whole, he says, 'the Government has concentrated on very high technology and helping investment in these industries, but they have not helped those who have to manage businesses in the traditional areas'. (Such as mining?) Jones planned to spend last week in his country cottage, thinking of the Trades Union Congress chief, John Monks, wrapping his presents in red tape. Not even a Christmas truce, then.

fields.headline: Heroes with a healing touch
fields.standfirst: Two visionary Asian directors triumph as Bruce Willis develops a 'sick sense' and inspired teachers bring hope to the downtrodden Kurds
fields.trailText: Films of the week: Unbreakable | Blackboards
fields.body:
Unbreakable (118 mins, 12) Directed by M. Night Shyamalan; starring Bruce Willis, Samuel L. Jackson, Robin Wright Penn

Blackboards (85 mins, PG) Directed by Samira Makhmalbaf; starring Said Mohamadi, Behnaz Jafari, Bahman Ghobadi

The year ends with a bang not a whimper, or rather with a pair of decisive bangs in the form of pictures by two confident young directors who first emerged in the late Nineties. Both are of Asian extraction and discovered a cinematic vocation early in life, learning to make films at the same time as they learnt to read books. Though superficially very different, they are visual stylists and movie fabulists.

The 29-year-old M. Night Shayamalan was brought up in Philadelphia, the son of sub-continental Indian parents, both of them doctors. He started to make short movies at the age of 10 and decided at 17 that he wanted to become a professional filmmaker, attending film school in New York rather than studying medicine.

The 20-year-old Samira Makhmalbaf appeared at the age of eight in The Cyclist, directed by her father, Mohsen Makhmalbaf, one of Iran's leading directors. She then studied film before becoming his assistant. Whether they'd have become more interesting cinéastes had they had a traditional academic education, we shall never know.

Shayamalan's third film The Sixth Sense (its two low-budget predecessors made little impact and weren't released here) garnered six Oscar nominations and became the tenth most profitable film of all time. Makhmalbaf's first, The Apple, was shown in the Un Certain Regard section at Cannes in 1998 and played to world-wide acclaim on the festival and art house circuits.

Like The Sixth Sense , Shayamalan's new film, Unbreakable, is an occult thriller, and it too is set in Philadelphia, and stars Bruce Willis as a traumatised victim of violence. In this case Willis plays David Dunn, a former college football star with a tottering marriage and an unrewarding job as security officer at a university sports stadium. He emerges unscathed as the sole survivor of a railway accident in which 131 people die.

As David comes to terms with his miraculous delivery he's contacted by Elijah Price (Samuel L. Jackson), the well-off African-American owner of a gallery dealing in original art works by comic book illustrators. Since birth, Elijah has suffered from a severe form of osteoporosis that results in constant fracturing of his bones, and he's in search of someone at the other end of the spectrum - someone like David who appears indestructible. Such a person, he believes, must have superhuman powers that could make him a hero comparable to those of ancient times, a type kept alive in purest form, so he argues, by comic books.

The Old Testament names (Elijah the prophet who sought to purify society and predated the coming of the Messiah; David the heroic leader and man of destiny) hint at the underlying allegory. With some subtlety the director traces the increasing if uneasy involvement of the two men and how one makes the other aware of his predetermined role. As in The Sixth Sense the dark, lowering city provides a portentous setting for the story. Sometimes we're made to see events from the characters' point of view, as when we watch TV upside down through the eyes of David's hero-worshipping son looking at a newsreel of the train crash, or we observe a would-be assassin on a railway platform from the twisted perspective of Elijah after he's fallen down a flight of stairs and fractured several bones. More often, however, there are long takes in deep focus in which we overhear conversations at some distance, with bars, staircases, rows of restaurant tables, the seats of a railway carriage or open doors between the camera and the people we're listening to.

A visual tour-de-force occurs when David becomes aware of his unusual powers at night on the railway station concourse. His mind takes in confusing information about the depredations of those he bumps into, and he has to decide whose victims are most worthy of his heroic attentions. Shyamalan, however, doesn't know how to resolve his picture. It ends abruptly, surprisingly and shockingly, and one leaves vaguely dissatisfied. But it's a film to see, to enjoy, and perhaps to ponder.

Samira Makhmalbaf's Blackboards, which won the Special Jury Prize at Cannes this year, strikes into different territory from The Apple, her semi-documentary debut about two little girls in Tehran escaping the bondage of their parents. But the theme of tyrannical oppression and enforced ignorance is pursued in the oblique, coded style that a rigid society has forced on Iranian film makers and which has given their films such resonance. The setting is the arid, awesomely beautiful north-west of the country, where Kurds are being persecuted on either side of the borders between Iran, Iraq and Turkey.

Offering hope and relief to the downtrodden of Kurdistan are itinerant schoolteachers, 10 of whom are first seen in the distance on a dusty mountain road, carrying blackboards on their backs and resembling the bird-like sculptures of Lynn Chadwick and Elisabeth Frink. They hide from a helicopter gunship, and then split to go in search of pupils. Like travelling holy men, they seek little in return for their simple, liberating lessons in reading, writing and arithmetic. The movie concentrates on two of them, Reeboir and Saïd.

Reeboir attaches himself to a party of teenage smugglers who risk their lives carrying heavy contraband goods across the border for exploitative, conspicuously absent employers. Saïd joins a large group of old men attempting to make a pilgrimage over the mountains to the native lands from which they presumably fled during the recent war. The only young person with the old men, and the only woman in the film, is Halalheh, the widowed daughter of one the most decrepit of the men, and she's accompanied by her little child. No one in either camp sees any value in education, having adjusted themselves to a life of permanent exploitation and persecution that leaves them at the mercy of cruel, anonymous border guards.

Nevertheless Reeboir and Saïd persist in a doggedly heroic manner, using their blackboards variously as protective camouflage, stretchers, clothes lines, screens for a wedding, doors for privacy, splints for broken limbs, shields against gunfire. So emblematic does his professional prop become that Saïd becomes known to the old men as Blackboard.

Blackboards is plainly an allegory or parable, but it has a force and documentary vividness that resists simple explanations and deters us from reading easy messages into it. But ultimately, and unsentimentally, it's an affirmative work. Only the young woman and one of the teachers has any previous acting experience, but Makhmalbaf (whose father co-scripted the film as well as editing it) manages to bind the two groups of young and elderly non-professional actors into distinct communities on the move.

Jason Robards Jr, who died last week aged 78, came late to acting and much later to the cinema, though he was the son of a well-known screen and stage performer and was educated at Hollywood High School. As a stage actor he was the greatest exponent of Eugene O'Neill (another theatrical son much drawn to the bottle), and one of my great regrets is that I didn't see his Hickey in the 1956 revival of The Iceman Cometh, though I was lucky enough to catch his Cornelius Melody on Broadway in A Touch of the Poet, and we're all fortunate that he reprised his Jamie Tyrone in Sidney Lumet's 1961 film of A Long Day's Journey into Night. The latter was only Robards' fourth movie, made when he was 40, but he went on to appear in a further 50 pictures, several of them classics, culminating in his final appearance as the dying patriarch in Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia last year.

That gravelly voice lent authority to the soundtrack of documentaries, and he was memorable in parts as different as the honest bandit in Leone's Once Upon a Time in the West and the exasperated cop chasing Bill Murray in Quick Change. But the finest roles to which he lent that craggy, crooked, infinitely experienced face were real-life figures, some good, some bad, but all in the American grain - Doc Holliday (Hour of the Gun), Al Capone (The St Valentine's Day Massacre), General Lew Wallace (Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid), Richard Nixon (TV's Washington: Behind Closed Doors), Ben Bradlee (All the President's Men), Dashiell Hammett (Julia), Howard Hughes (Melvin and Howard). This was a veritable Mount Rushmore of a movie career.

webTitle: Analyse this: David Baddiel's new sitcom

fields.headline: Analyse this...
fields.standfirst: They sit around talking about pipe-smoking and pistachios. William Leith asks if David Baddiel's sitcom is Britain's answer to Seinfeld while Kathryn Flett remembers her time filming the show
fields.trailText: They sit around talking about pipe-smoking and pistachios. William Leith asks if David Baddiel's sitcom is Britain's answer to Seinfeld while Kathryn Flett remembers her time filming the show.
fields.body:
'I am not a very good actor,' says David Baddiel, who stars in Baddiel's Syndrome, a new sitcom, 'but there has been a tradition in America of taking people who have got successful stand-up personas and just giving them legs - putting them in dramatic and narrative situations. Seinfeld, Roseanne, Bob Newhart, Bill Cosby. That hasn't happened much in this country, rather oddly.'

But now it has happened. In Baddiel's Syndrome, David Baddiel plays David Baddiel, an architect in therapy who suspects he is Jewish. The first thing that strikes you about this sitcom, which Baddiel has written with journalist Pete Bradshaw, is that it doesn't look like a British sitcom. It looks like an American sitcom which happens to be set in Camden Town. It's about middle-class people in their thirties, mostly idiots, who sit around talking rubbish. They muse about the nature of pistachio nuts, or pipe-smoking, or whether it's possible to sing a karaoke version of Mike Oldfield's Tubular Bells. The punch lines, crafted by a team of writers, as well as Baddiel and Bradshaw, come at you every few seconds. And just in case you hadn't made the connection, the scenes are linked with peppy, Friends -like guitar music.

Baddiel and Bradshaw are sitting in Baddiel's large and elaborately furnished house in Belsize Park, north London. 'I think Friends is brilliant,' says Baddiel, 'and it was massively underrated in this country for a very British reason, which is the assumption that because the cast is beautiful, it must be vacuous. Whereas in fact, it's brilliantly, brilliantly written. I've seen episodes of Friends which are as funny as any sitcom I've ever seen.'

Bradshaw, too, is excited by the American comedy model. 'It's more intensively farmed,' he says. 'I mean, take a British sitcom like Victoria Wood's Dinnerladies. I've got no problem with it; I think it's quite amusing. But it's very gentle, and it just lies there, and you just have to go up and cuddle it, basically. Whereas with American sitcoms like Friends or Seinfeld, every line has been crafted to punch or gouge out a laugh. Here, there's a kind of gentleman amateur school which sometimes creates wonderful things, and often creates rather watery and dull things which can go on forever, like Last of the Summer Wine which has always made me want to commit suicide.'

In Baddiel's Syndrome, Bradshaw plays Lord Peter Harrington, a fey aristocrat who has been at a loose end since he lost his seat in the House of Lords. Morwenna Banks, Baddiel's real-life girlfriend, is Eva, a Slovenian cleaning lady; the American actor Demetri Goritsas plays an idiot savant along the lines of Woody Harrelson's barman in Cheers. It is a story of deluded and whimsical people being put in their place, often curtly and abrasively, by the Baddiel character, which he plays more or less as the persona he employed as a stand-up comedian, or alongside Frank Skinner in Fantasy Football. At the beginning and end of every episode, we see Baddiel on the couch, being analysed by the voice of Stephen Fry.

'Artistically,' says Baddiel, 'this has been the hardest thing I've had to write. Harder than a novel, definitely. The physics of it is really difficult. You think you've got enough storylines. But they run out if you use three or four an episode.' He held auditions for writers, asking them to come up with ideas, and organised weekly sessions with a group that included Jonathan Ross and his wife Jane, and Jack Barth who has written for The Simpsons.

Baddiel's Syndrome was commissioned by Sky, for an estimated £5 million, which works out at about £250,000 an episode. Some reports wrongly suggested that the £5m was Baddiel's personal fee. ITV had commissioned a pilot episode but thought it was, in Baddiel's words, 'too sophisticated'. He says: 'There's an episode which begins with two people going into a cubicle to take drugs, which some people would say is too alienating. But actually that's bollocks. Working-class people in Bradford are not going to say, "What's going on?" One of the things that people in TV seem very frightened of is this sense of, "Oh, but you'll alienate them because you're talking about something they might not know about." I think the people that don't know about this stuff don't really exist.'

Elisabeth Murdoch at Sky was keen to buy the series. Baddiel recalls: 'She had this big visionary idea that Sky was going to turn into HBO, and would do really quality programming. I remember her saying, "I want to get away from the idea of dishes on council homes and Rupert Murdoch".'

Like his character, Baddiel has been in therapy, but he doesn't like to talk about it - he thinks comedians trade too readily on their depression. 'When they play the depressed card,' he says, 'they're really saying, "I'm a genius".' He grew up in the suburbs north of London; his father collected Dinky toys and his mother was a hoarder of golf memorabilia. His house, he says, was 'wall to wall covered in either toys or pictures of toys, or golf memorabilia, or golfing scenes, in a mental, mental way.'

Bradshaw, the son of a retired photographer, has never been in therapy. 'I'm terribly frightened of what I might find out about myself,' he says. He first met Baddiel in 1979, at Haberdasher's school in Elstree, at a school election. The earnest Baddiel stood as the Socialist candidate; Bradshaw was a Satanist. 'He won,' says Baddiel, 'and I got about four votes.' Later, they performed together with the Cambridge Footlights.

Bradshaw is a revelation in the show; he is a natural clown. His character is always trying, and failing, to find a purpose in life. In one episode he grows a moustache, believing that this might be the answer, and finds himself under siege because people think he's a pervert. Baddiel says: 'I forced him into situations that, in a way, he'd rather not confront.' Like Bradshaw, his character, Lord Peter, is blind in one eye; Baddiel wrote a storyline in which he injures his other eye. A lot of the humour is edgy. Baddiel puts in frequent references to the Holocaust, and one set-up requires you to laugh when a door is opened to reveal a room full of Ku Klux Klan members.

Baddiel says: 'I remember watching an episode of Seinfeld in which George can't understand why security guards can't sit down. He gets obsessed with it and eventually buys a chair for a security guard who sits down and goes to sleep. The shop gets robbed. That's a brilliant extrapolation of what is essentially observational comedy. And that's where we've pitched the show.'

'Also,' says Bradshaw, 'it's topped and tailed structurally in the same way that our show is topped and tailed.' 'Now you're making it sound too much like Seinfeld ,' says Baddiel.

Kathryn Flett: My life as a TV cow in Baddiel's sitcom

'Er, this is a bit of an unusual request...' said the voice on the phone, 'but we wondered if you might be interested in screen-testing for a part in Sky's new sitcom, Baddiel's Syndrome?' It had taken a while but finally, last summer, my Mrs Trapes in the 1981 Old Vic Youth Theatre production of The Beggars Opera had been recognised as the groundbreaking work I had always known it might be if I ever got extraordinarily lucky.

'Shall I bring my own sheet music and tap shoes?'

In the cramped Soho casting office, I read the script for the benefit of a video camera. It included the line 'cherry-wood olive-oil drizzlers, £149.99' and took about 90 seconds. After a second reading, I was offered the part. Outside the room, rows of real actors were huddled together on school assembly chairs, clutching scripts and wearing convincing expressions of extreme hopelessness - though perhaps this was merely a Method. Could I really take work from struggling professionals when I already had a regular job and a pension, even if it was with Equitable Life?

After extensive contractual negotiations ('We'll pay you X.' 'Really? Wow! Thanks!'), I turned up for rehearsals at a church hall in south London. It was just like donating blood: reasonably painless and over very fast, plus free tea and biscuits before you left. Admittedly, I hadn't yet learnt my lines, but I reckoned I could pull it off with the help of idiot boards, just like Brando in Apocalypse Now. Hopefully, I too might be shot in flattering gloomvision.

Back home, I pondered my motivation. I hadn't dared ask why I had been chosen to play the microscopically small, but frankly pivotal role of Martina Chatwin, though I had a big hunch: 'Martina' is a broadsheet hackette who writes a first-person confessional column, and given that I hadn't done that sort thing for, ooh, years, the Sunday Times 's Liz Jones must already have turned it down. Then there was the undeniably worrying fact that Martina was, in the words of David Baddiel's character (an angsty thirtysomething called David Baddiel): 'a cow'.

I think it takes balls to say to someone, 'Would you like to play a complete cow whose character is, in fact, not terribly loosely based on you...', and so I should have the guts to prove that - ha!ha!ha! - I could laugh at myself, or at least the me they humorously perceived me to be, while also bringing something extra to Martina: a level of humanity and grace that was, admittedly, not altogether evident in the script. And all of this in roughly 90 seconds of airtime. Who wouldn't leap at that sort of challenge, given that there are so few good parts for journalists in their mid-thirties? Hey, Martina might be a cow, but she was a well-written cow.

At Teddington Studios, I had a dressing-room with my name on the door and a horrible costume on a hanger. This came as no surprise because if Martina was going to be 'a cow' hidden inside the Versace-clad body of a love goddess, then they would have given the part to Liz Hurley. Indeed it is, I think, fair to say that I eventually emerged from hair and make-up looking like Olive from On The Buses. I enjoyed the whole experience very much but there was no escaping the fact that, even as my heart said, 'You are Uma Thurman', the TV monitor said, 'You are in panto in Wolverhampton playing the Ugly Sister's slightly uglier banjo-strumming cousin'.

So, after several fraught months on a rigorous high-collagen/low-carb diet, last week I again summoned the courage to speak to Peter Bradshaw - Baddiel's Syndrome 's co-writer, co-star (and memorably, in episode six, Martina Chatwin's boyfriend), not to mention the Guardian's film critic, who once sensibly turned down a part in a production of Cyrano de Bergerac directed by some bloke called Sam Mendes but has finally got himself a proper acting break.

After some polite obfuscation in response to my inquiry about the genesis of Martina's character ('well, obviously, it was based on your book and column...'), Bradshaw admitted that:'If we get recommissioned, you may have to clear your schedule.' Sweet! And if they allow Martina to wear the sort of frocks that reveal both her inner and outer beauty and then spin her off into a Frasier -style series of her own, Ms Chatwin and I might even think about it. In the meantime, however, I urge you to enjoy the series - an entirely unbiased review of which reads: 'I laughed out loud and corpsed twice! Pure televisual Temazepan!' - Martina Chatwin, The Observer.

 Baddiel's Syndrome starts on 14 Jan, Sky One.

In Baddiel's Syndrome, Bradshaw plays Lord Peter Harrington, a fey aristocrat who has been at a loose end since he lost his seat in the House of Lords. Morwenna Banks, Baddiel's real-life girlfriend, is Eva, a Slovenian cleaning lady; the American actor Demetri Goritsas plays an idiot savant along the lines of Woody Harrelson's barman in Cheers. It is a story of deluded and whimsical people being put in their place, often curtly and abrasively, by the Baddiel character, which he plays more or less as the persona he employed as a stand-up comedian, or alongside Frank Skinner in Fantasy Football. At the beginning and end of every episode, we see Baddiel on the couch, being analysed by the voice of Stephen Fry. 'Artistically,' says Baddiel, 'this has been the hardest thing I've had to write. Harder than a novel, definitely. The physics of it is really difficult. You think you've got enough storylines. But they run out if you use three or four an episode.' He held auditions for writers, asking them to come up with ideas, and organised weekly sessions with a group that included Jonathan Ross and his wife Jane, and Jack Barth who has written for The Simpsons. Baddiel's Syndrome was commissioned by Sky, for an estimated £5 million, which works out at about £250,000 an episode. Some reports wrongly suggested that the £5m was Baddiel's personal fee. ITV had commissioned a pilot episode but thought it was, in Baddiel's words, 'too sophisticated'. He says: 'There's an episode which begins with two people going into a cubicle to take drugs, which some people would say is too alienating. But actually that's bollocks. Working-class people in Bradford are not going to say, "What's going on?" One of the things that people in TV seem very frightened of is this sense of, "Oh, but you'll alienate them because you're talking about something they might not know about." I think the people that don't know about this stuff don't really exist.' Elisabeth Murdoch at Sky was keen to buy the series. Baddiel recalls: 'She had this big visionary idea that Sky was going to turn into HBO, and would do really quality programming. I remember her saying, "I want to get away from the idea of dishes on council homes and Rupert Murdoch".' Like his character, Baddiel has been in therapy, but he doesn't like to talk about it - he thinks comedians trade too readily on their depression. 'When they play the depressed card,' he says, 'they're really saying, "I'm a genius".' He grew up in the suburbs north of London; his father collected Dinky toys and his mother was a hoarder of golf memorabilia. His house, he says, was 'wall to wall covered in either toys or pictures of toys, or golf memorabilia, or golfing scenes, in a mental, mental way.' Bradshaw, the son of a retired photographer, has never been in therapy. 'I'm terribly frightened of what I might find out about myself,' he says. He first met Baddiel in 1979, at Haberdasher's school in Elstree, at a school election. The earnest Baddiel stood as the Socialist candidate; Bradshaw was a Satanist. 'He won,' says Baddiel, 'and I got about four votes.' Later, they performed together with the Cambridge Footlights. Bradshaw is a revelation in the show; he is a natural clown. His character is always trying, and failing, to find a purpose in life. In one episode he grows a moustache, believing that this might be the answer, and finds himself under siege because people think he's a pervert. Baddiel says: 'I forced him into situations that, in a way, he'd rather not confront.' Like Bradshaw, his character, Lord Peter, is blind in one eye; Baddiel wrote a storyline in which he injures his other eye. A lot of the humour is edgy. Baddiel puts in frequent references to the Holocaust, and one set-up requires you to laugh when a door is opened to reveal a room full of Ku Klux Klan members. Baddiel says: 'I remember watching an episode of Seinfeld in which George can't understand why security guards can't sit down. He gets obsessed with it and eventually buys a chair for a security guard who sits down and goes to sleep. The shop gets robbed. That's a brilliant extrapolation of what is essentially observational comedy. And that's where we've pitched the show.' 'Also,' says Bradshaw, 'it's topped and tailed structurally in the same way that our show is topped and tailed.' 'Now you're making it sound too much like Seinfeld ,' says Baddiel. Kathryn Flett: My life as a TV cow in Baddiel's sitcom 'Er, this is a bit of an unusual request...' said the voice on the phone, 'but we wondered if you might be interested in screen-testing for a part in Sky's new sitcom, Baddiel's Syndrome?' It had taken a while but finally, last summer, my Mrs Trapes in the 1981 Old Vic Youth Theatre production of The Beggars Opera had been recognised as the groundbreaking work I had always known it might be if I ever got extraordinarily lucky. 'Shall I bring my own sheet music and tap shoes?' In the cramped Soho casting office, I read the script for the benefit of a video camera. It included the line 'cherry-wood olive-oil drizzlers, £149.99' and took about 90 seconds. After a second reading, I was offered the part. Outside the room, rows of real actors were huddled together on school assembly chairs, clutching scripts and wearing convincing expressions of extreme hopelessness - though perhaps this was merely a Method. Could I really take work from struggling professionals when I already had a regular job and a pension, even if it was with Equitable Life? After extensive contractual negotiations ('We'll pay you X.' 'Really? Wow! Thanks!'), I turned up for rehearsals at a church hall in south London. It was just like donating blood: reasonably painless and over very fast, plus free tea and biscuits before you left. Admittedly, I hadn't yet learnt my lines, but I reckoned I could pull it off with the help of idiot boards, just like Brando in Apocalypse Now. Hopefully, I too might be shot in flattering gloomvision. Back home, I pondered my motivation. I hadn't dared ask why I had been chosen to play the microscopically small, but frankly pivotal role of Martina Chatwin, though I had a big hunch: 'Martina' is a broadsheet hackette who writes a first-person confessional column, and given that I hadn't done that sort thing for, ooh, years, the Sunday Times 's Liz Jones must already have turned it down. Then there was the undeniably worrying fact that Martina was, in the words of David Baddiel's character (an angsty thirtysomething called David Baddiel): 'a cow'. I think it takes balls to say to someone, 'Would you like to play a complete cow whose character is, in fact, not terribly loosely based on you...', and so I should have the guts to prove that - ha!ha!ha! - I could laugh at myself, or at least the me they humorously perceived me to be, while also bringing something extra to Martina: a level of humanity and grace that was, admittedly, not altogether evident in the script. And all of this in roughly 90 seconds of airtime. Who wouldn't leap at that sort of challenge, given that there are so few good parts for journalists in their mid-thirties? Hey, Martina might be a cow, but she was a well-written cow. At Teddington Studios, I had a dressing-room with my name on the door and a horrible costume on a hanger. This came as no surprise because if Martina was going to be 'a cow' hidden inside the Versace-clad body of a love goddess, then they would have given the part to Liz Hurley. Indeed it is, I think, fair to say that I eventually emerged from hair and make-up looking like Olive from On The Buses. I enjoyed the whole experience very much but there was no escaping the fact that, even as my heart said, 'You are Uma Thurman', the TV monitor said, 'You are in panto in Wolverhampton playing the Ugly Sister's slightly uglier banjo-strumming cousin'. So, after several fraught months on a rigorous high-collagen/low-carb diet, last week I again summoned the courage to speak to Peter Bradshaw - Baddiel's Syndrome 's co-writer, co-star (and memorably, in episode six, Martina Chatwin's boyfriend), not to mention the Guardian's film critic, who once sensibly turned down a part in a production of Cyrano de Bergerac directed by some bloke called Sam Mendes but has finally got himself a proper acting break. After some polite obfuscation in response to my inquiry about the genesis of Martina's character ('well, obviously, it was based on your book and column...'), Bradshaw admitted that:'If we get recommissioned, you may have to clear your schedule.' Sweet! And if they allow Martina to wear the sort of frocks that reveal both her inner and outer beauty and then spin her off into a Frasier -style series of her own, Ms Chatwin and I might even think about it. In the meantime, however, I urge you to enjoy the series - an entirely unbiased review of which reads: 'I laughed out loud and corpsed twice! Pure televisual Temazepan!' - Martina Chatwin, The Observer.  Baddiel's Syndrome starts on 14 Jan, Sky One.

webTitle: Television: 'Tis the season to be wary

fields.headline: 'Tis the season to be wary
fields.standfirst: Festive Britain appeared to be a dark, dysfunctional place - unless you were at Damien Hirst's house says Kathryn Flett
fields.trailText: Festive Britain appeared to be a dark, dysfunctional place - unless you were at Damien Hirst's house says Kathryn Flett.
fields.body:
The Royle Family BBC1

Cold Feet ITV

The League of Gentlemen BBC2

The Last Fast Show Ever BBC2

The Sleeper BBC1

Donovan Quick BBC1

Life and Death and Damien Hirst C4

So, the Christmas ratings were dismal. Titanic floundered (though given that Celine Dion's 'My Heart Will Go On' is, famously, the nation's most requested funeral dirge, maybe that came as no surprise to anybody outside the BBC), while The Royle Family just scraped into the top 10. It was a good episode, but perhaps the Royles reflect just a little too accurately the average blackly dysfunctional family Christmas to be classed as escapist entertainment. Indeed, this year a more ironically downbeat selection of seasonal offerings it would have been hard to assemble. Who could possibly have watched Charlotte Church, lip gloss a-quiver through 'Silent Night' during Sunday's Christmas in the Holy Land, without recognising that, outside, it was anything but.

Even the final episode in the penultimate series of Cold Feet - which, to my mind, always vacillates uneasily between toe-curling sentimentality and faux-grittiness - decided it couldn't face a wedding without invoking, for our light comedic delectation, domestic violence, infertility, adultery, divorce and pornography. Year by TV year, there is an ever-widening gap between the perceived tinselly cheerfulness of our collective Christmases Past and the grimy misanthropy pioneered by the soaps in the Eighties and which now seeps throughout the schedules, but if, during the season of The Suspension of Divine Disbelief, TV persists in reflecting too much warty real life, it's no wonder we turn off in favour of Playstation and the Who Wants To Be A Millionaire Quizbook. Denial may be a dangerous thing but at this time of year it's exactly what most of us need to get by.

Unsurprisingly, perhaps, The League of Gentlemen revealed the most nightmarish vision of Christmas. Never laugh-out-loud funny, always compulsive and often genuinely spine-chilling, it is surely no coincidence that all the multifariously horrifying residents of Royston Vaysey not only bear a spooky likeness to Fred and Rosemary West but that their grotesque moral universe reflects the Wests' own warped insularity. For an island of privacy-loving curtain-twitchers, Royston Vaysey nicely reflects the underbelly of a Britain writ inescapably, claustrophobically local. In The League 's sweaty hands, line-dancing suddenly looks like synchronised mass hysteria, excess consumption of cheese is the fastest route to a night-time vision of hell, and halo-haired choirboys are not merely the tragic victims of those who, like Herr Lipp, enjoy paedophiliac tendencies, but might collude in the exploitation even as they harbour their own dark, satanic secrets.

Admittedly, I had consumed a lot of Stilton prior to watching The League, but I can't entirely blame the cheese for the bad night's sleep that followed: as a child Bernice, the troubled vicar, had lost her mother to a murderous Santa, the circus ringmaster Papa Lazarou - a Black and White Minstrel to send, as Herr Lipp would have it, 'goosesteps up your spine' - who turned up in the final frames to capture Bernice from inside the sanctuary of her own church just as we were in grave danger of something that might have approached a happy ending. I fear for the sleeping patterns of small children who, furtively, might have treated themselves to The League. Several prescriptive nightly doses of 'Walking in the Air' may well be required.

In an elegiac The Last Fast Show Ever (an embarrassment of riches: 120 minutes worth, spread over three successive nights) Swiss Toni finally resorted to counselling to overcome his analogy addiction. For Toni, anything from fishing to crashing a car is 'like making love to a beautiful woman', but as the Fast Show team fleshed out many of their best-loved characters, we learnt that Toni may not, in fact, ever have made love to a beautiful woman. Which was, oddly, sort of sad.

Revelations came thick, if not very fast: the horribly familiar Competitive Dad (well, almost every home I know has one) was revealed to be merely the product of a difficult relationship with his own Competitive Dad; meanwhile, the two Kenneths from Suits You were given a bit of murky motivation for their idiosyncratic salesmanship (homophobic or gay? You decide). After a swift grimace, Ted finally agreed that Ralph might fill the hole left by the death of Mrs Ted (emotionally, if not necessarily physically), while a 'fed up, shagged out' Ron Manager decided to take his flailing punditry to ITV on the reasonable grounds that 'I've not got it in me any more'. Finally, shortly after being brought 'a bucketful of ankles' while clearly vay vay drunk, Rowley Birkin QC actually died, apparently at the age of 82. It was both the end of an era and a cue for more Stilton.

I watched The Sleeper mostly to see why Michelle Collins was in it, but got sucked into the story of the Moons, set against a background slurry of seasonal dysfunction, ouija boards and murderous paranoia, not to mention cowshit. Michelle proved she can do hoity-toity (at least until forced by the plot to get in touch with her inner Cindy Beale) but George Cole was wasted in a pointless role that appeared to exist simply to feed lines to Anna Massey's Miss Marple-ish spinster, hell-bent on investigating the whereabouts of her friend Kath, who had gone mysteriously awol at Christmas from the old people's home where they both lived. Unsure of whether to play it spooky or silly, plotwise The Sleeper got caught in a bit of a dramatic quagmire - can a farmyard really be sold as sinister, unless it is in the locality of Royston Vaysey? - but the acting, particularly from the older cast members, was suitably grand guignol. Which, come to think of it, would make a fine name for a new and challenging brand of cheese.

The week's most unlikely-sounding treat was, however, Donovan Quick, in which Colin Firth played the eponymous and mysterious southern stranger with a fondness for Cervantes who turns up north of the border to rent a room from the, yes, wholly dysfunctional Pannick family. Indeed, there is unlikely to be a more affecting drama set against the backdrop of rail and bus privatisation.

Harassed, alcoholic Lucy was in a bad relationship with arrogant, violent, unemployed Clive, while her younger brother, Sandy, had a learning disability and an unsuitable crush on a lovely Pakistani undergraduate; Lucy's unemployed son, Jim, meanwhile, spent all day on the sofa fighting with Lucy's semi-senile gran (the wonderful Liz Smith, in a slip) for control of the remote. So far, so seasonal. But when the evil Windmill company cut out the train stop nearest to Sandy's day centre, Donovan set up his own bus route, Quick and Pannick, and employed Sandy as conductor. 'Donovan's made me a company director!' said Sandy, proudly. 'Shouldn't you finish the rocket you were making out of a squeezy bottle first?' said Lucy, with some justification. It was lovely stuff - emotionally dark, as befits any contemporary drama with aspirations to Say Something, but leavened by touches of Ealing Comedy, sharp performances and a deft script. The ending was bitter-sweet, too, but Colin Firth didn't get his kit off. Still, you can't have everything - especially at Christmas.

Unless you're Damien Hirst who, if Channel 4's Life and Death and Damien Hirst was anything to go by, appears to have it all and more besides. I was expecting snarling Britart-brattiness, but Hirst is an apparently doting husband and father who enjoys nothing more than drizzling balsamic vinegar over something he's just rustled up in his gleaming moderne-rustic country kitchen for 20 of his closest friends, so this sweetly revealing documentary looked like a cross between Jamie Oliver's ads for Sainsbury's and the final frames of It's a Wonderful Life. If, that is, instead of an Etch-A-Sketch, Jimmy Stewart had bought his kids a gigantic 'build your own human body' kit; 16,000 pills displayed in a glass cabinet or a vast tank filled with Koi carp and dead computers. In among schedules packed with angrily disenfranchised secular schizophrenics, all loathing the season's enforced unselfishness but, none the less, passively-aggressively submitting to a seething collective sense of duty, at least, thanks to the Hirsts, we got to watch one happy family this Christmas.

fields.headline: Take your pick
fields.standfirst: Evelyn Waugh or Big Brother II - the Sequel - the choice is yours
fields.trailText: Evelyn Waugh or Big Brother II - the Sequel - the choice is yours.
fields.body:
At first glance, the New Year's schedules look like an Eng Lit A-level syllabus. Dickens, Hardy and Waugh loom large with lavish adaptations. The Mayor of Casterbridge (ITV), Nicholas Nickleby (ITV) and Sword of Honour (C4), which begins this week, are hefty slices of costumery guaranteed to take any guilt out of watching TV.

The other big drama of the season is BBC2's In a Land of Plenty, a 10-part series spanning the varying fortunes of a middle-class family over 40 years. For something lighter, there is the adaptation of Nancy Mitford's Love in a Cold Climate on BBC1. Then there's Michelle Collins as she eases her brassy persona into Perfect, playing a woman with a habit of walking down the aisle with assorted Mr Wrongs.

Former Big Breakfast presenter Liza Tarbuck takes the eponymous role in Linda Green as an attractive commitment-phobe, while Linda Green writer Paul Abbott has been busy elsewhere. There is a second series of his factory-set drama Clocking Off and he has also penned Best of Both Worlds, which stars Alice '102 Dalmatians' Evans.

Terrestrial viewers will be able to see West Wing for the first time next month on C4 and see why Martin Sheen, who plays an erudite US President, managed to outscore George W. Bush and Al Gore in the popularity stakes.

If you thought the 'real-life' drama of Big Brother was artificial, wait for Big Brother II: the Sequel next summer. The US phenomenon Survivor also arrives on ITV, with a group of castaways vying for a cash prize.

Perhaps thinking sentient viewers are weary of fictional legal eagles, BBC1 is going to provide the real thing. Not LA Law but Boston Law. The cameras shadow Boston's successful public prosecution team for nine months, presumably introducing a host of enjoyably combative characters. Will District Attorney Ralph C. Martin II emerge as one of the faces of 2001?

C4 launches its spin-off entertainment channel E4 in January. C4's younger sibling will preview the major US imports first and introduce several home-grown, teen-friendly series that, with luck, will bear little resemblance to Hollyoaks.

New ITV signings Ant and Dec turn pranksters for a Candid Camera -style format, called Ant & Dec's Secret Camera Show. The best exponent of that sort of thing at the moment is Dom Joly, the surrealist prankster of Trigger Happy TV. His show can only grow in popularity with its second series, especially as C4's other joker, Ali G, will be absent from television while he's making his film debut. He will be missed.

'Higher than Heaven', the No 1 song that accompanied Australian TV coverage of the Olympics, was sung by Bardot, an all-female quintet formed for the purpose of a hit TV show. The format has been snapped up by ITV and now looks likely to emulate the 'water cooler' success of Big Brother. For Popstars, 3,000, young hopefuls were whittled down to the five men and women who will be groomed for stardom. The band will learn their showbiz trade together, living in a house fitted with all-seeing cameras.

Starting next month, their progress will be broadcast to the nation every Saturday night for 13 weeks, and in between there will be multimedia opportunities to interact with the band. Popstars culminates with the debut single release of the song chosen by TV audiences, so expect it to go straight to the top of the charts.

In case the band become the next Steps, they've already signed a five-album deal with Polydor. Fittingly, the show by its very nature dispels any notion that the contestants are in it for anything other than fame. Judging from the experience Down Under, viewers will relish having cute young wannabes to root for.

The band will learn their showbiz trade together, living in a house fitted with all-seeing cameras. Starting next month, their progress will be broadcast to the nation every Saturday night for 13 weeks, and in between there will be multimedia opportunities to interact with the band. Popstars culminates with the debut single release of the song chosen by TV audiences, so expect it to go straight to the top of the charts. In case the band become the next Steps, they've already signed a five-album deal with Polydor. Fittingly, the show by its very nature dispels any notion that the contestants are in it for anything other than fame. Judging from the experience Down Under, viewers will relish having cute young wannabes to root for.

fields.headline: Possession: the Movie
fields.standfirst: A.S. Byatt is no stranger to having her work adapted for the screen, but 2001 will be a bumper year for the Booker Prize winner
fields.trailText: A.S. Byatt is no stranger to having her work adapted for the screen, but 2001 will be a bumper year for the Booker Prize winner.
fields.body:
Next year will be an interesting one for A.S. Byatt and her fans, with foreign directors taking a lively interest in her work.

The American director Philip Haas, whose Angels & Insects (an adaptation of Dame Antonia's novella, Morpho Eugenia) was shown in competition at Cannes five years ago, is preparing a version of its companion novella of Victorian cultural life. The Conjugal Angel, to be called The Seance, will possibly star Helen Mirren as Emily Tennyson, the Poet Laureate's wife.

Meanwhile, the Australian filmmaker George Miller, who was pleased and astonished to hear that Byatt was a great admirer of his Mad Max movies, is working on an adaptation of her adult fairy story, The Djinn in the Nightingale's Eye.

But the movie I'm really looking forward to is Neil LaBute's Possession, based on Byatt's 1990 Booker Prize-winning novel. This marvellous novel, deceptively subtitled 'A Romance' but the kind of thing that gives postmodernism a good name, has parallel plots and is about two late twentieth-century academics who live through and fight over the lives of a pair of Victorian poets, Christabel LaMotte and Randolph Henry Ash.

It's a fiendishly difficult book to adapt, mainly because it's very literary (letters and poems, some 10 pages long, are part of its texture), but partly because for the past decade it's been taught in universities around the world, and a very discerning audience will be awaiting it.

The film has been on the stocks for some years, and there have been rumours of unsuccessful scripts, of Jane Campion being a possible director, and Sean Connery playing the Browningesque Ash. Now it's in post-production after location shooting in England and France, with Gwyneth Paltrow (sporting another English accent) and LaBute regular Aaron Eckhart as the present-day writers, and Jeremy Northam and Jennifer Ehle as the Victorians.

LaBute's three previous films - In the Company of Men, Your Friends and Neighbours and Nurse Betty - show him to be a man of literary bent with a strong interest in language; early in his career, he had a graduate fellowship to study at the Royal Court in London, so he's no stranger to this country.

Dame Antonia, though not involved in the scripting or production, has apparently taken a lively interest in the movie, and has from time to time tendered advice. On a visit to the set, she was very impressed by the look of the film and the work of the production designer, and is pleased that the ending remains that of the novel.

'You get the feeling of people working on something they're excited about,' she told me. 'You never know, of course, how things will turn out, but the auguries are good and I'm looking forward to seeing Possession in the summer.'

fields.headline: Guess who's coming to dinner
fields.standfirst: Anthony Hopkins is back, along with a Texan Bridget Jones, a Californian Mayor of Casterbridge, and Ken Loach in LA
fields.trailText: Anthony Hopkins is back, along with a Texan Bridget Jones, a Californian Mayor of Casterbridge, and Ken Loach in LA.
fields.body:
Kung-fu, drugs and rock 'n' roll are a heady mixture. They provide the basic ingredients to the new year's opening batch of superior films. January will be a good month for movie-going, with the opening of the three films that topped the autumn class of Oscar hopefuls in the States. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Traffic and Almost Famous are compelling choices from three of the most entertaining and thoughtful filmmakers currently working in Hollywood: Ang Lee, Steven Soderbergh and Cameron Crowe. With a Hollywood strike looming, prestige movies could theoretically soon be few and far between.

Lee's Chinese-language martial arts epic Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon was not filmed in Hollywood, but its stunning marriage of action and drama, myth and romance make it wonderfully accessible. Traffic, directed by the resurgent wunderkind Soderbergh and starring Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas, is an ambitious and complex film that looks at the drugs trade from every available angle, admirably steering clear of moral judgments and earning comparison with Z and The Battle of Algiers. Crowe's semi-autobiographical Almost Famous is a bitter-sweet coming-of-age film set in the early Seventies about a 15-year-old rock journalist (memorably played by the wide-eyed Patrick Fugit) who joins an up and coming band for their eventful north American tour.

Two other films that succeeded in the States and are due for imminent release are Cast Away (12 January), with Tom Hanks as a modern-day Robinson Crusoe, and What Women Want (2 February), a high-concept fantasy about a lecherous ad man who can read women's thoughts, in which Mel Gibson makes an engaging romantic comedy debut.

The coming year also promises to throw up answers to a number of fascinating conundrums. If the reports are to believed, Leonardo DiCaprio spent as much time partying and canoodling with supermodel Giselle as he did on the set of Martin Scorsese's period gangster epic Gangs of New York. Following the relative disappointments of The Beach and Bringing out the Dead, both careers could do with a boost. In contrast, hot from the success of Gladiator, Ridley Scott should be bulletproof, but by making Hannibal, the sequel to The Silence of the Lambs, he is back in the firing line. The film, which opens in February, is arguably the most eagerly anticipated sequel since The Godfather Part II. Like the second Godfather movie, the cast has seen some changes: Anthony Hopkins is back but Jodie Foster makes way for another cerebral performer - Julianne Moore.

The adaptation of Thomas Harris's bestseller is one of a handful of big books heading for the big screen in 2001. There is the daring and box-office friendly casting of Texan Renée Zellweger as the eponymous Sloane Ranger in Bridget Jones's Diary (summer), counting the calories as well as the cost of getting involved with unsuitable Hoorays. Colin Firth and Hugh Grant provide the beefcake. Nicolas Cage, currently showing his softer side in Family Man, gives it another outing in Captain Corelli's Mandolin (scheduled for May), the Second World War romance directed by John Madden (Shakespeare in Love) and co-starring Penelope Cruz. This could be big year for Cruz, who also stars alongside cowboy Matt Damon in the western All The Pretty Horses, adapted from Cormac McCarthy's bestseller and directed by Billy Bob Thornton. Towards the end of the year, she'll appear with Tom Cruise in Vanilla Sky, the remake of the mind-bending Spanish thriller Open Your Eyes.

But the year's most interesting excursion into the Wild West is likely to be prolific British director Michael Winterbottom's The Claim (2 February), a reworking of The Mayor of Casterbridge transposed to the Californian gold rush, which has great advance word.

Closer to home, a number of new filmmakers are set to emerge in the coming months. Apart from the jubilation that greeted Billy Elliot, last year's homegrown screen fillers were a generally unin spiring crop. Thankfully, next year looks promising. First, Jonathan Glazer's colourful gangster movie Sexy Beast, released next month, will bring zest to a worryingly moribund genre; Jamie Thraves's loose and languid portrait of twentysomething slackerdom, The Lowdown (26 Jan), is both rewarding and frustrating. But The Last Resort (16 March) is probably the best of the Brit bunch. Paul Pawlikowski's artful tale of a Russian asylum seeker and her unlikely romance won the Best New British Feature award at the Edinburgh Film Festival and deserves to be a success.

There are also interesting movies from a couple of established British directors. Ken Loach changes his locale to Los Angeles but raises familiar social issues in the strike drama Bread and Roses (27 April). In similar vein, writer Jimmy McGovern and director Stephen Frears collaborate in Liam (23 February), a Depression-era drama about a family riven by fascism.

Another festival favourite due for release on 9 February is the Swedish film Faithless, Liv Ullmann's examination of the fallout from a middle-aged affair, written and apparently inspired by Ingmar Bergman. Finally, 'The Dancer in the Dark award' for Scandinavian eccentricity should go to director Ray Andersson for Songs from the Second Floor (16 February), a quasi-musical about modern disaffection and individual angst. And no, Björk isn't in it.

webTitle: Leader: Let's be proud of what we're good at...

fields.headline: Let's be proud of what we're good at...
fields.standfirst: ...and start behaving like a first-rate country
fields.trailText: ...and start behaving like a first-rate country.
fields.body:
New year's resolutions remind us that things can get better in the year ahead. Just as important, they remind us that, as individuals, we are more able than anyone else to be the engine of that improvement. Britannia has enjoyed more than 1,900 new years since her invention - by Antoninus Pius, to decorate a new coin, since you ask. What might her resolutions be this New Year's Eve for the nation from which she took her name (apart from her age-old pledges to visit her mum more often and lose a couple of librae by joining a gymnasium)?

Start behaving like a well-off country

Britain is the fourth strongest economy in the world, yet we have schools with leaking roofs, overflowing hospitals, a million children living in poverty and a farcical rail system. We believe we cannot afford residential care for our elderly unless they sell their homes, we cannot buy books for many of our schools unless their pupils run jumble sales and we cannot educate our young people at university unless they take out massive loans. Everywhere we look, our country is scarred by public squalor alongside much-vaunted private affluence. It does not have to be so.

Start behaving like a confident country

'We won the war, in 1944,' went the schoolboy chant. Sadly, for too many Britons now grown up, the Leitmotiv (yes, whisper it, a German word) hasn't changed. We enjoy one of the highest levels of international trade in the world. We have no reason to be frightened by our proximity to Europe, just good reason to be exhilarated by it. Of course, we don't want the French running our local councils (just as they wouldn't want us running their restaurants. Or their railways). But if we can play football with Argentina, we can allow a German European Commissioner to propose pension levels for European Court clerks.

Start behaving like a tolerant country

The horrible attempts to demonise asylum-seekers in 2000 betrayed one of our most unpleasant national characteristics, our - albeit occasional - willingness to scapegoat vulnerable or minority groups (if they're both, so much the better). We are sophisticated enough as a nation to celebrate our fantastic cultural diversity, which is not just racial, but religious, regional and sexual. It's time we laughed gently at, rather than took seriously, those groups which resent their age-old power being shared with others. Even in the last week, we have seen frothing outrage at the possibility of women soldiers serving on the front line. Tabloid Britain should no more be threatened by corporals in camisoles than by vicars in knickers.

Start behaving like a relaxed country

Why do we always think we must win the World Cup and the European Football Championship and the Rugby World Cup? We have a similar population to the Ukraine. We invented soccer, rugby and cricket and then popularised them around the world. We shouldn't be resentful that other countries now sometimes beat our home nations. Our harvest of medals at the Olympics and the recent victories in three Test series are remarkable achievements, not entitlements. And anyway, what about our actors? And opera singers? And novelists? And playwrights? J.K. Rowling is a worldwide bestseller.

Start behaving like a mature country

Our tendency to be mean-spirited or sneering does not do us justice. Tate Modern, the Walsall Art Gallery and the refurbished Somerset House are all triumphs which should overshadow the Dome. Our obsession with celebrity, particularly that which inhabits the House of Windsor, can demean us. And our acceptance of a bruising and petty level of public and political discourse too often offers a tacit endorsement of it.

After an anxious start to the new millennium, Britain could profitably become a more generous and open-minded nation. The Observer, a dogged student of the human condition since 1791, knows only too well that Britannia will not achieve all the New Year's resolutions we propose for her in 2001. But we live in hope. Happy New Year.

fields.headline: Labour advisers branded 'useless'
fields.standfirst:
Some of the 200 task forces set up since 1997 are yet to publish advice

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government has set up more than 200 task forces and advisory bodies since coming to power, many of which have failed to publish any advice at all.
fields.body:
The government has set up more than 200 task forces and advisory bodies since coming to power, many of which have failed to publish any advice at all.

A report passed to The Observer reveals that, since June 1997, at a cost of hundreds of thousands of pounds, Labour has sanctioned the setting up of 238 'task forces, ad hoc advisory groups and reviews'.

The 88-page government document reveals that more than 1,500 people are employed to give outside advice. The bodies examine subjects as diverse as which statue to put on the vacant plinth in Trafalgar Square and how to organise national dance and drama awards.

'This is a costly and wasteful exercise,' said Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP.

'It shows a government which cannot make a decision but kicks everything into the long grass by setting up a review or a task force. It is an abdication of responsibility.'

The Government has refused to put a total cost on the task forces but it is believed that running such a bureaucratic system costs the taxpayer hundreds of thousands of pounds a year.

The Department for Education and Employment comes top of the league table for having set up the largest number of task forces. David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, has agreed to 60 reviews, including one on citizenship, one on the nutritional standards of school dinners and another called the gifted pupils advisory group.

The reports published or due to be published by each body are also listed. Ones where the 'reports' column is blank include the headteachers' focus group for excellence in cities, which was set up in March 1999; the graduate apprenticeship national steering group set up last March; and the sixth form funding partners group.

The Department of Health has set up more than 50 reviews, in stark contrast to more traditional departments. The Foreign Office, for example, has three continuing review bodies while the Ministry of Defence has two.

Many civil servants are irritated by the large number of outside experts being brought in to advise the Government.

'There is a concern that our role as neutral observers and experts is being usurped by so many people coming in with special interests, particularly from the private sector,' said one senior civil servant.

The list of review bodies also reveals where Tony Blair wants to see more being done. Task forces have been set up to look at the modernisation of the health service, the crisis in the transport system and school standards.

Government advisers defended the setting up of the groups, saying they were an essential part of getting fresh thinking into Whitehall.

'Our own officials can sometimes be conservative and not think about wider options,' one Government adviser said. 'We have to improve the policy process so that more is done on the ground. Good ideas can come from anywhere. We have to cast the net widely.'

The Prime Minister has indicated that he wants to make a radical overhaul of the Whitehall system a priority if he wins a second term. He has signalled his frustration that, despite more spending on public services, the voters have yet to see significant improvements.

If in doubt set up a task force...

Home Office

Set up November 1997

Published reports: None

Mobile phone review group

Health Department

Set up June 1999

Published reports: May 2000, said evidence on health risks was 'inconclusive'

Hunting with dogs review group

Home Office

Set up December 1999

Published reports: June 2000, said that foxes' welfare was 'seriously compromised' by hunting

Lord Chancellor's Department

Set up November 1999

Published reports: None

Advisory group on nutritional standards for school lunches

Education Department

Set up February 2000

Published reports: None

Older volunteers working group

Home Office

Set up December 1997

Published reports: None

Music industry forum

Culture Media and Sport Dept

Set up January 1998

Published reports: None

webTitle: Former spies to be given a licence to tell

fields.headline: Former spies to be given a licence to tell
fields.standfirst:
The Official Secrets Act is about to undergo radical reforms to allow former spies to publish their memoirs

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Britain's top spies will be given the right to publish their memoirs under sweeping plans being drawn up to replace the current tough official secrets laws,  The Observer has learnt.
fields.body:
Britain's top spies will be given the right to publish their memoirs under sweeping plans being drawn up to replace the current tough official secrets laws, The Observer has learnt.

A series of high-profile court cases and the impending publication of the memoirs of former MI5 chief Stella Rimington have forced Ministers and senior civil servants to draw up plans for legislation to replace the Official Secrets Act if Labour wins the next election.

The existing Act was drafted before the collapse of the Soviet Union and was fiercely criticised by the Labour Party in opposition when it was introduced in 1989.

Ministers now believe that the more draconian elements of the Act have become irrelevant in the post-Cold War era. The reforms, which would affect military and intelligence staff, would mean that only those accused of the most serious breaches of national security would face prosecution. As it stands, there is not even a definition of 'national security' in British law.

Ministers are determined to bring British official secrecy legislation closer to the American system, where former intelligence officers can publish memoirs with the approval of an independent committee. At present, members of the British intelligence services are pledged to secrecy for life. It is likely that reforms would also give more teeth to the parliamentary Intelligence and Security Committee, which oversees the work of MI5 and MI6.

Senior officials at the Home Office and the Ministry of Defence are already working on a definition of national security based on advice from the Defence Advisory Committee, which produces guidelines for journalists and editors on official secrecy matters.

Minutes from the December meeting of the committee show that this process is well under way in relation to the new Human Rights and Freedom of Information legislation, where government officials have been instructed to use only the strictest definition of a breach of national security - 'when there is a grave threat to the State'.

The intelligence services and senior Whitehall officials are braced for reform, but will wait for the outcome of the trial of former MI5 officer David Shayler in April before acting. Lawyers for Shayler will argue that the Official Secrets Act breaches his right to freedom of expression under new human rights legislation. In particular, the Act does not let Shayler claim he was acting in the public interest when he made allegations about incompetence and illegal activity in the intelligence services. If he wins, the already shaky legislation will be left in tatters.

The driving force behind the reforms is the Attorney-General, Lord Williams of Mostyn, who is known to be furious about a series of embarrassing official secrets cases brought against journalists and their sources.

In November, Lord Williams was forced to intervene to have the case against Lieutenant-Colonel Nigel Wylde dropped due to a lack of evidence. Wylde was accused of passing information to journalist Tony Geraghty about intelligence activity in Northern Ireland.

A similar case involving the Northern Ireland editor of the Sunday Times, Liam Clarke, and undercover agent 'Martin Ingram' was also dropped. This year The Observer and the Guardian fought off attempts by the police to obtain material relating to the Shayler case.

There is also likely to be pressure from Lord Chancellor Derry Irvine, who said: 'Newspapers could be prosecuted for disclosing an Irangate in this country.'

Deborah Clark, director of public affairs at the civil rights organisation Liberty, said: 'Successive governments have used an extensive framework of secrecy to suppress information and prosecute whistle-blowers on the ground of national security. Half-hearted measures will not do, it must make amends by narrowly defining 'national security' and allowing access to information which doesn't pose a risk to it.'

Though he rejected attempts by Liberal Democrat MP David Heath to reform the Act by introduc-ing a new clause into the Freedom of Information legislation, he admitted that he was not opposed to reform.

webTitle: Everybody's talking about Spencer Treat Clark

fields.headline: Spencer Treat Clark
fields.standfirst: Unbreakable boy wonder
fields.trailText: Spencer Treat Clark, Unbreakable boy wonder
fields.body:
Even the people in the movie business still struggling to spell M. Night Shyamalan's name know this much: he's good with kids. Haley Joel Osment's performance in The Sixth Sense might have been a one-off, but the few people who saw Shyamalan's previous film, Wide Awake, all remarked on how he had coaxed uncommonly natural performances from the children.

So it comes as no surprise that the truly outstanding scene in Shyamalan's new film Unbreakable also involves a child actor. It would be giving too much away to say much more, but the kid is Spencer Treat Clark, who plays the son of a disintegrating couple, Bruce Willis and Robin Wright Penn. The boy rebuilds his relationship with his father after Willis survives a massive accident and strange things start to happen.

There has been the usual PR nonsense about how the Unbreakable casting people trawled the length and breadth of America for a boy 'who could project genuine emotion with an honesty and understanding... qualities of realism'. If they did, they wasted a lot of time watching untrained brats in the Midwest, because the child they used - elfin 13-year-old Clark - is a hardened Hollywood pro with two big hit movies behind him. He was Ashley Judd's son in the successful if deeply mediocre Double Jeopardy, and he was little Lucius, spawn of the imperial family and dedicated fight fan in Gladiator. And before that, he was Jeff Bridges's son in the conspiracy thriller, Arlington Road.

He got his start aged eight on Another World, one of America's long-running daytime soaps, and stayed in the cast for four years, on and off, with breaks to make television movies. Then Arlington Road came along, and he was pitched into the serious movie business. With adolescence closing in fast, though, he might have to cash in now while his freckles are still endearing.

Five things you should know about Spencer Treat Clark

1. Spencer was born on 24 September 1987.

2. His cinematic parents so far have included Jeff Bridges, Bruce Greenwood and Ashley Judd, Connie Nielsen, and Bruce Willis and Robin Wright Penn.

3. He was the third actor to play the role of Steven Frame on the soap Another World.

4. 'Acting on Another World has meant everything to me,' he claimed when the show was cancelled after 35 years.

5. The feature films he has appeared in average a big-league $100 million at the box office.
