fields.headline: Legionnaire disease hits model hospital
fields.trailText: A state-of-the-art new Paris hospital, hailed by President Jacques Chirac as a model for twenty-first century health care, yesterday declared a state of emergency after four patients were found to be suffering from legionnaires' disease.
fields.body:
A state-of-the-art new Paris hospital, hailed by President Jacques Chirac as a model for twenty-first century health care, yesterday declared a state of emergency after four patients were found to be suffering from legionnaires' disease.

'One isolated case isn't serious, two is irritating, but four - that's really disturbing,' said Professor Jean-Yves Fagon, head of the hospital's intensive care unit. Twenty-three people have died of the disease in the Paris region alone this year.

The first case of the disease was detected at the European Hospital Georges Pompidou in Paris on 12 December and a second on 18 December. Three days later, on 21 December, Chirac and other French dignitaries, including former Prime Minister Edouard Balladur and Paris Mayor Jean Tibéri, trumpeted the technological triumph of the revolutionary 827-bed hospital at its inaugration ceremony.

Two more cases of the disease were found last week and two more are suspected at the hospital. Now the outbreak has become a huge embarrassment to one of the most ambitious health care projects in French history. One of the four patients has since died but not, according to a hospital spokesman, because of legionnaires' disease. Some services had been closed pending an investigation. Patients have been prohibited from taking showers until the cause of the outbreak can be detected.

Outbreaks of legionnaires' disease, a form of pneumonia, are caused by water contaminated with bacteria. Exposure can come from shower heads, taps and drinking water, aerosol mists and cooling towers.

Those at most risk of infection are people with weakened immune systems, and with chronic lung disease. People on dialysis and those receiving chemotherapy are vulnerable too. According to hospital sources, most of the cases were discovered at the cardio-vascular surgery unit.

The European Hospital Georges Pompidou in south-west Paris, which opened to patients in July, has been touted as the hospital of the future. Twenty years in gestation, it was designed to revolutionise health care.

Multidisciplinary teams move around the patient rather than the other way round. Services are clustered in groups so that the specialist comes to the patient. Patients arrive at one of 22 different reception points to be met by a personal hostess, who guides them to their private room, where the computer is at the bottom of the bed, case notes are computerised and robots carry out operations. It has swimming pools, health clubs and cafés. There are even indoor palm trees, in a glass-topped, 220-yard galleria.

But the hospital has been plagued with problems. When it threw open its doors to the public this summer, two years later than planned, it was not able to receive patients. The logistical difficulties of transferring patients from three old hospitals serving a region of 570,000 people and merging more than 5,000 medical staff into one team proved too much. But, even before the first patients arrived, the hospital was consuming a budget of £130 million every 18 months. Over the intervening months, patients have been transferred, but the process has been remarkably slow, chiefly because the computer systems have broken down repeatedly. This month porters went on strike to demand more staff. The hospital is not expected to be fully functioning until the middle of next year.

At the inauguration ceremony just before Christmas, Chirac tried to reassure protesting staff. 'This hospital prefigures what the hospital of the twenty-first century will have to be like.' As the search for the cause of the outbreak of legionnaires' disease goes on today, France's medical profession must be hoping that Chirac is wrong.

Three days later, on 21 December, Chirac and other French dignitaries, including former Prime Minister Edouard Balladur and Paris Mayor Jean Tibéri, trumpeted the technological triumph of the revolutionary 827-bed hospital at its inaugration ceremony. Two more cases of the disease were found last week and two more are suspected at the hospital. Now the outbreak has become a huge embarrassment to one of the most ambitious health care projects in French history. One of the four patients has since died but not, according to a hospital spokesman, because of legionnaires' disease. Some services had been closed pending an investigation. Patients have been prohibited from taking showers until the cause of the outbreak can be detected. Outbreaks of legionnaires' disease, a form of pneumonia, are caused by water contaminated with bacteria. Exposure can come from shower heads, taps and drinking water, aerosol mists and cooling towers. Those at most risk of infection are people with weakened immune systems, and with chronic lung disease. People on dialysis and those receiving chemotherapy are vulnerable too. According to hospital sources, most of the cases were discovered at the cardio-vascular surgery unit. The European Hospital Georges Pompidou in south-west Paris, which opened to patients in July, has been touted as the hospital of the future. Twenty years in gestation, it was designed to revolutionise health care. Multidisciplinary teams move around the patient rather than the other way round. Services are clustered in groups so that the specialist comes to the patient. Patients arrive at one of 22 different reception points to be met by a personal hostess, who guides them to their private room, where the computer is at the bottom of the bed, case notes are computerised and robots carry out operations. It has swimming pools, health clubs and cafés. There are even indoor palm trees, in a glass-topped, 220-yard galleria. But the hospital has been plagued with problems. When it threw open its doors to the public this summer, two years later than planned, it was not able to receive patients. The logistical difficulties of transferring patients from three old hospitals serving a region of 570,000 people and merging more than 5,000 medical staff into one team proved too much. But, even before the first patients arrived, the hospital was consuming a budget of £130 million every 18 months. Over the intervening months, patients have been transferred, but the process has been remarkably slow, chiefly because the computer systems have broken down repeatedly. This month porters went on strike to demand more staff. The hospital is not expected to be fully functioning until the middle of next year. At the inauguration ceremony just before Christmas, Chirac tried to reassure protesting staff. 'This hospital prefigures what the hospital of the twenty-first century will have to be like.' As the search for the cause of the outbreak of legionnaires' disease goes on today, France's medical profession must be hoping that Chirac is wrong.

webTitle: Internet sex video blights career of Korean pop star

fields.headline: Internet sex video blights career of Korean pop star
fields.trailText: She was the country's top female pop star, a budding diva whose sexy moves scandalised older South Koreans and made her a huge star among the young. Then 'the video' hit the internet.
fields.body:
She was the country's top female pop star, a budding diva whose sexy moves scandalised older South Koreans and made her a huge star among the young. Then 'the video' hit the internet.

A brief cyberwar broke out. Fans of the singer, Baek Ji Young, tried to paralyse internet sites offering a video showing Baek having sex with a former producer. But the web's voracious nature could not be denied. The video clip multiplied and raced across the net, reportedly at a rate of 200,000 copies in a day. Baek, 24, at first hid on an island and denied she was the woman in the video. But then she held a tearful news conference to confess and apologise.

The star was the casualty of a clash of cultures. South Korea is one of the most 'wired' countries in the world, but it is also a traditional society in which sex is seen as a private matter and premarital sex is a scandal.

Baek is not the first casualty. Miss Korea 1988, Oh Hyun Kyung, 30, fled an acting career and South Korea last year after a video of her having sex with a boyfriend hit the internet. Since an estimated third of South Korea's 47 million people use the internet, one of the highest rates in the world, 'it was like branding her with a scarlet letter', one observer said. The internet and new forms of communication are 'changing Korean society very rapidly', said Henry Paik, a showbusiness columnist. 'But this still isn't America or Europe. Here, if you have premarital sex, you are treated like a criminal.'

There is a grudging suspicion in South Korea that this is all somehow the fault of the United States. Censors used to clip risqué parts out of American movies and videotapes. Now the internet and DVD have bypassed them. American rap has spawned Korean rap, complete with profanity. A local performer, Seo Tai Ji, has just released a music video with explicit sex and nudity.

'Times are changing too fast,' grumbled Oh Kwang Hwan, 55, an estate agent. 'I was shocked that the younger generation could even come up with an idea like making a sex video and putting it on the internet.'

Two male celebrities have also been caught in recent sex scandals. An actor, Song Young Chang, 42, was sentenced in November to 10 months in prison for having sex with a 16-year-old girl. Joo Byung Jin, who runs a TV production company, was charged last month with beating a student after forcing her to have sex.

These latest scandals show that the entertainment industry's sordid reputation is in some ways still deserved, said Paik. 'There used to be three ways to get into the business: bribery, sex or political influence,' he said. Although changes in the industry have reduced the power of producers and directors, he said, those are still familiar routes to success.

Baek's video offers a poignant example. The first half, apparently shot two years ago, shows her nervously practising imaginary media interviews under the direction of the producer. In the second half, they have sex. Baek insists she did not know the camera was rolling.

The ex-producer, Kim Si Won, has disputed her claims of ignorance. 'We watched it together afterwards and enjoyed it,' he said.

Others are also cynical about Baek's claims. Paik said it was not uncommon for managers or producers to insist that starlets make such videos, in case the woman tries to dump her old associates after she becomes successful. The speed of the internet makes such weapons more potent.

'Ten years ago these things ended with just a few rumours,' Paik said. 'Now the evidence goes out on the web.'

webTitle: Serial killer's confession leads to trail of care home abuses

fields.headline: Serial killer's confession leads to trail of care home abuses
fields.standfirst: French police believe bus driver's victims may be the tip of an iceberg as they probe cases of missing girls
fields.trailText: French police believe bus driver's victims may be the tip of an iceberg as they probe cases of missing girls.
fields.body:
A retired bus driver's confession that he murdered seven mentally handicapped young women in northern Burgundy 20 years ago has unveiled a series of sex crimes and raised the possibility of the active involvement of the French social services.

Emile Louis, 66, who drove young people in social services' care between their foster homes and schools during the late Seventies, said he had sex with the women, to which they freely consented. He confessed he had felt 'uncontrollable urges' to murder his victims, aged between 16 and 29.

Louis told police he buried all seven bodies on the banks of the River Serein in Rouvray, near Auxerre. So far only one female skeleton has been found and it has yet to be identified.

Louis cannot be convicted for the killings because under French law a suspect cannot be charged with murder more than 10 years after the crimes. Families of the victims have called for the time period of 10 years to start from the date when the bodies are found. Louis is being held for kidnapping, for which there is no statute of limitations. But, if the bodies are found and identified, Louis could be freed, since he cannot be charged with their murder.

The case of the disparues has shocked France and left many questions unanswered. How could seven young women, several of whom had no living natural parents, simply disappear without the affair causing a national scandal at the time?

Why did police investigators fail to spot the links between the disappearances, when several women lived with foster families in the same small village and four went to the same school in Auxerre? Why did they and the social services think each girl was a runaway? How could Louis, who has served jail terms for sexual offences, not have been charged with their murders?

But Louis's case may just be the tip of the iceberg in a region coming under intense scrutiny for its police and judicial incompetence as well as for the dubious management of its homes for handicapped children.

In another case, a 19-year-old girl called Huguette was found wandering the streets of Auxerre in January 1984. She told police she had been chained up for nearly three months in a cellar under a house in a nearby village. She claimed to have been tortured and raped, and told police that another girl was still there. Police officers found Michaela, 22, in the cellar, naked and suspended from a ladder by her wrists.

The owners of the house, Claude and Monique Dunand, had placed small ads in local papers and at employment agencies to recruit girls to look after 'an ageing, sick aunt'. From the applicants, Claude Dunand always chose handicapped girls in the care of the local social services.

Over 15 years, he locked girls in the cellar of the house, fed them dog food and then invited guests round to torture and kill his victims. 'He had a slate,' said his lawyer, Jean-Yves Linard, 'on which he would write in chalk the day's menu, how much to burn their breasts and so on.'

Dunand was jailed for life in 1991 for rape, kidnapping, sexual assault and torture, and his wife jailed for two years. But no bodies have been found, nor have any of Dunand's clients been traced.

'We always had the impression that there was another party, and that there were bodies that hadn't been found,' said Linard. 'It was absolutely impossible, when one saw the state of the two young girls who escaped at the edge of death, to imagine that there were not others. But where they are is an absolute mystery.'

In a third case in Auxerre, the general secretary of an association for handicapped adults and children (APJH), Pierre Charrier, was jailed for six years for rape in 1992. During his trial it emerged that for more than a year he had raped a 23-year-old mentally handicapped woman in the back of his car each week after choir practice while a boy stood guard. Charrier's wife, Nicole, still runs an APJH home near Auxerre.

Charrier and Emile Louis, who is now one of France's most notorious serial killers, were friends during the Seventies and Eighties. 'My husband had excellent relations with Mr and Mrs Charrier, and they came to our house at least twice,' said Louis's first wife, Simone Delagneau.

When Louis appeared in court in the early Eighties charged with sexually assaulting a minor, Mrs Char rier wrote to the judge protesting Louis's innocence. None the less he was sentenced to five years' jail, reduced to four on appeal.

In 1993, a report criticised APJH management for inappropriate behaviour at its homes. Last week a former teacher with the APJH disclosed she had made official complaints about the behaviour of staff at a home in Auxerre where she worked in the late Eighties, but nothing was done.

'At the time, I was shocked by their behaviour,' said Bernadette Petitcollot, who recalled seeing managers show their breasts and buttocks to a handicapped girl who ran away. She said these managers had worked at a school where four of Louis's victims were students.

Louis is now suspected of murdering at least three more girls who disappeared from the Auxerre region in the Seventies. Pierre Gonzalez de Gaspard, a lawyer representing the seven victims' families, has given police the names of three girls in the care of the social services from whom nothing has been heard since the mid-Seventies.

Louis was also investigated for the murder of Sylviane Lesage-Durand, 22, another woman in care, whose naked body was found under a foot of manure in a barn in Rouvray in 1981. The case against him was dropped for lack of evidence and now he can never be charged.

Louis's name has been linked to the murder of a British student, Joanna Parrish. The naked, sexually abused body of Joanna, 20, was found in the River Yonne at Moneteau in May 1990. She had been working as a teacher's assistant for a year at a secondary school in Auxerre. But the examining magistrate in her case says there is no obvious link between her murder and Louis.

Louis was arrested this month after an eight-year private campaign by Pierre Monnoir, a travelling salesman whose mentally handicapped brother was institutionalised in Auxerre. He set up a local association to defend the rights of the mentally ill.

He came across rumours of the disappearances of young women from an Auxerre care home linked to Louis. He tracked down the families and tried to start legal action against the bus driver. The only police officer who believed Louis was linked to the disappearances was Christian Lambert, who had been suspicious of Louis and said in 1997: 'For me, he is the sole suspect. But we can't prove anything against him.' Lambert was found dead two years ago with a bullet through his head.

On 13 December Louis was finally arrested after a chance discovery by his eldest, estranged daughter. She had been examining a trunk of old clothes at his former home in Villefargeau, near Auxerre, and found women's clothes. Investigators found that they included a coat that belonged to a girl who had disappeared.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Teenage killers lead Japanese youth crime wave
fields.body:
Teenage killers lead Japanese youth crime wave

Two 16-year-olds have been arrested in Japan for stabbing a taxi driver to death, the latest in a series of murders by young people. The teenage lovers are said to have told police they killed the driver to steal money in order to live together. Japan has traditionally enjoyed a low crime rate, but in the past year teen crime has generated a new phrase, '17 and deadly'.

America wraps up warm

As the first snow of the season fell along the east coast of America yesterday, New York and Boston braced themselves for blizzards and up to 1ft of snow. Shops reported bulk grocery buying and a run on shovels and boots.

Gun battle in Kashmir leaves eight guerrillas dead

Ten people including eight separatist guerrillas were killed yesterday in India's strife-torn Jammu and Kashmir state. Police said al-Badr militants fired on a security patrol yesterday 87km north-west of Srinagar. The al-Badr militant group is fighting for Kashmir's merger with neighbouring Pakistan.

Mugabe guards kill intruder

Police shot dead a man who tried to run into President Robert Mugabe's office in Harare. A spokesman said yesterday that a man ran past police at the State House gate, ignoring warning shots. Mugabe had already left Harare earlier in the day for Malaysia.

Israelis shoot Lebanese man

Israeli soldiers shot dead a Lebanese man at the border between the two countries yesterday. Witnesses said Israeli troops in security cars shot Hilal al-Hajj, 22, in the head at the Fatma Gate crossing as he walked with friends on the Lebanese side near a group of people throwing stones. Hilal was the first Lebanese to be killed since May.

Gadaffi wants global role

Libyan leader Muammar Gadaffi told a German newspaper yesterday that Libya welcomed globalisation. Those who opposed it would be considered reactionary.

webTitle: Montenegro poll will ring death knell of Yugoslavia

fields.headline: Montenegro poll will ring death knell of Yugoslavia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugslavia's President, Vojislav Kostunica, yesterday pleaded with Montenegro to remain in the Yugoslav federation as Montenegro's leader insisted on a referendum on his country's secession that would ring the death knell of Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
Yugslavia's President, Vojislav Kostunica, yesterday pleaded with Montenegro to remain in the Yugoslav federation as Montenegro's leader insisted on a referendum on his country's secession that would ring the death knell of Yugoslavia.

As the two republics appeared set on a collision course over the smaller country's desire for independence, President Kostunica said that Serbia and Montenegro should stay together because 'everything that connects Serbia and Montenegro historically, spiritually and culturally, is stronger and deeper than what divides them'. He added: 'If we stay together, all doors in Europe will be open to us.'

But in a defiant year-end message in the main Montenegrin paper Pobjeda , Djukanovic said: 'We want to run our own state, but Kostunica also wants to run our state.'

Yugoslavia currently consists of Serbia (including Kosovo) and Montenegro. It was remodelled in 1992 by Slobodan Milosevic, the former Serbian and Yugoslav leader, after the collapse of the old six-republic Yugoslavia. But since 1997 Montenegro has been independent in all but name.

After crisis talks in the Montenegrin capital of Podgorica last week, two parties in the governing coalition endorsed an independence plan on Thursday night, while a third, minor coalition party opposed to independence walked out of the government.

The independence 'platform' must be endorsed by parliament, but if the government cannot muster enough votes a general election will be called.

Montenegrin government sources believe that, with the votes of hardline pro-independence deputies from the Liberal Party, the 'platform' will be approved and the need for new elections avoided.

Until the fall of Milosevic last October, many Montenegrins and foreign analysts feared that moves towards independence would be met by a Belgrade-inspired coup in Podgorica, or even a civil war. Those fears have now evaporated.

Last week the Montenegrin President, Milo Djukanovic, went to Belgrade for the first time since 1998. He demanded, and received, the sacking of top Yugoslav military officials in the republic, plus the disbandment of the much-feared pro-Serbian 7th Battalion. This will not be enough, however, to dampen the Montenegrin government's demand for independence.

In an interview, Djukanovic told The Observer that he saw Montenegro 'with renewed statehood and internationally recognised'.

In the next two weeks Serbia will constitute its new government, which must then sit down with the Montenegrins to negotiate. Djukanovic is offering Serbia a deal - he wants international recognition for both republics, which would then form a 'union' or 'alliance'. This would pool resources for defence, foreign policy and operate a common market.

Zoran Djindjic, soon to be confirmed as Serbia's new Prime Minister, agrees that constitutional changes need to be made, but disagrees that the end result should be two new, independent states.

For one thing, he says, if Montenegro becomes independent, then Serbia would most probably lose its claim to restore its sovereignty to Kosovo. But Djukanovic says Montenegro cannot remain a 'hostage' to Kosovo.

The most serious impediment to negotiating a common future, within a new federation or outside, is the imbalance between the two republics. Serbia has a population of eight million, while Montenegro's is 650,000. Negotiating an equal status for both is going to be difficult and, as far as Serbia's new leaders may be concerned, ultimately not worth the bother.

The most recent polls show that just over half of Montenegro's citizens are in favour of independence, but analysts expect this to rise to at least 60 per cent during the referendum campaign.

webTitle: Manila on alert as 14 die in terror bombings

fields.headline: Manila on alert as 14 die in terror bombings
fields.standfirst: Muslim rebels blamed for wave of bombs
fields.trailText: A wave of bombings in the Philippines capital Manila killed at least 14 people yesterday and wounded more than 100. Hidden bombs, the suspected work of Muslim rebels from the country's south, exploded at the airport, a park near the US embassy, a hotel and aboard a bus and a train.
fields.body:
A wave of bombings in the Philippines capital Manila killed at least 14 people yesterday and wounded more than 100. Hidden bombs, the suspected work of Muslim rebels from the country's south, exploded at the airport, a park near the US embassy, a hotel and aboard a bus and a train.

The most devastating explosion was in the front coach of a crowded train as it pulled into Blumentritt station. At least 11 people were killed and about 60 wounded. Bodies were laid out on the platform, including one of a young girl. One person was being questioned.

Mari Vicpaglan, a ticket clerk at the station, said: 'The train was approaching when I heard the explosion in the front coach. It was so loud. I tried to help them. I felt dizzy because of the number of people pleading for help.'

Minutes later a second bomb exploded at a bus terminal in the suburb of Quizon city, killing at least one and injuring 15, followed shortly by an explosion at a fuel depot at Manila's Ninoy Aquino airport. At least six were hurt but the depot did not explode.

The fourth bomb exploded on a bench in a park near the US embassy. At least one of the packages was disguised as a wrapped present which exploded as a policeman tried to defuse it. The first four bombs exploded almost simultaneously at around noon.

Panic quickly spread in the city of 12 million people after the explosions. Streets were deserted by early evening and the usually crowded shopping malls virtually empty.

'This is the work of animals, people without souls,' said Manila mayor, Lito Atienza, after the attacks. 'They have no compunction about killing innocent civilians.'

Suspicion for the bombings has fallen on the Abu Sayyaf Muslim rebel group, which is fighting government forces, mainly in the south of the country, and kidnapped a group of foreign tourists early this year.

The attacks come against a background of deep political turbulence, with embattled President Joseph Estrada on trial before the country's senate on corruption charges. Estrada is charged with bribery, betrayal of public trust and violating the constitution after governor Luis Singson, a former drinking companion of the president, claimed the president had pocketed more than $8 million in bribes.

A presidential spokesman dismissed opposition claims that the bombs could have been the handiwork of government agents trying to distract attention from Estrada's troubles.

In a televised address, Estrada said: 'I assure you we will use all the forces of our law to halt this violence. I have directed the chief of staff of the Armed Forces of the Philippines to mobilise its intelligence agencies.'

The bombings deepened the growing sense of crisis in Manila - the worst in a decade. Estrada's trial is due to resume on Tuesday and few are now banking on his political survival.

The attacks, however, had been anticipated. On Friday, all Manila-area police were put on alert for the New Year's holidays because of feared attacks by the extremists.

Police had arrested Abu Sayyaf spokesman Hector Janjalani in Manila on Thursday and said they expected retaliation for the arrest. They said that Janjalani was carrying grenades and sketches of potential targets in the city.

Estrada's press undersecretary, Mike Toledo, denied claims by the opposition yesterday that Estrada would declare a state of emergency after the bombs.

The attacks led to several commercial centres being evacuated throughout the day on false alarms. Light railway transit officials also said they will start opening all packages of passengers immediately as a security routine.

A bomb also exploded at a gas station near the Dusit hotel. One bomb expert was killed and another injured as they tried to defuse it.

The bomb, which exploded near the US embassy, wounded at least nine, blasting a 2ft crater in the ground and damaging buildings 200 yards from the embassy. The bomb apparently was not directed at the embassy itself.

Lonnie Kelley, acting spokesman at the US embassy, said the building was not damaged and knew of no injured staff members. No extra security measures were being taken.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Baroque art bonanza
fields.body:
Baroque art bonanza

More Italian Baroque paintings than have ever before been shown together in Britain will be on view in January at the Royal Academy. The exhibition of early seventeenth-century art, entitled The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 , includes works by Caravaggio and Rubens and will feature more than 145 paintings. The exhibition at London's Royal Academy in Piccadilly, central London, runs from 20 January to 16 April.

Parents join lost rower search

The parents of an Oxford University rower, who is missing in Spain after being swept away in a swollen river during a training session, left for Barcelona yesterday to join the search for their son. Leo Blockley, 21, of Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester, vanished from sight after his boat became waterlogged. Seventeen other squad members from two coxed eights were rescued during the freak storm.

Bid to cut building site deaths

A summit to be held in the new year aims to cut the 'shocking' level of fatalities in the building industry. Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott will meet construction firms, contractors, unions and designers in February. The news follows a major increase in the industry's fatality figures. In the first six months of 2000, there were 62 construction deaths in Britain, compared with 39 in the same period in 1999.
One in five smokers will decide to kick habit

More than two million Britons - around one in five smokers - will decide to kick the habit on New Year's Day, according to research from Quit, the charity which helps people give up. Last year about one in three people who tried to stop smoking succeeded. Those who seek help from their doctor or a support group are most likely to succeed, says the charity.

Bomb horror

A six-year-old girl suffered hand and foot injuries yesterday morning when she opened a letter bomb destined for a pest control company in Congleton, Cheshire.

Body identified

Murder squad detectives yesterday identified the body found in a shallow grave by a man walking his dog at a beauty spot near Wickham, Hampshire, last Wednesday. A post-mortem revealed that the remains were those of 24-year-old Lee Horrell who had been missing since November.

Baby death

A couple arrested after the decomposing body of a two-year-old boy was found in his cot have been released on bail. The man and woman had been held in custody since the discovery of the baby's body on Thursday, following a tip-off. Police have confirmed the child lay dead for two weeks over Christmas.

Laid to rest

Thirteen years after slipping into a coma following the Enniskillen Poppy Day bombing, Ronnie Hill has been laid to rest.

Mourners at the funeral of the 69-year-old former head teacher heard there had been 'no evidence of bitterness' from his wife Noreen towards those behind the attack.

Eleven people died and scores more were injured in one of Northern Ireland's worst atrocities.

Tardy swans

A late winter and much warmer average temperatures for the year have led to the late arrival in Britain of thousands of Bewick's swans, which migrate 2,500 miles from their breeding grounds in Arctic Russia.

Fatal knife attack plea

A detective yesterday urged anyone with information about the brutal knife attack last Wednesday, which left 22-year-old Julie-Ann Osborne dead, to come forward. Detective Chief Inspector Roy Suitters said the attack was 'horrendous'. 'There were multiple, multiple stab wounds,' he said. 'She tried to fight the attacker off and suffered_ wounds which left her fingers sliced.' Her body was found in the lower Shankill area of west Belfast. Police are questioning a man in connection with her death, one of five fatal stabbings in Northern Ireland over Christmas.

fields.headline: Police chief 'ran drugs protection racket'
fields.trailText: KwaZulu Natal is a land sacred to Zulus and Afrikaners alike. But it is being destroyed by a culture of corruption, with one of its top policemen accused of being its leading gangster.
fields.body:
KwaZulu Natal is a land sacred to Zulus and Afrikaners alike. But it is being destroyed by a culture of corruption, with one of its top policemen accused of being its leading gangster.

Piet Meyer, the suspended head of the province's organised crime unit, has been charged with running a protection syndicate involved in drugs and vice, and having a lifestyle more suited to that of a Colombian kingpin than of the notoriously low-paid South African police.

Meyer denies the charges, but will face trial in March - as long as the prosecution witnesses are still around. Lawyers have already complained of intimidation, but they were too late to save police officer Eric Tussie. A star witness against Meyer, he was shot dead outside a Durban nightclub.

Meyer's case is the tip of the iceberg in KwaZulu Natal, a province formed after the 1994 all-race elections by merging the old Zulu homelands with the National Party stronghold of Natal.

Racked by corruption and dissent, the province's police force has become a byword for corruption, fuelling South Africa's crime wave rather than fighting it.

Several senior officers from the Durban North station were charged with gross misconduct this year after they allowed drug-dealers awaiting trial to bring telephones, televisions, drinks and weightlifting equipment into the cells.

Conditions in the station were described as being like those of a luxury hotel - all-night orgies, attended by police and criminals, were common. One suspect in a fraud case was allowed to escape by walking out of the front door.

Another Durban police station, at Chatsworth, is even more notorious. Policemen stationed there masterminded South Africa's biggest armed robbery that netted more than £3 million. More than half the station's officers have been investigated for criminal activities, a quarter of its guns are unaccounted for and evidence in murder cases was being sold for £100. The situation got so bad that one local community group labelled the station as 'the major source of crime in Chatsworth - if not Durban'.

The problem with the police is only a symptom of a wider disease of corruption in the province, famed for its battlefields as first Afrikaner settlers and then the British fought with the Zulus.

'The problems with the police have got a lot of attention, but the real root cause of it is a culture of corruption that is deeper here than elsewhere in South Africa,' said Professor Tom Lodge, a political scientist at the University of the Witwatersrand.

The problem stems from the bloody conflicts that raged across the province during apartheid. The white-run state used its policemen as a political tool to crush black activists, running dirty tricks campaigns and murdering opposition leaders. Fighting crime was low on the list of priorities and transforming into an effective police force has been difficult for 'old school' officers.

But Zulu nationalism has also played a role, during an appalling turf war between the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) and the African National Congress that cost about 10,000 lives in the decade up to 1994.

The violence bred a culture of warlordism and gangsterism that is still widespread in the villages and teeming townships that surround most large towns. Some efforts have been made to clean up the province. At Chatsworth, scores of officers were transferred from the station in a successful bid to break up the crime rings operating there. The arrest rate jumped from 100 a month to 355 in the first two weeks after the shake-up.

But doubts remain over the political will of the national ANC government. After so much bloodshed there is an uneasy peace in the province. 'To some extent corruption is the price you pay for stability. The ANC has adopted a "don't rock the boat" strategy there,' Lodge said.

webTitle: Malevolent Seven grip Texas in fear

fields.headline: Malevolent Seven grip Texas in fear
fields.standfirst: Police powerless as an escaped gang of heavily armed murderers and rapists plans string of audacious crimes
fields.trailText: Police powerless as an escaped gang of heavily armed murderers and rapists plans string of audacious crimes.
fields.body:
They are being called the Malevolent Seven. One of them paid to have his wife shot in the head. Another beat a one-year-old child almost to death. There is another murderer among them and a serial rapist, all led by an armed robber once described as 'the most dangerous man in Texas'.

When they broke out of jail, seizing a small arsenal on the way, they left behind a written warning: 'You haven't heard the last of us.'

More than two weeks later the seven convicts are still at large, despite the largest manhunt in recent Texas history. They gunned down a policeman on Christmas Eve as they robbed a sports shop, where they took yet more guns, bringing their armoury to about 40 semi-automatics, pistols and shotguns. Police are investigating a number of other raids on the suspicion the fugitives were involved. The local press is already comparing them with the Bonnie and Clyde gang of the 1930s, this time without the romantic interest.

'The combination of planning, the number of them, the discipline and then the follow-up violent crime... I think is unprecedented,' John McAuliffe, inspector-general of the Texas criminal justice department, told reporters.

Given the unsavoury records of the fugitives, the notes they left behind and their rigid discipline so far, Texas police are fairly sure this is not just a jailbreak. They think the Malevolent Seven may be planning something spectacular.

'They are apparently on a mission, and it's a pretty dark mission,' said Lori Bailey, an FBI spokeswoman in Dallas. 'Does anybody know what that is right now? I don't think anybody does.'

But nobody is taking any chances. Heavier armaments are being distributed to police patrols. The relatives of at least one of the escaped convicts have left the state. Others have gone into hiding. The policemen who arrested them are taking precautions.

Until this month, the Texas authorities had an almost impeccable record for tracking down escaped convicts. Over the past 16 years they had caught 274 out of 275. The sole successful escapee is still on the run in Mexico. The last serious group break-out attempt was two years ago, when seven death row inmates escaped from the Ellis Unit prison in Huntsville leaving dummies in their beds. Six gave themselves up within the prison perimeter. The last, Martin Gurule, was found drowned a few days days later.

This time it is different. The seven have surprised everyone by sticking together despite the greater risk of being spotted as a group.

The secret behind their cohesion appears to be leadership. That leader is a 30-year-old El Paso criminal called George Rivas, who was serving a 99-year sentence for multiple armed robberies and kidnapping. He plans his operations meticulously, using disguises, walkie-talkies and overwhelming firepower. Marcos Lizarraga, a prosecutor in the Texas border town, dubbed him 'the most dangerous man in Texas' for his calculated aggression.

The same degree of careful planning was evident in the jailbreak, which according to the authorities had been six months in the planning. Through good behaviour, the convicts at the Connally Unit jail, 60 miles south of San Antonio, had secured themselves coveted jobs in the maintenance workshop, where inmates are encouraged to learn new skills and put their talents to work

The Malevolent Seven did just that. They went to work as normal on the morning of Wednesday, 13 December, stopped for lunch and then returned from the cafeteria at 2pm, their chosen moment. They subdued a guard, 11 civilian employees and three other prisoners with a metal tool, bound and gagged them, stole the guard's uniform, the civilians' clothes and identification and simply walked to the first prison gate.

There, they fooled the prison guard with the fake IDs and overwhelmed him, leaving him tied and gagged. The next stop was a guardtower, which also served as a weapon depository. Again they conned the watchman, telling him they were technicians who had come to install a video monitor. fields.headline: One amazing not-too-bad day
fields.standfirst:
It's had a rough old year, all things considered. But the thousands who poured in for the Dome's last full day yesterday were having a ball. Amelia Hill reports.

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: It's had a rough old year, all things considered. But the thousands who poured in for the Dome's last full day yesterday were having a ball.
fields.body:
'Right that's it,' said Jamie's aunt as a Tube train pulled into North Greenwich Station. 'I've changed my mind, we're going home.'

Jamie's crisps spilled to the floor and his face froze in an expression of absolute devastation. Then his aunt laughed and his blissful beam returned: he had been waiting all year to visit the Millennium Dome and now nothing could stop him.

'I cried and cried two days over Christmas because I thought the Dome had closed already and I'd missed it,' he said. 'The second I found out I still had a few days left, I took £80 out of my bank account and got my mum to book the tickets and the journey down here on the coach.'

Having nearly missed the chance, nine-year-old Jamie Jackson was taking no risks. To ensure their trip to the Dome on its last full day began smoothly, he and his aunt caught the 11pm coach from Newcastle on Friday night, arriving in London at 5.20am yesterday morning.

'I wanted to do it properly,' said Jamie. 'I wanted to be first in the queue.' And he was, until 8.30am when an already stressed security guard shunted him and his aunt from queue to queue, eventually leaving them languishing at the back of a long line of people who had only just arrived.

Jamie, however, refused to be downcast. 'I knew there would be queues and that's why I brought my Gameboy and coloured pens,' he said, rifling through his purple rucksack. 'I know what people have been saying about the Dome, but this is going to be the best fun I ever had: I know it is.'

After a year in which it was ceaselessly and mercilessly lampooned by the press, politicians and public alike, the Millennium Dome will finally close its doors today at 6pm after a muted ceremony of farewell.

But as the Dome's deadline has crept closer, the humiliating trickle of visitors who dribbled through its doors steadily swelled to a raging torrent: an estimated 38,000 came yesterday and those arriving without tickets were turned away. Some of these were undoubtedly making the most of their last chance to revel in schadenfreude at the Government's expense, but others were eager to squeeze the last drop out of an entertainment attraction of which they are genuinely fond.

'When I think of the Dome, I think of fun and happiness,' said 11-year-old Michael Joseph, who left his home in Mitcham at 5.15 yesterday morning with his mother and sister to reach the Dome in time to see its gates open for the penultimate time. 'The words go together in my head even though I've never seen it.'

At 9am yesterday there were already 500 people patiently enduring the heavy morning frost and when the gates swung open at 9.05am, the straggling queue split itself evenly between the Dome and the centrally-heated, coffee-offering McDonalds that lies immediately inside the entrance.

'I know exactly where I want to go,' said 10-year-old Jamilla Barker, pulling her father firmly into the bowels of the Dome. 'I've been here twice before and I've made a list of my favourite zones and the order I want to do them.'

But some were more hesi tant. 'It just looks so tacky,' said Caroline Hill, a book designer from north London who decided at the last minute to see for herself what all the fuss was about. 'It's as though they decided that if they were dealing with huge spaces and huge exhibits, it all had to be vulgar. There was nothing beautiful to look at.'

By midday there were two queues curving round the popular Body Zone, one for the attraction and the other a spontaneous group which had spotted Pierre-Yves (or 'PY') Gerbeau, the chief executive and wanted to pay homage to him.

'Reactions like this are pretty much the only things that have kept me alive this year,' he said, signing autographs and modestly posing for pictures.

'Every time I had a dreadful day I would walk around the Dome. The only good part of being a public figure was that people stopped me and told me to keep going.'

Since replacing Jennie Page, ignominiously sacked as bad publicity surrounding the Dome hit disaster proportions last February, the obedient PY - previously a trouble-shooter at Disney World - has transformed Europe's most infamous Millennium monument into a visitor attraction that 88 per cent of visitors praise and has even, recently, been transformed into a commercial success.

fields.headline: Faith, hope and clarity
fields.standfirst:
With the Churches fighting for their lives, we must now look beyond gods to ourselves to build a new moral order, argues Will Hutton

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: With the Churches fighting for their lives, we must now look beyond gods to ourselves to build a new moral order, argues Will Hutton.
fields.body:
So that was that. Another Christmas. I did what most of us do and observed the Christmas rituals, from last-minute present buying to the Christmas Day turkey. I sang carols and tried to relate to the spirituality of the Christmas narrative. But each year it gets harder - the material excess of Christmas is dwarfing its spiritual content.

This year more than any other, I wondered whether Christmas as it exists will survive the twenty-first century. Maybe Christmas Day 2100 will be just like Christmas Day 2000, but I doubt it. There is an emerging crisis of faith which makes it harder and harder for the story of Jesus's birth to bear the load of these 10 days of holiday and celebration.

There is little to be gained by deploring this state of affairs as but more evidence of our irreligious and immoral society; even if there were a simple linkage between religion and morality, it would not matter because you can't force faith upon disbelievers and sceptics. Nor, I think, does the argument that religion is crucial to underpinning morality really stand up. We are perfectly capable of creating the moral contracts that sustain a just society without believing in, say, damnation.

Equality before the law; a free press; the presumption of innocence until proof of guilt; the need to provide a floor under the living conditions of the poor; the need to talk to our children, as Mary Warnock argued powerfully in these pages last week, to give them moral sensibilities - all are instincts that spring from our basic humanity and do not need to be underpinned by a belief in God. Secularity of itself is not immoral; it is perfectly consistent with a wide range of moral approaches and outcomes.

In any case, our state of growing disbelief cannot be turned around by rational appeals to have faith because this would be good for morality. At the moment, most of us inhabit a religious halfway house, hardly full-blown believers but reluctant to abandon Christian teachings and moral fables and whole heartedly to embrace the universe of agnosticism and atheism.

We recognise that Christianity's moral precepts are valuable in themselves even if we hesitate to embrace notions of Heaven, Hell and the afterlife. But while we find it hard positively to believe in God, we equally find it difficult to go the whole hog and dismiss the entire exercise as a charade. And even if we want to, the Anglican Church's own limitless tolerance and kindness make it hard to declare independence from religion. Who would want to raise a blow against a body of such good people?

But this is hardly a stable, steady-state condition. Our children are even less willing to occupy this halfway house than we are; their drift to agnosticism is obvious to all. Institutions, like relationships, need momentum; they must have vitality or they wither and die. For those who have dedicated themselves to a life of faith, working in the established church, the current situation is hardly satisfactory. There is no point for them in working in a lifeless mausoleum, effectively as no more than custodians of a relic that we value culturally but will not and cannot offer the faith to reanimate. Unless they can spread faith to others, they are not discharging their obligation to their God, their vocation and themselves.

I am sure that the movement inside the Church of England to break the ties with the state will grow; disestablishment offers it the chance to become a campaigning missionary and a real agent, as it will see itself, of rechristianising Britain. The status quo offers it a gentle decline, overwhelmed by secularism and scepticism which it will not be as free to contest as it needs to be if it remains custodian of the official religion. That condition forces it into too many compromises.

Thus it was no accident that on Christmas Eve the Archbishop of Canterbury opened up the question of disestablishment, acknowledging there was a 'real argument' to be had, at the same time as the Church of England prepared to join the other faith communities in the 'Faith Works' campaign in the run-up to the next election. The Church of England knows it must associate itself vigorously with other religions insisting on the importance of faith to stay alive as an institution; if that means opposing or criticising the Government, so be it. And if this in turn leads to disestablishment - better that than a slow death.

This is where politics in general, and New Labour's temporisations in particular, enter the frame. The Government will want this issue, like drugs or republicanism, simply to go away. The Tories will criticise any move towards disestablishment as a weakening of a crucial part of our cultural and constitutional identity and they will argue that an avowedly Christian society should not reduce its religion to the same moral worth as other religions in a multi-cultural, multi-faith society.

And because New Labour will not want to be seen as soft on British identity or the moral worth of Christianity, on past performance it will retreat to the Conservative position of trying to preserve the status quo, while sustaining order by a mixture of repressive social legislation, assistance to the working poor to improve themselves and moral hectoring.

Tactically, this is a perfectly tenable position. If the Church of England itself takes the lead, then New Labour can always climb down gracefully in response to pressure from below, without its own conservatism being compromised. But if this is how the debate plays out, as seems all too likely, it will be both an abdication of political leadership and another example of how a crucial tradition in democratic life - that of the liberal and reformist centre-Left - now has no presence in British political debate.

New Labour's positioning as an essentially liberal conservative party, forcing the Right to the extreme margins and the liberal Left into a conservative straitjacket, may be clever short-term politics but in the medium term it robs the country of one of its most important assets, the capacity to debate and talk to itself.

This is the greater moral threat than the advance of secularism or the decline of faith. The march of science and rationalism that undermines the capacity to believe in God and the afterlife cannot be undone. As a result, we have to construct our moral order ourselves as a constant process of exchange and argument, in which the exchange between Left and Right is an essential component. If there is no Left voice, making the case for a just society on first principles, then we find ourselves where we are - wringing our hands at the people's irreligiosity and lack of spirituality but with nothing to offer instead.

New Labour is currently debating its next manifesto and is asking itself what it wants to do with the mandate it seeks. The answer should be unambiguous. The greatest moral and political service it can do the country is to present us with a clear set of choices - over poverty, the responsibilities of the rich and business towards the commonwealth, over the primacy of social justice, over drugs, over how we should associate and live - that represent the best the liberal and centre-Left tradition can offer.

Don't hold your breath, but it is New Year's Eve and a time for optimism. Just hope.

webTitle: Comment: The loathed versus the unloved

fields.headline: The loathed versus the unloved
fields.standfirst:
In a May election, Tony Blair will get his second term with a substantial majority but from a minority of voters

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: In a May election, Tony Blair will get his second term with a substantial majority but from a minority of voters.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
The pope has one. So the Archbishop of Canterbury must have one. The Prime Minister does it. So the Leader of the Opposition has to do it. Even the leader of the Liberal Democrats feels the compulsion to string together a few plastic beads of wisdom and package it as a New Year's Message. In his offering to a bleary Britain, Charles Kennedy decries 'yah-booing' by Labour and the Tories (which is the traditional yah-boo at the bigger parties by the littler party) and bemoans what he calls the 'frenzy of speculation' about the election date.

Frenzy, what frenzy? I detect a nation swept by unfrenziness about the timing of the election. Why gaze in the crystal ball when you can look at the calendar? There are a small number of people saying April, mainly on the grounds that the Prime Minister would love to spit in the eye of the hated media by confounding our forecasts that he will go to the country in May. But 3 May is the date ringed in the diary of every important politician and influential strategist I know.

Tony Blair will want to go to the polls with the tax cuts announced by Gordon Brown in a March Budget jingling in wage packets, and the elderly in receipt of the uprating to their pensions. A May election is certain; at any rate, as certain as anything ever is in politics.

And if we know the date, we also have an increasingly clear view of the battlelines. William Hague uses his New Year missive to give advanced warning that the Tories will campaign on tax, Europe and crime. We guessed that already. The Conservative leader is nothing if not predictable. Had he told us that he planned to fight the election on a pledge to legalise cannabis, that would have been worth reporting. It would also have been popular, at least a lot more popular than the Conservatives. More people support decriminalising pot than are in favour of decriminalising the Tories.

It has always been my assumption, since he became leader of his party, that Mr Hague has planned on losing the next election, and his campaign outline does nothing to confound me. He talks to diehard Conservatives in the anti-European, anti-immigrant, anti-scrounger language they understand.

This skinhead Toryism has served to demonstrate that there is a core Conservative vote. It has also proved that this core is confined to a maximum of a third of the electorate. The Tory hard lands are for Hague. And so is practically no one else. Belatedly, his colleagues have woken up to the limits of an approach principally designed to save Mr Hague's neck after he has lost the election. The result is that they are already assessing him for the chop. Tory MPs are preparing to bury their leader before his body has even gone cold.

The list of candidates to replace him grows longer by the day. To the usual suspects of Michael Portillo, Ann Widdecombe, Kenneth Clarke and John Redwood have lately been added Francis Maude, Iain Duncan-Smith, David Davis, whose advantage is revealingly said to be that he is not a member of the Shadow Cabinet, and Sir Malcolm Rifkind, who is not even a Member of Parliament. At this rate, the Conservative Party will soon have more candidates for its leadership than it has members.

William Hague's failure has been his inability to fashion an approach which reaches out to the centre ground, the territory on which elections are won and lost. Unlike the Tories, these voters are not mono-maniacally obsessed with Europe, an issue which is likely to slumber with the boringly sensible Swedes occupying the presidency of the European Union for the next six months.

The floaters and swingers don't like being taxed - whoever did? But when real wages have been increasing, they don't feel Labour has been that punitive. The Government is undoubtedly exposed on the fall in police numbers, but the Tories have not provided answers to crime which resonate with voters. When the Lord Chief Justice, not a post occupied by a raving anarchist, announces himself against the Conservatives, you plumb the depths of the trouble they are in.

What most exposes the plight of the Tories is that Mr Hague has nothing of substance to say about health, education or transport. A confident Tory party would be raiding into territory which Labour had regarded as its own and where the Government's record is vulnerable. The Conservatives approach the election gripped by the fatalism of a party that is already mentally measuring the size of its defeat, which is usually a guarantee that the defeat will be even larger.

In the name of the Prime Minister has been issued not just a New Year's message, but an 'Eid al-Fatir Message' bearing his good wishes to the Muslim community, and a 'Chanukah Message' wishing 'every Jewish home' a 'happy Chanukah'. This typifies the great strength which is also New Labour's biggest weakness. Ever the ecumenicalist, Tony Blair persists in his belief that all men and women of peace and goodwill can be drawn to worship inside his broad church. The very width of his altar continues to mean that the Government lacks a sharp narrative about its not inconsiderable achievements and its future ambitions.

In the Labour heartlands, where manufacturing jobs are disappearing at an alarming rate, there is a continuing resentment that this is a government that does not feel as if it belongs to its natural supporters. They will not vote Tory; they might well protest by staying at home. In the bleeding heartlands, which have been disillusioned by New Labour's illiberality, they may favour the Liberal Democrats as an alternative place for their votes. Most worrying for the Prime Minister, there is the disappointment among the converts, that considerable number who voted Labour for the first time in May 1997.

New Labour misread many of them. What they wanted, it was assumed, was a Tory government with a more humane and competent face. From this flowed the pledge, which I am sure will be repeated in Tony Blair's next manifesto, not to increase income tax. From this also came the self-denying ordinance to stick to Conservative spending limits for the first two years. This was the most strategic choice made by Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, and they and we are still living with the consequences.

It helped deliver an economic stability never before experienced under a Labour government. The Chancellor presides over an embarrassingly large surplus, partly because even when he has released additional resources to his Cabinet colleagues, they have stuggled to find things to spend the money on. It is an extraordinary fact that this Labour government has been undershooting its spending totals.

Having been obsessed with establishing a reputation for economic competence, Messrs Blair and Brown have lately made the unwelcome discovery that this is necessary, but still not enough. The ungrateful voters have started to take prosperity for granted. What they now want from New Labour is delivery of the promise, most obviously not fulfilled on railways which are African with snow, that it would improve the quality of life. Manifest sums have been flagged for the health service, education and transport, but the money allocated in the last spending review will only begin to flow from the beginning of next April. That is much too close to the election to be able to tell whether it is going to make a serious difference.

So this election year opens presenting a choice between a Tory Opposition which is loathed and a Labour government which is not loved. I foresee Tony Blair back in Number 10 with a substantial majority - or I'll eat my crystal ball. But his second term will be founded on a miserably poor turn out, quite possibly a record low. About that last prediction, I'd gladly crunch glass to be proved wrong.

fields.headline: Israel's old bruiser
fields.standfirst:
Likud's hawkish leader has one rule: strike first and hard. Leading the polls to become Israel's new Prime Minister, a decade or more of peace in the Middle East may depend on whether he has softened in old age

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Likud's hawkish leader has one rule: strike first and hard. Leading the polls to become Israel's new Prime Minister, a decade or more of peace in the Middle East may depend on whether Ariel Sharon has softened in old age
fields.body:
Passing through the Damascus Gate into Jerusalem's Old City you enter the Arab Quarter, a place of narrow, shady lanes, tiny shops and cramped coffee houses where elderly men sit smoking hookahs. It is, by any reckoning, a quintessentially Palestinian space. Save, that is, for a house a few hundred metres from the gate built in an arch that spans the street. From it hangs a giant Israeli flag. It is the residence in the Old City of Ariel Sharon: right-wing Likud leader; Israeli war hero; zionist hawk, and declared enemy of both the Oslo peace process and the putative Palestinian state.

Sharon's House, as it is is known, is a bit of a misnomer. He keeps it to make a point: that even in the heart of Arab Jerusalem, Jews still stake a claim. But then Sharon has always been keen on provocations. His house in the the Old City is one. His visit in September to Islam's third holiest shrine, the nearby compound of Haram al-Sharif - the trigger for three months of bloodshed - was another.

The question now is whether he is prosecuting the greatest provocation in his long career: running for Israel's highest political office on 6 February for no other reason than finally to torpedo the Oslo peace process. For Sharon has made it clear that he considers the emerging US-brokered peace deal that would create a definitive Palestinian state, to be dangerous and illegitimate. He says he would not feel bound to honour it if he is elected.

It is more than a moot point. On Friday an opinion poll in the weekly Maariv put Sharon ahead of his rival in the prime ministerial elections, the incumbent Labour leader Ehud Barak, by a margin of almost two to one. A second poll in the daily Yediot Aharanot put Sharon 13 points ahead, but the reasons for his sudden popularity are not hard to fathom.

Sharon's support has been galvanized by reports of concessions on offer to the Palestinian side by Prime Minister Barak in the present round of negotiations including de facto sovereignty over Haram al Sharif, revered by Jews as the site of the Biblical Second Temple; the surrender of large areas of Occupied Arab East Jerusalem, and the abandonment of all but a handful of the settlements in the Occupied Territories.

By the same measure, support for Barak has been devastated. For supporters of the peace process there is a sense of deja vu. Like his Likud rival Binjamin Netanyahu in the 1996 election when he defeated Shimon Peres - Sharon is also riding high on the public outrage that has followed a wave of recent terrorist attacks, including last week's bus bomb in Tel Aviv.

Suddenly it seems that Sharon's boldest and most dangerous gamble may be about to hit pay dirt. After being sidelined from the highest offices of army and state for four decades, the bloodshed of the Al Aqsa intifada has brought the prize he has pursued for a lifetime almost within his grasp. The three months since his visit to Haram al-Sharif have been momentous ones for Sharon, a burly man of 72, still fighting friends and foes alike at an age when most would be contemplating retirement rather than planning to lead a country which his election would inevitably tip into faster escalating crisis.

While Sharon has denied that his visit to Haram al-Sharif was intended to trigger the violence of the intifada that followed, his timing could not have been better, tapping into a widespread anti-peace sentiment among Israeli settlers and others on Israel's Right that escalated following the break-up of the Camp David talks. Conveniently it also catapulted him into the headlines on the very day that graft charges against his main rival for the leadership of Likud, Netanyahu, were dropped.

Strong-willed, brilliant and ambitious, the name of Ariel Sharon peppers Israel's short, half-century of history like gunshot. From the questionable but brilliant Gaza and Kinneret raids which he led against Egyptian and Syrian positions in the 1950s, through Suez (where he was criticised for leading his paratroopers into an ambush by disobeying orders), to the massacre of civilians at the Sabra and Shatilla refugee camps in Lebanon, an atrocity in which he was implicated, the figure of 'bulldozer Ariel' has loomed large.

Politically too he has attached himself to the most incendiary of causes. He encouraged the land grab of the settlement builders, called for the liquidation of the first Palestinian 'intifada' of 1987-1993, and suggested the effective imprisonment of the Palestinian population within walled pockets. All the while he has thumbed his nose at American-led interventions to cement a permanent peace process. So it was, perhaps, inevitable that at the moment of the Middle East Peace Process's greatest crisis, it should have been Sharon who provided the casus belli.

Born in 1928 into a family of eastern European refugees named Scheinerman in Kfar Malal, one of the first agricultural settlements in Palestine in the Sharon valley not far from Tel Aviv, his first taste of trouble came with membership of Gadna, a paramilitary youth battalion, prior to joining Hagganah, the underground Jewish Defence Force defending settlers against Arab attacks.

It was this early experience of Jewish communities under threat that coloured his whole outlook. After independence in 1948 he led commando units that specialised in behind-the-lines raids forcing Palestinians to flee their homes, encouraging - critics say - as many terrorist attacks as he prevented.

This explains why Palestinians, Arabs and left-wing Israelis hate him, and why so many Israelis of the Right adore him. To them Sharon is the epitome of the tough Jew, represented in the image of the 13-year-old Sharon being given a dagger by his father to protect his family. Sharon recalls: 'The knife was symbolic, to protect ourselves from our enemies. It was a lesson I have never forgotten.'

But his policy of striking first and hardest - summed up in his motto 'always escalate' - has also been responsible for his worst disasters. His belief in pre-emptive defence led to the disastrous invasion of South Lebanon in 1982 - Israel's first war of choice. His adherence to a strategy of pre-emptive action has not been confined to the battlefield. He sued Time magazine for libel, ostensibly to clear his name in the Sabra-Shatilla affair. Cynics, however, believe the real purpose of the attack was to relaunch his political career.

His approach to the Occupied Territories and his encouragement of Jewish settlement is similarly coloured. 'Grab more hills,' he has insisted. 'Whatever is seized will be ours. Whatever isn't seized will end up in their hands.'

It is a policy that he assiduously enacted as Housing Minister from 1990-1992 when he presided over the biggest construction drive in Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip since Israel captured the lands in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. But for all of Sharon's frightening and erratic brilliance as a short-term strategist, his personal tragedy is of forever being the 'nearly-man', who promised everything but always snatched defeat from the jaws of victory.

His flair for improvisation as a soldier - most famously in leading the counter-attack against the Egyptians in the 1973 Yom Kippur war - won him as many enemies as admirers, blocking his route to the most senior positions in Israel's armed forces. In his political career, too, he has been similarly thwarted.

The commission of inquiry into the massacres at Sabra and Shatilla when he was Minister for Defence, while clearing him of direct responsibility, held him responsible for not halting the bloodshed. Since then he has struggled to rebuild his political career launched in 1973 when he was instrumental in the founding of the Likud party.

But even within Likud, Sharon's style has created obstacles for his advancement, not least in his rivalries within the party with the likes of Netanyahu and Yitzak Shamir. This time, however, Ariel is playing for keeps. Old age may not have softened the 'bulldozer', but he has shown in recent months that he has learned to play a rather longer and more cunning game keeping Barak guessing over whether he would join an emergency government of national unity while undermining his position.

He is also not above some cynical PR. Last week he sent Yasser Arafat - a man whom he said he would never shake hands with - a card to mark the Muslim feast of Eid al Fitr in which he expressed his hope that the two peoples could live in 'peace together'. Perhaps, it is not as cynical as it appears. This is the man, after all, who surprised observers in 1997 by declaring that like the hawkish Menachem Begin before him who made peace with the Egyptians, he was the only person could deliver peace. 'You just haven't known it,' Sharon declared. 'I'm the only person who can successfully negotiate a peace agreement with the Palestinians.'

He may believe it. The question is whether he is inclined to do it.

Ariel Sharon

Born: 1928 (Kfar Malal, near Tel Aviv)

Jobs: Army chief, Housing Minister, Minister for Defence

Education: Officers' Training College, university in Jerusalem studying history, law at Tel Aviv University

Highpoint: Leading the attack against the Egyptians in the 1973 Yom Kippur War

Lowpoint: Ill-conceived invasion of South Lebanon in 1982
