fields.headline: Flood, sweat and tears - Part 2
fields.trailText: JULY
fields.body:
JULY

We dreamed of someone to watch over us. After 50 years of pressure, it was announced that the Government would pay compensation to the few remaining survivors of Japanese prisoner-of-war camps; each man would get in the region of £10,000. Channel 4's compulsive piece of guinea piggery, Big Brother, selected 10 people from 40,000 applicants to exist for two months in an enclosed compound under the constant gaze of 25 television cameras. The incentives to survival were £70,000 and the twenty-first-century equivalent of 15 minutes of fame: ubiquitous tabloid and television exposure for months on end; glossy magazines competing for pictures of your kitchen units. The group shared varying degrees of paranoia and charmlessness, prompting a new version of the prisoner's dilemma: the problem lay not in deciding who to vote out, but rather who on earth could possibly stay in.

The inspectors of IRA arsenals, the former ANC leader Cyril Ramaphosa, and Martti Ahtisaari, former president of Finland, agreed with the IRA on a system of dual keys to the arms dumps, the latest in an unending series of 'major breakthroughs' in the peace process. It was claimed that the weapons would be put beyond use, but no one quite knew how or when.

There was a sense of Groundhog Day at Drumcree, where the Orange Order march was blocked for the third year running. The RUC used water cannon to disperse protesters, who included the freed Ulster Freedom Fighters' leader, Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, forcing them 200 yards back up a hill towards the Church of Ascension.

Eight-year-old Sarah Payne went missing in West Sussex, and her body was subsequently discovered in a field off the A29, which overnight became a vast shrine of flowers and teddy bears. News of the World editor, 31-year-old Rebekah Wade, anxious to make her mark with Rupert Murdoch, pledged herself to naming and shaming 110,000 paedophiles in Britain and encouraged her readers to 'scout out the beasts'. Within hours of the publication of the first 50 names, Ian Armstrong's house in Manchester was surrounded by a lynch mob of 300 people hurling bricks and abuse. Armstrong had been mistakenly identified as the sex offender Peter Smith, who, like him, wore a neck brace. He later appeared at a press conference supporting the campaign.

Euan Blair, the 16-year-old son of the Prime Minister, was found drunk and disorderly, vomiting in Leicester Square after finishing his GCSEs at the London Oratory School. Addressing the Faith in the Future conference of black evangelical Christians the following day, his father quoted Henry Wadsworth Longfellow: 'For thine own purpose thou hast sent strife and discouragement.' Richard Williams, who had coached his daughters Venus and Serena out of a Los Angeles ghetto to victory at Wimbledon, danced on the roof of the commentary box on Centre Court, and held up a series of hand-made signs, including 'We love you, Duke and Duchess'. Tiger Woods, whose father predicted he would have more impact on the world than Gandhi, easily won the British Open at St Andrews.

A week after it was reported that cracks had been found in the wings of 11 Concordes, one of Air France's fleet bound for New York's John F. Kennedy airport crashed near Charles de Gaulle airport, killing all 109 passengers as well as four people on the ground. Euro-dreams of supersonic travel seemed to to be part of the scattered wreckage. Later, a metal strip was found on the runway, believed to have fallen from a distinctly subsonic Continental DC-10; the piece of metal was suspected of puncturing one of the Concorde's high-pressure tyres, causing the accident. John Aspinall, the zookeeper and casino owner died, black-boxed with him, perhaps, the true story of the disappearance of Lord Lucan.

AUGUST

The seven ages were being redefined. British scientists were granted the right to clone human embryos for the purposes of research. William Hague, keen to lose his 'Tory foetus' image, made extravagant claims about the extent to which he had been pickled in a former life; he was, he said, a 14 pints a night man. The Queen Mother turned 100, a credit to the preservative powers of malt whisky and champagne, and received a telegram from her daughter. Madonna revealed the limits to her love affair with Cool Britannia when she returned home to the States to have her baby, Rocco, believing British hospitals to be 'old and Victorian'.

Chancellor Gordon Brown resisted the temptation of turning his wedding to PR girl Sarah Macaulay into a publicity stunt: Hello! and Alastair Campbell were not invited. The only nuptial budgetary leak suggested that the pair were toasted with £11.99 socialist champagne from Sainsbury's. Anthea Turner and Grant Bovey, the diminutive darlings of daytime TV, seemed less concerned with the dignity of their union; a wedding photo of them eating his-and-hers Cadbury's Snowflake bars, given away as a promotion at their wedding, was released to the Sun by OK! Turner, whose all-too-candid autobiography, Fools Rush In, was being readied for publication, was said to be distraught at this 'betrayal of trust', and anyway, she pointed out: 'Grant doesn't even like chocolate. He's far too vain ...'

No one, it seemed, could keep a confidence. David Shayler, who publicly detailed bungled MI5 operations, returned to Britain facing a six-year sentence for breaking the Official Secrets Act. Dame Stella Rimington, his former spy chief, announced that she, too, would be writing her memoirs. Nasty Nick Bateman became public enemy number one, when his Machiavellian approach to Big Brother was rumbled: 'You've made me look a c- in front of everyone,' he claimed to his nemesis, the Scouser Craig, the reality of reality TV striking him as if for the first time.

There were voyeuristic variants of the show-topping ratings elsewhere in the world. In Holland, 11 people shared an 18-foot bed on the top deck of a bus. The show attracted 6,000 would-be fare dodgers prepared to submit themselves to 24-hour live coverage of a not very magical mystery tour. The Russian nuclear submarine Kursk, pride of the Baltic fleet, sank with all hands after a missile exploded in a torpedo tube. There was brief hope that those trapped inside might be rescued, but a British team, with the latest mini-sub technology, was called in too late by Vladimir Putin to attempt to save the doomed crew.

Marks & Spencer launched a rare TV advertising campaign to appeal to the 'fuller-figured woman', many more of whom they hoped would be squeezing themselves into their fitting-rooms. The ads showed a naked, size-16 woman clambering to the top of a hill in order to tell the world: 'I'm normal'. Simon Russell Beale's inspired and rotund Hamlet came to the National Theatre and re-examined our stereotypes of tortured leading men: 'Tubby or not tubby, fat is the question,' suggested one headline. The Polar icecap thawed, melted and resolved itself into a dew for the first time in 50 million years

SEPTEMBER

We seemed a nation in gridlock. Brynle Williams, a sheep farmer from Wales, and a raggedy army of farmers and road hauliers brought Britain to a standstill in a demonstration of word-of-mouth solidarity against fuel duties. Lorries blocked motorways; there were lightning raids on refineries and depots, and the just-in-time supply policies of supermarkets and retailers were exposed.

The tortured relationship at the heart of government between Chancellor and Prime Minister, revealed in a book by The Observer's Andrew Rawnsley, came under its strongest pressure yet: 'It's like a marriage, a tempestuous marriage,' noted one insider. 'The rows can be terrible... but you come between them at your peril.' The British Physiological Society discovered that grown men cry more readily than women.

Conjoined twins Jodie and Mary were ordered to be separated by the appeal court against the wishes of their parents. 'Do we murder Mary to save Jodie?' asked Lord Justice Ward, setting in motion a national moral tug-of-war over the fate of the two girls. A magazine devoted to the possibilities of life after divorce was launched called New Era. Noel Gallagher split from his wife Meg Mathews, suggesting that he would rather stay in with daughter Anais in their Buckinghamshire home than go partying. Paula Yates, the former wife of Bob Geldof, was found dead in bed by her four-year-old daughter, Tiger Lily, after a heroin overdose. Her funeral service began with 'These boots were made for walking'.

The Olympic spirit proved more stimulating than nandrolene in Sydney which, for a month, became a city of natural wonders: Ian 'Thorpedo' Thorpe's flipper-sized feet; Cathy Freeman's gap-toothed smile; the Brazilian women's beach volleyball team. Uniquely, the performance of Britain's athletes outweighed expectations: Denise Lewis heroically limped to victory, Jonathan Edwards finally hit the ground running and Audley Harrison, a heavyweight with a sociology degree, boxed clever. Steve Redgrave's pulling power was rewarded with a special commemorative pin from outgoing IOC president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, who had proved his commitment to the cause by returning to the games after attending his wife's funeral. No one wished they were in Manchester.

Salman Rushdie announced to the world his intention to remove to New York because of the tyrannical 'bitchiness' he had encountered on this side of the Atlantic. Harold Pinter turned 70; fellow playwright Alan Bennett suggested that the occasion be marked with a minute's silence.

OCTOBER

Past crimes returned to haunt us. Reggie Kray bequeathed a posthumous pop song, accepting full responsibility for the murder of Jack 'the Hat' McVitie, and declaring love for his wife.The 16 volumes of official memos and undercover deals detailed in the Phillips Report on BSE revealed the extent of the former Conservative government's wilful misinformation and culpability in the beef crisis. The human strain of the disease vCJD claimed its eighty-second victim in Britain, Zoe Jeffries, 14, who, her crying mother explained, had been fond of burgers as a toddler. As BSE fears grew in France and Germany, some estimates suggested that the eventual death toll could be up to 130,000 people.

At Hatfield, almost a year to the day after the Paddington disaster, four passengers died after a derailment caused by a piece of broken track that was due to have been replaced six months previously. Railtrack chief executive Gerald Corbett offered his resignation, and was initially refused; eventually, Corbett agreed to a £400,000 pay-off: £20,000 for each mile of fatally neglected track.

Hollywood discovered picket lines: Billy Elliot, a fable about a boy ballet dancer set against the 1984 miner's strike was a surprise box-office hit. Elizabeth Hurley, the unblemished face of Estée Lauder, was labelled a scab by protesters from the Screen Actors' Guild at the premiere of her film, Bedazzled. Hurley marched past striking actors in Spandex trousers; later, as Variety magazine observed, she issued 'more mea culpas than a penitent at Lourdes'.

England football manager Kevin Keegan talked himself out of a job he felt he had been pressured into accepting in the first place. After a defeat by Germany, and apparently plagued by a sense of tactical inadequacy, 'Mighty Mouse' explained that he felt 'a little bit short at this level'.

At the much-hyped Apocalypse show at the Royal Academy, the enfants terrible of Britart, Jake and Dinos Chapman, unveiled a new vision of hell: thousands of mutant Airfix Nazis locked in frenzied civil war. Slobodan Milosevic, tinpot architect of ethnic cleansing in the former Yugoslavia, was voted from power in Serbia in an election he believed he couldn't lose. After sponsoring a decade of civil terror in Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo, Milosevic reluctantly relinquished control saying he wanted to spend more time with his family. Marko, his son, a racketeer and owner of the Belgrade theme park, Bambiland, promptly fled for Moscow, trailing corruption charges.

Tolerance was hard to come by. Shadow Home Secretary Ann Widdecombe launched a wicked witch attack on soft drugs at the Conservative party conference, and found herself in danger of prosecuting seven dope-smoking colleagues. Concerned about teenage pregnancy rates, the Governnent unveiled an advertising campaign instructing young people to keep a grip on themselves: 'Sex: Are you thinking about it enough?' billboards inquired. In his first act as London Mayor, Ken Livingstone decided he would be taking no shit from Trafalgar Square's pigeons, and insisted that tourists cease feeding them.

The Nobel Prize for Literature was awarded Gao Xingjian, a Chinese exile living on the nineteenth floor of a Paris towerblock. As a younger man, during the Cultural Revolution, he had been forced to burn 'kilos and kilos' of his own writing. The prize was like 'something that falls on you out of the blue sky,' he said. 'Like a miracle.'

NOVEMBER

A celebration of the work of England's greatest apocalyptic visionary, William Blake, opened at Tate Britain. The waters rose over our green and pleasant land, swamped by days and nights of rain. Geysers erupted on Salisbury Plain, impromptu ferry services sprang up in villages around York, and thousands were evacuated from sandbagged homes. The floods seemed further incontrovertible proof of global warming, and were accompanied by predictions from the Met Office that temperatures would increase by six degrees in this century, causing water levels to rise by seven metres, inundating every major coastal city in the world.

At a conference on climate change in the Hague, Britain's chief negotiator, John Prescott, stormed out after failing to broker a deal on acceptable targets for carbon dioxide emissions between America's intransigent polluters and European environmentalists. Outside the conference, protesters declared that sparring delegates had 'sunk the world'.

The new Jerusalem looked a distant prospect. On the West Bank, fighting had been intensifying for a month following the publication of graphic pictures of a 12-year-old Palestinian boy killed in the crossfire between Israeli troops and Arab protesters; one observer suggested that the conflict was 'like a PlayStation game: they have helmets and bulletproof vests but we Arabs have nothing'. Palestinians subsequently gained revenge in an attack on a police station in Ramallah where two Israeli soldiers were lynched, their attackers displaying bloody hands to the mob. Bill Clinton, anxious to seal the end of his presidency with a foreign policy coup intervened, unsuccessfully, for peace.

The United States failed in its attempts to decide on a successor to Clinton. The race to the White House between Al Gore and George W. Bush rested on Florida's ballot, which was too close to call, and slowed to a crawl as American courts disagreed on the constitutional process of recounts. Russian President Vladimir Putin, straight-faced, wondered if he could offer Americans assistance in resolving its democratic difficulties.

There were songs of innocence and experience. Elton John, in court suing his former manager for mishandling his financial affairs, admitted having once spent £40m in a period of months, including £300,000 on cut flowers for his home. Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas blew a reported £1.3m on their wedding celebrations at Donald Trump's Plaza Hotel in New York, including £10,000 on a cake. Guests were invited to give cash rather than gifts; a seven-figure deal for exclusive rights to their nuptial photographs, signed with OK! magazine, was undermined by rival Hello! which published unofficial pictures; the happy couple sought an injunction.

Proprietor of OK!, soft-porn baron Richard Desmond purchased Express Newspapers from the Labour peer Lord Hollick. Desmond had made his money from magazines such as Nude Readers Wives and Asian Babes. On arrival at the Express, Desmond reportedly 'enjoyed a celebratory drink' with editor Rosie Boycott, founder of Spare Rib.

Chris Woodhead, controversial Chief Inspector of Schools, resigned his position in order to take up more lucrative educational work as a consultant to the Daily Telegraph and to Bell Pottinger, Margaret Thatcher's favourite PR firm. The Weakest Link, a quiz show loosely based on the notion that there is 'no such thing as society' moved to prime time on the BBC. Its host, Anne Robinson, employed the authentic rhetoric of the Ofsted inspectorate: 'You are the weakest link. Goodbye.' Judith Keppel, a distant cousin of Camilla Parker Bowles, was the first jackpot winner on ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire?; she had invested £1,000 in phone calls to earn a place on the show.

DECEMBER

Satisfactory endings were in short supply. George W. Bush was granted the American presidency in the Supreme Court, which ruled that all votes in Florida should not, necessarily, count. Al Gore, who had won the popular vote, and who, as later unofficial recounts seemed to prove, also won in Florida, accepted his curious fate as the President Who Never Was. Bush, smiling his father's thin smile, surrounded himself with his old man's jowly cronies, and wondered what to do next.

Richard Branson lost the chance to run the People's Lottery - and more priceless personal branding as a beneficient billionaire - and retired to his private island to contemplate might-have-beens. Tony Blair suggested that perhaps, in hindsight, the Dome had not been quite the 'runaway success' he'd predicted, though he did not ever actually set foot in the 'Blame Zone'. The highlight of the Millennium Experience was generally agreed have been the failed heist in November, in which a team of theme-park jewel thieves launched an attempt to steal a Diamond as Big as the Faith Zone, foiled by police thinly disguised as cleaners and eager tourists.

Damilola Taylor, a 10-year-old Nigerian boy, ended his life bleeding to death in a stairwell in Peckham. All-seeing, impassive CCTV cameras caught him on his way to a library, eyes bright, just before he was stabbed to death. William Hague, denying he was playing a race card, chose the moment of the initial arrest of a gang of black youths in connection with the murder, to launch an odd attack on the MacPherson Report into the Stephen Lawrence case. Police, he suggested, lived in mortal fear these days of being branded racist by Polly Toynbee.

Neil Hamilton, now apparently a junkie for public humiliation, saw his libel appeal against Mohamed al Fayed collapse and faced bankruptcy. Bilal Mohammed, from Birmingham, who, at 18, claimed he had seen the Prophet in a dream, launched a suicide bomb attack on an Indian barracks in Srinigar, killing himself and eight others.

And a few fairytales came true. England won at cricket; Prince William was cleaning lavatories in Chile; Gordon Brown agreed to wipe out the debt owed to Britain by the world's 41 poorest countries; two men in a boat were plucked from the waves near Rhum; Harry Potter was on the cover of Radio Times; and despite the efforts of one photographer who lay overnight in the undergrowth at Skibo Castle to escape detection by thermal imaging devices, and another who hid for 60 hours in the organ-casing at Dornoch Cathedral with two bin bags to collect bodily waste, Madonna and Guy Ritchie proved, just about, that private lives still existed.

Damilola Taylor, a 10-year-old Nigerian boy, ended his life bleeding to death in a stairwell in Peckham. All-seeing, impassive CCTV cameras caught him on his way to a library, eyes bright, just before he was stabbed to death. William Hague, denying he was playing a race card, chose the moment of the initial arrest of a gang of black youths in connection with the murder, to launch an odd attack on the MacPherson Report into the Stephen Lawrence case. Police, he suggested, lived in mortal fear these days of being branded racist by Polly Toynbee. Neil Hamilton, now apparently a junkie for public humiliation, saw his libel appeal against Mohamed al Fayed collapse and faced bankruptcy. Bilal Mohammed, from Birmingham, who, at 18, claimed he had seen the Prophet in a dream, launched a suicide bomb attack on an Indian barracks in Srinigar, killing himself and eight others. And a few fairytales came true. England won at cricket; Prince William was cleaning lavatories in Chile; Gordon Brown agreed to wipe out the debt owed to Britain by the world's 41 poorest countries; two men in a boat were plucked from the waves near Rhum; Harry Potter was on the cover of Radio Times; and despite the efforts of one photographer who lay overnight in the undergrowth at Skibo Castle to escape detection by thermal imaging devices, and another who hid for 60 hours in the organ-casing at Dornoch Cathedral with two bin bags to collect bodily waste, Madonna and Guy Ritchie proved, just about, that private lives still existed.

fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.trailText: The rights and wrongs of Warnock
fields.body:
The rights and wrongs of Warnock

Mary Warnock has written a very sensible article on teaching children morality, particularly in regard to bullies (Comment, last week), but she fails to recognise two serious flaws.

First, although she rightly establishes that bullies are careless of the feelings of others and themselves, she does not look to the reasons for their own emotional damage, for example. If society acted to prevent that damage in the first place, would they still need to be taught morality?

Second, if society is filled with such communal despair and lack of morality, is there anyone who is capable of teaching morals? Who has the right morals to teach? Who will decide who will do the teaching?

Ms Warnock even admits the difficulty of taking the 'high moral ground' but then insists that we must, and identifies 'we' as those who have any connection with children. But who of 'we' has the right morals that should be taught?

For instance, do parents who are supporters of fox hunting have better morals than anti-hunting parents?
Leon Richard Bunnewell
Norwich

Mary Warnock is right to say that you can have morality without religion, but there's a catch. Without some external point of reference or authority, a personal sense of right and wrong is exactly that - personal. And who's to say whether your personal idea of right or wrong is superior to another's?

Baroness Warnock's manifesto for a little judicious social engineering deserves full consideration, but let us not confuse the debate by bringing morality into it.
Martin Brasier
Beeston, Notts

Us, not the US

If the right-wing coup described by Will Hutton (Comment, last week) had been in a country on the other side of the Atlantic, where the declaration of victory was in Spanish or Portuguese, the British reaction would have been different. There would have been murmurs of disapproval from the FO, but we would not lose too much sleep over it.

That may yet be the right response to the American electoral fiasco. The time has come to shake off our obsession with the US and concentrate on the struggle for social justice where we can have some real influence - in Europe. Trying to get more commitment to EU welfare policies would do for starters.
Rev Geoff Reid
The Methodist Church Touchstone Centre, Bradford

HRH my hero

Well done, Your Majesty! Someone had to stop the liberal rot in this country and there is no one better than you. You had the guts to stand and be counted and express your personal Christian beliefs and how much they mean to your life - take note wishy washy churchmen and women and liberal politicians, teachers and social workers who believe in everything but have convictions about nothing.

Her speech on Christmas Day will do more to arrest the moral and spiritual decline in this country than any churchman or politician has done in the last 20 years or more.

I am so proud of you, Your Majesty!
Simon Icke
Aston Clinton, Buckinghamshire

Up and at 'em

My reaction to the headline 'Women to fight on front line' (News, last week) was that this is very old news - they have been on the front line for many a year.
Tim Harrap
Bridport, Dorset

Christian soldier

Bob Holman wrote (Letters, last week): 'Socialism is about promoting equality by having just a modest income, by being close to the materially needy, and conceding power to the socially deprived. Is there a single one of this liberal élite prepared to be a socialist example?'

Perhaps not. Yet what he is describing is not so much socialism as Christianity. I try, probably unsuccess fully, to ascribe to those ideals but it is years since I was a member of the Labour Party. Today, I settle for being a Liberal Democrat, and trying to be a Christian.
Alfred Baker
Tunbridge Wells, Kent

Rotten Rowe

It was sad, on Christmas Eve of all days, to read the report of Tory backbencher Andrew Rowe undermining the position of minority groups under the pretence of defending Christian organisations in their appeals for central government funds (News, last week).

I stood against Andrew in 1997 as Labour Party candidate for Faversham and Mid Kent, and I know that he is both intelligent enough and astute enough to understand the significance of his remarks. Back then, he was also sufficiently principled to appear embarrassed by some of his party's policies and he always looked a bit ill at ease in the company of many of the activists of his newly formed constituency association.
Alan Stewart
Macclesfield, Cheshire

A cheap shot

I am appalled by the destructive editorial cynicism evident in your layout (Letters, last week) in which a serious and well-argued plea from Paul Foot, Edward Said, Noam Chomsky, Harold Pinter, Tony Benn and others to stop the slaughter by Israeli soldiers and settlers of Palestinian protesters is negated by being used as a frame for an image of a masked Palestinian brandishing a pistol.

The letter calls upon people to recognise the politics of that process and to protest it, but its presentation inverts its message, not only by portraying victims as aggressors but also by transforming pragmatic politics into a struggle of world religions.
Glenn Bowman
University of Kent, Canterbury

Apple sauce

While I do not deny the Committee on Standards and Privileges may have 'fudged' the Reid/Maxton judgment (News, last week), I would like to draw peoples' attention to the fact that it was not an accusation of being found with one's fingers in the till; it was the accusation of putting the money in the till. Compared to the US system, Reid and Maxton were allegedly caught 'scrumping apples'.

Perhaps it is more pertinent to ask 'What do we mean by democracy?' and 'How do we promote it?' Alternatively, how to vote out the major political winner in this country and probably in most liberal democratic states - Apathy!
Gordon G. Davidson
Ellon, Aberdeenshire

fields.headline: Stand up and be counted
fields.standfirst: Lenny Henry returns to his roots, Noble & Silver make their television debut and Simon Munnery has an identity crisis
fields.trailText: The New Year starts with a blast from the past: Lenny Henry returns to the live arena with a date at London's Hackney Empire (12 January), temporarily forsaking his senior role as TV writer-star-producer in order to stand on a stage in front of 3,000 people and tell jokes.
fields.body:
The New Year starts with a blast from the past: Lenny Henry returns to the live arena with a date at London's Hackney Empire (12 January), temporarily forsaking his senior role as TV writer-star-producer in order to stand on a stage in front of 3,000 people and tell jokes.

Other TV-polished acts returning to the basics of theatre include Victoria Wood, at the Royal Albert Hall (6-12 September), and the League of Gentlemen - though you can probably expect their show at Theatre Royal, Drury Lane (12-19 March) to be rather more elaborately staged than the average stand-up show.

For a rawer and broader look at the modern comedy circuit, the place to be this winter is the Leicester Comedy Festival (9-18 February), where a big and talented cross-section of comedians will perform longer-than-usual sets. Much the same can be said for the Newcastle Comedy Festival (November), though at least the host city is more exciting. There's a similar bill, too, at the Kilkenny Comedy Festival in Ireland (31 May-5 June), but with the added attractions of warmer weather and a more charming locale, plus endless cheap pints of Murphy's, the brewery that sponsors the event.

By this point, many acts will be honing the one-hour shows that they will take into the month-long madness of the Edinburgh Fringe Festival (5-27 August), by far the biggest comedy event (and, despite all the competing attractions of theatre, music, dance and juggling, it is essentially a comedy event) in the European calendar. For those unable or unwilling to brave the snaking queues of American tourists, though, it's worth going to the BACS Festival (July) at Battersea Arts Centre, where the hottest acts iron out the flaws in their shows in front of smaller and less critical audiences.

In September you can see the results of the Edinburgh Festival in the shapes of the winners and nominees of the Perrier Award, who play three consecutive Sunday nights at Her Majesty's Theatre. Predictions of who might be performing on those nights are far too risky to mean much at this distance, but it might be worth a long-term, each-way bet on Dave Gorman (who was nominated last year), Omid Djalili (who should have been) and Noble & Silver (who won the Perrier Best Newcomer award).

Noble & Silver are among several innovative live acts being given the chance to make their own television show by the main terrestrial broadcasters through the medium of new digital channels. In their case, it is Channel 4's brand new E4, which starts transmission this month and will feature experimental arts and entertainment programmes.

The probability is that few people will watch it, but those few will be highly important television producers who will use the channel as a testing ground for new talent. This process has already worked in the case of Simon Munnery (see panel) who hosted two series for the BBC-owned UK Play.

Closer to the TV mainstream, the hottest expectations surround the second series of Spaced! on BBC2, which will do well to maintain the critical and commercial success it achieved at the end of its first run, and Sacha Baron Cohen's first foray into televisual comedy post-Ali G, with what Channel 4 are describing as a 'Jewish family sitcom'.

Less intensely anticipated is the new series by Baron Cohen's former 11 O'Clock Show cohort Iain Lee, who will then either disappear from our screens entirely or become the newer, thinner version of Nick Hancock.

My Highlight of the Coming Year

Attention Scum is not perhaps the most ingratiating of titles, but here at least is a comedy TV show that does not treat its viewers like imbeciles. It is the creation of Simon Munnery, who has been one of the most innovative, intelligent and acclaimed comics in Britain for the past five years, but who can still walk the streets of London with his unmistakably weird and ratlike face going completely unrecognised. Munnery's curse and gift is to be ahead of his time, which makes it entirely appropriate that he should finally become famous in that most futuristic-sounding of years, 2001.

For, while British television has spent the Nineties awash with mediocre stand-ups like Phill Jupitus and Lee Hurst, Munnery, whose live show has always been centred around the televisual image, has been banished to its edges, too smart and proud to appear on dumb gameshows, mobile phone adverts and The National Lottery Show. Then again, Camelot would hardly be likely to sanction a comic character whose act contains the line: 'Is life so unfair that we need a lottery and a justice system? Oh yes, we punish the guilty and reward randomly chosen people.'

This is not Munnery himself speaking, but his fascistic alter-ego, The League Against Tedium, an alien Nietzschean superbeing who assails his audience with home-made cartoons; self-glorifying slogans ('Fluent in 99 languages! Inventor of 98 languages!'); violent threats ('He who disagrees with me in private, call him a fool. He who disagrees with me in public, call him an ambulance'); and wise sayings ('Many are willing to suffer for their art. Few are willing to learn to draw'). Every line is delivered in a robotic, high-pitched whine, spoken so quickly that you are left straining to keep up.

The advance word on Attention Scum has been almost breathlessly positive. Industry insiders have described it as 'awesome' and 'unique', and it is top of most people's lists for the comedy show they're most looking forward to in 2001. I heard the same kind of superlatives just before Black Books came out, and look how good that was. Conventional wisdom may suggest that a comedy show presented by a nerdy-looking man who hates his viewers will go down like a lead balloon, but as The League Against Tedium himself says: 'If conventional wisdom is a forest, then I am a chainsaw.'

Attention Scum goes out on Sundays at 11.15pm on BBC2, starting on 18 February. BBC Choice viewers can see it from Tuesday at 10.30pm

fields.headline: Aussie rules...
fields.standfirst: Antipodean invaders at the Royal Opera, Gothic horror in the North and a Freudian Swan Lake
fields.trailText: Sir Anthony Dowell bows out as the longest-serving artistic director of the Royal Ballet with a farewell gala at the Opera House (23 May). Participants will be starry and seat prices are astronomical. Ross Stretton takes over as director after the summer break, by which time both the company and the school - headed by Gailene Stock - will be run by Australians.
fields.body:
Sir Anthony Dowell bows out as the longest-serving artistic director of the Royal Ballet with a farewell gala at the Opera House (23 May). Participants will be starry and seat prices are astronomical. Ross Stretton takes over as director after the summer break, by which time both the company and the school - headed by Gailene Stock - will be run by Australians.

Royal Ballet debuts to savour in the spring season include Tamara Rojo as Juliet and Alina Cojocaru as Giselle. Nicholas Le Riche of the Paris Opera Ballet returns to partner Sylvie Guillem in Romeo and Juliet. The Linbury Studio Theatre downstairs at the Royal Opera House has new works by Cathy Marston and Tom Sapsford for Royal Ballet dancers (6-12 Feb) and a brief season by Rambert Dance Company (2-5 May).

Rambert celebrates its seventy-fifth anniversary with a nationwide tour and a two-week season at Sadler's Wells (12-23 June). Former Rambert dancer Mark Baldwin teams up his own company with the Sinfonia 21 orchestra: the programme includes a commissioned score by Julian Anderson for The Bird Sings With Its Fingers (premiere, Wycombe Swan 14 Feb).

Northern Ballet Theatre launches a season of horror, pairing its Dracula with a new Jekyll and Hyde, chore ographed by Massimo Moricone - premiere at Leeds Grand (19 Feb) before going on tour. Birmingham Royal Ballet offers Arthur Part 2, David Bintley's forthcoming sequel to his Camelot saga, at Sadler's Wells (8-12 May) before touring.

Woking's Dance Umbrella (19 Mar-8 April) includes a new work by Kim Brandstrup for his Arc Dance Company. The Barbican presents the Cullberg Ballet from Sweden in the British premiere of Mats Ek's Freudian Swan Lake (May), a radical rethink long before Matthew Bourne's gender-bending version. Dutch National Ballet comes to Sadler's Wells at the same time (13-20 May), with ballets by Balanchine and Hans van Manen.

Victor Hochhauser brings back the Kirov Ballet to the Royal Opera House (11 June-7 July), followed by the Kirov Opera (9-21 July). New to London will be the Kirov's account of MacMillan's Manon , as well as revised productions of Le Corsaire and La Bayadère. Hochhauser also presents La Scala Opera Ballet from Milan, making its London debut with Sylvie Guillem's Giselle (6-11 Aug).

With so many big dance companies at last visiting our shores, the Edinburgh Festival (Aug-Sept) is moving in favour of cutting-edge ones, Amanda Miller's Ballett Freiburg and Charleroi Danse Plan K among them. Edinburgh should have its new Dance Base up and running by then. The spectacular site below the castle will provide much-needed studio space.

London will gain a £7 million dance complex when The Place, near Euston Station, reopens. The Laban Institute's ambitious scheme to move from New Cross to purpose-built premises (by architects Herzog and de Meuron) in Deptford is scheduled for August 2002.

My Highlight for the Coming Year

In the spring, Wayne McGregor, extraordinary performer and ground-breaking choreographer, combines his Random Dance Company with Royal Ballet members in a programme of hi-tech dance. Signs are that this will be a work worth booking ahead for. His earlier experiment with ballet dancers, Symbiont(s), shown last year in the Clore Studio, cried out to be more widely seen. Symbiont(s) will be followed by Aeon III , the virtuoso section of his recently completed trilogy for Random. Then, dancers from both companies unite for his new piece, brainstate.

'Wayne's stretching our bodies and minds in a new way,' says Deborah Bull, who is in charge of the project as well as performing in it. 'He demands we collaborate in making the movement instead of doing as we're told. His ability to push and play with the language of ballet is just incredible.'

McGregor has always been radical, experimenting with new technology as well as techniques. Now he has dancers who can keep up with him - both in his own company and the Royal Ballet - there's no stopping him.

Duo:logue in three parts, Linbury Studio Theatre, ROH, London WC2 (19-21 April); The Maltings, Aldeburgh (29 April)

Now he has dancers who can keep up with him - both in his own company and the Royal Ballet - there's no stopping him. Duo:logue in three parts, Linbury Studio Theatre, ROH, London WC2 (19-21 April); The Maltings, Aldeburgh (29 April)

webTitle: Comment: Is it Hair or Blague?

fields.headline: Is it Hair or Blague?
fields.standfirst:
As we count down to the next general election, we can all play Spot the Difference

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: As we count down to the next general election, we can all play Spot the Difference.
fields.body:
The British entered the first year of the new century with our flattering self-image facing a challenge. It was a touch difficult to believe in native tolerance, decency and an innate sense of fair play when asylum-seekers were being libelled by the far-Right press and persecuted by the Government. Tony Blair ordered them to live way below the poverty line on £10 a week in cash and £26 in asylo-vouchers while they waited years for his vastly incompetent Home Office to deal with their claims. To add insult to penury, he allowed supermarkets to pocket the change when refugees exchanged vouchers for food.

To William Hague, these were the wet tactics of the liberal élite. He wanted all refugees to be locked in internment camps. In a neat example of the under-examined phenomenon of right-wing political correctness, Hague insisted on calling the camps 'reception centres', as if prisons for people who have committed no crime (and are often the victims of the world's worst criminals) were hotels and the warders were receptionists cooing 'enjoy' and 'have a nice day'.

Never mind. Tony Blair announced a new holiday which will allow everyone to feel jolly good about dear old Blighty. On 27 January, we can have a nice Holocaust Memorial Day. The BBC and Home Office will invite us to reflect on the beastliness of the Germans of a mere 60 years ago and pity the plight of refugees from Nazism.

The Foreign Office has insisted, and the independent BBC has accepted, that there should be no tactless mention of Turkey's genocide of the Armenians in the First World War, the mass slaughter that inspired Hitler.

When Turkey is not pushing Kurds into seeking what sanctuary is on offer in Fortress Europe, it gets very ticklish on the Armenian question. It threatened to expel US troops from its territory if the American Congress described the carnage as 'genocide' and has put an Armenian priest on trial for speaking out. (A life sentence could follow if he is convicted.) One of the stated aims of Holocaust Memorial Day is to rebut denial of genocide, but the good intention is strictly circumscribed. When Nazis and other crackpots on the fringe deny, they must be fought ferociously. When a fellow Nato power with large export markets does the same, respectful reticence is in order.

Speaking of dictatorships, the Government's Stalinist reputation was enhanced in February when a study by the Liberal Democrats found that the Blair administration produces more targets than an Soviet apparatchik with a gun at his head. Five thousand have been set since May 1997 as noble and banal aspirations were sent whirling around Whitehall.

There are so many targets that there are targets of the number of targets civil servants must hit. There are targets to halve world poverty and improve dental hygiene; to end child poverty within 20 years and raise 'the quality of service by catering staff at the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Centre to 88 per cent' within one; to cut hard drug use by 50 per cent by 2008 and 'increase the favourability of media coverage of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority by 43.9-50 per cent' by 2001.

My favourite was from the Department of the Environment: 'Prescott Sets Targets For Improving Quality of Life - For Everyone.' As those who rely on the trains know, he hasn't quite got there yet.

The betrayal of the year is undoubtedly a prize William Hague can claim. Jeffrey Archer had turned the Leader of the Opposition into a real leader; transformed him from Wee Willie, a bleeding-heart who bleated about his support for gay marriages and single mothers, into Big Willie, a hard man, a man who would shoot you in the back with an illegally-held sawn-off shotgun if you so much as thought of giving money to a gypsy beggar.

Every day, Willie was graciously allowed to prepare himself for the political struggle in the great novelist's private gym. Hague's attraction to gay rights was suppressed by the exercise of grabbing fellow gymnast Sebastian Coe by the sleeves of his flapping judo pyjamas, crushing him in a constrictor's embrace, bending the screaming aide's tortured body back until the pain was unendurable and then burying him with a cathartic scream of triumph into the hard, sweat-stained mat. Archer's many kindnesses are forgotten now. One petty perjury charge and Hague acts like they never met.

For those grown weary of vapid political speeches, tested on focus groups and delivered without verbs, the Countryside Alliance rally at the Labour Party Conference was a relief. There was unadorned passion as Sam Butler, one of its leaders and the master of the Warwickshire Hunt, bellowed in Churchillian tones about the townies' plot to wipe out rural England. 'Our forebears did not not fight Hitler to let Blair destroy hunting,' he exclaimed.

He didn't add that one of his forebears was 'Rab' Butler, who, as a Foreign Office Minister, appeased Hitler throughout the Thirties, then allied with Lord Halifax in a manoeuvre to force Winston Churchill to accept a negotiated peace in 1940.

Nor is the Alliance opposed to all arrogant slickers. Butler runs Butler Sherborn, an estate agency which makes a very good living. It prices the local peasantry out of the Oxfordshire property market by selling their cottages as commuter and second homes. When Butler warned that banning hunting would lead to enraged yeoman turning on their oppressors, I phoned his agency posing as a cash buyer for a remarkably over-priced Cotswold pad.

'But couldn't there be trouble?' I asked nervously. 'Won't I be set on for coming from the town with pitchforks and stuff?'

'Oh no,' replied the eager saleswoman. 'Everyone round here's a commuter.'

The great political puzzle of the twentieth century continued to baffle the twenty-first: how do you tell the difference between New Labour and the Tories? In the autumn, Tony Blair explained that there really was no mystery at all. As he stared across the Commons at William Hague and Ann Widdecombe, he let slip the definition of the Third Way, which has eluded researchers for so long.

'What is the alternative?' he cried. 'What does the Right Hon Gentleman offer? Why was it that he made a policy-free speech, apart from a load of nonsense from the Shadow Home Secretary, most of which we are doing in any event?'

Understand these lines and you will have learned all you really need to know about modern politics and need never listen to the Today programme again until 2008 at the earliest.

Convergence criteria are being met in virtually every area of politics. For example, in 1999 the Tories demanded that the unemployed, suspected of working in the black economy, must be forced to sign on every day. The workless who lived miles from a benefit office would see a slice of their tiny incomes frittered away on bus fares. All would waste time when they might be looking for a job.

New Labour responded with a rare display of radical anger. Jeff Rooker declared the Conservatives had descended into 'right-wing madness'. David Blunkett cried that the cost of this lunacy would be £540 million a year as thousands of staff would have to be recruited to monitor the workless.

They were silenced by Gordon Brown, who transformed insanity into prudence within seconds and conceded that the Tories had a point. He asked Lord Grabiner, a New Labour peer, to investigate. In the spring, Grabiner upheld the finest traditions of the English Bar by recommending that claimants suspected of - but not convicted of - working illegally should be presumed guilty and forced to report daily.

Grabiner's experience of the struggle to make ends meet in the slums is limited. He's the most expensive barrister in London who rarely touches a case worth less than £100m and charges £800 an hour (or 216 times the minimum wage) for his services. A government which is anxious to revive the concept of shame in wider society is rarely embarrassed by its own shamelessness.

While Labour triangulated with Conservative class war, the Conservatives attempted to match Tony Blair's intimacy with the Supreme Being. William Hague, whose previous religious beliefs were of the New Agey Tibetan healing stones variety, had a Pauline conversion and embraced Christianity. Not the boring Christianity of the established churches, but the born-again fundamentalism of the Christian Coalition of the American South, which provided so much support to George W Bush and could just provide activists for the Tories.

At Easter, he addressed 8,000 ecstatic evangelicals who gathered to bother God in the Minehead Butlin's camp (memo to editor: Boss, I swear I'm not making this up ). He promised that a Tory government would allow them to have national television networks. Tele-evangelism would be imported to Britain and sobbing preachers would exhort us to send them money and pray for miracle cures.

Whoever wins the forthcoming election, I think we're going to need them.

fields.headline: My long weekend with Schnittke...
fields.standfirst: ... plus centenaries for the Wigmore and Verdi, Adès on Brendel, and Steve Reich at 65
fields.trailText: The dog days of January traditionally end with the BBC Symphony Orchestra's annual Composer Weekend at the Barbican. Serious, stimulating (exhausting, too), a luxurious 48 hours is devoted to the work of one twentieth-century composer; in 2001 it's Alfred Schnittke.
fields.body:
The dog days of January traditionally end with the BBC Symphony Orchestra's annual Composer Weekend at the Barbican. Serious, stimulating (exhausting, too), a luxurious 48 hours is devoted to the work of one twentieth-century composer; in 2001 it's Alfred Schnittke.

This first retrospective of the Russian's work since his death in 1998 focuses on his symphonies and concerti grossi. Towards the end of his life, having suffered paralysis in his right-hand side, Schnittke annotated, but left incomplete, a work called Fragment , which will receive its world premiere by the London Sinfonietta who commissioned it. Other highlights include the string quartets played in St Giles, Cripplegate, by the Keller Quartet (13 Jan) and a study day at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama next door.

Equally appealing, but sadly clashing, Beethoven's complete chamber music will be performed at the Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester, by performers including the Brodksy and Endellion Quartets and the Florestan Trio. To mark the refurbishment of Leeds Town Hall, Opera North is offering 'a striking new presentation' of Wagner's Tristan und Isolde. Susan Bullock, surely a natural in the role, makes her debut as Isolde, with the American tenor Mark Lundberg as Tristan. In Birmingham (20 Jan), Cecilia Bartoli joins Christopher Hogwood and the Academy of Ancient Music for a rare performance of Haydn's Orfeo .

February sees the return of Raymond Gubbay's Arena Opera to the Albert Hall with a new production of Verdi's Aida, one of many events commemorating the death of Verdi in 1901. It's by the team which brought us a stunning, aquatic Madam Butterfly two years ago. English National Opera stage a new production of Il Trovatore. Mark Elder, a great Verdian, conducts the Hallé in music from Nabucco, Trovatore, Don Carlos and Aida at Bridgewater Hall, Manchester (25 & 27 Jan). The LSO has two Verdi evenings conducted by Antonio Pappano (21 & 23 Jan); the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic has a Verdi evening (27 Jan); and the London Philharmonic performs his Requiem (9 & 16 Feb). Welsh National Opera is reviving La Traviata, but its new production is Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro, with Katya Kabanova later in the season.

To celebrate Hans Werner Henze's seventy-fifth birthday in March, the Royal Opera House mounts his Boulevard Solitude for the first time. Roughly speaking, this 1952 work is Abbé Prévost's novel Manon Lescaut removed to a seedy, post-Second World War Paris. Nikolaus Lehnhoff directs. Other Henze events include a celebration by the Philharmonia Orchestra at the South Bank (29 Mar & 4 April), conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi. At the Barbican, the LSO launches a programme of Czech music entitled Bohemian Spring (4 Mar-22 April), featuring work by Dvorák, Janácek, Smetana and Suk.

In April, English National Opera continues its admirable tradition of commissioning and performing new work with the world premiere of David Sawer's From Morning to Midnigh t. Sawer has made his own libretto for this, his first major opera, from Georg Kaiser's expressionist play, first performed in 1917. A bank clerk, shaken from the comfort of his daily routine by a mysterious lady, decides to rob a bank, and his life hurtles 'towards a shocking climax'. Another new work by Sawer, Musica Ficta, will receive its world premiere in Poole (and Basingstoke) on 2 and 3 May, given by the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra. Hear the new generation of composers in the London Sinfonietta's 'State of the Nation' weekend at the South Bank, on 21 & 22 April.

The Royal Festival Hall celebrates its fiftieth birthday on 3 May with a gala concert and associated events. The venerable Wigmore Hall is enjoying a centenary festival all season (keep an eye on the concerts, all tempting) which reaches a climax on 31 May and 1 June with two gala concerts featuring Andras Schiff, Andreas Scholl, Barbara Bonney and Graham Johnson. The summer opera season gets under way in May with Glyndebourne, where the two new productions are Deborah Warner's staging of Fidelio (conducted by Simon Rattle) and Peter Hall's of Otello. This is followed in June by Garsington; Strauss, a recent strength of the Oxfordshire festival, features in a production of Intermezzo directed and designed by David Fielding. Another exciting June event will be Alfred Brendel's seventieth-anniversary concert; Thomas Adès, Luciano Berio and Harrison Birtwistle have written settings of the pianist's poems, and Brendel is soloist in piano concertos by Mozart and Schumann (30 June).

The Cheltenham Festival opens on 30 June with a staging of Peter Maxwell Davies's The Lighthouse by Music Theatre Wales and (1 July) Thomas Allen singing Schubert's Die Winterreise. The Proms begin in July, but their secrets remain hidden until spring. Edinburgh has already revealed a skeleton programme: Donald Runnicles conducting Berlioz's The Trojans; Scottish Opera's keenly anticipated Die Walküre; plus stars including Ian Bostridge, Kurt Sanderling, David Daniels, Christopher Maltman and a host of foreign orchestras (Leipzig Gewandhaus, Boston Symphony, St Petersburg Philharmonic).

Other anniversaries to watch: the newly redeemed English pastoral composer Gerald Finzi (the centenary of his birth, 14 July); Steve Reich's sixty-fifth birthday (3 Oct) and the twenty-fifth anniversary of Benjamin Britten's death (4 Dec).

My Highlight of the Coming Year

One of the most intriguing events of the new season is Because I Sing - a choral extravaganza organised by Artangel, to be held at London's Roundhouse. Five hundred singers from 17 different amateur choirs around London perform a new piece by Orlando Gough together with his professional choir, The Shout. Members of this unique and eclectic vocal group will work with each of the participating choirs in advance, preparing a work of their choice along with the new 90-minute piece by Gough, which promises to be a choral portrait of London.

The choice of choirs - selected for their distinctive characters - should ensure variety; when you mix the Metropolitan Police Male Voice Choir, the London Gay Men's Chorus, the London Diocese Deaf Choir and the Congolese Christian Choir, something mildly interesting, at least, must result. Members of the award-winning Women's Institute Choir, Lea Valley Singers and girls from South Hampstead High School are there to add ballast.

Alain Platel, best known for his pioneering work with Belgium's inimitable Les Ballets C de la B, is overseeing the design and direction of the event, and will take into account the fact that the term 'choreography' has its roots in the word 'chorus'. At the same time, Sophie Fiennes will film the project for a Channel 4 documentary.

This project is the culmination of Artangel's lottery-funded sequence of animations at the Roundhouse, which began with William Forsythe (1997) and Ilya and Emilia Kabakov (1998). Looks one of the liveliest and whackiest dates in the season.

Because I Sing, 31 March & 1 April at the Roundhouse, London NW1

fields.headline: Know your Mancunians
fields.standfirst: A new New Order, Noel goes solo, and the first great album of 2001?
fields.trailText: The two most ambitious British pop bands of the Nineties both release albums next year. It is to be hoped that Massive Attack and Radiohead will cap 10 years of innovation with their new releases, giving a fillip to all those who believe that pop still matters.
fields.body:
The two most ambitious British pop bands of the Nineties both release albums next year. It is to be hoped that Massive Attack and Radiohead will cap 10 years of innovation with their new releases, giving a fillip to all those who believe that pop still matters.

Massive Attack, arguably the most influential and critic-friendly band of the past decade, will resurface after a three-year hiatus - minus founder member Mushroom - with a new album late in 2001. Their first release, Blue Lines, was a classic and they haven't made a dud yet. Surely it's too late to start now?

Radiohead are not on such firm ground. They return with a new album largely culled from the same sessions that produced this year's Kid A. Amnesiac (March/April) promises to be a less esoteric listen, although vocalist Thom Yorke believes the new release is 'really fat and dark'.

Manic Street Preachers will want to retain their credibility with their sixth album, provisionally titled Know Your Enemy (March). Connoisseurs will be pleased to note contributions from DJ David Holmes and My Bloody Valentine's Kevin Shields. The Manics have also pulled off a promotional coup, becoming the first Western band to perform in Cuba. On 17 February, 5,000 fans will pack the Karl Marx Theatre in Havana for a first listen to the new songs.

After a year of personal upheavals and a poorly received album, Oasis will attempt to break America yet again, this time supporting the Black Crowes on tour. Meanwhile, Noel Gallagher plans to release a solo album later in the year. Comeback of the year is a tie between two AWOL dance acts: New Order and Stereo MCs. After a much-publicised rift, the pioneering Mancunian quartet have re-formed and are busy working on their first album since 1993's Republic. Remember the Stereo MCs? They're finally about to release Deep Down and Dirty, their follow-up to 1992's hugely popular Connected.

It will be interesting to compare the old guard with the likes of the Chemical Brothers, Basement Jaxx, Air and Daft Punk who are also working on new material. While UK Garage should continue to rule clubland. Björk fans, too, can look forward to a new album.

The past year has been characterised by hits from artists of whom little or nothing was known 12 months ago. So Craig David, Badly Drawn Boy and Coldplay flourished as Oasis and Radiohead trod water. In 2001, the biggest names in pop can strike back.

The industry is buzzing with rumours about the new Michael Jackson album, partly produced by Rodney Jerkins (Destiny's Child, Whitney Houston) and reportedly featuring Slash and R Kelly. Jackson has been such a peripheral figure of late that it's easy to forget he's the same age as Madonna. But can he match her flair for reinvention? Don't expect a makeover for the Boss, though. Bruce Springsteen is said to be going in the opposite direction, teaming up with the E Street Band again. Does that mean he's going to drag Steve Van Zandt from his current acting gig on The Sopranos? Someone should inform Tony.

Guns N' Roses are also making their first album in six years, but with a depleted line-up and fanbase, they're unlikely to be essential listening. More worthy of attention is the burgeoning breed of hard rock or nu metal American acts that include Amen, Slipnot and At the Drive-In.

Their music can seem secondary to the occult rituals, self-mutilation and vomiting over fellow band members, but they have caught the Zeitgeist in the States, feeding into the kind of nihilism that seemingly inspires Eminem. Judging by the reaction to nu metal bands at festivals at Leeds and Reading in 2000, they also have a potentially massive following here.

Black American music is in a healthy state, with new releases from Lauryn Hill and Macy Gray to cheer. Hip-hop should continue in the same rootsy vein as of late with a headline release from Method Man, and expect to hear more from recent chart debutant Nelly and experienced campaigners Outkast.

So hip-hop will continue to equal street cred. Perhaps Jacko will try his hand at rap. Failing that, he can always get Ali G to star in his new video.

My Highlight of the Coming Year

'Every generation throws a hero off the pop charts,' sang Paul Simon. He should have added that if you stay around long enough, the next one might get you back on to Top of the Pops . Just ask Tom Jones or Santana. Or Bobby Womack, the soul legend who lends his gravelly voice to two of the outstanding tracks on the new album from homegrown R'n'B duo Rae & Christian.

Their second album, Sidewalking (January), is an occasionally brilliant fusion of British sensibilities and American swagger, mixing hip-hop, Latin and classic soul influences. The Mancunian-based pair have made one of the great records of the coming year.

There is no shortage of impressive American soul music around at the moment, but Mark Rae and Steve Christian have wider horizons than nu soul luminaries such as Jill Scott, D'Angelo and Erykah Badu. This is classy, but not coffee table soul à la Macy Gray, as the double appearance of rap group The Pharcyde attests. They have cut down on the samples and upped the musicianship from their first release, 1998's Northern Sulphuric Soul. And they're British which counts for something because, aside from Soul II Soul (the jury is still out on Craig David), successful soul music has usually been imported.

Of course, Rae & Christian have brought in Womack, but the results are stunning, especially on the first single, 'Get A Life' - a stirring, jazz-tinged call to arms that is sophisticated, passionate music at its best.

fields.headline: Soap springs eternal
fields.standfirst: Martine McCutcheon goes all posh; Anna Friel gets even closer. But don't worry - Brook, Marber and Warner will be there, too
fields.trailText: Peter Brook's production of Le Costume will have its British premiere at the Young Vic, which presents Can Themba's tale of township life - first adapted for the stage by the Market Theatre of Johannesburg - in collaboration with the Theatre des Bouffes du Nord and LIFT (24 January to 3 February). All performances - in French, with English surtitles - are already sold out, but returns and day seats will be available.
fields.body:
Peter Brook's production of Le Costume will have its British premiere at the Young Vic, which presents Can Themba's tale of township life - first adapted for the stage by the Market Theatre of Johannesburg - in collaboration with the Theatre des Bouffes du Nord and LIFT (24 January to 3 February). All performances - in French, with English surtitles - are already sold out, but returns and day seats will be available.

Deborah Warner directs Medea at the Queen's (for 12 weeks from 30 January) with Fiona Shaw in the title role. In this, Warner and Shaw's seventh collaboration, Jonathan Cake will play Jason. Warner, who has described her influences in thinking about the matricidal drama as Who's Afraid Of Virginia Woolf?, Oleanna and A Streetcar Named Desire, promised: 'I'm going to make you laugh at a play you didn't think you could laugh at.'

Japes, a new play by Simon Gray featuring two brothers who love one woman, and starring Toby Stephens, Jasper Britton and Clare Swinburne, moves from Colchester to the Theatre Royal Haymarket on 7 February. Particularly pleasing, as Gray's last play was elbowed out of its designated theatre by a tawdry play about boy bands.

Two of TV's most adored heroines take to the stage in the new year. Anna Friel, who, since bestowing her Brookside kisses, has appeared in the Broadway production of Closer, as well as in Landgirls, will appear in Nicholas Wright's new version of Wedekind's Lulu plays, directed by the Almeida's Jonathan Kent in a particularly apt setting for this tale of love lives and a pure heart. While their Islington building is closed for refurbishment, the Almeida is to make a new performance space in an old bus garage in King's Cross: the conversion will be undertaken by the same architects who in 2000 triumphantly transformed the Gainsborough Film Studios.

And the National will stage My Fair Lady (Lyttelton, 15 March), with an enticing line-up: Martine McCutcheon, who's been singing ever since she stopped being beaten up by Grant Mitchell in EastEnders, is Eliza; Trevor Nunn directs; choreography is by Matthew Bourne who can put a spring in the step of the most sluggardly thesp; Jonathan Pryce is the reproving Professor Higgins.

Three shows make a welcome return in the first half of the year. Mnemonic, Complicite's study of the workings of memory, has a brief run at the National (Lyttelton, 2-10 February) - to chime with Pinter's adaptation of Proust - before touring to Barcelona, Paris and New York.

The gloriously grisly junk opera Shockheaded Peter galvanises the Piccadilly from 14 February. And Tamasha's playful homage to Bollywood, 14 Songs, Four Weddings and a Funeral, comes back to the Lyric Hammersmith (16 February). Soon afterwards, Lloyd Webber's Bollywood musical may touch the West End with a bit of Eastern promise.

At the Royal Court there's a new play, Mouth to Mouth, by Kevin ( My Night with Reg ) Elyot (6 February) and Spirit (14 March), a new work by always inventive Improbable Theatre; this one features headless puppets and a demon in the bakery. Patrick Marber has a new (as yet untitled) play at the National in June. And Julie ( Lion King ) Taymor will bring medieval puppetry to BITE at the Barbican in August.

There'll be a double first for Conor McPherson in February. His new play, Port Authority - a study of three generations of Dublin men - opens for a strictly limited six-week season at the New Ambassadors (22 February), after which it moves to the Gate in Dublin; the cast will include Jim Norton, one of the haunted tale-spinners in the original cast of The Weir . This premiere will also be McPherson's directorial debut in the West End; he's been branching out from the stage recently, directing Michael Gambon and David Thewlis in the film adaptation of Beckett's Endgame.

My Highlight of thr Coming Year

Joseph Fiennes will take the title role in Marlowe's rarely performed Edward II at the Sheffield Crucible in March, where he'll be directed by Michael Grandage, the winner of this year's Evening Standard Award for best director. Actor and director seem to have looked over Shakespeare's shoulder to Marlowe at the same moment: Grandage had just decided to stage Edward II when he received a call from Fiennes saying he had been looking for a way to do the part.

Grandage considers him perfect casting, since the play - generally considered to have influenced Shakespeare's Richard II - demands an actor who can suggest a concentrated internal struggle, and Fiennes is more interested in the passive aspects of character than in rhetorical 'splurges'. Nevertheless, he can splurge and declaim when required.

This is an epic play with a big narrative sweep; the action covers several decades, shifting from Paris to the Tower of London, from battlefield to palace. The production will have a cast of 18, and will be designed by Christopher Oram, who has created beautiful spaces for Grandage's previous productions.

Edward II has, Grandage recalls, been performed as 'a rubber-clad gayfest', but he sees it differently: as a political play with a gay theme which, in telling a chunk of English history, pits a new generation against the old in a way that makes it possible to side with anyone. It is, he thinks, 'fantastically anarchic'.

Edward II runs from 8-31 March at the Sheffield Crucible (0114 249 6000)

fields.headline: Farewell to...
fields.trailText: March
fields.body:
March

Ian Dury, singer-songwriter, died after a long battle with liver cancer, aged 57.

April

Bernie Grant, anti-racism campaigner and MP for Tottenham since 1987, died of a heart attack, aged 56.

May

Sir Larry Lamb, newspaper editor who made the Sun the highest-selling daily of the Seventies, and introduced its Page 3 girl, died aged 70.

August

Sir Alec Guinness, theatre legend whose film and TV credits ranged from Great Expectations to Star Wars, died aged 86.

Sir Robin Day, journalist, broadcaster and inventor of the modern television interview, died aged 76.

September

Paula Yates, television presenter, died of a drugs overdose in her Notting Hill home, aged 40.

October

Reggie Kray, East End gangster, died of cancer, aged 66, shortly after being released from prison after 30 years.

Donald Dewar, Scottish First Minister, died of a brain haemorrhage, aged 63.

November

Sir Malcolm Bradbury, novelist, academic and critic, died aged 68.

December

Kirsty MacColl, singer-songwriter, died after being hit by a speedboat while on holiday in Mexico, aged 41.

August Sir Alec Guinness, theatre legend whose film and TV credits ranged from Great Expectations to Star Wars, died aged 86. Sir Robin Day, journalist, broadcaster and inventor of the modern television interview, died aged 76. webTitle: My Life as as TV Cow in Baddiel's Sitcom

fields.headline: My Life as as TV Cow in Baddiel's Sitcom
fields.trailText: 'Er, this is a bit of an unusual request...' said the voice on the phone, 'but we wondered if you might be interested in screen-testing for a part in Sky's new sitcom, Baddiel's Syndrome?' It had taken a while but finally, last summer, my Mrs Trapes in the 1981 Old Vic Youth Theatre production of The Beggars Opera had been recognised as the groundbreaking work I had always known it might be if I ever got extraordinarily lucky.
fields.body:
'Er, this is a bit of an unusual request...' said the voice on the phone, 'but we wondered if you might be interested in screen-testing for a part in Sky's new sitcom, Baddiel's Syndrome?' It had taken a while but finally, last summer, my Mrs Trapes in the 1981 Old Vic Youth Theatre production of The Beggars Opera had been recognised as the groundbreaking work I had always known it might be if I ever got extraordinarily lucky.

'Shall I bring my own sheet music and tap shoes?'

In the cramped Soho casting office, I read the script for the benefit of a video camera. It included the line 'cherry-wood olive-oil drizzlers, £149.99' and took about 90 seconds. After a second reading, I was offered the part. Outside the room, rows of real actors were huddled together on school assembly chairs, clutching scripts and wearing convincing expressions of extreme hopelessness - though perhaps this was merely a Method. Could I really take work from struggling professionals when I already had a regular job and a pension, even if it was with Equitable Life?

After extensive contractual negotiations ('We'll pay you X.' 'Really? Wow! Thanks!'), I turned up for rehearsals at a church hall in south London. It was just like donating blood: reasonably painless and over very fast, plus free tea and biscuits before you left. Admittedly, I hadn't yet learnt my lines, but I reckoned I could pull it off with the help of idiot boards, just like Brando in Apocalypse Now. Hopefully, I too might be shot in flattering gloomvision. Back home, I pondered my motivation. I hadn't dared ask why I had been chosen to play the microscopically small, but frankly pivotal role of Martina Chatwin, though I had a big hunch: 'Martina' is a broadsheet hackette who writes a first-person confessional column, and given that I hadn't done that sort thing for, ooh, years, the Sunday Times 's Liz Jones must already have turned it down. Then there was the undeniably worrying fact that Martina was, in the words of David Baddiel's character (an angsty thirtysomething called David Baddiel): 'a cow'.

I think it takes balls to say to someone, 'Would you like to play a complete cow whose character is, in fact, not terribly loosely based on you...', and so I should have the guts to prove that - ha!ha!ha! - I could laugh at myself, or at least the me they humorously perceived me to be, while also bringing something extra to Martina: a level of humanity and grace that was, admittedly, not altogether evident in the script. And all of this in roughly 90 seconds of airtime. Who wouldn't leap at that sort of challenge, given that there are so few good parts for journalists in their mid-thirties? Hey, Martina might be a cow, but she was a well-written cow.

At Teddington Studios, I had a dressing-room with my name on the door and a horrible costume on a hanger. This came as no surprise because if Martina was going to be 'a cow' hidden inside the Versace-clad body of a love goddess, then they would have given the part to Liz Hurley. Indeed it is, I think, fair to say that I eventually emerged from hair and make-up looking like Olive from On The Buses. I enjoyed the whole experience very much but there was no escaping the fact that, even as my heart said, 'You are Uma Thurman', the TV monitor said, 'You are in panto in Wolverhampton playing the Ugly Sister's slightly uglier banjo-strumming cousin'.

So, after several fraught months on a rigorous high-collagen/low-carb diet, last week I again summoned the courage to speak to Peter Bradshaw - Baddiel's Syndrome 's co-writer, co-star (and memorably, in episode six, Martina Chatwin's boyfriend), not to mention the Guardian 's film critic, who once sensibly turned down a part in a production of Cyrano de Bergerac directed by some bloke called Sam Mendes but has finally got himself a proper acting break.

After some polite obfuscation in response to my inquiry about the genesis of Martina's character ('well, obviously, it was based on your book and column...'), Bradshaw admitted that:'If we get recommissioned, you may have to clear your schedule.' Sweet! And if they allow Martina to wear the sort of frocks that reveal both her inner and outer beauty and then spin her off into a Frasier -style series of her own, Ms Chatwin and I might even think about it. In the meantime, however, I urge you to enjoy the series - an entirely unbiased review of which reads: 'I laughed out loud and corpsed twice! Pure televisual Temazepan!' - Martina Chatwin, The Observer.
