Pure televisual Temazepan!' - Martina Chatwin, The Observer.

webTitle: After a wobbly bridge, a rusty Guggenheim

fields.headline: After a wobbly bridge, a rusty Guggenheim
fields.standfirst: The Guggenheim reaches Las Vegas, Mies van der Rohe is reappraised, and there's anything but trouble at t'mill
fields.trailText: The trouble with making predictions about architecture is that you are never sure what you are going to get until a project is finished. No amount of intricate modelling or computer simulations can prepare you for the overwhelming impact of seeing an abstract diagram turned into an physical architectural presence.
fields.body:
The trouble with making predictions about architecture is that you are never sure what you are going to get until a project is finished. No amount of intricate modelling or computer simulations can prepare you for the overwhelming impact of seeing an abstract diagram turned into an physical architectural presence.

At the same time, architecture is more subject to the kinds of delay that are the inevitable accompaniment to builders overconfident about their abilities and wishful thinking among clients than other areas of the arts. It makes precise predictions about opening dates problematic. If only the Queen hadn't been booked a year in advance to open it, the millennium footbridge might have turned out differently.

What was meant to be the most monumental project of 2000, the enormously ambitious recreation of the great library of Alexandria in contemporary form will, according to its website, have to wait until a still unspecified date in the coming months for its official opening. The library, designed by Snøhetta, a Norwegian practice that has been working on the scheme for more than a decade, is Pharaonic in scale and shape, a tilted, stone-faced drum etched with carved letters like a giant Rosetta stone on the city's waterfront.

This is the year that Rotterdam and Oporto share the title of European capital of culture. Both are building new performing-arts halls. The New Luxor in Rotterdam, designed by Peter Wilson and Julia Bolles, is relatively well advanced and will make a striking addition to the city's fast changing dockland area.

But Oporto will be lucky to use its new Casa de Musica, designed by Rem Koolhaas, surely 2001's most fashionable architect, before the year is over. Completion is not predicted before mid November. Koolhaas's other major cultural project in 2001 is more likely to open on time, but its content sounds like parody beyond parody.

The Las Vegas Guggenheim, scheduled for inauguration in the summer, is a rasping, rusty steel cuckoo clasped in the unlikely nest of a casino loosely modelled on the Venetian Grand Canal. Just like Las Vegas's other major landmarks, from the Versace outlet in Caesar's Palace to the Hard Rock, the Guggenheim is part of a worldwide franchise chain.

And in a calculated game of double-bluff, its architecture is just as themed as the Las Vegas mirror-glass Great Pyramid hotel of the Luxor, and the prefabricated Palladianism of the Venetian resort. But Koolhaas's theme is the ultimately exotic post- industrial recycled warehouse that has become the style of choice for the contemporary gallery rather than anything with older historical roots.

Since Las Vegas has never had any industry beyond the thousands of workers who daily tend its slot machines, Koolhaas is building something that looks like an old warehouse, completed with travelling crane, from scratch. It has the same relationship to the real thing as Las Vegas's own half-size version of the Empire State has to the original. Its first, suitably Las Vegas-friendly show, devoted to the motorcycle, is being designed by Frank Gehry.

In Britain, the big millennium-funded projects in London are mostly out of the way now, but we will still be seeing the completion of some major new investments in cultural plant in the next year. Tate Britain is hoping that unveiling a new range of galleries in the summer, designed by John Miller and deftly inserted into one of its courtyards, will help to restore visitor numbers badly hit by the opening of Tate Modern.

The most impressive British project of 2001 looks like being the Baltic in Gateshead, a conversion of a grain silo into 300,000 square feet of space devoted to the contemporary arts on six levels designed by Dominic Williams of Ellis Williams.

In cultural terms, the biggest architectural events in 2001 are likely not to be new buildings but two blockbuster exhibitions devoted to Mies van der Rohe that will run side by side at the Museum of Modern Art, and the Whitney Museum in New York ( 21 June-11 September). Re-establishing a reputation 32 years after the death of the brooding Ger man-American apostle of architectural restraint will do as much as any new building to realign the direction of contemporary design.

Enough time has gone by for Mies to emerge from the period when he was under attack from all sides. In the eyes of the postmodernists, less was not more as Mies had it, but a bore. With the benefit of fresh eyes, it's clear that he succeeded in defining architecture in a way that was basically optimistic.

At a time when the nihilism represented by Koolhaas is in the ascendant, it is a valuable reminder of what architecture can be.

My Highlight of the Coming Year

Due to open in the autumn, the Baltic Centre for Contemporary Art began life as the Baltic Flour Mills, built in Gateshead in 1950 on the bank of the Tyne. It looked vaguely art deco, a bit like a slimmed-down version of Battersea power station, shorn of its chimney at each corner.

Its working life as a mill came to an end in 1981 and, as part of its plans to regenerate the waterfront, Gateshead Council began to look at the feasibility of reusing it as a cultural building rather than demolishing what had become a familiar local landmark.

The architect Dominic Williams won the competition for the conversion in 1994, and established his practice, Ellis Williams Architects, on the strength of it.

Unlike Tate Modern, whose architects took a determinedly restrained approach to remodelling Bankside, Williams's design makes it quite clear that the mills have a new use now. While the brick skin survives, the old grain silos have been hollowed out and floored to create six internal levels. And a giant, wing-shaped door, four floors high, brings natural light into the centre of the building. The exterior is decked with lifts, and a roof-top restaurant juts out towards the neighbouring new millennium bridge. The £46m project will provide 100 000 sq ft in total, including galleries and working studios. It combines urban renewal with a bold and creative approach to the arts.

The Baltic has been running an exhibition programme since its director, Sune Nordgren, was appointed in 1997 - most impressively with an installation by the sculptor Anish Kapoor. Kapoor filled the hollowed-out void of the structure - left after preliminary demolition was complete - with vivid red polythene stretching right across the 140ft hollow, creating a dizzying and beautiful disruption of scale and space.

webTitle: Home is where the art is...

fields.headline: Home is where the art is...
fields.standfirst: Swoon at Caravaggio and Rubens as you do the history of art - from Paris to Bombay, medieval sculpture to Rothko - without leaving Britain
fields.trailText: The year 2001 is the one of the Great Exhibition - or the grandiose title, for certain. Just consider what we're promised: Zero to Infinity, Desire Unbound, The Soul of Paris, The Genius of Rome. Berlin, Washington, Amsterdam and Tokyo will all be despatching their art like greeting cards from across the globe. No more need for the city break, then: we might as well stop at home.
fields.body:
The year 2001 is the one of the Great Exhibition - or the grandiose title, for certain. Just consider what we're promised: Zero to Infinity, Desire Unbound, The Soul of Paris, The Genius of Rome. Berlin, Washington, Amsterdam and Tokyo will all be despatching their art like greeting cards from across the globe. No more need for the city break, then: we might as well stop at home.

Tate Modern has not one but nine cities in a single, extravagantly ambitious exhibition. Century City (1 February) is a whistle-stop tour from Paris to Lagos, Moscow and Bombay, each metropolis a 'creative flashpoint' at some stage of the twentieth century. The empty Turbine Hall will echo with the sounds of Schoenberg and the bossa nova. The galleries will be filled with Fauvism, Suprematism, Pop, Op and Neo-Geo. Expect miles of film and video - plus queues from here to Timbuctoo.

The Whitechapel celebrates its own century (10 March) with proud highlights from the past - Malevich, Mondrian, Pollock, Rothko and Kiefer. The National Gallery travels back to the nineteenth century, borrowing 80 masterpieces from its Berlin counterpart (7 March). This should be a stunning survey: from German Romanticism to the early modernism of Manet, Monet and Cézanne.

You could, indeed, get the story of art - minus a few chapters - without leaving Britain this year. Tate Britain has medieval sculpture from June. The Royal Academy is showing Pisanello in September, Botticelli in March. It's also borrowing masterworks by Caravaggio, Carracci, Rubens et al for The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 (20 January) - go and swoon.

Rembrandt is back yet again, or at least his portly women, in a show that opens at the National Gallery in Scotland on 8 June and travels to London in September. Vermeer and the Delft School is at the National Gallery (6 June). For anyone with a sweet tooth, there is also Murillo: Scenes of Childhood at the Dulwich Picture Gallery (14 February).

I could go on through this exhaustive almanac, mentioning James Gillray at Tate Britain (6 June), Ingres to Matisse (RA, 30 June) or the Hokusai show at the British Museum from 11 May. But you will be wondering about those innovative, novel or even just contemporary exhibitions - something to make you gasp and stretch your eyes.

In the absence of a British Art Show, a Liverpool Biennial or another Apocalypse , there isn't much to report at this stage. The Serpentine (30 January) has invited Hans Haacke, German conceptualist and self-appointed art martyr, to meddle with the objects in the V&A for his own purposes - generally political, always mischievous. There is contemporary art from America (Barbican, October), Brazil (MoMA, July) and Japan (Hayward, October). But so far, nobody is trying to shoehorn three dozen artists together on the grounds that they all make jokes or lists or wilfully poor paintings.

Solo shows seem to be this year's contemporary format: specifically younger women and older men. Rachel Whiteread is at the Serpentine in June and the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art in September. Tates Liverpool and Britain have Lisa Milroy and Tacita Dean in January and February, respectively. Christine Borland, Emma Kay and Abigail Lane are all having one-woman shows. Mark Wallinger, after some deliberation, will be representing Britain at the Venice Biennale.

Two of the biggest shows this year are so long-awaited they almost feel like come-backs - Malcolm Morley at the Hayward (15 June) and Frank Auerbach at the Royal Academy (14 September). It's good to see these great British painters, now in their seventies, getting their belated due at full stretch. But the show I am most looking forward to centres on one of the longest careers in the history of art: Goya: Drawing From His Private Albums (22 February) at the Hayward Gallery.

My Highlight of the Coming Year

Lost drawings, dark drawings, drawings from the final nights of his life: the exhibition of Goya's private albums at the Hayward Gallery in February will surely be one of the most powerful shows anywhere in Britain this year. In 1793, Goya contracted an illness that left him permanently stone deaf. For the next 35 years, until his death in Bordeaux at 82, he drew incessantly on sheets of paper stitched by his own hand into journal-sized volumes.

Like journals in that they reveal so much of what Goya was thinking and feeling, these books were unstitched, sold by the page and dispersed across the world after his death. Some drawings have disappeared, others are only now being found. An amazing little figure, tumbling down a cliff, clothes billowing, arms flailing, was recently discovered in Marseilles. It was identified by Juliet Wilson-Bareau, curator of this exhibition.

'In so many of these drawings you see people totter or collapse. For Goya, this is the human condition: we're born, we climb the ladder of life and then we tumble down the other side. He makes the predicament seem humorous and absurd, but this latest drawing is also a terrifying image.'

A witch with a rope - for strangling or skipping? Inquisitors jostling in Klansmen hoods - ridiculous or incredibly menacing? One hundred drawings, many with captions, yet Goya never tells you what to think. 'These are the creative springs to all his other work,' says Wilson-Bareau. 'Witness them close up - so vivid, urgent, jumping from the page - and you can almost see his hand being pushed by his imagination. They're very complex: sharp touches and glints of black ink against luminous paper in the late works, light versus dark being so completely his subject. What's so moving is to see the dirty sheet edges. These were really well-thumbed little volumes. These drawings are the fundamental language of his art.'

Goya: Drawings From His Private Albums runs from 22 February-13 May at the Hayward Gallery, London SE1

fields.headline: Separate Ways
fields.trailText: January
fields.body:
January

Mel B (Scary Spice) and husband Jimmy Gulzar called it a day after 15 months of marriage.

May

Liz Hurley and Hugh Grant split after 13 years together.

June

Meg Ryan (left) left husband Dennis Quaid after nine years. They have one son. She is now involved with Russell Crowe, Australian star of Gladiator.

July

Patsy Kensit and Liam Gallagher split after three years of marriage - then divorced in September. All Saints' Nicole Appleton announced in November that she is two months pregnant with Liam's second child.

August

Teenagers Macaulay Culkin and Rachel Miner separated two years after tying the knot.

Anne Heche and Ellen de Generes - Hollywood's most famous lesbian couple - also split. Hours after the announcement, Heche was reported to have been discovered wandering the streets of Hollywood dazed and confused.

September

Meg Mathews and Noel Gallagher's wonderwall came crashing down eight months after the birth of their daughter Anaïs. Noel explained: 'Meg became more Ozzy Osbourne and I became more Donovan.' They'd been together six years and married for three.

November

Supermodel Claudia Schiffer dumped 'cash-strapped' lover Tim Jeffries after 14 months.

Harrison Ford, 58, and his wife of 17 years, Melissa Mathison, brought to an end one of the steadiest marriages in Hollywood.

December

Boris Becker announced his separation from Barbara Feltus after seven years of marriage.

fields.headline: Fads for the Memory
fields.trailText: Burberry
fields.body:
Burberry

Everyone from Liam Gallagher to the Queen Mother was seen wearing it.

Scooters

Public hazard or public humiliation? Take your pick.

Sparkly pop star T-shirts

Even Madonna chose to have 'Britney' across her chest.

Cod

The most fashionable fish among chefs: 'Quite the little seabass de nos jours ,' according to the Guardian .

Flip-flops

This year's faux pas was to be seen with warm toes.

Pokémon

The Japanese card game became a phenomenon and infiltrated all types of media. Pokémon: The Movie is the most successful animated film in history.

Reality TV

Britons were seen emigrating to a desert island, and 10 million viewers tuned in to watch the dull antics of 10 bored housemates.

Text messaging

Everyone realised that the 'occasional' text message leads to addiction.

Culture jamming

Anti-corporate activists, or 'guerrilla artists', subverted public advertising campaigns with a vengeance.

Palm Pilots

The latest technological innovation from the US: personal organisers that can read your handwriting began to take over from mobile phones as the indispensable accessory.

fields.headline: Tied the Knot...
fields.trailText: June
fields.body:
June

TV chef Jamie Oliver, 25, married childhood sweetheart Jules Norton, 25, in Rickling, Essex.

John Bayley, 74, widower of novelist Iris Murdoch, wed long-time family friend, Audi Villers.

Davina McCall, 32, married fellow TV presenter Matthew Robertson, 30.

July

Jennifer Aniston, 31, star of US sitcom, Friends, tied the knot with movie star Brad Pitt, 36.

Sophie Ward, 34, and her lesbian partner, Rena Brannan, 'married' at London's Groucho club.

August

Patsy Palmer, 28, wed second husband, taxi driver Richard Merkell, 35.

The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, 49, and his long-term girlfriend, Sarah Macaulay, 36, tied the knot in North Queensferry, Fife.

November

Catherine Zeta Jones, 31, married Michael Douglas, 56, in the opulent surroundings of New York's Plaza Hotel.

December

Madonna, 42, wed Guy Ritchie, 32, film director and father of Rocco, at Skibo Castle, Scotland.

fields.headline: Hello to...
fields.trailText: January
fields.body:
January

Anaïs Gallagher: Meg Mathews and Noel Gallagher had their first child at 1.17pm in the Portland hospital, London on 27 January. The baby weighed 7lb 6oz.

May

Leo Blair: Cherie Blair, 45, gave birth to her fourth child, Leo George (6lb 12oz), at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital on 20 May.

June

Fenton Merkell: Former EastEnders star Patsy Palmer gave birth to a son (4lb) on 15 June - a month earlier than expected.

August

fields.headline: Reasons to be cheerful
fields.standfirst: ' It's about loving and being loved, about doing the right thing, about one day being missed when we're gone. ' By  John Diamond
fields.trailText: Like most journalists I'm loath to let light in on the magic that is the editorial process, but this was the first commission I've had in 20-odd years in the game which read quite so much like an extract from a suicide note. 'Just tell me, John, what the hell is the  point of it all?' said the email from the editor, although it probably had somewhat more potency before I coyly changed the word to 'hell'.
fields.body:
Like most journalists I'm loath to let light in on the magic that is the editorial process, but this was the first commission I've had in 20-odd years in the game which read quite so much like an extract from a suicide note. 'Just tell me, John, what the hell is the point of it all?' said the email from the editor, although it probably had somewhat more potency before I coyly changed the word to 'hell'.

Bizarrely, people hint at much the same question all the time, although few of them put it quite so starkly or are prepared to pay me to try and answer it. This is hardly a boast: were you in my position, they might do the same to you. They think I know something nobody else knows, that I've found the secret answer to a question which, through fear or embarrassment they can't quite bring themselves to ask.

My position is this: I have an apparently terminal disease which doesn't allow me to make any realistic plans for more than a couple of months ahead, a voice which stopped when my cancerous tongue was removed, a diet entirely dependent on the food blender, and a fair to middling amount of pain on most days. To add insult to cancerous injury, I neither feel the need of nor can I discover any comfort in religious faith and I take refuge, legally or otherwise, in no more than the occasional dose of mind-nudging drugs.

And yet most of the time, and within the usual limits, I seem to be happy, even - given my willingness to accept commissions like this one - smugly so. What, they want to know, is the trick?

Well, yes, there's the nice house and the reasonable income from a cushy job that lets me show off in public the loving wife and family, the circle of supportive friends who indulge me in my various whims. To that extent, I suppose I have it all, or as much of it as it's possible to have under the circumstances. But those circumstances do make a difference: I might have it better than most tongueless terminal cases, but I know of no scale against which one can compare friends, family and possessions with the prospect of a long and healthy life. Would I swap a child or a friend or the family house for a new working tongue and a clear scan? Don't even ask, and not least because I'll never have to make the choice.

But it's a fair assumption on the part of my inquisitors: with so little time left for living, what is there to live for?

The easy answer is Philip Larkin's about none of us ever being able to get out of bed in the morning if we had any real sense of our own mortality, and it seems to be an answer borne out by the mortality statistics. Depressed and fraught as we're all meant to be with our fast and unlivable modern lives, last year only 5,000 or so of us were so desperately unable to cope with it all that we killed ourselves, which ranks the act of suicide alongside one or two of the less common cancers as a cause of death. Even if we don't know what there is to live for, we all want to carry on living. Well of course we do - it's what we're programmed for. A species which could take life or leave it alone wouldn't get anywhere like this far in the lottery of evolution; I imagine that death is as much of an unwanted shock to the day-old and senile mayfly as it is to the average Briton who has reached the age at which death is to be expected.

Indeed, before all this happened to me I used sometimes to wonder what it must feel like to be 78 or 82 or 90 and wake up every morning knowing not that today might be your last, but that whatever happened the chances were against life continuing for much longer. How, I wondered, could the Saga company sell holidays to all those elderly types in their elastic-waisted trousers and their treble-E fitting sandals? What were the customers expecting to bring back from their gentle cruise in the Med? Memories? But surely they have enough memories. What can you do with memories when you have only months or a few years to play with them? How can you relax on that cruise when every morning you wake up surprised still to be here and anxious that tomorrow you might not?

Except that here I am, a nominal 47 but in the position of an energetic and slightly breathless 90-year-old with most, but not all, of his faculties, knowing that the chances are against my seeing more than one more birthday and yet I wake up as keen as ever I was to improve the shining hour. I am as happy as I seem to be, yes, but that's because this side of sociopathy or advanced religious zealotry we can only take so much happiness before we are saturated with it. We have a limited capacity for happiness, but an almost infinitely unlimited capacity for, well, not unhappiness exactly, but non-happiness.

Which, I imagine, is why much of the time we are as fulfilled by the various forms of personal non-happiness - anger, disappointment, envy, hatred, frustration, fear, alienation - as we are by contentment. This article, for instance, is a rarity in the British press, with its chirpy positivism and its imminent injunction to look on the bright side. Apart from tales of individual bravery, endeavour or luck, most newspaper stories are designed to enrage, upset, frighten and otherwise encourage all those negative emotions of jealousy and territoriality which we seem to relish, which is why papers published by the types who ask 'Why can't there be more good news in the papers?' invariably fail.

But the truth is that in the developed world, for most of us, most of the time, life is as good as it ever could be and infinitely better than it was for any generation preceding ours. As a teenager, I was, like millions of others, taken with the utopianism of William Morris's News From Nowhere and the description of a society where equality and social justice prevailed and as a result fear, anger, jealousy and the rest of it fell away. It wasn't just that everyone in that impossible world had plenty to eat, a roof over their head and fulfilling work, but that they never woke up feeling grumpy, never envied anyone else their greater happiness, never suffered, in short, from the iniquities not of economic distribution but those of serotonin levels and pain thresholds.

Yes, I know it's easy for me in the soft South to say it, and I know that there is real poverty and deprivation in the country, that the income gap is widening and the distribution of the country's wealth is getting less equitable by the day. And yes, I know too that it's no comfort to the freezing pensioner or the confined single mother at the end of her tether to know that three or four generations ago their lives would have been regarded by the freezing and confined masses as normal or even comparatively desirable. But the fact remains that for the first time in the history of our species, the vast majority of us in the West have more than enough to eat, somewhere relatively warm to live, the ability to move ourselves around the country and even the world as the fancy takes us, a sufficiency of resources with which we can entertain and distract ourselves.

I understand why when the Roundtree Trust reports on poverty in Britain it annoys Daily Mail readers (or, more usually, writers) by including a TV and video recorder in the list of essentials without which normal life isn't considered possible, but I can't bring myself to believe that the reason for most of the unhappiness in the country has to do with economic imbalance as much as it does with some innate need for a couple of portions of discontent as part of our psyche's emotional diet.

But even if you can't agree with that as a description of the country as a whole, let's look at it as a description of you and me, that part of society which reads lengthy essays in broadsheet Sunday newspapers and which, by that definition, has enough superfluous income to afford the paper and enough superfluous time to read it.

The other week, I wrote in this paper about alternative medicine. Briefly put, I was, and am, against it because I think it doesn't work on real organic illness. I don't want to rehearse that argument again here, but what I didn't point out in the piece is that the boom in alternative medicine has little to do with the failure of orthodox remedies to cure serious disease - the vast majority of people with heart conditions or cancer or what have you still, quite rightly, submit to the orthodoxy - but with the alternativists' claims to be able to deal with illnesses which orthodox doctors can't diagnose, let alone treat.

They are, if you like, the luxury illnesses, the illnesses which can be afforded by a society with too little to worry about. In my pre-cancerous, hypochondriacal days, I was forever presenting my GP with vague symp toms of even vaguer illnesses, being sent off for blood tests, investigations to see whether my fluttering heartbeat was a sign of something more organically entrenched than a mere fondness for too many cigarettes, late nights and dodgy social situations. They are the illnesses which result from overexpectation, from the belief that we can feel happy, comfortable, positive, motivated all the time. But to feel that good that often you have to be pretty stupid in that way that stupidity so often manifests itself, as a lack of imagination.

But because most of us aren't stupid and do have enough imagination to posit a world beyond our immediate and personal space and time we create worries which previous generations wouldn't have had time for. It's no coincidence, for instance, that animal rights as anything but the most intellectual of concepts has arrived as a popular movement only with postwar prosperity. Only the rich, with their Gore-Tex and Polar Fleeces can afford to be sniffy about animal skins; in polar societies where you skin a seal or die of hypothermia the options for animal liberationists are more limited.

Or we worry about televised violence but rarely stop to consider that ours is one of a handful of recent generations which only sees that sort of violence on television. I, for instance, have never seen a dead body in, as it were, the flesh, but I doubt if my four-times great grandfather escaping the pogroms of Russia could have said that, or even somebody brought up in a big city during the war. My children have seen only the most cartoon-like violence and are none the less shocked by it; a London child 200 years ago would have lived in a town surrounded by death, disease, prostitution, violence and poverty on a level we can only imagine.

It's the same with politics generally. Until relatively recently, mass political movements were still about basic rights of food, shelter, education and self-sufficiency. The reason fewer people vote these days, or turn up to political meetings, is that for the vast majority of us those rights have been fulfilled. The nearest thing we had to a political rally this year had nothing to do with the rights of man or human suffering or any of the subjects which my forebears - or even my younger self - would have recognised as the sort of thing which brought a country to its knees; no, it was about the price of petrol, and although at one level it was about the conditions that lorry drivers and farmers operate under, for the most part it was about how much it costs us to drive in our own cars into work every day.

The nonsense of the campaign as a chapter in the movement for human rights became most apparent when the lorry drivers hijacked the spectre of the Jarrow March to push their essentially petit-bourgeois message. But then, that's the nature of modern politics and the only time you'll see the old political icons these days are in adverts for mobile phones or foreign holidays where phrases like 'Join the revolution!' and 'Cry freedom!' are bandied about for a generation which knows nothing of their provenance. Just as we have luxury illnesses to replace the real ones, so we now have luxury politics.

All of which seems to have distracted me from the chirpiness I promised and, more importantly, the answer to the editor's question.

And the answer is this:

This is what it's all about. It's about reading a paper on a Sunday morning while you're thinking about whether you can be arsed to go to the neighbours' New Year's Eve party tonight. It's about getting angry with me for having different opinions from yours or not expressing the ones you have as well as you would have expressed them. It's about the breakfast you've just had and the dinner you're going to have. It's about the random acts of kindness which still, magically, preponderate over acts of incivility or nastiness. It's about rereading Great Expectations and about who's going to win the 3.30 at Haydock Park. It's about being able to watch old episodes of Frasier on satellite TV whenever we want, having the choice of three dozen breakfast cereals and seven brands of virgin olive oil at Sainsbury's. It's about loving and being loved, about doing the right thing, about one day being missed when we're gone.

And that's all it's about. It isn't about heaven and hell or the love of Christ or Allah or Yahveh because even if those things do exist, they don't have to exist for us to get on with it.

It is, above all I suppose, about passing time. And the only thing I know that you don't is that time passes at the same rate and in much the same way whether you're going to live to 48 or 148. Why am I happy? Because I'm alive. And the simple answer to the question 'What the hell is the point of it all' is this is the point of it all. You aren't happy? Yes you are: this, here, now, is what happiness is. Enjoy it.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Susan Greenfield went to the same school as her mother Doris, but while she ran away to become a chorus girl, Susan has excelled academically, winning a professorship of pharmacology, a directorship and a CBE
fields.trailText: Susan Greenfield went to the same school as her mother Doris, but while she ran away to become a chorus girl, Susan has excelled academically, winning a professorship of pharmacology, a directorship and a CBE.
fields.body:
Susan Greenfield: My mother is very bright, but she was born into the sort of background where people didn't have access to education. Her father was a painter and builder during the war when there wasn't very much work. I was just very fortunate that she encouraged me all the time. She was never pushy, but her dictum was that you must always do what you want to do in life.

My mother encouraged me to be a bit of a pioneer and gave me the ability to debunk things. She won a county scholarship to a girls' school in London which was a very big deal. She found it very snooty and ran away. I was sent to the same school because she said, 'It's a really intellectual snooty school, it'll just suit you.'

A lot of my work is geared towards popularising science and a very happy spin-off of that is that my mother can understand a lot of the scientific work I do. She had been a chorus girl so she met a broad range of people. London working-class women of the 40s and 50s weren't known for their liberal attitudes, but the fact that she married my father, who's Jewish, speaks volumes for her open-minded nature.

On rainy days we used to love looking at her photographs. Her time on the stage seemed like a fairy-tale world, all those fabulous costumes. She is still very glamorous. I've never seen her without make-up on or in casual clothes. It's something I've inherited, which is probably why I don't look like a typical scientist.

I was given a lot more freedom than many of my middle-class friends. My mother made a great fuss of everything I did. When I was young she let me paint my bedroom in a lurid orange colour with black stick men marching across the wall.

If anything good happens, she is the first person I tell. When I got my CBE, my first thought was, 'God, I can't wait to tell her she's coming to Buckingham Palace, she's going to love that.' She was crying down the phone when I told her and she cried when I received the Queen at the Royal Institution.

Doris Greenfield: It was obvious that Susan was clever when she went to school at the age of three and was already able to read.

We've always been very close and accepting of each other for what we are. She's academic and I was a chorus girl, but she hasn't tried to turn me into a scientist and I didn't try to put her on the stage.

I used to do her homework with her because I really loved maths. It's funny thinking back, but I should have known she'd end up working in science. I remember when she was learning how to work out how to convert from Fahrenheit to Centigrade. I made a table with all the calculations on for her bedroom wall to help her learn it. I've done a lot of groundwork with her since she was tiny, but, of course, she outgrew me.

Susan's pet subject is the brain and she's researching something that might one day cure Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. She wrote one of her scientific books for the layman and dedicated it to Reg, her dad, and me because she knew that we would be able to understand this particular book. So that's got pride of place on the bookshelf.

We really knew how to have fun together. I knew how to make clothes from my time on the stage, so we would go to the market or to Oxfam and buy material for me to make up her designs. I like to see people looking glamorous and she's always been like that since she was a child. I gave her her first lipstick when she was 13.

Susan's made us feel like teenagers in our old age, giving us something to get up for in the morning. She takes me anywhere she can. We went to lunch at the Getty's house, but the most exciting day was when she got her CBE. When Prince Charles pinned the medal on her, I really wanted to clap and shout but I didn't dare.

I never thought I'd see Susan go so far. I knew she was clever, and when she went to Oxford I said, 'You're going to end up being a don', but I never thought she'd end up with a professorship of pharmacology, a directorship and a CBE. I understand her not having children because she always has to give her best to what she's doing.

She won a county scholarship to a girls' school in London which was a very big deal. She found it very snooty and ran away. I was sent to the same school because she said, 'It's a really intellectual snooty school, it'll just suit you.' A lot of my work is geared towards popularising science and a very happy spin-off of that is that my mother can understand a lot of the scientific work I do. She had been a chorus girl so she met a broad range of people. London working-class women of the 40s and 50s weren't known for their liberal attitudes, but the fact that she married my father, who's Jewish, speaks volumes for her open-minded nature. On rainy days we used to love looking at her photographs. Her time on the stage seemed like a fairy-tale world, all those fabulous costumes. She is still very glamorous. I've never seen her without make-up on or in casual clothes. It's something I've inherited, which is probably why I don't look like a typical scientist. I was given a lot more freedom than many of my middle-class friends. My mother made a great fuss of everything I did. When I was young she let me paint my bedroom in a lurid orange colour with black stick men marching across the wall. If anything good happens, she is the first person I tell. When I got my CBE, my first thought was, 'God, I can't wait to tell her she's coming to Buckingham Palace, she's going to love that.' She was crying down the phone when I told her and she cried when I received the Queen at the Royal Institution. Doris Greenfield: It was obvious that Susan was clever when she went to school at the age of three and was already able to read. We've always been very close and accepting of each other for what we are. She's academic and I was a chorus girl, but she hasn't tried to turn me into a scientist and I didn't try to put her on the stage. I used to do her homework with her because I really loved maths. It's funny thinking back, but I should have known she'd end up working in science. I remember when she was learning how to work out how to convert from Fahrenheit to Centigrade. I made a table with all the calculations on for her bedroom wall to help her learn it. I've done a lot of groundwork with her since she was tiny, but, of course, she outgrew me. Susan's pet subject is the brain and she's researching something that might one day cure Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. She wrote one of her scientific books for the layman and dedicated it to Reg, her dad, and me because she knew that we would be able to understand this particular book. So that's got pride of place on the bookshelf. We really knew how to have fun together. I knew how to make clothes from my time on the stage, so we would go to the market or to Oxfam and buy material for me to make up her designs. I like to see people looking glamorous and she's always been like that since she was a child. I gave her her first lipstick when she was 13. Susan's made us feel like teenagers in our old age, giving us something to get up for in the morning. She takes me anywhere she can. We went to lunch at the Getty's house, but the most exciting day was when she got her CBE. When Prince Charles pinned the medal on her, I really wanted to clap and shout but I didn't dare. I never thought I'd see Susan go so far. I knew she was clever, and when she went to Oxford I said, 'You're going to end up being a don', but I never thought she'd end up with a professorship of pharmacology, a directorship and a CBE. I understand her not having children because she always has to give her best to what she's doing.

fields.headline: Your Man of the Year
fields.standfirst: Don Hale
fields.trailText: 'Me? Really? Well, I don't know what to say. This is disconcerting, you know.' Don Hale's reaction, when told he had been chosen by Observer readers as their Man of the Year, is typically understated. He isn't comfortable with fame. He has never sought to be the centre of attention. He's a journalist, the editor of a local newspaper, a modest and diligent man.
fields.body:
'Me? Really? Well, I don't know what to say. This is disconcerting, you know.' Don Hale's reaction, when told he had been chosen by Observer readers as their Man of the Year, is typically understated. He isn't comfortable with fame. He has never sought to be the centre of attention. He's a journalist, the editor of a local newspaper, a modest and diligent man.

Yet he has been heroic. For six years, since becoming editor of the Matlock Mercury , Hale has campaigned for the release of Stephen Downing, who, 27 years ago, was found guilty of murdering Wendy Sewell. Now that Downing looks set to be released on bail pending appeal in January, Hale is being applauded (the day after I spoke to him he was named Journalist of the Year by What the Papers Say). But the years of campaigning have been lonely and dangerous. He has been threatened, intimidated and derided: the police have been hostile; there have even been two attempts to kill him.

Did he never feel like giving up, I ask? 'Oh well no. And I only had six years of carrying the torch. Stephen has held on for 27.'

In 1973, Wendy Sewell, aged 32, was murdered in a graveyard in Bakewell, where Downing worked as the gardener. He was 17, but had the mental age of 11. He found Sewell as she lay dying, ran to get the police, even pointed out the pickaxe lying next to her. He was then taken to the police station and subjected to nine hours of interrogation, without a solicitor or a care worker. 'They kept on at him,' says Hale. 'He claims they shook him to keep him awake, they pulled his hair. Downstairs, they were taking bets as to who would get a confession out of him. Eight times, his parents tried to get to see him. The police told Stephen he wasn't to worry - Sewell was in a coma, and when she came round she could tell them who really did it. They told him to sign the confession and then he could go home. So the lad signed.'

Wendy Sewell died, and Downing immediately retracted his confession; since then has steadfastly insisted on his innocence. He should have been released from prison 10 years ago, but because he was categorised IDOM (In Denial of Murder), was kept behind bars. He has just spent his twenty-eighth Christmas in prison, because the CPS botched the paperwork and refused him bail.

Hale was first approached by Downing's parents, the other unsung heroes of the case. He started investigating and immediately 'knew there was something amiss'. He unearthed a very different story from the official one. Downing's confession was full of holes. There was no forensic evidence to link him to the murder. Witnesses had come forward to say they had seen another man fleeing from the graveyard, bloodstained, 'like a bat out of hell'.

When Hale finally published his first story about the case, a slew of fresh witnesses came forward. 'The community knew he was innocent,' says Hale. 'There is in Bakewell a sense of collective guilt.' But they were also scared of helping Hale: many of them told him to come and see them, but to park his car in the next road or come after dark. Sewell had had many boyfriends, many of them married men, prominent in the area. People believe they know who the murderer is. Hale believes he knows.

But if members of the community wanted to help Hale, others wanted to stop him. The paper 'wasn't exactly helpful', he says mildly. 'I think they wanted to move me on. And the national press probably thought I was barmy.' Prison officers were hostile: they swore at him, strip-searched him, tried to prevent his access to Downing. His mail was intercepted. A tap was put on his phone. He was once followed by a car and, when he checked its registration through a police contact, found that it belonged to either MI5 or CID.

It becomes more dramatic. Hale was nearly run down by an unmarked car which came roaring at him on a dark night, headlights off. Months later, he was called out on a fake story and found himself in a country lane. A lorry came up behind him and bumped several times into the back of the car, trying to knock him off the road. As he rounded a bend, a second lorry was blocking his way. At the last minute, he veered off the lane into a field. The lorry behind crashed into the one in front. It sounds like James Bond. 'Yes,' he agrees. 'A murder-mystery; surreal.'

Still, Hale's admiration is for Downing. 'I call him the invisible man. No one wanted to know. He was lost in a system that didn't care. And, you know, he's had no life. He's never had a girlfriend. He's never drunk a pint of beer. He is the victim and the hero. I won't rest until he's out of there. Free.'

Hale carries a torch and it throws some light on the dark. Observer readers did well to choose him. 'Thank them from me', he says. 'Gosh.'

fields.headline: Your Woman of the Year
fields.standfirst: Susan Greenfield
fields.trailText: Three days after Christmas, and most of the country snowbound, it was no surprise to find Professor Susan Greenfield in her Oxford laboratory at 8.30 in the morning. This, after all, is a someone who sets her alarm clock for 5am, who unwinds on her day off by writing books, one of those people who takes her laptop on holiday. You could call the Observer Woman of the Year many things - academic, author, medical researcher, entrepreneur, newspaper columnist, television and radio presenter, director of the Royal Institution - but never, even in the dead zone of late December, a slacker.
fields.body:
Three days after Christmas, and most of the country snowbound, it was no surprise to find Professor Susan Greenfield in her Oxford laboratory at 8.30 in the morning. This, after all, is a someone who sets her alarm clock for 5am, who unwinds on her day off by writing books, one of those people who takes her laptop on holiday. You could call the Observer Woman of the Year many things - academic, author, medical researcher, entrepreneur, newspaper columnist, television and radio presenter, director of the Royal Institution - but never, even in the dead zone of late December, a slacker.

She was surprised she had come top in the reader's poll, and claimed there were 'far more worthy candidates'. About the idea of role models, she has mixed feelings. 'If it's to show people what one can do, what it's possible to achieve, then I think it's a good thing. But it would be rather sad if anyone went around copying me, wearing a silly pair of black platform shoes.'

Ah, yes, the clothes. Famed for sporting a silver anorak and leopard-skin leggings at work, Greenfield has grown used to the attention that, as a woman in the public eye, her wardrobe has inevitably drawn. And having posed for Hello! in a mini-skirt and high heels, she appears unafraid of the danger of not being taken seriously. But then she can't exactly win on this one. She was criticised for donning a white lab coat in Brain Story, the six-part BBC2 series she wrote and fronted earlier this year, because it was felt it could alienate some viewers. 'Would you rather I wore a bikini?' was her knowing reply.

The irony, of course, that lies behind all this surface discussion is that Greenfield's main project in life is to make us all more cerebral in our interests. As she often says: 'The brain is everything you are.' Not only is she bright enough to understand papers with titles such as 'Ultrastructural evidence for dendritic release of acetylcholinesterase in the rat substantia nigra', but she's also smart enough to know that the rest of us are not.

As such, she is an unapologetic populariser. In 1998, she won the Michael Faraday medal from the Royal Society for her contribution to disseminating science to the public. The same year she became the first woman director of the Royal Institution, an establishment that hitherto had been settling into comfortable stuffiness but which Greenfield wants to transform into a kind of Groucho Club for the sciences.

The daughter of an electrician and a dancer from west London, Greenfield has made a convention of being unconventional. She didn't take so much as an 'O' level in science at school, and having started out reading philosophy at Oxford, she switched to experimental psychology, before going on to write her PhD on pharmacology.

She is now professor of synaptic pharmacology at Oxford, from where she also runs Synaptica, a company she helped set up with venture capital to exploit the research she and her group were conducting into brain degeneration. She has patented a protein which she hopes can be used in treatments in the near future for Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.

She is also no stranger to controversy. While a committed feminist - 'I run my lab in a less confrontational way than men,' she once said - she upset a number of women colleagues when she said that she did not think being a mother was compatible with making it to the top in science. Now 50, she and her husband, fellow Oxford don Peter Atkins, decided a decade ago not to have children.

Awarded a CBE this year, Greenfield, who is also President of the Association for Science Education, has published two books in the past 12 months, both on the brain. Although she would like to write a novel in the future, for the time being her energies are concentrated on revealing the mysteries of our least understood organ.

'It's going to be the century of the mind,' Greenfield told me. It's reassuring that, at its beginning, Observer readers recognised someone who uses her mind and wants us to use ours.

fields.headline: Running on empty
fields.standfirst: Colourless lager, super dry beer, alcohol that sobers you up... drink designers don't always get it right
fields.trailText: Colourless lager, super dry beer, alcohol that sobers you up... drink designers don't always get it right.
fields.body:
Tonight, if not sooner, we raise a glass to our tomorrows, but what does the future hold for the drinker? According to the brave new world of Aldous Huxley, we are supposed to be stoned on an ancient Indian plant juice called soma. We came close a few years ago when the American brewer Miller test-marketed a beer containing guarana, an extract of the cocoa plant. Among its several effects, guarana is supposed to sober up the drinker. Perhaps for that reason, this potion did not sell.

Bass, which used to be a brewing company, is planning to test-market a 'premium lager' (ie, 'it gets you drunk'), with guarana and caffeine. There is already a guarana 'energy drink' called Indigo.

Drinks with flavour are a problem for the marketing man. One solution is to give all drinks a sugary-sweet fruitiness, as in alco-pops. The ultimate is to eliminate all flavours. This view might be said to colour marketeers' view of the future. Except that colour is often eliminated, too.

Much exploratory work on the beers of the future has been done by the Miller Brewing Company. Its record of aberrant innovation goes back to Miller Lite. 'Like drinking wet air' was the verdict of one critic. To make this kind of beer, use as little barley malt as possible and ferment as far as feasible. Some brewers of 'light' beers help things along with industrial enzymes, or simply add water. Then came Miller Genuine Draft, sterile-filtered to remove any sign of life, and much of the flavour. Finally, there was Miller Clear Beer, filtered also to remove all colour. This one failed in test market.

Remember 'dry' beer? And 'ice' beer? Such 'techno' beers tend to sweep all before them for three or four years, then fade. Whatever happened to the 'dry ice' beer predicted by cynics?

The newest 'techno beer' in test market, again from Bass, is called Arc. It is served through a chiller at sub-zero celsius, at high pressure, which stops it freezing solid, though there are tiny ice crystals in the glass. Why so cold? Because cold beer tastes of nothing. My most chilling prediction for 2001: beer on a stick.

Now is surely the time for someone to reveal the flavours of Romulan Ale, favoured by the bad guys in Star Trek . The good people drink 'Rigelian' brandy. As always, the grain is demonised and the grape elevated. Thank goodness for down-to-earth Scotty, and his occasional whisky.

Even in 2001, this is the proper drink for New Year's Eve, and the continuing rise of malts is another good omen. After 'wood finishes' (in Port pipes or Madeira drums, for example) and 'cask strength' malts (alcohol by volume in 60s or 50s, rather than the usual 40s), the newest trend is vintage-dated bottling. I'm tempted to wonder whether the 2001 vintage of Glenmorangie will be plutonium-finished.

What we flavour freaks want is yet more. We are looking forward to a Longrow whisky made entirely with the distillery's own pungently peated malt, but that is not due until 2002. As Longrow whisky is also distinctly briney, I wonder whether it might be used in the Pan Galactic Gargle Blaster, as featured in the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy . The recipe for that drink includes 'one measure of water from the seas of Santraginus; Fallian marsh gas; and Arcturan Mega-gin'. In the book, the cocktail is favoured by the supreme egotist Zaphod Beeblebrox, who has two heads. After tonight's celebrations, we may all wake up tomorrow feeling similarly endowed.

In honour of Thunderbirds ' return to terrestrial TV, Match Bar's Dick Bradsell has created an International Rescue cocktail. It's a bloody mary variant made with tomato juice, tequila, lime, orange and, dangerously, 'a dash of whatever gave you the hangover.' Or you could try:

The Pan Galactic Gargle Blaster

A less extreme version, culled from cyberspace: fill a Collins glass with ice. Add 2oz vodka and 1oz triple sec. Fill the glass almost to the top with pineapple juice. Add oz grenadine for colour, and top off the glass with 7-Up. Stir the drink until it turns orangey-pink.

fields.headline: Tea tree oil
fields.standfirst: It gives Earl Grey its flavour, but soon you'll be drizzling it over your salad. Sybil Kapoor gets set for Bergamot oil
fields.trailText: It gives Earl Grey its flavour, but soon you'll be drizzling it over your salad. Sybil Kapoor gets set for Bergamot oil.
fields.body:
Food is frequently at the forefront of scientific development. The creation of everything from margarine to freeze-dried strawberries in your breakfast cereal has resulted from scientists applying their minds to a particular problem. Margarine was created to help feed France in 1869 while freeze-dried food was developed for astronauts. Today, however, many of our most fashionable foods owe their appeal to a resurgence in ancient technology.

The latest überchic ingredient, for example, is an exclusive Italian extra-virgin olive oil flavoured with bergamot. It is currently only available to a few select London chefs - you have to dine at Belair House, Roussillon, Isola or Orrery to experience bergamot oil's amazingly floral-citrus flavour.

Bergamot (Citrus bergamia) is a subspecies of the Seville orange. Its rind yields an aromatic oil that is widely used by perfume houses, although most of us will be more familiar with its scent in Earl Grey tea. The trees grow in Calabria in southern Italy, not far from the remote olive groves on the rugged slopes of Monte Vulture. Here, the Sinigaglia family have hand-picked their rare Ogliarola del Vulture olives for centuries, before using a traditional millstone to grind them into a paste. This then sets and gradually releases a small amount of oil, which is slowly decanted to make 2,000 bottles of a delicately unacidic oil.

Around 150 years ago, some discussion arose in Melfi, the local town, about the Roman practice of flavouring olive oil with bergamot. As a result, the Sinigaglia family decided to reproduce this Roman delicacy. Not easy as the natural acidity of the bergamot could easily upset the fragile oil.

According to the Bruno Giorgi, marketing director of FreshTruffle.Com, the sole UK importer, the family crushes the bergamot zest with their olives to produce the oil. So far, no one else has managed to successfully copy it.

As the company only sells direct to select chefs, I quizzed one on the appeal of this recherché ingredient. Having managed to lay my hands on a rare bottle (the privilege of being a food writer), I have to agree. It's fantastic stuff.

fields.bodyText: Food is frequently at the forefront of scientific development. The creation of everything from margarine to freeze-dried strawberries in your breakfast cereal has resulted from scientists applying their minds to a particular problem. Margarine was created to help feed France in 1869 while freeze-dried food was developed for astronauts. Today, however, many of our most fashionable foods owe their appeal to a resurgence in ancient technology. The latest überchic ingredient, for example, is an exclusive Italian extra-virgin olive oil flavoured with bergamot. fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: native American warnings and facing a brighter future
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: native American warnings and facing a brighter future.
fields.body:
Science fiction has morphed into science fact so smoothly we've hardly noticed. We adapt to new technology more and more quickly, almost in pace with the market's roll-out rate of new products. We are blasé to the point of absurdity. We politely overlook the human fallibility factor inherent in all technology, and not so much bumble as hurtle around in a numbed state of semi-enlightenment, our twisted buddha minds hardly arrested by newspaper headlines such as 'Danger Junkie to return to the UK!' Imagine a Victorian trying to make sense of that. (I remember Danger Man - I remember Danger Mouse - but now we have Danger Junkie.)

Because it seems, in this sci-fact morphed sci-fi world, we have become a society of committed junkies. Whether for information, gossip, drugs, alcohol, food, excitement, sex, travel, good looks, or the plethora of assorted fashion items we simply must have, we are almost all of us junkies of at least one sort or another. Our science, in the sense of our collective gnosis, is so huge in its implications and far reaching in its sophistication it defies description, let alone assessment. No need to bore you with yet another résumé of the technological wonders on offer - most of us have gone into overload, induced inurement to it all already. In short, we have entered, perhaps illegally, into what appears to be the intelligence of the divine realm itself. Splitting the atom initiated an irrevocable process of splitting the very fabric of reality as we perceive it, in our quest to know more, be more and have more (and of everything).

We have earnestly attempted to eradicate all diseases, insulate ourselves fully from the elements, whether indoors or on the road, and bring the wild animals who would normally be eating us for breakfast under our dominion. And we have been successful. We have managed disease well and instead now face a series of global plague epidemics. We have insulated ourselves so effectively using fossil fuel as the glue, that we've created an unpredictable weather monster capable of wiping out entire cities with a gust of wind and a touch of tidal action. Moreover, we've done such a good job with the lions, tigers and all other species of the wild, we shall soon have none left.

As we sail forth into the sunset of the next global recession and whatever social or geopolitical chaos that may unleash, our faces will be handsome and taught with botox and face lifts. As we wander the streets full of knife wielders and gun toters, we will do so WAP-phones in hand, with boldness and aplomb. In the midst of a world order crumbling before our eyes, we will display equipoise and courage.

And why? Because we have finally discovered our spirituality. Perhaps a little late in the day to prevent disaster on a scale hardly imagined, but certainly not too late to help us all find inner peace and enjoy the show to the max, online or off, until the lights finally go out.

Two thousand years ago, the Hopis, the revered spiritual fathers of all Native Americans, made a prophecy that at precisely this time in history, we would cede the dominion game to rodents and insects and proceed to destroy our world, unless we made a rapid reversal in our consumeristic tendencies. This message was elucidated with understated elegance almost 20 years ago in the film, Koyaanisqatsi , Hopi for 'Dire warning - world out of balance!' Twenty years have passed. Two thousand years have passed and we still really haven't listened much. Now I'm a healer, not a prophet of doom, and have personally witnessed many miracles of healing in the course of treating supposedly terminal cases. I have also witnessed things go the other way. I have learned not to make rash prognoses. No one alive has access to enough of the relevant data to be able to make a truly informed prognosis. So rather than give way to pessimism, we would be better advised to continue to explore the mysteries of healing and spirituality: in other words, those methods that will enhance our innate enjoyment of life. Because only from the state of joy will come the inspiration that could guide us, and specifically our scientists in all their many guises, to find the miraculous solutions we so crucially and urgently require to facilitate our very survival as a species at this time.

One thing's for certain. Whichever way destiny's pendulum swings, and you can be sure there will be a lot of swinging action forthcoming, we'll all enjoy it a lot more if we learn to breathe and relax. It is also true to say that the world we have created has, in all its myriad forms, been instigated by peoples' ideas. Architects, designers, philosophers and their like, have through the ages helped mould the sculpture we call civilisation. It follows then that if we wish to engineer a subtle change of course in order to avert global disaster, we must like them, start with the idea or vision. To this end, you may feel occasionally moved to visualise our globe spinning majestically, enveloped in a sheath of otherworldly healing 'light', as if after having eaten Readybrek, and imagine that light bringing common sense, balance and uncommon wisdom to the minds and actions of us all. Fairies at the bottom of the garden stuff, perhaps, but if enough of us share the vision, while it may not move many mountains, it might prevent the oceans moving us from our homes. So do be optimistic, for as any healer will tell you, while there's still life there's still hope.

 If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com.

webTitle: Colombian policy puts Bush under pressure

fields.headline: In the line of fire
fields.standfirst: America's controversial plan to rid Colombia of drugs will put George Bush under pressure from the start of his presidency, writes  Hugh O'Shaughnessy
fields.trailText: America's controversial plan to rid Colombia of drugs will put George Bush under pressure from the start of his presidency, writes  Hugh O'Shaughnessy.
fields.body:
George W. Bush faces a baptism of fire over his Latin America policy that will threaten the first days of his presidency next month. Responsibility will lie heavily on the shoulders of Condoleezza Rice, formerly his tutor in foreign affairs and now his National Security Adviser, as the political bombardment opens up on the White House from Colombia, Venezuela and Cuba.

Next month a huge, much-criticised US military operation, Plan Colombia, will begin what is seen as the impossible task of stopping the production of marijuana, cocaine and heroin in the wildest country in the Western Hemisphere.

Five hundred US troops are already in Colombia supporting an army which itself deals in drugs. This army's human rights record is as bad as any in the Balkans, Central or West Africa or Chile, and its collaboration with civilian death squads against left-wing guerrillas is routine and goes unpunished. On 21 December alone, 26 Colombian military and police personnel, including four colonels, were accused of collaboration in the massacre of civilians.

Fighting between the army and guerrillas has forced up to 2 million Colombians from their homes in an exodus comparable to the calamities seen in Rwanda in the 1990s. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) were probably behind the murders on Friday of Diego Turbay, the Liberal Party chairman of the peace commission of the lower house, his mother and three bodyguards. They killed his brother three years ago.

Former US Secretary of State George Shultz and the conservative economist Milton Friedman are among many now saying that the war on drugs, so dear to Bush, is causing more harm worldwide than drug abuse itself. Meanwhile, President Jorge Batlle of Uruguay is the first Latin American head of state to come out in favour of the legalisation of drugs. William Ratliff, from the conservative Hoover Institution at Stanford, the university Rice herself used to run, argued last week that Plan Colombia was heading for crisis.

Colin Powell, Bush's Secretary of State, Ratliff concluded, 'must have noticed the large and war-oriented US aid package to Colombia flies in the face of his own famed doctrine: clarity of objective, use of massive force, certainty of victory and exit strategy, and public support'.

When the body bags start coming back from Colombia, and the cost of increased aid and of replaced equipment is understood, there will be popular protest in the US, he forecast. He might have added that Colombian violence started in 1948, decades before Colombia became a drugs exporter. But the arming of ill-disciplined and bloodthirsty soldiery continues in Colombia as it did in the 1980s in Central America.

Just before Christmas the US government signed two contracts for 30 Black Hawk helicopters, of the type the guerrillas have already succeeded in shooting down, which should all be delivered next year. As if they sensed future casualties, the manufacturers said each helicopter could carry 'up to 11 fully outfitted troops or four stretchers'.

For its part, Farc in its New Year's message threatens to 'defeat the evil war plans of the governments of the United States and Colombia'.

Meanwhile in neighbouring Venezuela, President Hugo Chávez, himself a former paratroop colonel who enjoys great popular support, is perfecting the none too difficult art of infuriating Washington.

He has refused US warplanes permission to fly over Venezuelan territory from their new bases in the Dutch Antilles. He is bitterly critical of Plan Colombia, as is Mireya Moscoso, the President of Panama, who has denied the Pentagon leave to reoccupy the former Canal Zone bases it gave up a year ago.

Chávez has flown to visit President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad and Muammar Gadaffi in Tripoli. He has expressed his great admiration for President Fidel Castro on a visit to Havana and is supplying Cuba with the cheap oil it desperately needs.

Most seriously for Bush, Venezuela, as the principal founder of Opec, has this month been able to nominate Ali Rodríguez, Chávez's former Oil Minister, as secretary-general of Opec in Vienna. Venezuela, the main supplier of the fuel oil which keeps New York and other US cities warm in the winter, is not expected to do any favours for Bush, who faces the prospect of a serious slowdown in the US economy, by trying to keep the world oil price down.

In addition, José Vicente Rangel, Chávez's Foreign Minister, has publicly challenged Washington to explain why $4 billion worth of marijuana is being grown in the US itself.

Rumours are circulating that hawks in Washington are seeking allies within the Venezuelan mili tary for a coup d'état against Chávez. Were that to happen, the image of the 'Ugly American' would resurface worldwide.

In comparison with the potential for yet more disaster in Colombia and Venezuela, Cuba is the least of the President-elect's worries. Yet it does present him with some ticklish problems.

The Cuban exiles in Florida who did so much to win Bush the presidency have put the humiliation they suffered in the Elián González crisis this year behind them. Newly confident, the exiles, and perhaps his brother Jeb Bush, Florida state governor, will be seeking some recompense from the new President, perhaps in the form of harsher measures against Castro.

But if these are introduced it will upset the World Trade Organisation, the European Union, and many US businessmen. The businessmen are seeking to sign more, not fewer, deals with the largest island in the Caribbean where, despite shortages, tourism is expanding rapidly and where, in the absence of Uncle Sam for the past 40 years, the Canadians and Europeans are well entrenched.

As a Russian specialist, Rice may not have the experience needed in Latin America but one of her skills may prove useful: she is an excellent ice-skater. She and Bush will need all her dexterity on the hard, slippery, unforgiving surface of US relations with the Latin Americans in 2001.

fields.headline: Refugees pour back to London
fields.standfirst:
Asylum dispersal system collapses as record numbers seek refuge in UK

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's system for dealing with asylum seekers is in complete disarray after the collapse of attempts to disperse potential refugees around the country.
fields.body:
Britain's system for dealing with asylum seekers is in complete disarray after the collapse of attempts to disperse potential refugees around the country.

Local councils and refugee groups have warned Ministers that asylum seekers in their thousands are drifting back to London after dispersal, or are simply choosing to remain in the capital or the south east without any money for housing.

The compulsory dispersal system was introduced with a fanfare last April to ease the burden of supporting asylum seekers on a few councils in these areas. It was designed to house 65,000 people across the UK by next April.

But the latest figures from the Home Office show that only 9,340 have so far been dispersed, despite generous financial incentives for private companies to find empty properties, and the removal of all money for accommodation from those who fail to comply. Home Office officials told The Observer that the target has now been cut to 36,000.

The North West and Yorkshire have each taken 2,500 people, still well short of their targets of 6,000. But in some areas the figures are even lower. The South West has taken only 209 asylum seekers under the scheme and, so far, only nine people have been sent to Wales.

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the British Refugee Council, said asylum seekers were rejecting dispersal in droves because they are often sent to sink estates where they are too frightened to venture outside their homes.

'Many asylum seekers are giving up their right to accommodation and squeezing into already cramped conditions with relatives so they can reach proper legal support, pursue their claims with the Home Office or simply feel safe,' he said.

'To ensure the dispersal programme works, asylum seekers need to feel confident that their basic needs will be met and that they are not at risk of racial harassment.'

The collapse of the dispersal programme comes as the Government braces itself for record asylum applications. Attempts to toughen the system by introducing a compulsory voucher system have done nothing to deter people. Up to November, 70,215 asylum seekers had entered the country. With a further 7,000 expected in December, this year's total is set to far exceed the 71,000 who arrived in 1999.

The Government also faces criticism over the rising cost of asylum. By next April this will have risen to £694 million, an increase of 18 per cent over last year.

Steve Hitchins, leader of Islington Council in London, said: 'I don't know a single council in London that doesn't want this problem dealt with humanely, but the money to deal with it has to come from central government. The Government believed that if they made life hard for people when they arrived in Britain, word would get back, and they wouldn't come here in the first place. They have been completely wrong.'

Amanda Sebestyen, of the Asylum Education and Legal Fund, said: 'People are just being shunted into places where there is no one qualified to help them. Because of this many have no chance of getting asylum, even though they have a clear-cut case.'

She said government claims to have cut the backlog of asylum applications to under 70,000 were boosted by a 40 per cent rise in the number rejected for not filling in their forms correctly.

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes, whose Southwark constituency is home to many asylum seekers, said: 'The Home Office must take responsibility for what is going on and recognise that dispersal just has not worked. There is huge pressure on London boroughs and housing services are already stretched beyond capacity.'

A Home Office spokesman insisted last night: 'We have yet to feel the deterrent effect of many of the measures we have put in place.' The backlog of asylum seekers awaiting decisions on their applications was being reduced.

'The numbers [of asylum seekers entering the country] were increasing before we enacted these measures. They could have been much higher if we had done nothing.'

The crisis has led the Government to draw up secret plans to house increasing numbers of asylum seekers in prisons. At the beginning of December, Home Secretary Jack Straw ordered the creation of 500 new places in prisons, including Liverpool and two London jails.

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes, whose Southwark constituency is home to many asylum seekers, said: 'The Home Office must take responsibility for what is going on and recognise that dispersal just has not worked. There is huge pressure on London boroughs and housing services are already stretched beyond capacity.' A Home Office spokesman insisted last night: 'We have yet to feel the deterrent effect of many of the measures we have put in place.' The backlog of asylum seekers awaiting decisions on their applications was being reduced. 'The numbers [of asylum seekers entering the country] were increasing before we enacted these measures. They could have been much higher if we had done nothing.' The crisis has led the Government to draw up secret plans to house increasing numbers of asylum seekers in prisons. At the beginning of December, Home Secretary Jack Straw ordered the creation of 500 new places in prisons, including Liverpool and two London jails. Related story Nowhere left to run

webTitle: BA in urgent flight safety review

fields.headline: BA in urgent flight safety review
fields.standfirst: BA orders urgent safety review after attack led to near disaster on jumbo
fields.trailText: British Airways announced yesterday that it is launching an urgent review of flight security after the near disaster when a deranged passenger fought flight crew for control of the aircraft.
fields.body:
British Airways announced yesterday that it is launching an urgent review of flight security after the near disaster when a deranged passenger fought flight crew for control of the aircraft.

The announcement came as airline pilots warned The Observer they would resist moves to tighten security on flight decks of British planes, by locking them into the cockpit. The dispute came as Captain William Hagan, praised as a hero for overpowering Paul Kefa Mukonyi, who had sent the the Kenya-bound 747 into a terrifying dive over Sudan, said he had only done 'what he had to do'.

Hagan returned as a passenger on the aircraft that had come close to destruction hours before. After being bitten on the ear and hand during the struggle, the 53-year-old was last night examined by doctors before leaving on holiday with his wife and two children, who were also on board. Describing his ordeal, he said: 'I pulled a man from the controls and my co-pilot, who was sitting there, did what he had to do. He controlled and recovered the aircraft and he did it well.'

The intruder had managed to turn off the auto-pilot as he struggled with Hagan and co-pilot Richard Webb, 35, sending the plane plummeting 10,000ft with 379 passengers on board, including singer Bryan Ferry and his family, and Jemima Khan with sons.

Hagan and Webb forced Mukonyi, 27, a Kenyan, into an upper-deck compartment where he was handcuffed. BA is the only airline in the UK to carry metal handcuffs, but others may now follow suit.

Pilots have suggested that Mukonyi - who is now being assessed in a Kenyan mental hospital - might have been spotted at check-in if more trained ground staff were available to talk to passengers. He was seen wandering around one section of the plane for about 30 minutes before he burst into the cockpit. Extra security measures already being suggested include passenger-screening on all flights, locked flightdeck doors and on-board security guards.

But screening is being dismissed as too time consuming - airlines like Israel's El Al already screen passengers at check-in and this makes the process four times longer than normal.

Virgin Atlantic's Deputy Chief Pilot, Geoff Andreasen, said: 'When it comes to the cockpit door, these have to be flimsy for evacuation reasons and it is unclear whether locking them would prove a real deterrent.'

The growing popularity of air travel will mean an increase in such incidents, according to the Brussels-based European Organisation for the Safety of Air Navigation. 'The problem is that you cannot see into people's minds, and that for every 1,000 passengers there will be someone who is unstable,' a spokesman said

A former Concorde pilot who has flown for 20 years said increased in-flight security would not be welcomed by pilots and many feel that it would be easy to gain access even to cockpits with locked doors. 'Britain has done the right thing by prosecuting those guilty of air rage, rather than just leaving them as other countries have done,' said one pilot.
