webTitle: Freeze wreaks havoc with easyJet flights

fields.headline: Fun for some but misery for hundreds as freeze wreaks havoc with easyJet flights
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Hundreds of New Year travellers flying with the budget airline easyJet were facing chaos this weekend as staff struggled to clear a backlog that built up following heavy snow falls on Thursday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of New Year travellers flying with the budget airline easyJet were facing chaos this weekend as staff struggled to clear a backlog that built up following heavy snow falls on Thursday.

The shambles came as forecasters said Britain's freeze is set to continue wreaking havoc with more snow, followed by floods once the thaw sets in.

Police were called to Luton and Liverpool airports in the early hours of yesterday to restore calm after more than 200 people were left stranded when the airline cancelled flights late on Friday. Around 100 staged a sit-in at an easyJet sales desk in Luton airport.

The airline is based at Luton, which was closed following the heavy snow for most of Thursday, and accounts for 60 per cent of the airport's flights.

One person was arrested at Liverpool, which was closed for most of yesterday because of ice, then freezing fog. Passengers flying from Belfast to Liverpool arrived yesterday after being stranded for two days.

Would-be travellers complained of lack of information and food. One man, told by the low-cost airline to go home, replied: 'I live in Spain.'

The company blamed a sub-contractor's failure to de-ice planes for the delays and said it had chartered extra flights. It promised compensation, but warned of further delays.'It is likely that many of the crews will be over their flying time limits by then, so there could be more problem,' a spokeswoman said.

Weather forecasters said that heavy snow showers would pepper northern parts of the country today, with the chance of snow further south 'It is going to be horrible,' said a PA Weather Centre spokeswoman.

She said it was difficult to tell when the band of weather would hit the country. 'By the time people go out, it will have started raining and it will be windy. It will be quite miserable.' She warned that the rain could turn to ice, making roads treacherous.

The big freeze has already taken a toll. A 48-year-old woman who stopped on the A460 near Rugeley in Staffordshire to clear her windscreen was killed after a collision with a Vauxhall Astra driven by a 51-year-old man from Heath Hayes, Cannock. Her Citroen Xsara rolled forward and trapped her under the wheels. Pensioner Ronald Webster of Blakenhall, West Midlands, died after suffering a heart attack while clearing snow from his drive. And in Cornwall a 14-year-old boy was seriously injured after being hit by a car while sledging on a snow-covered disused airfield at Davidstow.

Fracture clinics around the country have reported an increase in cases. In Lincolnshire, six people were hurt when an Alfa Romeo Spider sports car skidded on ice, ploughed into shoppers then smashed into a department store.

New Year sales were badly hit, with shops reporting a drop of 50 per cent in turnover.

With hundreds of road crashes being reported, police across the country warned motorists not to make non-essential journeys. The AA advised drivers to take blankets in case they got stuck in the snow. It was the AA's busiest day of the year with 3,000 call-outs an hour. The RAC also had record numbers of callers.

Dozens of football matches were called off, including Premiership clashes between Aston Villa and Leicester City, Everton and Leeds United in England, and games between Celtic and Motherwell, Aberdeen and St Mirren and Kilmarnock and Rangers in Scotland.

In Belfast, Rolf Harris and Jools Holland are preparing to perform outdoors in Arctic conditions at a New Year concert in the grounds of Belfast City Hall. The Met Office was predicting minus 10C in the province on New Year's Eve. Nationally, forecasters warned of sleet, snow and freezing rain on New Year's Eve. Snow is expected on higher ground in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and northern England with freezing rain in the Midlands and East Anglia.

South-east England is expected to escape the worst, with any snowfall turning to rain later on New Year's night as temperatures rise. But the thaw threatens severe flooding as snow melts in some areas.

Despite the current cold spell, this year will go down as one of the warmest and wettest in England since records began. It was the tenth warmest year in central England since temperature records began in 1659, with six of those 10 warm years occuring since 1989.

webTitle: Victim of Enniskillen bomb buried after 13 years in coma

fields.headline: Victim of Enniskillen bomb buried after 13 years in coma
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A man who spent 13 years in a coma after being injured by the IRA's Remembrance Day bombing atrocity in Enniskillen was buried yesterday.
fields.body:
A man who spent 13 years in a coma after being injured by the IRA's Remembrance Day bombing atrocity in Enniskillen was buried yesterday.

Ronnie Hill, 68, was laid to rest in his wife's home town of Kilkeel, Co Down, after dying last Friday. The former principal of Enniskillen High School never regained consciousness from the coma he fell in to two days after the bombing at the war memorial in the centre of the Fermanagh town in 1987.

He was looked after throughout that time by his wife, Noreen, in the residential home she bought for him in Holywood, Co Down. Dr John Ross, a former Presbyterian Moderator who knows the Hill family well, said it had been a traumatic time for them.

'I'm very sad and yet happy for him, and in some ways for his family because they have been under enormous pressure for 13 years,' he said.

webTitle: Tories' corporate gifts fall to record low

fields.headline: Tories' corporate gifts fall to record low
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Corporate donations to the Conservative Party have sunk to their lowest level since records began.
fields.body:
Corporate donations to the Conservative Party have sunk to their lowest level since records began.

Last year, 31 companies gave a total of only £359,059 last year, compared with the £2.5 million handed to the Tories in the equivalent year of the last Parliament. It signals a crisis of confidence in the party among its most loyal traditional supporters.

'It's a fact of life that our corporate donations are declining,' a party spokesman said last night. 'It's something we've got to live with. We're doing all we can to encourage wealthy individuals to donate instead.'

The party refuses to disclose details of company gifts, simply listing donors of more than £5,000. However, the new figures come from a survey to be published this week by Labour Research, the independent analysts who check the annual reports of almost 3,000 firms every year. Companies are obliged by law to declare political gifts of more than £200.

Those which stopped donating to the Tories in the financial year ending in March include the property developer Castlemore Securities, which gave £100,000 the year before, and road builder Tarmac, which had handed over £40,000. Weetabix axed its £25,000 donation, although it is understood to have resumed giving since. Hanson, P & O, Dixons, Johnson Matthey and Scottish & Newcastle are among the major companies which have stopped funding the party since its 1997 election defeat. Haymarket, the publishing group owned by Michael Heseltine, has started giving money to the pro-European Conservative Mainstream group instead.

Only eight years ago, the Conservatives could bank on almost £5m a year in corporate gifts.

webTitle: Stage is set for Rolf and Jools despite freeze

fields.headline: Stage is set for Rolf and Jools despite freeze
fields.standfirst: New Year's Eve outdoor concert in Belfast goes ahead as plunging temperatures bring danger to the roads
fields.trailText: New Year's Eve outdoor concert in Belfast goes ahead as plunging temperatures bring danger to the roads.
fields.body:
A New Year's Eve concert in the grounds of Belfast City Hall will go ahead despite the freezing weather, organisers said last night.

Rolf Harris and Jools Holland, stars of the BBC's Animal Hospital and Later with Jools Holland, are the main attractions at the celebrations.

The Met Office had been predicting that temperatures in the Province could fall to minus 10C tonight, raising fears that the city council would be forced to reschedule its open-air party.

'The forecast is improving day by day. It's coming up a couple of degrees each day, so we feel we can still operate the site,' said city council spokesman Gerry Copeland. 'I'm sure people will come down and enjoy themselves and have a fantastic night. A bit cold, but if you wrap up warm enough you will be OK.'

Northern Ireland has experienced the worst snow falls in 18 years and temperatures plummeted to minus 15C in some parts of the Province over the weekend.

Driving conditions remain hazardous, with the big freeze in Ulster set to continue into the middle of this week. Motorists have been warned about black ice on the M1 and M2 motorways outside Belfast.

The Roads Service has come under fire over its response to the freezing conditions. Belfast Ulster Unionist Councillor Jim Rodgers criticised the service for failing to grit roads in advance of the freeze.

'The gritters were not called out early enough,' Rodgers said yesterday.

But a spokesman for the Roads Service said the Department of Regional Development had done all in its power to keep roads clear with the resources available.

The weather has severely disrupted flights in and out of the Province's three airports. A Sabena flight from Belfast International Airport to Brussels was cancelled because no de-icer was available.

The RUC, meanwhile, has advised motorists not to travel unless it is absolutely necessary. The force's message was repeated by police on the other side of the Irish border. The Gardai urged drivers in the Republic to exercise extreme caution.

The Midlands and west of Ireland are the worst-affected areas, with bus services to Donegal and Galway being cancelled last night. Both Galway and Shannon airports were closed for most of yesterday.

In Scotland, police have urged an expected 100,000 partygoers in Edinburgh to protect themselves from the cold weather.

David Strang, Assistant Chief Constable of Lothian and Borders Police, said: 'It looks as if this Hogmanay is going to be a really cold one.' Some of the weekend's top football matches, including the games between Celtic and Motherwell, Aberdeen and St Mirren and Kilmarnock and Rangers were called off.

In England, the weather brought fatalities. A 48-year-old woman motorist who was driving her mother through Staffordshire died when she stopped at the side of the road to clear her car windscreen. A Vauxhall Astra driven by a 51-year-old man from Heath Hayes, Cannock, was in collision with the woman's Citroen Xsara on the A460 near Rugeley, causing it to roll forward and trap her under the wheels. The woman was airlifted to Birmingham's Selly Oak Hospital with serious head injuries, but died later. Her mother was treated for shock.

Pensioner Ronald Webster of Blackenall in the West Midlands died after suffering a heart attack while clearing snow from his driveway.

In Cornwall, a 14-year-old boy was seriously injured after being hit by a car while sledging. The youngster was among a group of young people playing on a snow-covered disused airfield at Davidstow. As he was being towed on a surfboard by a car he was struck by another vehicle and suffered a broken jaw and arm. Fracture clinics around the country were reporting an increase in the number of cases being treated.

Crisis, the charity for the homeless, warned that there could be dozens more deaths among the homeless once short-term Christmas shelters shut down and they are forced back outside.

Angry scenes erupted at Luton and Liverpool airports when EasyJet was forced to cancel a total of 25 flights to destinations including Glasgow, Liverpool, Amsterdam and Malaga.

At least one person was arrested at Liverpool Airport in the early hours of Saturday morning after a disturbance broke out among disgruntled passengers.

Forecasters issued an early warning of sleet, snow and freezing rain sweeping in from the west on New Year's Eve.

Snow is expected on higher ground in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and northern England with freezing rain in the Midlands and East Anglia.

webTitle: Gunmen shoot ally of King Rat ally

fields.headline: Gunmen shoot ally of King Rat ally
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Ulster Volunteer Force was being blamed last night for the attempted murder of an associate of the late Billy Wright.
fields.body:
The Ulster Volunteer Force was being blamed last night for the attempted murder of an associate of the late Billy Wright.

Several shots were fired at the man - named locally as Ron Buchanan, a loyalist supporter in his mid-thirties from Portadown - who was sitting in a van on the Moy Road outside Portadown yesterday afternoon. He was hit several times, but according to the RUC his injuries are 'not life-threatening'.

Reports suggested he was sitting in the van with Gary Fulton, a cousin of Mark Swinger Fulton, one of the founders of the Loyalist Volunteer Force. Three days ago Buchanan attended a memorial service for Wright at his graveside in Portadown's Seagoe Cemetery.

Wright was shot dead inside the Maze prison on 27 December 1997 by INLA prisoners who had managed to smuggle a gun into what was meant to be a top-security jail.

Local loyalist sources claim the UVF's Mid-Ulster Brigade carried out yesterday's shooting.

Despite a truce on Belfast's Shankill Road between warring factions of the UDA and UVF, there has been no settlement of the year-long feud involving the UVF and the LVF.

The attack comes nearly a year after the death of Richard Jameson, the UVF's Mid-Ulster Brigadier, who was shot dead by LVF gunmen outside his home.

This latest shooting is bound to spark an escalation of the UVF-LVF feud, which has its origins in the expulsion of Wright - known as 'King Rat' - from the UVF during the disturbances at Drumcree in July 1996.

Although they have established a working truce with the UDA following a vicious feud this summer, which claimed seven lives in west and north Belfast, the UVF leadership insists it will carry on its war against the much smaller LVF.

Officially, the UDA has accepted the UVF's demands that the LVF cannot be included in the negotiations which ended the loyalist feud in greater Belfast.

However, the attendance of large numbers of UDA members at the Wright memorial service last week indicates that many UDA activists still maintain close ties with the LVF. If they were to rush to its aid, this would create the danger of the UDA-UVF feud breaking out again.

This latest shooting is bound to spark an escalation of the UVF-LVF feud, which has its origins in the expulsion of Wright - known as 'King Rat' - from the UVF during the disturbances at Drumcree in July 1996. Although they have established a working truce with the UDA following a vicious feud this summer, which claimed seven lives in west and north Belfast, the UVF leadership insists it will carry on its war against the much smaller LVF. Officially, the UDA has accepted the UVF's demands that the LVF cannot be included in the negotiations which ended the loyalist feud in greater Belfast. However, the attendance of large numbers of UDA members at the Wright memorial service last week indicates that many UDA activists still maintain close ties with the LVF. If they were to rush to its aid, this would create the danger of the UDA-UVF feud breaking out again.

fields.headline: Third of prisoners 'must be freed'
fields.standfirst: Jails inspector's outburst is a challenge to Straw
fields.trailText: Up to a third of criminals should be released from prison to take the pressure off Britain's most overcrowded jails and reduce reoffending rates, according to the Chief Inspector of Prisons.
fields.body:
Up to a third of criminals should be released from prison to take the pressure off Britain's most overcrowded jails and reduce reoffending rates, according to the Chief Inspector of Prisons.

In an interview with The Observer, Sir David Ramsbotham says that Britain's jails are dangerously overcrowded and that prisoners are receiving too little education and spend too much time locked in cells discussing crime.

Ramsbotham's outspoken comments put him in direct conflict with the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, who says Britain's rising prison population is a consequence of a crackdown on crime.

'My gut feeling is that if we had a proper system of community punishments and community sanctions which were credible, then one third [of prisoners] need not go to prison,' Ramsbotham said. 'Prison has a role to perform and if you swamp it with people so that it can't do what it is there to do, it is actually not performing as it should.

'Overcrowding is not just too many people to go in all the cells; it swamps all the work of the education and the offending behaviour programmes. Overcrowding means that far too many people are left sitting idle.'

His comments will reignite the debate over prisons at the centre of the Government's get-tough stance on crime. They were welcomed by prison reform groups, which said that in the past five years the prison population had risen from 44,000 to 66,000. It is likely to continue rising for the next two years.

It is estimated that a reduction in prison numbers to the levels of the mid to late-Nineties would save up to £500 million a year.

'It costs £25,000 per year to keep someone in prison,' said Richard Garside of the prison reform organisation, Nacro. 'Community service is a tenth of the price. There is no obvious or clear link between a rise in the prison population and a decrease in crime. We have to look at this problem in a more sophisticated way.' Lord Woolf, the Lord Chief Justice, last week accused Ministers of playing the 'prison card' to show the public they were being hard on criminals.

His comments were contradicted by William Hague, the Conservative leader, who said more people should go to prison.

Ramsbotham said he agreed 'wholeheartedly' with the Lord Chief Justice's comments, a coded attack on Straw, whom the chief inspector has fallen out with in the past. Ramsbotham said that a third of women should be released from prison and sent on community service programmes instead. 'A hideous number have drugs problems,' he said. 'A large number are also the primary carers for children, which adds to the problem.

Ramsbotham said many prisoners had mental health problems and should be in hospital.

Ramsbotham's decision to speak out about prison overcrowding comes after a Home Office announcement that he would be retiring in the summer. He said he was still in negotiation with the Government over an extension to his contract and had been 'surprised' by the way the issue was being handled.

fields.headline: 2001: a literary odyssey
fields.standfirst: Tynan, DeLillo, Rushdie, Hornby, Steiner, Naipaul, Pratchett, Updike, PD James and Grisham -  Stephanie Merritt  finds that the coming months promise great riches in fact and fiction
fields.trailText: Tynan, DeLillo, Rushdie, Hornby, Steiner, Naipaul, Pratchett, Updike, PD James and Grisham - Stephanie Merritt finds that the coming months promise great riches in fact and fiction
fields.body:
Hardly have you had time to clear away the beer cans, empty the ashtrays and pick up the streamers from the festive party poppers than speculation has begun about the contenders for the new year's literary prizes.

The year 2001 promises to be a strong one for fiction, with novels from big names vying with exciting debuts, so that whichever footballers, soap stars and video jockeys find themselves appointed to the judging panels will no doubt be faced with a few hard choices.

January sees the publication of Margaret Drabble's The Peppered Moth (Viking), the story of four generations of a family, which ought to provoke controversy in some quarters. There's also Patrick McCabe's The Emerald Germs of Ireland (Picador), Peter Carey's True History of the Kelly Gang (Faber), a fictional biography of the outlaw Ned Kelly; former Whitbread winner Justin Cartwright's tale of celebrity and scandal, Half in Love (Hodder) and a comic love story from Macallan Gold Dagger winner Jonathan Lethem, As She Climbed Across the Table (Faber).

In February, Picador publishes The Body Artist, Don DeLillo's first novel since Underworld, and Tobias Hill's second novel, The Love of Stones (Faber), promises to be a strong contender for literary prizes. On the more commercial front, there's a new John Grisham novel (Century), still under wraps, and a new offering from Candace Bushnell, creator of Sex and the City, entitled Four Blondes (Little Brown).

PD James fans can look forward to March, when her new Commander Dalgliesh novel, Death in Holy Orders (Faber), appears, and two masters of comic literary fiction, David Lodge and Jonathan Coe, also have novels out - Thinks... (Secker) and The Rotter's Club (Viking) respectively. Look out for number9dream (Hodder), the second novel by Japanese-based writer David Mitchell, whose first book, Ghostwritten, was highly rated by the critics, and a new Hanif Kureishi - Gabriel's Gift (Faber).

April brings new novels by Carlos Fuentes, Pat Barker and Paul Theroux. Fuentes's The Years With Laura Diaz (Bloomsbury) tells the story of an artist whose life encompasses most of twentieth-century Mexican history, while Barker takes a new angle on her familiar themes of history, memory and psychology in Border Crossing (Viking). Theroux's Hotel Honolulu (Hamish Hamilton) is an episodic novel narrated by a Hawaiian hotel manager.

There's also a new novel, Soho (Hodder), by the inimitable Keith Waterhouse, a new Stephen King thriller, Dreamcatcher (Hodder), his first full-length novel for three years, and a new collection of poetry from Seamus Heaney, Electric Light (Faber).

Acclaimed young poet Glyn Maxwell turns his hand to the complex form of the verse novel in May with Time's Fool (Picador). Booksellers can look forward to a titanic clash of Literary Lads with new novels from Nick Hornby and Tony Parsons, both out this month. Hornby's How To Be Good (Viking) charts the course of a north London marriage, while Parsons's One For My Baby (HarperCollins) mines the valuable emotional seam of men and children again, with the tale of a widowed man who learns to love again with a single mother.

If the prospect of that makes you queasy, you could turn to Terry Pratchett's latest Discworld offering, Thief of Time (Doubleday), for some light relief. On the literary fiction front, there's a new short-story collection, Licks of Love, from John Updike, including a novella, Rabbit Remembered, which revisits the characters of his best-known novels. There's also a new Sebastian Faulks, On Green Dolphin Street (Hutchinson).

In June, there's a new novel from former Booker winner James Kelman, his first since How Late It Was, How Late; Translated Accounts (Secker) is set in an unnamed country under severe military rule. Young authors Emily Perkins and Magnus Mills also have new novels out, The New Girl (Picador) and Three To See the King (Flamingo) respectively. The much admired poet, academic and novelist John Fuller also has a new book, The Memoirs of Laetitia Horspole, By Herself (Chatto), a fictional manuscript containing the story of a nineteenth-century femme fatale. Helen Dunmore's novel The Siege (Viking) follows the course of two love affairs during the Nazi invasion of Russia.

Finally, looking further ahead, there's a new Irvine Welsh in July - Glue (Jonathan Cape), the story of four boys growing up in Edinburgh - and for thriller fans a new Nicci French, The Unburied (Michael Joseph), featuring the protagonist from her previous book, Beneath the Skin. In September, VS Naipaul has a new novel and a new publisher, his first book since moving to Picador, and October sees the publication of Austerlitz by WG Sebald (Hamish Hamilton), a sequel to his acclaimed The Immigrants. Another autumn highlight will be Fury, a new novel from Salman Rushdie (Cape).

While many publishers save their heaviest-hitting non-fiction books for the autumn lists, there are still some fascinating books to look forward to early next year. In January, Bloomsbury publishes The Adversary by Prix Femina-winning French writer Emmanuel Carrere. Already a best-seller in 18 countries, it is the true story of a World Health Organisation doctor who murdered his wife and children and the investigation that followed.

One Market Under God (Secker) by Thomas Frank, founding editor of Chicago-based satirical magazine the Baffler, has already caused a stir in the US with its caustic critique of how marketplace jargon has infiltrated democracy. And this year's controversy over the David Irving trial looks set to be resurrected by Cambridge historian Richard J. Evans's investigative account, Telling Lies About Hitler: the Holocaust, History and the David Irving Trial (Heinemann).

Ensuring that controversial reviews continue into February, Stephen Jay Gould produces his new book, Rocks of Ages (Jonathan Cape). Subtitled 'Science and Religion in the Fullness of Life', the book proposes the scientist's theory that science and religious faith can comfortably co-exist. And as preparations for the election shift into top gear, Guardian journalists Polly Toynbee and David Walker pause to take a look at the past term of office in Did Things Get Better? An Audit of New Labour (Penguin Press).

George Steiner's ground-breaking new work Grammars of Creation (Faber) is published in March, exploring the nature of the ideas of 'creation' and 'invention' in literature, art and science, while Canadian academic Alberto Manguel offers a sequel to his History of Reading in Reading Pictures: a History of Love and Hate (Bloomsbury).

In April, Dennis Overbye, the New York Times's deputy science editor, publishes Einstein in Love: a Scientific Romance, his new biography of the great scientist concentrating on his marriage to Mileva. Journalist Jon Ronson's Them: Adventures With Extremists (Picador) is the result of extensive and sometimes hair-raising travels in search of fundamentalists and groups committed to extreme beliefs. This month, Harvill publishes A Dirty War by Anna Politkovskaya, the first eyewitness account by a Russian journalist of events in the Chechen war and how the Russian government attempted to manipulate media coverage of the conflict.

May sees the publication of the final part of Peter Taylor's trilogy about the Troubles; Brits: the War Against the IRA (Bloomsbury) looks at the northern Ireland question from a British perspective. Paul Steinberg's Holocaust memoir Speak You Also (Penguin Press) is an Auschwitz prisoner's account of his survival in the camp and the cost to his own humanity; Steinberg was the prisoner immortalised by Primo Levi as 'Henri'.

In June, there's a new new book from Michael Lewis, author of the acclaimed The New New Thing and Liar's Poker. This New New Life (Hodder) is an analysis of how digital technology and the net have changed the way we work and live. Those tired of analyses of contemporary culture could turn instead to Antonia Fraser's biography of Marie Antoinette (Weidenfeld).

One important development in the world of non-fiction publishing will be the launch of Short Books, a new company set up by former Sunday Telegraph journalists Rebecca Nicolson and Aurea Carpenter. The aim of the list is to provide high-quality biographies and histories that are, well, short, given that the average busy professional of 2001 has neither the time nor the briefcase space for weighty tomes. The first, Short Lives, is launched in May with a series of 96-page biographies of 'overlooked but interesting' historical figures by authors such as Kate Hubbard and Adam Nicolson. The second, Front Lines, surfaces in August and will include contemporary essays and reportage.

So far, there's nothing in 2001 to bestir the public in quite the way Harry Potter did this year, but look out for film and television adaptations sparking a renewed interest in The Lord of the Rings, Joanne Harris's Chocolat and Tim Pears's In A Land of Plenty.

Possibly the most sensational autobiographical volume of the year, already serialised in the New Yorker, will be Kenneth Tynan's Diaries (Weidenfeld).

webTitle: Observer review: The Artist & the Garden by Sir Roy Strong

fields.headline: There was life before Charlie Dimmock
fields.standfirst: Sir Roy Strong unearths the history of British garden design in The Artist & the Garden, but could have taken better care of the plants
fields.trailText: Sir Roy Strong unearths the history of British garden design in The Artist & the Garden, but could have taken better care of the plants
fields.body:
The Artist & the Garden
Sir Roy Strong
Yale University Press £29.95, pp288
Buy it at BOL

Sir Roy Strong discovered gardening at about the time he left the National Portrait Gallery for the directorship of the Victoria and Albert in 1973. What soon became an enduring passion was rapidly put to good use and combined with his already unrivalled expertise on sixteenth- and early seventeenth-century court culture and early British painting. The immediate results were The Renaissance Garden, which appeared in 1979, and the chaotic exhibition, The Garden, which he put on at the V&A later the same year.

Since then, after a couple of TV series, some manuals on the design of small gardens and a biography which lists him as garden design consultant to Versace, Elton John and the Prince of Wales, Strong has sometimes seemed in danger of becoming the Charlie Dimmock of garden history. His sumptuously produced new book, The Artist & the Garden, however, is a solid, academic work in which he returns to the roots of his scholarship.

Though focusing on paintings of gardens of the past, it is a misleading title for a book whose subject is, in effect, a history of garden design in Britain from the sixteenth to the eighteenth centuries. Strong's Renaissance Garden was dedicated 'in memory of all those gardens destroyed by Capability Brown and his successors'.

Here he has had to bite the bullet and include, for example, the landscape painter Richard Wilson's Italianate views of Wilton House with the gardens newly flattened into a park by the ninth Earl of Pembroke, whose ancestor, the fourth earl, had commissioned the original Hortus Penbrochianus in the 1630s, one of the largest and most elaborate formal gardens of its age.

Strong's knowledge of the byways of British portraiture stands him in good stead, and nearly a quarter of the book is devoted to the gardens seen in the backgrounds of portraits. Inevitably, he is at his best with those of the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries, but as well as providing new conclusions about some of those covered in The Renaissance Garden, he devotes a whole section to the work of two eighteenth-century provincial painters of the archetypal English conversation piece, Arthur Devis and his follower Edward Haytley, convincingly suggesting that a high proportion of the settings for their portraits were based on actual gardens.

The Artist & the Garden, both for its authoritative text and the quality of its illustrations, is likely to become the standard work on early British garden design but, despite his horticultural achievements, Strong often continues to write with the art historian's healthy disregard for botanical niceties. The square beds in a compartmented garden glimpsed in a portrait of Elizabeth I are 'outlined with some low-growing plant [like] rosemary' - which grows to two metres and does not take kindly to cutting back.

On the basis of some tulip-shaped blobs in a view by the Dutch painter Jan Siberechts of the house and garden of Cheveley, Cambridgeshire, Strong postulates this as being in 'late spring', despite the evidence of golden corn fields in the surrounding landscape.

In fact, there is scarcely a recognisable flower portrayed in the whole book. A blight similar to the one which has recently afflicted Strong's box hedges in the enormous formal garden which he has created for his Herefordshire home, The Laskett, also seems to have descended on the editing of the book, and proper names occur in several spellings and one out of only five chapters is misnumbered. Despite flaws, however, and like the Laskett, it remains a monumental achievement.

webTitle: Observer review: Smashing People by Michael Fishwick

fields.headline: Wilfred the great
fields.standfirst: Michael Fishwick sets Smashing People in the 80s - but does this 'sparkling light novel' have a darker purpose?
fields.trailText: Michael Fishwick sets Smashing People in the 80s - but does this 'sparkling light novel' have a darker purpose?
fields.body:
Smashing People
Michael Fishwick
Jonathan Cape £15.99, pp250

Michael Fishwick is a brave man. If there's one thing that's harder than writing a sparkling light novel of contemporary manners, it's setting such a novel in a recent decade of brilliant, but controversial, memory - the 80s, for example. And if there's one thing that's riskier than setting a SLN of contemporary manners in the Age of Greed, it's deciding to make the protagonist a literary man. And then if there's one thing that's even more risky than attempting to write any of the above, it's to go right ahead and actually publish a sparkling light novel of contemporary manners, set in the 80s, starring as its protagonist a literary man who writes for the newspapers. Mr Fishwick certainly deserves the big hello for stepping in where many another literary angel would fear to tread.

Wilfred Wellingborough is that familiar English comic hero: the amiable lost soul precipitately confronted with an extraordinary challenge, and thereby forced to come to terms with his tumultuous life and times.

The times we already know about: Mrs Torture, the Miners' Strike, Saatchi & Saatchi, champagne flowing like water, everyone getting hired and fired, or hitched and ditched in the snakes and ladders of love and work. Yet it is a decade that endlessly fascinates, particularly for those of us who came of age professionally then. There was so much excess, along with so much social upheaval.

Wilf's life is more original than other fictional ones from that era, although at first it doesn't seem so. A boyhood friend puts our 'faltering, if charming' hero in charge of a low circulation arts magazine in place of the high-maintenance, high-octane Kitty Greaves.

Overnight, Wilf finds himself in the ruthless world of journalists, publishers and literary agents, in the London of Martin Amis and the New York of Tom Wolfe. And then, because the first instinct of light fiction is towards the improbable, Wilf stumbles into unexpected success.

Another writer might have decided to pause right there and to make this foray into the absurdities of the literary demi-monde the focus of the rest of the book.

Fishwick, however, does not take the easy way out. Wilf breaks up with his girlfriend, and is shortly afterwards fired from the magazine, whereupon he goes home to his parents, becomes a gardening correspondent for another sunday broadsheet, falls in love again, and then, among other things, belatedly achieves vengeance against his ex-boss, along with a modicum of self-knowledge. When, on the final pages, Wilf puts the score of his adventures as, 'Wellingborough 1; Life 1', the reader can hardly disagree.

Behind the novel's madcap narrative is a deeper moral purpose, just as behind the mask that Fishwick has put on I suspect there lurks a more sombre expression. At the heart of this high-spirited novel is a polemic against Thatcher's children which breaks cover on the penultimate page, when one of the characters, quoting The Great Gatsby, says: 'They're careless people... They smash people up. Then they retreat into their carelessness and leave everyone else to clean up the mess.'

As one who experienced every vertiginous twist and turn of literary London during the 80s at first hand, I was particularly interested in Fishwick's version of this dreadful merry world. I can't remember all the details, of course, but his account of it seems to be worryingly on the money.

webTitle: Observer review: The Brontë Myth by Lucasta Miller

fields.headline: Another Brontë hunter
fields.standfirst: Can we ever really know what happened at Haworth? Lucasta Miller is on the trail of the literary sleuths in The Brontë Myth
fields.trailText: Can we ever really know what happened at Haworth? Lucasta Miller is on the trail of the literary sleuths in The Brontë Myth
fields.body:
The Brontë Myth
Lucasta Miller
Jonathan Cape £18.99, pp320
Buy it at BOL

The Brontë Myth is a sharp-witted study in literary reputation. Lucasta Miller traces the evolution of the 'public personae' of Charlotte and Emily Brontë - from their implausible noms de plume, through vilifications and eulogies to their current 'images' as radical and mystic, respectively. Sister Anne is, by Miller's own admission, ignored because she never 'took on the mythic stature of her sisters in her own right'. Dipsomaniac Branwell is, brutally, but probably justly, discussed only when he 'impinged on Charlotte and Emily'.

Miller's main concern is the process by which the 'truth' of a writer - the words she or he writes - gets drowned out by the chatterings of journals, little magazines, critical introductions and, more blaringly still, by the bowdlerisations of pop-lit - the tourist industry, Hollywood biopics, pop songs. Miller supplies a cultural materialist-ish unpicking of the heritage trade - that profitable network of writers' houses, coffee shops, souvenir shops selling Virginia Woolf fridge magnets and Brontë sisters jam.

This trade thrives on snapshot caricatures and miniaturisations; its reserve currency is the bucolic idyll, the dying afternoon of the English summer - Shakespeare's quiet memorial in Stratford church, the expanses of lovely garden at Monk's House, Woolf's country residence.

Miller supplies a deft and immaculately detailed tracing of the many 'constructions' of Charlotte Brontë, from her initial disguise as the elusive and haughty Currer Bell, to her tentative unveiling (and immediate censure as 'unfemininely' candid about Jane Eyre's passions and predilections), to the self-abnegating daughter of Mrs Gaskell's biography, The Life of Charlotte Brontë.

She argues persuasively that Mrs Gaskell was responsible for the 'popular perception' of Charlotte as an angelic neurotic, trapped in the most remote moors with a capricious, violent father, disturbed from her writing by the clanging of church bells and the hammering of rain on her little, rustic window.

Miller neatly documents the nineteenth-century boom in Charlotte worship - the first devotees at Haworth and the frantic requests for relics. Demand for snippets of her handwriting grew so persistent that the Brontës' maligned father, Patrick, was forced to cut Charlotte's letters into tiny pieces, sending them out to fans as gnomic one-liners.

Misinformers are trounced - Harriet Martineau and Mrs Gaskell for (Brontë's own complaint) deciding 'that I shall be a sort of invalid'; G. H. Lewes and Thackeray for deriving 'schoolboy amusement from the supposed naughtiness of her novels'; twentieth-century psycho-biographers such as Lucile Dooley for tediously diagnosing Charlotte as a neurotic with a father complex.

Emily Brontë was, Miller suggests, obscure for longer than Charlotte. Wuthering Heights was generally dismissed as the freakish, unholy product of a terminally ill child. But she was secretly devoured by schoolgirl rebels of the 1890s and, later, by turn-of-the-century philosopher-novelists such as May Sinclair. Miller cites Sinclair as the originator of the 'Emily as mystic' myth - the pagan seer, skipping the moors in the company of her wild, bucking imagination, 'not a talented craftswoman but a being of rare spiritual gifts'.

The novelist E. F. Benson, writing in 1932, 'hero-worshipped Emily in the religious language of mysticism'. Emily the mystic rebel became Emily the lesbian, a new 'image' first propounded in the 1930s by Virginia Moore and taken up again by Camille Paglia in Sexual Personae. Brontë's poems were ingeniously read for 'subtextual' Sapphic love. But, Miller suggests, all attempts fail; Emily Brontë is left 'the Sphinx of English literature', indifferent to posterity, writing for motives unknown.

Miller tends to move seamlessly from the academic to the pop-biographical, from the souvenir shop to the literary life. Brief phrases in Radio Times are cited as sources of equal interest as the careful musings of Sinclair.

This skitters over the question of whether different sources are variously trustworthy, whether some media are more likely to yield reliable information than others. It also leaves unresolved the question of whether all comment on writers is mythopoetic, or whether some particularly talented biographers and writers can occasionally stray towards the 'truth' about a writer.

Certainly, Miller's antipathy to biography is palpable - she mistrusts its sliding into fiction, its phoney cries of disinterestedness. Biographers are, she suggests, never quite the altruistic detectives of authorial personality they claim to be. The question remaining is what you put in the place of personality analysis and myth-creation. The deconstructing critique towards which Miller strays should, taken to its logical conclusion, decide that any image of a writer is a despoiled hash of personal fixation or cultural archetype. But this is to leave us with nothing at all. So Miller suggests that we must cling to the works themselves as the final truth - the expression of the inner self, as opposed to the compromised external persona.

The trouble with this argument is that it relies on readers communing properly, meaning innocently, with the works. If we can turn to the Brontës and read them as they hoped to be read, draw their imaginative vision out pure and unsullied, then none of the image-making matters. Either we are always more incredulous than tourist boards would have us - knowing in our postmodernish fashion that nothing is quite as the forces of hard sell make it seem - or we are distracted by the bleats of the heritage racket, in which case our engagement with the works is already tainted.

What comfort is there for the writer in all of this? Writers, from Miller's account, can hardly hope to control their images - the Brontës, despite their initial reticence and despite Charlotte's intervention in the literary reputation of Emily, failed to exert an abiding force over the powers of caricature and moneymaking. Miller so thoroughly enforces the argument for the interference of reviewers, academics and film directors in the reading process that her final point, that the works will always out, is not as consoling as it should be.

In the cultural world Miller has supplied, biopic will traduce, however secretive and controlling writers try to be, and readers of Wuthering Heights will struggle at every line against recollections of Kate Bush screeching in a flimsy white robe or Laurence Olivier marching through the gorse.

webTitle: Observer review: Boggs by Lawrence Weschler

fields.headline: It's money, it's funny - but it isn't art
fields.standfirst: Lawrence Weschler takes a sardonic look at money and reality, evaluating the banknote drawings of JSG Boggs
fields.trailText: Lawrence Weschler takes a sardonic look at money and reality, evaluating the banknote drawings of JSG Boggs
fields.body:
Boggs - A Comedy of Values
Lawrence Weschler
Chicago University Press £8, pp160
Buy it at BOL

There's nothing new about copying things. The Apollo Belvedere, which Winckelmann thought the 'highest ideal of art', is actually a Roman copy in marble of an old Greek bronze. In the seventeenth century, the French Academy in Rome taught its students to copy 'everything beautiful', a process which resulted in French government buildings from Djibouti to Calais being full of good, bad and mediocre knock-offs of something else. In the nineteenth century the Academie des Beaux-Arts insisted copying was the second most important artistic discipline after life-drawing. In those days 'creativity' was not valued as much as technique.

Reproduction technologies question the special status of 'art'. Walter Benjamin's famous 1936 essay, 'Das Kunstwerk im Zeitalten seine Technischen Reproduzierbarkeit' (' The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction'), established an argument that photography made art 'ephemeral, ubiquitous, insubstantial, available, valueless, free', as John Berger put it.

Photography encouraged fakes, too. Joe Rosenthal's memorable picture of the 28th Marines of the 5th Division taking Mount Suribachi was staged. Rosenthal found the original, spontaneous planting of the stars and bars on a bit of bent pipe by a scruffy bunch of squaddies a little unimpressive, so ordered up a more photogenic team of marines with a proper flag. In architecture, the architect Philip Johnson said the great thing about minimalism is that it's easy to copy.

And so to Boggs. To this rich tradition of classical academic values, Frankfurt School sociology and post modern muddle, JSG Boggs brings a welcome wry hucksterism. Boggs is the American artist who draws money. No tradesman in Antibes ever bothered cashing a cheque with Picasso's signature because, almost irrespective of its face value, the autograph was worth more. Boggs has developed this concept with hilarious energy and flair.

A night out with Boggs ends with him offering as payment a very well copied hundred dollar bill. Boggs will say something like: 'I'm an artist, I drew this, it took me many hours to do it, and it's certainly worth something. I'm assigning it an arbitrary price that just happens to coincide with its face value. This means, if you do decide to accept it as full payment for our meal, you're going to have give me change.' This delightful conceit has put Boggs at odds not only with restaurateurs across the United States and Europe, but with the 1981 Forgery and Counterfeiting Act when in London (where he has been based since 1980).

In this intelligent, amusing and diverting study Lawrence Weschler explains that Boggs has mischievously put our perceptions of worth and value into free fall. Boggs has won credibility in the art world and shaken the Secret Service. It is one thing to settle the cost of dinner with a painstakingly drawn hundred-dollar bill, it is another entirely to plan to reproduce a million dollars worth of drawings with the help of a colour laser printer. For this, Pittsburgh police busted him.

But Boggs is not a simple fraudster. His work reminds Weschler of that paradox of Zeno, where the race cannot be finished because first the runner has to do half the distance, then half the remainder and so on to infinity. Boggs is the same with counterfeiting. He never quite gets there: art and humour prevent closure. His drawings are also rather charming.

Boggs - A Comedy of Values is a brilliant little book whose sardonic scholarship (check out: Fernand Braudel, Milton Friedman, Jacques Derrida, naturellement, and Gertrude Stein's Selected Notes on Money) is a perfect match for its subject.

Very amusingly, and with great sympathy, Weschler tests our beliefs about money, art and reality. It is a miniature of great depth. Boggs himself explains that genuine paper money is itself a form of mystification (and that early US notes carried illustrations of 'real' silver dollars to assure the public of their worth). After all, the concept of credit is etymologically related to 'belief'. Boggs's money might not be beautiful, but ask yourself whether you believe in it and you're right into the debate about value that characterises aesthetics today.

But is Boggs art? Not really. He's too funny.

webTitle: Time to keep a hold of nurse - for fear of something worse

fields.headline: Time to keep a hold of nurse - for fear of something worse
fields.trailText: There is one key issue for even the most patriotic of British investors at the beginning of the year: what will happen to the US?
fields.body:
There is one key issue for even the most patriotic of British investors at the beginning of the year: what will happen to the US? Will its economy have a hard or a soft landing? How far can interest rates fall? Will the collapse in technology stocks continue? The answers will, to a large extent, determine what happens in British markets.

The new year is likely to start as nervously as the old one ended, as US companies announce their fourth-quarter figures. If the profit warnings issued by everyone from e-toys to the mighty Microsoft are anything to go by, the results season could be 'bloody', as John Hatherly, head of global analysis at M&G, puts it. He encourages investors to 'hold on to nurse for fear of something worse'.

Roughly translated, that means they will carry on selling tech stocks, which, far from being immune to economic downturns, as had been thought, seem to be even more vulnerable than old-fashioned companies, and buying 'safe' shares such as utilities and healthcare.

But Hatherly, like most commentators, is sanguine about the outlook for the US later in the year. While the economy is slowing, growth could still end up as high as 2.5 per cent - hardly the stuff of recession - and there is little sign of inflationary pressure. Provided President George W. Bush resists the temptation to cut taxes or increase spending too much, interest rates should be able to fall enough to ensure a soft landing.

That should be good news for shares in the second half of the year. Then, according to Justin Abercrombie, head of investment strategy at Schroders, interest rate cuts will have become a reality, and stock markets should 'rally quite strongly'. He believes investors should be positioning themselves for that by buying in unpopular sectors such as retailing, which have been out of favour for some time but should benefit from falling interest rates.

His favourite market, however, is not the UK but Europe, one of the strongest areas in 2000. The euro should finally strengthen, to British investors' advantage, and interest rates should start to fall again.

But what does this mean for investors? The key is likely to be careful stock selection. In 2000, the most important thing was to be in the right sectors - technology, media or telecoms in the first quarter, virtually any high-yielding 'value' stock in the final one.

As reality returns, so will the need for stock picking. There will be good investments in technology, but there will also be a lot of losers. January trading statements from e-tailers are likely to underline just how wrong the predictions about the growth of on-line shopping were; it is odds on that at least one heavily geared telecoms operators will go bust in 2001. It is too early to predict winners. Technology companies with cash on their balance sheets - Energis and Cable & Wireless are telecoms examples - will be in a strong position to buy up companies in distress. There is, however, a danger of buying too early: investors should wait until, perhaps, the second quarter of the year, when it is clearer what is happening in the US.

Outside TMT, it would be sensible to look at interest-rate sensitive companies, such as retailers and housebuilders. These staged a bit of recovery in the closing weeks of 2000, but companies such as Boots, Scottish & Newcastle, and George Wimpey are still on low ratings.

He believes investors should be positioning themselves for that by buying in unpopular sectors such as retailing, which have been out of favour for some time but should benefit from falling interest rates. His favourite market, however, is not the UK but Europe, one of the strongest areas in 2000. The euro should finally strengthen, to British investors' advantage, and interest rates should start to fall again. But what does this mean for investors? The key is likely to be careful stock selection. In 2000, the most important thing was to be in the right sectors - technology, media or telecoms in the first quarter, virtually any high-yielding 'value' stock in the final one. As reality returns, so will the need for stock picking. There will be good investments in technology, but there will also be a lot of losers. January trading statements from e-tailers are likely to underline just how wrong the predictions about the growth of on-line shopping were; it is odds on that at least one heavily geared telecoms operators will go bust in 2001. It is too early to predict winners. Technology companies with cash on their balance sheets - Energis and Cable & Wireless are telecoms examples - will be in a strong position to buy up companies in distress. There is, however, a danger of buying too early: investors should wait until, perhaps, the second quarter of the year, when it is clearer what is happening in the US. Outside TMT, it would be sensible to look at interest-rate sensitive companies, such as retailers and housebuilders. These staged a bit of recovery in the closing weeks of 2000, but companies such as Boots, Scottish & Newcastle, and George Wimpey are still on low ratings.

fields.headline: Of managers and hi-tech hitches
fields.standfirst: Funds that chose internet stocks had an awful year. But a bio or eco bias made all the difference, writes  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Funds that chose internet stocks had an awful year. But a bio or eco bias made all the difference, writes Jill Insley.
fields.body:
The year 2000 will go down as the worst in a decade for many investors, with markets around the world ending with hefty losses. Fund managers have struggled, with only 39 per cent of funds producing a positive return (according to figures from Lipper on 19 December). The worst have lost more than half their value over the year.

The biggest losers have been those who piled into technology funds on the back of an astronomical 1999 performance. Despite a promising January and February, they have seen their investments plummet as technology stocks fell out of favour. Nasdaq, the leading technology index, has fallen by more than 37 per cent this year. Funds that concentrated on internet stocks suffered most of all - Framlington's NetNet has dropped by 47 per cent.

Likewise, Japan started the year well, with many experts believing its economy was finally recovering from the recession that dogged it for 10 years. But the Nikkei ends the year nearly 30 per cent down, and many Japanese funds have fared even worse. Thirteen of the bottom 20 funds are Japanese, and the worst of all 1823 funds is Invesco GT Japanese Smaller Companies, which fell by 55 per cent over the year.

Index tracker funds, which many financial advisers recommended as a suitable initiation to the stock market, have also produced losses. The FTSE 100 slid sideways all year, and has missed out on the traditional end-of-year rally to end about 10 per cent below its January starting point. This will be the first time since 1994 it has ended the year with a loss.

Smaller companies funds, particularly those holding biotechnology, dominate the top 20. Although Framlington's NetNet fund is currently scraping the bottom of the tables, its Health fund has turned in the best performance of the year, producing a 108 per cent increase, and outperforming its nearest competitor, Close Finsbury Biotechnology, by more than 20 per cent. Framlington marketing director Craig Walton, says: 'There was a tremendous run in biotech stocks in February and March, so we benefited from a huge increase. Antony Milford [Health fund manager] then sold biotech stocks and bought pharmaceuticals just before biotech stock prices corrected. He bought back into biotechnology in time for a second run in the summer.'

Despite the acrimonious departure of founder John Duffield, Jupiter has three funds in the top 20, including its specialist green fund Jupiter Ecology. Fund manager Simon Baker says Ecology has benefited from being able to invest globally: 'Ecology invests in companies that produce services and products that benefit the environment. These tend to be immune to economic cycles.'

Anna Bowes of Bath independent adviser Chase de Vere says investors shouldn't be too perturbed by losses this year. 'It's a classic example of why you shouldn't consider short-term investment. As funds become more specialised, they become more volatile. You can have a cracking year followed by a really bad year.'

webTitle: Organisations that made us richer - and some that didn't

fields.headline: Heroes, but too many villains
fields.standfirst: Do you feel richer than this time last year? Maria Scott on organisations that helped - and some that didn't
fields.trailText: Do you feel richer than this time last year? Maria Scott on organisations that helped - and some that didn't.
fields.body:
As the world recovered from its millennium party, it became clear that computer systems had resisted the Y2K computer bug. On New Year's Day 2000 we awoke to bank accounts intact and investment portfolios unscathed.

The first heroes of the year, therefore, were the information technology experts, who prepared so thoroughly for the turn of the millennium. Questions were raised about money spent on Y2K-proofing - but, on balance, it was probably money well spent.

Building societies continued to demonstrate the benefits of mutuality, particularly for borrowers. This was confirmed in a survey published just before Christmas by rate-tracking service Moneyfacts. Building societies occupy seven of the top 10 places in a league table of the cheapest lenders for a £50,000 variable-rate loan over 12 months. In most cases these rates apply to longer-standing borrowers - recognition by the societies of loyalty.

But building societies don't have a monopoly on good value: Moneyfacts points out that Standard Life and Direct Line charge the same relatively low rates to all borrowers, regardless of how long they have been on the lender's books. Both lenders feature in the top 10, so deserve end-of-year prizes.

Skipton building society deserves a mention for handing out to members the £50 million profit it made on the sale of share dealing subsidiary Dealwise in the form of special bonuses worth up to £1,000.

Banks and other financial companies do not launch new products for the glory of it. But truly innovative products can do their customers a favour - and the past 12 months have brought some innovation. The Halifax's new subsidiary, Intelligent Finance, launched an account that recognises a nonsense in the way many people handle their finances. If you are paying more to borrow on a credit card, or even a mortgage, than you are receiving on savings, it does not make sense to have savings. But many people like to have a bit put aside for emergencies, and IF deals with the contradiction by 'crediting' savings against borrowing, thus reducing interest costs. This is not the first or only product to promote 'connectivity', but IF's high profile has helped to spread the word.

Certain charities stand out for their campaigning on financial issues. The Consumers' Association has championed several causes, the most recent being that of policyholders with insurer Axa, whom CA believes have been shortchanged in the insurer's plan for dividing up surplus or 'orphan' assets.

Age Concern and Help the Aged have both campaigned on pensioners' behalf over the pitiful basic state pension. This work has helped convince the Government that pensioners are a force in the electorate worth listening to.

The dedicated individuals who set up and run credit unions deserve recognition. These savings and loans 'clubs' which offer low-cost loans are gathering strength: figures published before Christmas by the Registry of Friendly Societies show a 16 per cent increase in members by the end of 1999.

The internet continued to bring mainly benefits for users. While several sites folded, the internet remained a source of competitive deals in mortgages, savings and insurance. It continues to put pressure on traditional financial organisations. Online stockbroking services introduced large numbers of people to share trading for the first time this year.

The new enthusiasm for share trading boosted longer-established brokers too. One, The Share Centre, run by "people's capitalist" Gavin Oldham, earns a merit award for giving free shares to customers who helped to put the business on the map. The Share Centre followed up this move by being among the first companies to launch one of the Government's new employee share ownership schemes; free shares were given to workers.

Don Cruickshank, the former telecommunications regulator who now heads the Stock Exchange, is a prizewinner in 2000 for taking on the banks in his temporary role as leader of a special inquiry into the banking industry. He concluded that customers were being overcharged by about £5 billion a year. The Cruickshank report led to the announcement before Christmas by the Government of a new watchdog to clamp down on credit card and other money transmission charges levied on retailers by banks.

Cruickshank also waded into the row over cash machine charges, helping to push the banks into submission; most will scrap the charges from the new year. Cruickshank said it should be easier to move accounts from one bank to another, and this ensured that the banks speeded up plans to introduce an electronic direct debit switching service. A pilot scheme is now getting under way, and all banks should be participating by this time next year. In addition, banks are obliged under a revamped code of banking practice - coming into effect tomorrow (1 January) - to cooperate in helping customers move.

Other changes in the code - such as a requirement to give at least eight weeks - notice of a branch closure, and to warn on-screen of any charges on cash machine withdrawals - are responses to other controversies that engulfed banks during 2000 and put their industry collectively near the bottom of class.

Even newcomers to the business, notably internet banks such as Egg, First-E, Smile and Cahoot have failed to live up to all expectations because of technical difficulties and, in some cases, security problems. But they all get a big E for effort. They offer better value than the traditional banks.

Many banks and building societies deserve an 'F'-for-failure mark for trapping customers in Tessa savings accounts offering lower rates than the successor scheme, the Isa. The Banking Ombudsman issued instructions to ensure savers were protected but some banks, even big names such as Abbey National, seemed peeved at the ruling.

Motorists have been hit by increases in premiums averaging more than 20 per cent for comprehensive cover, for which the industry is blaming a host of difficulties other than any perpetrated by itself.

But the life insurance industry is where there has been the most misbehaviour this year. Equitable Life has closed to new business in a crisis that was apparently unforeseen by its management or the regulators. The Equitable disaster, which has shocked the insurance industry, continues to unfold. Axa deserves no prizes for the complexity of the scheme it dreamt up to distribute surplus, or 'orphan' assets. The Court may have sanctioned it, despite a challenge from the Consumers' Association, but few policyholders can have understood what they were being offered.

Of much wider concern has been the realisation that up to 4 million people may face shortfalls on their endowment mortgages. The insurance industry was forced by its regulator to face up to the potential problem by reviewing all policies and writing to homeowners to update them. But the regulator and the industry continue to brush aside allegations of widespread mis-selling.

Anecdotal evidence suggests that many borrowers were given far too optimistic a view about how their endowments would perform. One insurer earns marks for effort this year, however. Standard Life pulled up its socks after fighting off an attempt by policyholders to force it to demutualise. Most notable of its pro-mutual initiatives, perhaps, is its promise to make good any shortfalls on endowment policies provided investments grow by 6 per cent a year. Given that the insurer did not start sending out letters warning its borrowers about shortfalls until after the demutualisation vote had taken place, this may seem the least it could do. But this is a worthwhile guarantee for worried homeowners. Similar gestures from other insurers would be welcome.

Some new credit card operators, such as Egg and Capital One, earn some points for their effort in developing innovative and competitive deals. But the deals are also becoming increasingly complicated, with pitfalls for the unwary. Anecdotal evidence from debt counsellors also suggests that card companies are being far too liberal in handing out cards and upping credit limits. The Government has set up a task force to investigate.

Some retailers, including Comet, get an 'F' for failure for the so-called interest free credit they offer. If borrowers miss their final payments by just a few days, they may be charged up to nearly 30 per cent for all the months they thought were interest-free. There is nothing unlawful about the deals, but the Office of Fair Trading has expressed its concern.

The Government deserves an end-of-year report of its own. Its efforts in 'helping' us with our finances have had mixed results. Generally its intentions have been good, but its solutions were often overly complicated. The pensioners' credit for example, announced in Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report, aims to ensure that people who have saved small amounts for retirement do not lose means-tested benefits. But the scheme is unlikely to be understood by many, if any, of those it aims to help.

The idea that the DSS could run a scheme of complex credits seemed laughable at a time when its computer systems were already delivering miscalculated state pensions to tens of thousands of people every year.

The Government did drag its feet in putting right a scandal over widows' pensions from the State Earnings-Related Pension Scheme. This problem had its roots in the previous Tory administration, but the Labour government tried a penny-pinching approach to sorting it out, before giving in last month and announcing that people who reach retirement age by 6 October 2002 will keep their full spouse's Serps entitlement. For others, the new system will be phased in over 10 years.

Government action to bring down the price of cars was also criticised for its narrow approach, but the car industry seems to have taken note of consumer anger over high UK prices, and there has been steep discounting.
